It was stale and blah, completely uninviting.Service was meh, food was given to us quickly.Asked for a split check, which seemed to be a hassle.Skip it, hop a plane to NYC and go to a real "New York Deli"

Reviews.Author: Molly B.
Reviews.Content: A true LA institution, Canter's Deli has stood the test of time, and is a timepiece in its very own way. Bagels and lox? They got it! Pastrami on rye, cole slaw and  pickle on the side? They got it! This always-busy deli has been in business for over 75 years, and at its current location in the "Little Israel" section of Fairfax Avenue since 1948. The menu offers a wide selection of breakfast items in various combinations, and several permutations of the classics (bagels and lox, bagels and cream cheese, pastrami on rye, etc.) Though the menu has broadened out a bit in a nod to changing times, I'd stick with the Jewish Deli classics, it's what they do best.The bakery is located at the front entrance, and offers a wide range of killer baked goods at very reasonable prices. For late night folks, the good news is that Canter's is still open 24/7, and caters to the rock and roll crowd in the wee hours, especially in the "Kibitz Room" bar and lounge. The cocktail bar is open with a full bar from 10:30am (love that) till 1:40am.  The career waitresses here are as charmingly acerbic as ever, which just adds to the texture of the whole Canter's experience.  Street parking or validated parking is available in the adjacent lot. Some of the old delis are dying off, as the times, cholesterol levels and pastrami prices change, yet Canter's remains. If you love classic delis, there's a lot here to love.

Reviews.Author: Robbie H.
Reviews.Content: I had the Downtowner.  Hat pastrami as Swiss on rye bread.  Very good. Ambiance was nice as well. And so was our service.  Theresa did an excellent job. Yes this is a short review however that doesn't mean the place isn't good. It's definitely worth a stop

Reviews.Author: Jen S.
Reviews.Content: I am addressing this to the new owner and the management at Canter's:Way to go guys, you took what was once an iconic eating place in Los Angeles and one of the greatest Jewish delis on the West Coast, and turned it into fake deli that serves pork while nixing the perks and amping up your prices. Way to go. A tradition of Canter's and Jewish delis in general is to offer complementary pickles. Well, no longer at Canter's. Now you have to pay for them. Pig meat at a Jewish deli? What the hell? If people want pork they can go somewhere else. Hey, why not add Chinese food to the menu too, you ass. They have like 5 or 6 types of rueben sandwiches, including a vegetarian option. What the hell. JUST SERVE A TRADITIONAL RUEBEN LIKE YOU USED TO!!!And paninis are on the menu now. LAME. Do Jews even run this place anymore? If so, they must be the ones who killed Jesus. Because they killed the awesomeness that used to reside here. I am never eating here again. There is that other Jewish deli Greenblatt's on Sunset that still serves a normal simple menu without pork products and that offers traditional Jewish comfort food. From now on I am going there.

Reviews.Author: Rich O.
Reviews.Content: A place that really has a lot of history but in my opinion that's kind of all it has. Anyway, I was there for lunch this past Sunday before my stop at LACMA. The place had good activity for 2 in the afternoon and I was excited to try their pastrami. Let's just say if it was okay. Nothing I'd write home to rave about but I wouldn't pan it either. Honestly I'd rather make a drive to Langers and get their #19.The one thing that made me ding a star was the pickle. This is a deli, so the pickles should be good, right? I mean companies that jar pickles try and market with the angle that their pickles are like the ones you'd get at a deli. Anyway, if they're making their own pickles the person in charge needs to go back and take a refresher class because the pickle was unbelievably bland. No salt, no tang and no dill flavor, plus it wasn't very crunchy.On a positive note, our server was a sweet older lady, named Gina who was very pleasant and attentive and left a positive impression on me about the service. But that's the only plus.

Reviews.Author: John R.
Reviews.Content: Open 24/7 and I love the atmosphere inside and out - it's like being teleported back in time. Yes, the decor is brown, orange and god awful - yes it hasn't seen an update in years... wait... decades, but it's pretty much a historical landmark - you can't mess with that. Also the place is HUGE.I didn't get to eat a proper meal here, but my buddy had the (obligatory) pastrami and assured me it was great. His wife had the marzipan and while I'm not a big marzipan fan, I actually really enjoyed theirs. I had an apple turn-over, and I can say it was.. meh. Let's just say Arby's does em better.My other buddy had a chocolate russian coffee cake ala mode.  I didn't get to try it, but man that thing looked incredible in it's rich gooey, chocolately goodness. I'm definitely going back to try it.My next visit here? Pastrami sandwich followed by the chocolate russian coffee cake ala mode. Done.

Reviews.Author: paige f.
Reviews.Content: I LOVE PICKLES! Let's just leave it at that. The BLT and onion rings are soo good. The waiters/waitresses are nice and a bit older but add to the feel. The cookies from the front part of the areas case are good too.

Reviews.Author: Joshua J.
Reviews.Content: The food is good, but the service is lousy. Me, and my friends would frequent this place, but after today, no more. If your not paying attention they rip you off on the bill, and sometimes the waitress adds her own tip. Today kid in the parking lot tried to scam me for a dollar, when i didn't pay him he started writing down my license plate as if I'll ever be back after today. When I called in to ask for the manager they hung up on me. Good riddance.

Reviews.Author: Chris C.
Reviews.Content: While visiting the Grove, we walked a few blocks (5-10min) to eat at Canter's on a Sunday afternoon. We ordered the signature sandwich corned beef reuben and a side of onion rings for $3 (used the Groupon $11 for $22)- 5-10min wait time at 1pm to be seated- Lots of pickles while we waited. different- Corned beef rueben: grilled corned beef, swiss cheese, sauerkraut, and russian dressin on grilled rye bread served with french fries (14.50). - Basket of onion rings (4.95) nothing to special. burnt looking- Although it tasted alright, not my kind of food that I usually eat. haha. Very heavy. I suggest Mendocino Farms for a good sandwich a few blocks back to the Grove.- Service was just like Norms.- Didn't try the bakery.- Tax included with the Groupon! yes!- Remind me of Norms fused with The Hat.

Reviews.Author: N H.
Reviews.Content: not the best deli - but definitely a must at some point if you live in LA. The food/service is mediocre, but the experience is quintessentially unique to this city.Easy free parking is a huge plus - don't forget to get validated.

Reviews.Author: Mitchell I.
Reviews.Content: Some of the best pastrami you will get in the Los Angeles area.  I suggest the potato pancakes with extra sour cream and apple sauce.  It reminds of me of Chicago.  Excellent.  I order the pastrami, extra fat on rye bread.  It has never disappointed me.  I have ordered a few of the other sandwiches, but this is my go to sandwich here.  There is always a lively and fun crowd here.

Reviews.Author: Richard And Elainne S.
Reviews.Content: Had some dinner with the hubby and friends and it was pretty good. Our waitress was very nice and sweet. And the sandwiches were yummy! I had the egg salad sandwich. It was okay. Lettuce pieces were too thick so i didnt care for that. The hubby got the open face brisket. He said it tasted more like roast beef but the meat was very tender. Our friends got the fairfax sandwich which was packed with meat! And our other friend had the bbq brisket. Very tastey. Must try the strawberry cheesecake. Its delish! Will probably some here again if we are in the area.

Reviews.Author: Marconi de M.
Reviews.Content: I had a very painful experience... top moment: "sorry for the delay bringing your beer... the bar is packed"... note: it was bottled - not tap...coming from the manager... how long it takes to open a bottle? All the more than 10 minutes they tooked?Steak fries... GREAT - I could say PERFECT !!! Brisket,,, overcooked... chicken milanese... over fried... mashed potatoes - NOT REAL potatoes - AWFUL... and they even forgot to bring a salad on a dish that supposed to be served with...I can't go lower because of the pastries... server tried to fix the situation as much as she could... very kind (although late) and a smart ass at register tried to blame the server because she was new... shame on him... lame... Well... I will return... if I have ANY OTHER choice...

Reviews.Author: Christina L.
Reviews.Content: Canters  is a staple in Los Angeles. I am a Los Angeles native, but for some dumb reason I had never tried this place until my ex took me here. I got rid of the ex, but kept my relationship with Canters...zing! Canters is a traditional deli...sandwiches piled high with meat; delicious breads, deli pickles, steak fries, cole slaw and matzo ball soup. All the portions are way too big and way too good. If you haven't been here you have to come. My only reason for the four stars out of five is that I really don't like the pickles...AND I AM PREGNANT. With that being said, I have to go now so I can order my turkey dip sandwich to take home and eat in bed.

Reviews.Author: Aizel A.
Reviews.Content: Popped into the open mic area for a bit to see what was happening in there and watched a band play (they were decent). It's a small space though. Not too many seats, and it doesn't help that most of the space is taken up by huge half-circle booths. They look cool and all, but with so many of the groups being parties of two taking up entire booths, it was a little bit clunky. Lots of people had to stand, and even clogged up the entrance. Isn't that a fire hazard?I might have to update my review if I go back sometime since I wasn't there too long, but for now, I'll say this place was A-OK.

Reviews.Author: Alan B.
Reviews.Content: Excellent corn-beef. I have been going to Canter's since I was a kid. You got the love the fact it's open 24 hours a day. No matter what time you go you can order breakfast. The waitress have been here over 25 years and even longer. If you are picky desert eater you will love the bakery.  The French toast is one of the best in town. If you love corn beef you came to the right place. Plenty of parking in the private lot or street parking. Enjoy the food that your parents grew up.

Reviews.Author: Skya E.
Reviews.Content: I checked this place out on a Sunday and it wasn't that crowded, considering it being lunch time. The waiter was really friendly but my salmon Benedict wasn't as good as I expected. I felt like the salmon wasn't cooked thoroughly. The lady who was at the front at the register was really rude and you can tell she forced herself to say "have a good day" with no enthusiasm. I don't remember her name but she wore glasses and had a curly Afro-like hairstyle and wore glasses. That kind of threw me off.

Reviews.Author: John S.
Reviews.Content: I liked my first visit to Canter's, the pastrami and corned beef was great. The complimentary pickles were much more pleasant than eating commercial pickles. And the service was above-average. Now you may be asking, why just 3 stars? Simply put, there isn't anything on the menu that's going to blow you away. Although the menu is very large the bulk of it consists of your typical deli selections, breakfast items, and generic dinner entrees. Just an FYI, I haven't had the chance to go to many delis so I can't really compare how good Canter's pastrami and corned beef are to other places. But solely focusing on Canter's deli meats, I would say that it was really good.Again I can't explain why this place doesn't get that extra star. The food was good, however, I just don't see myself coming back here on a regular basis. If you're around the area then give it a try, hopefully you'll fall in love with Canter's! To good eatings!

Reviews.Author: James G.
Reviews.Content: Just was not a fan. Maybe I had it hyped up in head because of all the hooplah, but I was just not impressed with the food. My Reuben was less than $tellar for the price.

Reviews.Author: Aaron G.
Reviews.Content: Such a great place to grub at. The beef dip is to die for. Love the bland drab paint on the walls. We just love this server named Laurie there too- she is so nice & my girlfriend Tiffany remembers her well.Anyways, brisket dip or pastrami dip with coleslaw. Can't go wrong.

Reviews.Author: Denny C.
Reviews.Content: If you have the patience to read through my many Yelp reviews, you'll know I love me a good reuben sandwich.I came here with some other folks on a Sunday evening for dinner.  There was no wait.  The restaurant's huge as there's basically another section in the back after you go up a few stairs.  Our waitress seemed like a seasoned veteran and upon hearing it was our first time, she delightfully offered us free samples of the corned beef and pastrami.  I opted to get the corned beef reuben and switched my regular fries with sweet potato fries.  The sandwich was delicious and totally hit my spot.  The bread was perfectly grilled and the corned beef - with just the right amount of saltiness - essentially fell apart in my mouth.  The dressing was pretty light, so it wasn't one of those sandwiches that is dripping with dressing.  The sweet potato fries were good, too:  lightly fried, crunchy on the outside and thin strips.  I'd say they give Veggie Grill - my personal favorite - a good run for their money.After sampling their pastrami and their corned beef, I'd definitely recommend the corned beef.  My friends who got the pastrami liked it, but I think there was at least some agreement that the corned beef was better, to varying extents.  The pastrami tasted a bit salty and dry for my tastes.  Service:  Hard to beat.  Our waitress was a pro.  Granted the restaurant wasn't too busy, but she was attentive, friendly, and I'd like to think she took particularly good care of us because it was our first time at Canter's.  As for the ongoing debate between Canters and Langers, I can only say I was really satisfied with my reuben here.  I haven't had a reuben at Langers (I've had other items) so this makes me really want to get one there for comparison.  Let's just say it's a high bar to surpass.  Bottom line:  Corned beef reuben with sweet potato fries, please.P.S. - Make sure to watch out for the signs if you do street parking on Fairfax.  I thought it was free on Sundays, so I didn't bother reading the signs or paying the meter.  Let's just say what would have been a fairly inexpensive meal became probably the most expensive reuben I've ever had.

Reviews.Author: Alex C.
Reviews.Content: Great service, and friendly staff. I like'd how they asked before we ordered if we're doing seperate checks. I really appreciate that. Food was good, id definently come back.

Reviews.Author: Alfa S.
Reviews.Content: Came here for dinner on 30 July 2013 with J after spending a couple days in L.A. We split the Hollywood, kettle chips, the potato salad, and I had some pickles. It was my first time and everything was amazing. The service was great and I really don't have anything negative to say, at all. On our way out, we bought dessert from their bakery. I got a brownie, I bought J a chocolate chip cookie, and I got my sister these chocolate dipped almond cookies for her birthday. Forgot what they're called. Anyways, J went to the car 'cause he couldn't find the parking thing so we could get it validated. While he did that, I got the baked goods.  I asked the baker guy for a sample of the chocolate almond cookie thingers to see what I was getting my sister. J doesn't come back in time so I get his cookie, my brownie, and seven of the almond whatchamacallits for my sister. The guy tells me that he gave me an extra chocolate chip cookie because the other one was too small; I thank him. J comes back and I tell him to stand further away from me. I pay for the stuff and we're off on our way home.There isn't any way in heaven, earth, or hell that one of the cookies was bigger than the other. They were like hockey pucks! Both of them!! I explain to J what happened and we laugh at my whatever-it-was-that-made-the-guy-gimme-a-free-­cookie skills.Turns out that the parking ticket was in J's pocket the whole time. I ask him if it was all done by design; his leaving got me a free cookie. He says that that was the plan from the get go. I'm skeptical, but I'll give him the benefit of the doubt. All in all, I can't wait to go back to Canter's.

Reviews.Author: Gail G.
Reviews.Content: For us Canter's makes you feel like home.  We love the established waiters and waitress there.  Normally we just go for breakfast and have never been disappointed.  Prices not cheap so we don't go too often, but they do have breakfast specials now.  You cannot get better pancakes anywhere.  Potato pancakes, turkey sausage, bagels and fruit fresh and to die for.  Coffee can be strong.  Always have great service.  Yes it's dark and old but has a great vibe.

Reviews.Author: Ada L.
Reviews.Content: Oh mah gawd! This place is the bomb!!  Everything here looks so old and cute!  Menu is pretty extensive and offering lots of comfort food choices and various sandwiches.  Foods taste great and are served in huge portions.  Price wise, very reasonable, say maybe $10-15 per person.  The French Dip Sandwich is really good; the roast beef is super tender.  Packed with lots of calories, the Bronx Special with thick stacks of pastrami and chopped liver (liver pate) served open face on rye is soooooo delicious, which I would highly recommend.In the display cases right at the entrance, all the desserts and sweets, including many different kinds of classic cookies, pastries, and cakes, look very adorable!  Please do not expect to find Macarons, Tiramisu, dressed-up cupcakes, or any fancy desserts here; but, they do have the good old banana bread, jam-filled butter cookies, shortbread cookies, carrot cakes, Italian cream cakes, bear claws, almond horns, etc., of which all remind me of my favorite sweets from the childhood.  Also, the bakery makes the biggest Palmiers that I have ever seen in life!!!   I've got a bag of cookies of various kinds (about 30 pcs) and a Palmier for just $9.42!  Nom nom nom :)  Anyways, it is a pleasure already just by looking at those many cookies and desserts while waiting to be seated! Last but not least, Canter's opens 24/7, from breakfasts to late nights, meaning that anytime you crave comfort foods and/ or desserts, just drop by!

Reviews.Author: Dmitry D.
Reviews.Content: Nice place, excellent food. It reminds me NY delis with CA twist (just a bit). Food comes in absolutely indescribable size portions. We never got served pickles. Some pastry (cake) wasn't as good as we expected. Overall it's a nice place and definitely deserves some attention. It's a very strong "4 star" place.

Reviews.Author: Sean M.
Reviews.Content: So I had been meaning to try Canter's forever and ever now. I was up at a school near the school taking an exam for work and i finished about 1:30 in the afternoon. After one circle around the block I got lucky and found a parking spot open. I ordered the matzo ball soup for starter and a pastrami sandwich on rye. The soup was very tasty. the matzo was good and the broth was tasty. Their homemade pickles were delicious. The pastrami came out and it was very thinly cut and absolutely delicious. It was packed full of flavor. The rye bread was soft and delicious. It comes out with no mayo/mustard on it. I am not a fan of mustard so they brought me a side of mayo at my request to put on the bread. This was the PERFECT pastrami sandwich. I cannot wait to go back and get another one!!

Reviews.Author: Angela K.
Reviews.Content: Entourage was filmed here. There are framed pictures inside the restaurant if you'd like to see it.In the heart of Jewish community in LA, Canter's is one of my bf's family's favorite places to go (though they aren't Jewish). The food is a-ok but a good place to come with family. Don't have high expectations and Canter's may not be on the priority list of restaurant to go for LA visitors but i think Canter's one of those places you'd want to try at least once if you've been living in LA for a while.Free validated parking.

Reviews.Author: Vera E.
Reviews.Content: I pretty much had a mouthgasm with everything I had. I got an email for a Groupon, so of course I was on that like Sriracha sauce on most of the food that I eat.After finding our way through the disaster that is Fairfax at around 7PM, my company and I were immediately seated in the other dining room and was greeted by David, our server for the night.He was fantastic. Attentive, considerate, efficient... All that Jazz! He even had the kitchen split a matzo ball soup because I was the only one who ordered it. (The other person said she didn't like that soup, but after taking a bite she kept eating... I win! Again!)She had the Pastrami Dog while I got the Pastrami Reuben, both of which were out of this world. It takes me a lot to be vocal (tee hee), but YES! YES! MORE! Juicy Pastrami, Melted Swiss Cheese, Sauerkraut, and Russian Dressing between a toasted Rye Bread that's crusted with Fennel Seeds. Oy Vey.I have left overs which I am deciding whether or not to eat it right now.After paying, we took a gander at the bakery and I got the Prune Hamantaschen, Four Coconut Macaroons and a Black and White Cookies. I have sampled all and I am content with all.The cookie was more cakey in texture, good layer of the Black and White frosting. Very reminiscent of my trips in New York. My Israeli friend introduced me to Hamantaschen, but this one is HUGE! And delicious. A good balance between crisp and soft. Think of a slightly moist Shortbread. Lastly, the Macaroons have a slight lemon essence which is interesting, but makes it taste good nonetheless.Overall? Definetely coming back. Even if it's just for the bakery. (But why would I do that?)

Reviews.Author: Linda R.
Reviews.Content: Much love for Canter's.  I''ve been coming here ever since I started drinking and staying out late..  It wasn't until I had nasty potato pancakes elsewhere that I realized I'd never reviewed Canter's.Their potato pancakes are the best in town.  Their pastrami is gently seasoned, not overly salty, heaven.  A lot of their other food can be spotty, but those two items never disappoint.After hours at Canter's is always a mixed bag.  I've seen famous people famously trashed there.  I've seen drunken little people start fistfights there. Are you catching onto the theme?  On an average weekend the late-night crowd out Tarantinos Tarantino.  Canter's is an LA institution....of crazy!On the downside, the bakery does nothing for me. It seems like everything they make is dry.

Reviews.Author: Wendee H.
Reviews.Content: I've been here twice in one month, already. First time I dined in I really enjoyed my sandwich. Second time I dined here I was not at all disappointed.I loveee how they always give you a plate of pickles. Hey, some people like chips and salsa or french bread and balsamic vinaigrette, but I like them pickles! The Pastrami Reuben is delicious. Loaded with so much grilled pastrami, the sauerkraut is spilling out and the swiss cheese is oozing from the rye bread.The Mac Attack is also good. Want sum cheeeese??! This deli melt is satisfy your cravings.I had to finish off with some dessert the last time I was here so I shared the a slice of Carrot Cake. They make a killer carrot cake. Super moist with smooth cream cheese frosting. Yummmm. This place has a run down diner feeling, but service was good. There is ample seating everywhere. They even have happy hour!

Reviews.Author: Duggan B.
Reviews.Content: Well let me just say this may be one of the most solid late night spots in all of Los Angeles, for the most part you can't really get much better.  My friend and I came here after a long day wanting something closeish, non-korean and decent. I've been here a few times on a drunken late night but was actually sober this time around so i was a little more tuned in with my experience. To start the place is a totally outdated looking diner which i imagine is part of its charm with a load of seating booth and table alike. The Service was excellent, we got seated and got our orders promptly taken care of, they made sure out drinks were always topped off and the waitress was very cordial and sweet. Now to the food! I ordered Matt's Special with pastrami instead of turkey (suggested by waitress) and it was a very formidable sandwich! Pastrami with melted muenster, cole slaw and russian dressing on challah egg bread. This sandwich delicious! My friend went with the corned beef reuben which we both traded half of and that was almost as good as mine. My only con is that the meal felt a little greasier in comparison to the same things you'd get at Langers. But all in all our meals were enjoyed and after getting down on these bad boys we went to the bar attached, The Kibitz Room and listened to some sludgey techno metal band rip out some songs. Great food and great night!

Reviews.Author: Jess R.
Reviews.Content: I'm from Brooklyn NYC. so no CA deli will ever get 5 stars, but Canter's remains the hands down best deli Los Angeles has got.  We ate breakfast there this weekend, and the deli omelet is first rate.  Lox and eggs - so nice, the salami and egg pancake omelet - also first rate.  I even had a chocolate egg cream - for those of you who even know what that is - OMG!.  For those who don't - well, it's on an as need to know basis.  Totally sinful - i haven't indulged in such a treat in over three decades.Canter's rules!

Reviews.Author: Robert G.
Reviews.Content: They ALMOST get the same number of stars as "Nate 'n' Al's."  Same idea, except that Nate 'n' Al's is in Beverly Hills, and you might see a celeb, and Canter's is in the Fairfax District.  It's interesting that it could almost be in a "smaller" city, once inside, but it's near a heavy-hitter corner, between the Miracle Mile District and Hollywood.It's not exactly cheap, but the portions are abundant.  I don't remember their pastrami sandwich as being any more than good, but it was large.  Also, I HATE rye bread - it spoils any sandwich, so they have to switch that out, and they do.  But the cheesecake was top notch.  A Jewish deli without good cheesecake is like a night without sleep.Better for an occasional novelty visit than for regular patronage.

Reviews.Author: Wesley L.
Reviews.Content: I try and go here once a week; they literally have the best pastrami ruben I have ever had, and that's coming from someone who lived in a few hassidic areas in the past (typically these places breed great delis). Seriously though, they are infinitely better than Langer's and all the other places that people seem to rave about in LA. There just isn't anything better if you are looking for something reminiscent of an NY deli and are prepared for one of the best sandwich experiences of your life. Oh, and their baked goods and bagels are pretty good too.

Reviews.Author: Mal C.
Reviews.Content: What could you not love about this 24-7 Jewish deli?!  Sometimes, I just get random cravings for their meat and will have to go at odd hours!  I order the Fresser signature sandwich, which comes with hot corned beef and pastrami piled extra high (and they do mean piled high) on rye with cole slaw, potato salad, and a garlicky dill pickle.  I would also recommend adding some pickled tomatoes to your order!

Reviews.Author: Amy A.
Reviews.Content: Your chicken soup is the best there is. Anywhere. Ever. Your cole slaw is also fantastic and your pastrami is very, very good. Your chopped liver, however, needs to be fluffier. Please! (I want to eat it, not use it to regrout my shower.)

Reviews.Author: Joseph A.
Reviews.Content: Great spot to take the family. Feels like your stepping into the past. Also - the foods good. The hot pastrami is perfect.

Reviews.Author: Maureen M.
Reviews.Content: Bought a Groupon because I knew it wouldn't go to waste at Canter's.I had the corn beef/pastrami combo on rye with a side of potato salad.  It's stacked so high that I had to take it apart and eat the guts before I could reconstruct a sandwich to fit into my gaping maw.  I love deli food, so of course I love this place.  The pickles are crunchy, not soggy, and they do not skimp.  The Michael Unit had a pastrami with colesaw, thousand island on rye which was equally delicious.  We split a bowl of chili - no need to do that again.  The drive on a Sunday was a freaking MESS from Long Beach.  But the food made me forget the traffic.  Canter's never disappoints.  Pricey, yes, but a worthwhile experience just to watch the tourists, hipsters and freaks.

Reviews.Author: Jessica G.
Reviews.Content: First time going, Took my family, the décor was something out of the 50/60's. I had the Corned Beef Sandwich. It was so good and juicy, The bread was also fresh. As a side you got potato salad that was served in a tiny paper cup. I wish It came in something bigger I thought it was soo good! I'm not a big potato salad fan it usually has to look appealing for me to give it a try. It was so good! I will def go again if ever in the area.

Reviews.Author: David L.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is always a good spot to come to when in desperate need of a sandwich. I came here late night the other night with a friend who was in need of some deli food. I normally don't come here but the menu is very extensive. The waitress was a sweet woman and told me what was the best to order. I would go back for sure if I was in a bind. I normally go to Nate N Al in Beverly Hills or Labels Table on Pico in Beverly Hills as well.The pastry counter I had to avoid! Everything looked amazing!!!!!!!There is parking attached to the property if there isn't parking on the street.

Reviews.Author: Mike B.
Reviews.Content: Great last night sandwiches spot in LA. I had the pastrami with sauerkraut and it was solid.

Reviews.Author: Dan E.
Reviews.Content: What the hell is going on at Canter's? I've been eating there since the late 70s, and they've always offered consistently good Jewish comfort food in an old-school deli setting. Went back today for the first time in a while, and found that they've massively overhauled their old menu: Gone are the charming mid-century menu graphics, along with many of their classic sandwiches and dishes; in their place are quesadillas and (wait for it) panini-style sandwiches -- including one with friggin' macaroni and chees and bacon on it -- as well as "dessert paninis".  You can't get Dr. Brown's Cel-Ray there any more, but you CAN get a Rockstar Energy Drink? WTF?!? I ordered a roast beef and turkey on rye, only to have it arrive literally split into two halves -- one half a roast beef sandwich, the other half a turkey sandwich. The rye bread was still good as ever, but It's like the place has been body-snatched by alien beings who have no idea what a classic deli is. Canter's was once a timeless culinary and cultural landmark, but whoever's running the show these days seems completely oblivious to the things that made Canter's great. Is it just a matter of time before they rip out all the great old light fixtures, decorations and booths in favor of a generic "Fifties Diner" look? Will they replace knishes and kasha varnishkas with "extreme burritos"? I'm a lifelong customer, but now I'm not sure I ever want to come back and find out...

Reviews.Author: Karl M.
Reviews.Content: What I had: pastrami on rye, mish mash soup, pickles. Review: They didn't have celray / Jewish champagne which bummed me out. The place isnt even kosher so its not even really deli. The food was very bland and not well seasoned. However the most important thing and the reason I'm bothering with a review is I have eaten here 3 times and every time I have gotten sick. The place looks like a kitchen nightmare from the dining room u can only imagine what lurks in the kitchen. In conclusion if you enjoy paying money to get sick, than maybe its for you. I vow to never return no matter who tries to drag me there.

Reviews.Author: Jenny M.
Reviews.Content: Jewish Penicillin! Yes PleaseWhen a matzo ball comes out and its bathing in a pool of golden broth there's this calm that transcends your body. It's almost too perfect to eat but yet the majestic orb beckons you, and before you know it you have shawshank redemtioned a escape route in that mutha. Matzo Ball Soup: 1 gargantuan size matzo with broth (Canters is also one of the only Jewish delis that allows you to get it with rice, noodles ad or chicken)Bagels: Its a Jewish Deli - I've never met one I didn't care for mashugana!Parking: Private Lot with validation.

Reviews.Author: Ms. C.
Reviews.Content: I love this place! I have been going here for all my life and it never changes! Still great pickles, delicious rye bread and the best matzo ball soup ever.  Heaven!  The potato pancakes are another favorite of mine.  This place is an institution!

Reviews.Author: Marlon T.
Reviews.Content: I've passed by this place many times but never noticed it. It's next to the restaurant Animal and the popular street clothing store Supreme.I came in by myself, grabbed a seat at the counter and had myself some Matzo Ball soup and a Pastrami Sandwich. Both were amazing and I recommend getting these 2 Jewish items. I came during Passover and they had given me some unleavened bread. I'm not sure if it's because of Passover or that's just a standard thing here. There was another single-diner near me who was in his 60's and he kept annoying the waitresses telling tales about how he used to go to Canter's everyday growing up.I like how this place is open 24/7. I wouldn't mind coming back here if someone suggested it. Fairfax Ave. is so Jewish. There's a lot of history at this restaurant so don't miss out if you're only in LA for a few months or so.

Reviews.Author: Mr And Mrs V.
Reviews.Content: Service was good & fast, prices were high for type of food, pickles had a weird after taste, hot pastrami was not tasty, fries were old and stale, glass of water was straight from tap, cheese cake was the only thing that deserves a 5 star rating. Restaurant smelled like hospital cafeteria. We expected more from world famous Canters. Disappointment!!

Reviews.Author: Mahtab P.
Reviews.Content: The classics are still there but now have veggie varieties too!!! The best just got a better!

Reviews.Author: Jennifer W.
Reviews.Content: Canter's.  You're only one sweet pastrami sandwich away from living the dream.  Just went here for brunch/meat gorging.  It was Sunday at 1pm.  There was a line, a long line, that extended out the doors and into the streets.  Most of the time I come after a concert around 2am and there is no line and rarely other customers.  They do have a parking lot which can get full pretty quickly.  Look for street parking but beware that some streets are permit only after 6pm.  But back to the food.  Hot damn, do these guys make a good corned beef pastrami sandwich.  And they set a full plate of pickles on the table before your food arrives.  The waitress knew the drill, she'd obviously served our kind of hungry meat eaters before.  The atmosphere is old school eclectic with many a Guns N Roses poster to commemorate their time at Canter's getting drunk whilst underage.  Best to come late at night when you want to sit in a large empty restaurant and hash out the fuzzy details of what happened in the past few hours.

Reviews.Author: G P.
Reviews.Content: the absolute worse food, place and service

Reviews.Author: Wes C.
Reviews.Content: Definitely an old school deli transported straight from New York City. Sandwiches are good, not great and are huge. Also has an large variety of deli pastries baked in house.

Reviews.Author: Casey O.
Reviews.Content: What can be said about Canter's that has not already been said? This place is legendary, and it lives up to the legend. It's got a menu full of absolutely wonderful comfort food, and it's open 24 hours a day.Canter's has served me the best Belgian waffle I've ever eaten -- sweet and hearty with amazing toppings. I die. And one of the best baked potatoes I've ever had -- cheesy and delicious. Whenever I'm sick, I head into Canter's for some soup and tea, and it really hits the spot.So much respect for this wonderful delicatessen.

Reviews.Author: Lindsey M.
Reviews.Content: It was cool to check it out because of the history of it, the service is fast and they have all the traditional jewish deli treats. I had a pastrami, it was good, pretty standard.

Reviews.Author: AJ N.
Reviews.Content: Not the best or worst sandwich bar in town, but surely worth a visit.The parking lot adjacent makes going in easier, however, it's a bit dingy and old looking from the paint to the chairs.  I didn't visit the restroom, but overall it appears mostly clean. What really slows this place down is that they had one cashier station and make the customer wait in line to check out, like the way the Denny's chains do.Taste of the food is rather good, but I asked for potatoes and got overburnt and painfully crispy hash browns. Asked for no ice and apparently the waitress didn't listen, but she was good enough to bring a whole tray of lemons.  This was my 2nd time eating there, and I'll say Cherisse (the waitress) did a nice job on this visit.Moral of the Review:  Don't let the fact that Guns N Roses appear to have gotten famous from this place pull you into a $15 sandwich.

Reviews.Author: Scot O.
Reviews.Content: The restaurant interior is old but has lots of character.  We went on a Saturday afternoon in the summer and it was crowded, but we didn't wait long to be seated.  The service was acceptable but not overly friendly.  We ordered some of their most popular sandwiches and they were ok but I wouldn't consider it to be all that different than any other place's deli sandwiches.  It's fun to be here considering the history but it's rather pricey - sandwiches and drinks for three was over $65 with tip.Save some room for the pastry counter.  Big selection and tasty.  We'll probably come back but maybe only for dessert.

Reviews.Author: Red F.
Reviews.Content: Canter's may not have the best deli food around, but the atmosphere there is just the best.  It has such a history, and you know that your server has been working there since before you were born.Being a Jew, I always have to get the matzo ball soup.  it's not better than my grandmas matzo ball soup, but it definitely does the trick! Recently I tried their Corned Beef Reuben, which I thought was really good.   It was served warm with sauerkraut and a side of russian dressing. But I suggest eating it with mustard.  The Marilyn Sandwich is also one of my favorites (grilled cheese on rye with swiss and tomatoes).  Before I leave, I always go to the bakery section and get some chocolate and cinnamon rugelach. yummmm

Reviews.Author: Wes C.
Reviews.Content: There were so many items to choose from, but alas I decided to go with a sandwich. I've already had the best pastrami in LA so I ordered their Little Corned Beef panini. I believe this was the first time I've ever had corned beef and it was quite delicious - not mind blowing, but just right.

Reviews.Author: Whitney P.
Reviews.Content: If you're a fan of rock you'll love this place- especially if you're into Guns n' Roses. The 24/7 place caters to any hunger at any time, and alcohol is also served while you will dine amongst rock memorabilia, mostly GnR (no complaining here) - you can't go wrong.I'm disgusted by sandwiches and Deli's in general- not that I'm a vegetarian by any means, but that wet sloppy meat turns me off. That being said, this place doubles as a diner- meaning if sandwiches and typical deli (ugh I hate even typing that word) don't wet your palette , there are plenty of other options- chicken fingers, breakfast menu, or go all out Jew and have the matzoh ball soup! They also deliver, which is helpful for those, can't get out of bed/never leaving the couch days. Delivery (to Hollywood) took about 45 minutes, which is pretty average unless you are ordering pizza- no complaints! Side Note: Our waitress was an older lady, which was nice. Sometimes you can get stuck with some snotty brat 'wanna be celeb' waitress when you're dining in LA, you know the type-thinks they are too good for a service job, that role as 'extra in a music video' didn't pay enough so they have to wait tables- but these ladies are all business and no attitude!

Reviews.Author: Steve H.
Reviews.Content: Canters was originally located in Boyle Heights until the Jewish exodus of the '50's took them to the promised land of Fairfax and beyond (there is a Canters in Vegas now.)  It remains L.A.'s signature Jewish deli.Walking into Canters gives you an aromatic whiff of Kosher-style cuisine.  The pickles, corn beef, pastrami, tongue, and herring combined harken back to the days of Delancy and Hester streets in old New York.I love their corned beef and pastrami.  They make a fair Matzoh Ball soup (Katella Deli's in Los Al is better).  They have a large selection of sandwiches and meals (many of which are named after old movie stars and comedians) that will send you home stuffed and with left-overs.If you stop by the deli counter, pick yourself up some of their delicious whipped cream cheese.  It is the best I have ever tasted.  Then stop by the bakery for some of their tasty yiddishah baked goods (rugulah, bagels, challah, danish, bagels, and of course a black and white cookie).No matter what the hour (and they are open all 24), Canters will take you back to the days when Jewish L.A. made this the place to ess and fress.Now eat and enjoy!!

Reviews.Author: Katie R.
Reviews.Content: A vintage force to be reckoned with, Canters is an LA classic. If you're new or Angelino-born, head on over for great breakfast treats 24/7 and a mid-century design inspiration!

Reviews.Author: Scott C.
Reviews.Content: It has been around forever and looks it! It needs freshing up. The food is old school and it's O.K., nothing to write home about. The staff is ify. the cashier is very unhappy and needs to find another job.

Reviews.Author: Kameron S.
Reviews.Content: Ahhh my favorite restaurant. Just classic delicatessen, the corn beef is the best in the world the matzo ball soup is extraordinary the chocolate chip Rugelach are just amazing. DONT EVEN GET ME STARTED ON THE SERVICE, honestly the best service you can receive at a restaurant fast, helpful, and very pleasant. This place screams old LA everyone should try this place!!!!!

Reviews.Author: Ryan R.
Reviews.Content: Went here after purchasing a $22 for $11 Groupon.We decided to stop in for a quick bite for lunch. Since we had heard so much about the corned beef here, my friend and I decided to get a corned beef reuben with sweet potato fries.While the corned beef was excellent, the size of the sandwich did not warrant an almost $15 price tag. It really is a great sandwich, but because of the name, it comes with a hike in the price. The fries were also very tasty and had a great crispness to them.Since we had some more money to spend with the Groupon we decided to share a banana split which was actually a healthy size and quite satisfying. The main fault I have with this place other than the price is that the service is a bit slow in my opinion. They seem to have a lot of tables to cover, but I was expecting a little more from our waitress as it seemed that we had to track her down quite often.Overall, this place is a classic and is priced as such. I probably wouldn't have come here without a groupon, but if its available I would definitely give it a try.

Reviews.Author: Noel J.
Reviews.Content: This is the classic deli every other classic deli strives hard to be.This place is old and full of history. It has been featured in a bunch of movies/tv shows.In fact, Slash at one point lived upstairs just at the start of GNR.I'm not going to lie and say that I have eaten everything off the menu and that I'm a total expert.I come here for the Pastrami on rye and a bowl of Matzh ball soup.It is so damn good.

Reviews.Author: Dana L.
Reviews.Content: I could not believe when my friends and I stopped by after a late night for a snack that such a place as this would have GLUTEN FREE BREAD!I wasn't hungry, but because of the GF bread, I got their 3-meat plate with roast beef, pastrami, and liverwurst, with cole slaw.Oh. My. Holy. Heavenly. Fuzzy. Navels. Liverwurst on bread. I haven't had that in years since I've gone gluten-free. They gave me so much, I had enough for the next three days of lunches. And the other meats were juicy and delicious as well.The only thing bleh about the place was the pickles. I know it's a personal thing for my friends loved their pickles. And can they please update their cash registers??? It's only cute and retro for like five minutes, after that, you just want to pay the bill and go home. Oh, well. I will definitely have to make this place a regular for those late night snack-attacks.

Reviews.Author: John T.
Reviews.Content: I definitely love the pastrami and deli style sandos here. Had a pastrami burger that was good, but after ordering it medium rare, kindly sending it back because it was medium well, it's a little irritating when I don't get food done the right way. Excellent pickles and my chocolate shake was decadent. Either way, it's a classic joint in LA, a good piece of history to partake in. I'm coming back, it's a good old fashioned piece of Americana that you won't find in many other parts of LA.

Reviews.Author: Alix A.
Reviews.Content: Had the Brooklyn with pastrami, side of sweet potato fries. Ohmygod. That pastrami was some of the best I've ever had. Fries were good, not spectacular but crispy & not soggy, which was nice. Also, unlimited free pickles! So good.

Reviews.Author: Jenna G.
Reviews.Content: Absolutely Scrumptious!!!I would highly recommend starting your deli extravaganza with a matzo ball soup (the matzo balls can only be compared to the size of your head..Move right along to the hot brisket sandwich on challah bread (un-toasted) topped with cole slaw...magic in my mouth!!!Finish the meal with a warm chocolate chip rugullah and call it a day..you will not be disappointed...Just thinking about this place is making my mouth water...NOM NOM NOM!!!!  I WILL EAT IT ALL UP!!!!!

Reviews.Author: Efti P.
Reviews.Content: Canter's! I have heard so much about this place. It is name dropped by like big famous mega star producers on Late Show interviews. This is the Cantor's of Guns N' Roses road story lore.  I have been living in LA for over a year now and been itching to check this out.  Dam! What a dam let down! I thought this was going to be a pound for pound answer to the Lower East Side's Kats Deli. HUGE LET DOWN! I mean the food was technically good. It wasn't 'bad' per se. But It would be a good in terms of in stuck in the Pine Barrens of New Jersey and this is the only place open at 2:30 am. Certainly NOT ' I saw this place on TV and made a road trip to come here' good. The rye bread just simply wasn't good and the pastrami was so-so. Weinersnitzel does a better pastrami sandwich.  Even though the portions border on the generous, the meal borders on the PRICEY side for the food you are getting.Normally I'd give the food 3 stars. But it loses a full star for failing to meet their "legendary" expectations.Oh yea and nothing but nothing in the bakery window looked terribly appealing or original.

Reviews.Author: Ashleigh E.
Reviews.Content: Eh, not as good as I'd hoped considering the hype. The pickles were really good, but other than that, I was incredibly disappointed.It's partly my fault for ordering this turkey avocado wrap instead of a pastrami or burger, or something...but still. It was flavorless, ice cold and not super filling.

Reviews.Author: Kay M.
Reviews.Content: Hard to rate. The hostesses were great. But our server was awful. Really. When I went to pay, the cashier man asked me how everything was. I told him the server wasn't the business and he said well you should've gotten another server. Really?

Reviews.Author: Pratik P.
Reviews.Content: Alright guys, I just broke a personal record of mine tonight... I ate perhaps the BIGGEST matzoh ball ever known to humans. Not only was it the biggest, but it was hot, delicious, and savory. Two hours later, I can still taste it. I'd be fine if this taste stayed with me for an entire week. Mmm...Anyway, I went into Canter's for dinner tonight at the suggestion of a close friend and walked out completely STUFFED. Make sure you build up an appetite before you go since they have what seems to be an endless choice of fresh sandwiches, soup, salads, and drinks. i first started with one order of the matzoh ball soup. The matzoh ball was so huge that after three minutes of continuous eating, it looked like I didn't even make a dent... fast forward another five minutes and I finally finished the soup. If I left the deli right at this moment and called it a night, I still would've given this place 4 stars. It's that cool. But I had one more dish on the way...THE CANTER'S FAIRFAX. It's basically a tower of meat supported by two incredibly fresh slices of rye bread. If you're having a hard time visualizing the sandwich, do this: take an iPhone and stand it up straight... that's about 4.5 inches from top to bottom. The sandwich is right around that size (a little shorter). And just to put it in perspective, close to 90% of the sandwiches' height is meat. I wasn't kidding when I said bring your appetite, you're going to be leaving this place satisfied.Unfortunately, I live in DC and won't be able to become a 'regular' here, but I do hope work sends me to LA more often... I have a lot left on the menu to try :)

Reviews.Author: David H.
Reviews.Content: After an Easter Vigil (the night before Easter) at St James in the City Church, my friend wanted to come to Canter's.  I had never heard of the place, but he was like "You can get you a grilled cheese!".  He mentioned grilled cheese because I had told him how I take bagels and shredded mozzarella cheese and heat it up in the microwaveAnyways, he was in the mood for Canter's, and having to go to St James's church, it gave him an excuse to eat here afterwardsWe get to the small paid parking lot  with a "sorry lot full" sign, but as we pull up to the attendant to see if there are any other parking areas, he mentions that a space will be opening up.  So we park and walk the short distance to Canter's.As we walked in, I saw two female employees talking really loud over one another.  It looked like one was mad at the other for some reason.  That just made me cringe, because I was thinking I didn't want to get stuck with her as our waitress. Next, we wait to be seated like the sign states us to do.  This other woman just looks at us and without saying anything, grabs two menus and tells us to follow her.  She seemed like she didn't want to be there or do her job.  It wasn't busy, so we were seated right away.  Right away, I feel like I am getting LA attitude. We look over the menu and my friend mentions that they had changed the menu.  Because this was my first time here, I wouldn't know what, if anything, had changed.  The waitress that we had was really nice.  Although a little forgetful when it came to our drinks.  Diet Coke and Root Beer, doesn't seem that hard to remember.  But like I said, she was really nice so it didn't bother us when she didn't get the drink order right. Looking over the menu, I find the grilled cheese with a price of $7.50.  Really? Are grilled cheeses really that expensive now at sit down restaurants. (A couple of days earlier I had ventured to Sonics, and one of the items I got was a $1.10 grilled cheese).  I looked at the the hamburger section and I was having a hard time deciding which items would be worth the price.  My friend suggested to me to just get the grilled cheese.  It didn't take long for our food to arrive.  On the menu, the grilled cheese was suppose to come with kettle chips, but I was served potato chips.  Wasn't sure if they ran out or what, but it didn't bother me.  Although I did mention that I had a better grilled cheese at Hooters which made my friend chuckle a bit.  My friend mentioned that his salad was good. Overall the experience was O.K. For me, I don't think this is a place that I will rush to get back to, even if I was in the area again.  I did it once and got to experience some sort of "special" LA thing.

Reviews.Author: Angelina S.
Reviews.Content: Excellent food, great service, good drinks, felling good as remembering the past of the place. Love coming at the place. Good location, the interior part is like old man....no it is old shape. Cost is not standard with the service. should I come back........

Reviews.Author: jay r.
Reviews.Content: First, of all, kudos for that plate of pickles that they plunk down without even asking if you want them. Woot!Generally for me it's the pastrami reuben w/ fries--these are planks of potato like the chips you get in a newsprint cone after a night of drinking in a British pub. Yes, I soak them in malt vinegar and salt them heavily.  Having once back-to-backed a Canter's reuben vs. a Langers' reuben on the same weekend for a NYer friend on holiday here who was craving "juicy pastrami" and matzo ball soup, I can say that Canter's was indeed juicier!  The staff isn't rude, but they're not going to put up with a lot of insensible dithering about what to order or how to order it. Efficient, I would say. New Yorker-like, I would say. Comforting, I would say. We always, always, always take a loaf or half loaf of the double-baked rye bread home.  It's tangy, has a perfect crust and is heavily seeded with caraway. Got a loaf in the freezer right now...don't wait too long to eat it. Wrapped in foil and then plastic, you'll have insane rye toast for days. I've even wrapped it carefully and frozen it in a pinch. Toasted, buttered and lightly sprinkled with kosher salt, it's still to die for. Sometimes I stop just for a loaf to go. It's that good.

Reviews.Author: Anna P.
Reviews.Content: Canters is open 24/7 yay! This is my dessert go-to place when I'm in LA area. The Hungarian Cheesecake is worth the midnight drive from Irvine, yes, it's THAT good! Chocolate chip rugelach are the very best, I can't have enough of those!Everything from their dessert section makes excellent breakfast, oh and don't forget the potato knish! I have dined in a couple of times, and gotten desserts to go too many times to count. Parking can be a little hard sometimes and the walk from the parking lot to the store is not the most pleasant experience, but those pastries, those pastries are the best.The inside isn't very appealing, it's the kind of old that makes it look dirty, but I assure you it's not actually dirty, it's just old. But the pastries are delicious.

Reviews.Author: Rob F.
Reviews.Content: Food was good & I definetly would go back, anything pastrami is a winner, added bonus our waitress charmagne was a hottie too!

Reviews.Author: Lynnette P.
Reviews.Content: Sorry Canter's, you don't hold a candle to Brent's Deli in Northridge! Your meat is way too dry(especially the turkey), your rye bread is like something I get in Ralph's, and your cole slaw is hard  and sour. They only served pickles(no rye and butter), and I didn't have any. I could tell from my husband only having a small piece and leaving the rest(and no one else eating them) that they were meh. They looked like store brand pickles, and the Claussen we buy looks more appetizing.I know this because Saturday night, my husband and I went to Brent's, and Sunday afternoon went to Canter's. And my husband had leftovers from Brent's he could compare it to. I will say the wait staff is very nice, and there is plenty of room for a wheelchair. And we sat across from the Guns n' Roses booth. Above which is a photo of them where Axl's hair reminded me of a cockapoo I had as a kid.

Reviews.Author: Trung N.
Reviews.Content: Comparisons to Langers are inevitable for Canter's.Let me be clear that I am a big fan of Langers and came in with really high expectations for Canters.I came here solely to try their pastrami sandwich and was disappointed.  The pastrami was pretty standard and nothing really stood out. The pastrami was thinly sliced and served on rye bread and was a decent portion.  I was just looking for more flavor from the pastrami.  The servers were really nice. Everything was decently priced and I even got some things from the bakery.  It's nice that they are open 24 hours but I am not sure if I'd go back here.

Reviews.Author: Randy B.
Reviews.Content: Oy vey.  What is going on here at night?  What isn't?  It's not schmanzy, so you can dress up schnazy or be comfortable and schlocky.  Some are already schlitzy when they walk in, while others are on their way to being schmeckles.  As for me, I'm into the schmear.Canter's in LA for a Deli is like the xerox of copiers.  It's THE NAME in Deli...and certainly on Fairfax.  But for a place that had it's heyday in the 70's (and earlier)...it was a shock and awe show when I came here for late nights eats.   Apparently, Canter's is back on the map with a whole new, younger crowd.The place was hopping, jammed pack, and at midnight on a Friday night...word has got out that matzoh balls and corned beef sandwiches are cool again, and it's for everyone.While it may not have been the best corned beef sandwich I ever had, tasty but sliced the wrong direction so not as tender or as lean as I would have liked, the rye was super fresh and the fries were AWESOME, and the fellow diners provide FREE entertainment.  The portion was large, and I took half of the sandwich home.  One note to Father's Office and fans of, they have ketchup here!Upon entry, an overstuffed bakery section...and while it is super difficult to resist, it was sub-par and not amazing, but a solid B for the 3 items I tried.  If you are strong enough to pass by it on your way in, there is no way to resist it on your way out.  YOU WILL GET SOMETHING...it's impossible not to.Recommended for late night, dining solo (you may strike up a conversation with Meg Ryan or at least her movie double), a writer (sure to get some new characters for your screenplay or novel), a date (plenty of giggles to ensue), or a group of rockers (well, you won't get thrown out....this place is synonymous with the Sunset Rock scene from the 80's on up).

Reviews.Author: John W.
Reviews.Content: The food is delicious. My wife and I really liked the bakery section and I would recommend the cabbage rolls. I've never had Jewish comfort food but I definitely crave it now. The lights in the ceiling are a little trippy, not something you see eeveryday.

Reviews.Author: Hash T.
Reviews.Content: My first visit to Canters was very fun. We were seated within two minutes. I told my server it was our first time and asked what he'd recommend, he was excited we came, and told us the Pastrami/ Corned Beef Reuben was the best sandwich you'll ever try. He then told us he'd bring back samples of their cured corned beef and pastrami(loved his knowledge of the meat). He came back with meat samples, sold! Their is nothing more satisfying then knowing the staff stands behind their product and has knowledge of the meat. I appreciated that. Honestly in my whole life I've never been offered samples of the meat served, and his knowledge of the meat impressed me and then I made my decision. I got the Pastrami/ Corned Beef Reuben signature sandwich with substitute sweet potato fries soo worth it. I was pleased by the service and loved the food! This is now my favorite deli and I will tell everyone about it and my experience. Highly recommend it. I would say its big enough to share but then you couldn't enjoy round two:)Try this sandwich!

Reviews.Author: Sonia Q.
Reviews.Content: Twilight Zone....I visited this place a few months ago but forgot to finish up my review. I wish I wasn't forced to give it a 1 star because I wouldn't give this place any stars. Terrible service with terrible attitude from waitress. I know this place is like a landmark but obviously its not for food or great service!! Its almost as if we were bothering her to come take our order!

Reviews.Author: S M.
Reviews.Content: HEY CANTERS !  Thanks for the super stale challah I bought for dinner tonight.

Reviews.Author: Art K.
Reviews.Content: After our visit to The Price Is Right, my cousin suggested Canter's. My mom, cousin , sister and myself are all New Yorkers and Canter's took us back to New York... CIRCA 1950 ... AND THIS WAS THE CHARM.  It was sort of a theme restaurant in that sense. Our waitress was customarily gruff but polite and efficient. The food: Excellent. I liked that you can get a half sandwich with soup for a reasonable price. I had the turkey on rye and mushroom barley soup. I wasn't around in the 1950s but I appreciate nostalgia and there is a lot of it at Canter's.

Reviews.Author: Gerard U.
Reviews.Content: BANDS BEWARE. Played a free show, and packed the house. Not even a beer ticket, and they gouge us for parking. Just another venue that takes advantage of countless hours of work, and thousands of dollars worth of music education. DO NOT PLAY HERE.

Reviews.Author: Meg G.
Reviews.Content: Walked out after 15 minutes, and being led astray by 3 counters, and not one of those people could help me with a simple to-go order, a bagel & cream cheese. Come on, yutzes, it's a jewish deli for God's sake! Went to Bagel Broker and got my order in under 3 minutes!

Reviews.Author: Mike C.
Reviews.Content: With nearly 2000 reviews about this place I can't add much, but I will comment on the delivery. The two times I ordered delivery here (against my will), they've taken extremely long. They quote 45-60 min but it's always closer to 90-105 min. As a result the food is cold and it's generally unpleasant. I get this place is popular so a lot of idiots are ordering delivery at night, but if you cant promise within the time frame, then dont!

Reviews.Author: Robin R.
Reviews.Content: I love eating at Canter's whenever I visit LA.   Their hot pastrami sandwiches are are my favorite on the west coast.  Friendly wait staff. Love the original decor.

Reviews.Author: Severine C.
Reviews.Content: Three words: MATZO BALL SOUP. Whatever problems you're having that day will quickly fade with some of this amazing soup. Canter's is a pretty typical deli, just bigger. The menu is huge, and it will probably take you some time to decide what to get. In my opinion, the 1/2 sandwich and soup combo is ideal because you can pick from one of their Classic sandwiches (all you need is a half because they put so much meat in them) and you can get some soup. For only $12!! Their rye bread is phenomenal (but then again...any of their fresh breads are great).I haven't gotten dessert yet but their pastries look delectable. Definitely a must try next time i go.

Reviews.Author: Karen H.
Reviews.Content: I have been here several times and have always found the experience to be underwhelming. My boyfriend, not a local, had a craving for lox this weekend and read online that Canter's has the best, so we drove from the valley.The parking lot was jammed, with cars piled up waiting for a spot. We bypassed the headache and parked in a two hour zone a few blocks away. I have no clue why so many people insist on waiting for a spot in the lot.Although the lot was packed, there was plenty of seating in the massive restaurant.We shared two items- The little New Yorker (bagel with cream cheese and lox) and a waffle (Best in LA winner). The food was good, but nothing outstanding. Like most deli's, the items are very overpriced. I definitely don't think that the prices match the quality or quantity of the food.The best thing about Canter's is our server. He was so nice and ridiculously competent. He even refilled my boyfriend's latte with regular coffee. We really liked him and wish that we had gotten his name to write a nice letter- older man, working in the back room on Sunday around noon? Anyhow, really a gem. All of the staff that we encountered at Canters was top notch and this makes me a bit more forgiving about the prices/food.I love that this place has so much History. It's worth a visit.

Reviews.Author: Scott S.
Reviews.Content: This is one of the must eat at restaurants in L.A. The atmosphere, the food, the people that frequent this restaurant are each an experience onto itself. For seating, make sure you sit in the main room, not the one off to the side. The experience is just not as complete when they stick you over there. For food, I recommended the matzo ball soup, the kasha knish, the pastrami sandwich, and their chocolate milk shakes. Their coffee is good too.Recommended !!!

Reviews.Author: Justin C.
Reviews.Content: I like the food here, but I have to say, customer service has taken a nosedive in the last several months. They have some new waitresses now who are not nearly as "on it" as past waitresses.  But, I still like the food. :)

Reviews.Author: Gina M.
Reviews.Content: Delicious food & sinful bakery, I want to go back often just to try all the options they have.  Matzo ball soup was a good starter, panini & sweet potato fries were great.  Got a mini black & white cookie to top it off!  Loved it, & our server was super sweet - gave me some hot water with lemon & honey when I said I had a sore throat.  A little more expensive for a deli, but luckily the portions are so big that I took half home anyway.

Reviews.Author: Geraldine N.
Reviews.Content: Not my favorite. I'm having a hard time liking their sandwiches. The bread are so hard and meat is too dry. The chili is very salty!Although this is a Los Angeles's historic favorite, I'm not a fan. Food is pricey and nothing is out of the ordinary.Very plain non memorable diner food.My coffee was watered down and waitress never came by to see if I wanted a refill.

Reviews.Author: Jim W.
Reviews.Content: Well now that @Yelp and @foursquare say I'm a "regular" @cantersdeli I should write a review.  Before this I guess I was "Irregular" or maybe "sporadic".Canter's has a great feel - totally LA and totally old school deli at the same time.  The decor is very dated and yet just right.Now that I've been a number of times (apparently I like it...and also they are open late which is when I sometimes drop in) I have noticed some inconsistencies.  The service is faster and oddly the portions are larger during the early evening than late at night. By late I mean 10pm or beyond.Local industry guy @lonhaber once told me that Canter's is where people go to be seen, Langer's is where they go to eat.  I will say that Langer's does have the edge as far as the food but Canter's is very good and also has...parking, late hours, hipper neighborhood, live music drop ins at the lounge...oh and I have spotted some mid-level celebs and such around if that does anything for you.

Reviews.Author: Anthony N.
Reviews.Content: When you're drunk you don't give a rat's ass where or what you shove in your mouth, okay? *gives you the knowing eye* ummhuh..My friend lives across the street, literally less than 200 feet away.  We were watching movies, gushing about boys, and life and ended up getting super drunk and hungry at like 4 in the morning.  It just made sense to go here because its 24 hours and I didn't want to drive.Pastrami on ryeCheese friesDone!Argh now I feel like a whale!The pastrami was good, but It felt lackluster.  Overall the bread was dry like a lady going through "the changes".  It lacked any wow factor but it was good considering.Cheese fries were big crispy steak fries with the cheddar cheese just melted over it.  It was good in the beginning, but then the cheese started to solidify and get gelatinous and hard to swallow.  *I don't swallow...sorry*Solid drunk food.  I shoulda just got dessert but it was definitely what the doctor ordered to avoid a hangover in the morning.

Reviews.Author: Mike J.
Reviews.Content: After craving a pastrami sandwich all day, I made the drive over to Canters. The Canters Fairfax signature sandwich, pastrami & corned beef stacked high on rye, was everything I wanted. It wasn't quite a heaping behemoth you'd find at Carnegie Deli, but just as delicious. Don't come here if you are planning to eat a salad, but if you want a savory deli sandwich chased with a slice of strawberry cheesecake, Canters gets it right.

Reviews.Author: Katie B.
Reviews.Content: I have to say I sauntered into Canter's in a terrible mood. I secretly (or not so secretly) wanted to shake some booty at the Dime across the street, but was forced into the calmness of a booth by my friends who weren't in the same mindspace. I started the night off staring sullenly at the table while I sipped on a beer and, quite frankly, played the Negative Nancy part in the group.However, everything turned around once the waiter brought out a mountain of fresh, hot, golden onion rings. These crispy suckers turned my frown right upside down. I dug right into that oniony goodness and my night was complete. And to put a cherry on this good mood sundae, the man at the front counter took a moment out of his busy night to compliment me on my outfit. This place knows the way to a girl's heart!

Reviews.Author: Hazel Q.
Reviews.Content: The combination of a somewhat inebriated Hazel Q and the behemoth of a menu at Canter's is never a good combo. I just stare and stare and stare. After a awhile I think I forget that I'm even supposed to pick something, and I try to stare through it like it's a Magic Eye thing and suddenly the right answer will pop out at me like a schooner. Alas, after the waiter's third visit to the table, and no magical 3D answers popping out of the menu, I'm forced to pick something on the fly - and that thing is always, ALWAYS, potato pancakes with sour cream. And they always satisfy... along with a few bites from someone else's pastrami sandwich and the order envy I immediately suffer. Sure, the potato pancakes are carby deliciousness, but that pastrami... oh... that pastrami. It's so effin' perfect, it's criminal. Of course, what really makes Canter's Canter's is that it's open 24 glorious hours a day. And you can be drunk, and loud, and laughing, and in your pajamas - and nobody will bat an eye... magic or otherwise.

Reviews.Author: Christina P.
Reviews.Content: The late night food selection in LA is for the most part pretty pathetic. I can't even remember how many times I found myself at a Denny's or Norm's at 3am wondering why I was eating a dish I would never think to order sober while sitting in a depressingly sterile space. I like Canter's because it obviously caters to a drunk crowd looking for a nosh post-bar but it still has a lot of character and yummy selections. After perusing the ginormous menu for a long time, I settled on the potato pancakes last night. You can choose a side of apple sauce or sour cream but of course I went with both and was not disappointed. I liked the flavor but I didn't think it seemed super fresh and piping hot. Those who got Canter's famous pastrami sandwiches seemed very pleased with their selections, especially the warm chips, although we were told that they're not homemade as we thought. The late night service was very friendly and efficient, though it did take a little while for our stuff to come out. The guy at the cash register up front was very chatty and cool as well, and even complimented my dining date Katie B on her lovely pink onesie pajamas. It's a comfy and cool place to go when you're starving and don't want the night to end yet!

Reviews.Author: Sonya Z.
Reviews.Content: For a person of certain tastes, Canter's is a beautiful thing. If you don't harbor somewhere in your subconscious an undying love for the classic middle-class American family diner / the retro diner vibe of old-school LA when it was all glitzy dirty & glam, then Canter's is not for you.Canter's is open 24/7 and has it's own humongous parking lot. The place itself is huge, with two dining areas and a small bar attached. You can come here at any time of night and satisfy your need for a hearty Turkey Reuben or a pastrami sandwich or onion rings or a dessert panini or a slice of carrot cake or a banana split or a root beer float etc. etc. etc. etc. [insert diner foods here] [insert delicatessen foods here] [Canter's has it all and they have it 24/7].Canter's is like Denny's (because of the "place to sit down and eat when intoxicated late at night" factor), but on steroids and AT LEAST 10x more cool. People watching here is the best. Shout out to the girl last night with two snakebite hoop piercings and a SLIPKNOT jacket, as well as the next girl who sat down and who looked eerily similar Dita von Teese. The lighting is fluorescent, which I think is perfectly fitting for a place that caters so well to the post-midnight crowd. Things are already weird at night, why not make them a little weirder?Vincent, you are a great server and I commend you.

Reviews.Author: Mary C.
Reviews.Content: You need to know three things about this girl:1.) I don't like pastrami2.) I don't like rye bread3.) I don't like when Karey R. thinks I'm a schmuck**So after having a blasty blast in our PJs, Karey R., Cecilia C., Vannessa R. and I went to Canter's to wash away thoughts of fried crickets. I perused the menu, and was a little overwhelmed since there were lots of choices. I asked my seasoned Canter's eater, Karey R., what she was going to get and she replied, "Pastrami... That IS why you come to Canter's." I looked at the pastrami sandwich that was served on rye bread, and then I looked at Karey R. who had visions of schmucks dancing in her head. Pastrami it is.Count this girl as anything but a schmuck. SO GOOD. Meat-filled sandwiches "melting in your mouth" never really made sense until now, and whoever created rye bread created it for one purpose and one purpose only, pastrami! There were like four bottles of different mustard to choose from, but once I started with the regular deli mustard I had no time to bother with anything else! When you go to Canter's don't be a schmuck. **See Karey R.'s review: yelp.com/biz/canters-del…. To my knowledge, she has never actually thought I was a schmuck.

Reviews.Author: Anna M.
Reviews.Content: Canter's. You surely can't meet a Jew from Los Angeles that has not dined at Canter's (or at the very least scarfed down chunks of Canter's challah or a few of Canter's cookies). Until this weekend, my mom had not tried Canter's and feeling like the last Jew within 50 miles to not have, she made me take her into the orange-tabled cafeteria oozing with old people. Yes, old people. Everything about Canter's says OLD. Anyway, I ordered the matzah ball soup to wrap myself up in the warm, strong grip of Jewish cooking. Solid work. My ancestors would agree, I'm sure. The $13 Rueben I split with Mommy was okay. The pastrami could have been juicier for that scorching price, to be honest. Nicely toasted rye bread and sauerkraut to boot. I love the complimentary pickles. However, you can't live on pickles alone, friend. Where Canter's does score points with me is:1. Their bakery2. Their serviceThe challah is fresh like the Prince of Bel Air, the black and white cookies with ganache make me drool, and I'm looking forward to trying the cheesecake Katrina M. raves about. Everyone at Canter's is cheery and helpful. While Canter's has aged to the point of needing a walker, it has kept its personal charm. If you enjoy historic locations, visit Canter's at least once. 60 years, baby. For new school Jewish deli: see Brent's in Northridge.

Reviews.Author: Lucy Y.
Reviews.Content: I came here tonight for a late night, post Yelp party food fix with Ciara G, Mary C and Hugo C.  It was surprising that at close to midnight, the parking lot had barely a space available - and most of the tables inside were filled.We were still seated immediately, and our no-nonsense server Maria was quick and all business with drinks, menus, and our food.I got a side of roast beef (the amount that comes on a sammich), and a side of coleslaw for $12.75.  Um, yes deli food is a little pricey.I was angling for a side of chopped liver too, but after I found out it would be $11.75 - I passed.  That's a lot for a side of anything!I love deli food, but since the roast beef wasn't anywhere near rare (which is my preference) - even though usually deli roast beef IS rare, and the prices for my sides were on the high side, I'm not super excited about returning.

Reviews.Author: Mimi L.
Reviews.Content: I love old school deli's! I love the food and the feel of the place. Canter's is old. Like fossilized old school deli that makes delicious sandwiches. Came here on another nice day in LA for lunch and decided on Canters just because we found a great parking spot. Parking is a pain in that area. So, when you do find a spot, make a day out of it or just a lunch date like myself. The place was semi crowded and we were seated within minutes. I flipped open the menu only to see and extensive list of things that I wanted to order. Being the conscious eater that I am, I ordered the corned beef and pastrami with a side of cole slaw. The corned beef and pastrami was very juicy and wasn't overly greasy. The sandwich tasted a lot better once I topped off the sandwich with a layer of cole slaw. Delish! Pastrami, corned beef, cole slaw, and a pickle. That's food made for a champion.

Reviews.Author: Barry W.
Reviews.Content: *** I've been under the weather so I stop by matzah ball soup. ***Soup was excellent ... broth delicious ... good textured matzah ball.So that made me feel a lot better ... probably just psychological? ;pMy pastrami reuben was just awight ... and service was nonchalant.Total bill: $21.06 ... pricey maybe but portions HUGE (2 meals in 1).*** Canter's is an LA icon.  I'll ret'n, tho there is room to improve. ***

Reviews.Author: Mike L.
Reviews.Content: My boy Fran D. hits it on the head. I don't get this place either.However I do need to make an apology to the establishment.The place as much as it had that old NY's style deli look... to be fair and honest, it reminded me of my local coffee shop. There's not much of a difference except for the hype and unnecessary nostalgia for this place. It only gets the weird characters out at night to make a real difference.You can get anything here that you can get at Denny's anyways. Not much of a big difference for me. I don't get the cultural phenomenon or the historical significance of this place at all. Personally I think the food is nasty. The service is not bad, but overall the food was a total pit. The French toast I got was soggy and the egg was almost inedible.Our man in the table Tony T. took a bite of each and decided he had enough. Plus the Chicken noodle soup was very bland.Even though the food was not good, I should have been more classier than this. Once we walked out of the place, I  redeposited the food in front of the place.That I do need to apologize. It was midnight and I just had a few drinks too many.
