However your food just didn't sit well in my stomach. I just can't stopped it. So sorry!Big props to Tony T. and Lisa V. to make sure I got home OK after this experience.

Reviews.Author: Kevin B.
Reviews.Content: A friend and I were heading to Beverly Hills for a play and my friend suggests Canter's for dinner.   I've heard of Canters over the years, but had never been.   My friend knew it well as he's been many times over the last 35 years.THE FOOD:  OY... such an extensive menu!   So many things look so good, but what do I try.... one of the 10 different soups or 15 different salads or 30+ sandwich or 20 dinner entrees?   I repeat... OY!I decided to go for a sandwich, but which one?   Since I'm in a authentic New York style deli I'd better try what deli's are known for corned beef, pastrami, right?     I choose pastrami on sourdough bread instead of the traditional rye... which I later discovered was a mistake.   My friend chose a sandwich with pastrami and chopped liver (eek!) but said it was very good.   Our food arrived very, VERY quickly!   My sandwich was a large stack of pastrami on plain dry bread.   Though I'd swear the bread was of the cheap plain white sandwich variety rather then sourdough, I was dissapointed, but hey that was my choice.   Otherwise the pastrami was very, VERY tasty!BEVERAGES:  My friend asked our server "Do you still carry Dr Browns?Server: Yes we do.Friend: Do you have the Cel-Ray soda?Server: Yessir.Friend: That's what I'll have.  Last time I had one was about 20 years ago!Me: Cel-Ray.. what's that?Friend: It's celery flavored soda.Me: Celery flavored...wait... WHAT??    What the hell???Friend: Its good, you want one?Me: Um, not sure....Server: One Cel-Ray and I'll bring a small glass and you can try some of his..Me:  (still a little unsure) OK that will work.The beverages arrive and my friend pours some of his Cel-Ray from the bottle into the small glass.   I take a sip and....... Oh Wow! (this is bizzare)...... WOW (a familier flavor, but a little sweet)......... I take another sip and... WOW (in a fizzy liquid form)... OMG WOW!!!!!!    I am COMPLETELY blown away by this!   A celery flavored soda... yet bizzare as it sounds, was surprisingly good!   I take a few more sips and can't stop saying  'WOW" as my friend laughs.   Our server is standing there this whole time and I say "OK, I'll have one too!"   I couldn't believe it, a new flavor sensation I have never had or even heard of before!   It was quite the surprise!   WOW!  yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…SERVICE:   Our server was an older gentleman with gray hair, but very nice, very polite, very attentive and very "old school" if you will.   By old school, I mean I suspect this is the type of service you would get 30 - 40 years ago and that was a good thing!   I was very pleased!OVERALL: Execpt for my bread choice mistake, my first time at Canter's Deli was a great experience!   The food, the service, the feeling you're in a place where the people really care about their customers.   I will be back!

Reviews.Author: Squinka C.
Reviews.Content: Kasha Knish. If you don't know, well, hereen.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kn…but really if you haven't eaten one, you will have no idea why every once in a while I NEED one the same way every once in a while I need an egg cream that, yes children can only be made with Fox's U-Bet Chocolate Syrup and all I can tell you is that no one at Canter's would need any of this explained to them. A nice Jewish deli that has been in the business of quelling deli cravings of the chosen and the goyem, like me, who once in a while must be kosher fed. I am not Jewish, but I grew up near Miami Beach and I know the real deal delis and Canter's is not only real, but because it's open 24 HOURS and it's in L.A. can in addition to serving up good deli food, be certified as surreal.The additional dish at our table - and I can't, if I want to keep my ellay friends, completely decode it for you- may have included personal tidbits, including possibly illegal propositions overheard from, photos shown at our table taken by personal photographers, and amazing deals turned down offered from-Van Halen, Jerry Lee Lewis, David Lee Roth, Neil Young, and Tom Waits. And that was all before my knish even came to the table. We also witnessed what I later learned was the nightly visitation -at his very own booth- of a kinda famous, kinda strange, 1960s DJ dude, Rodney Bingenheimer. At a certain point, the food -solidly good deli fare- and the service- inconsistent, but overall adequate- seemed beside the point, as I listened to all the people at our table who all seemed to be living by their wits, as they manage to at once both fend off and work with the artists they were photographing, designing or otherwise framin to look good, and at the same time do nothing short of skywalkin downdirty bloody battle with those same artist's agents, managers and producers. For the most part, however, they all seemed -as they talked about last minute custom stagelights, nasty personal requests, a spotlit song sung secretly just for them, narrowly avoided stagecenter catastrophes, and managers parading as the poorhouse rep at paytime- well, they all seemed uh happy. Like they were doing what they loved.So when I couldn't find our waiter and I asked another server could he bring me some gravy- for my knish, people!- and he snapped "I am VERY busy, you'll have to find YOUR waiter.", I just kinda relaxed back into the surreal swirl of our tabletalk. I figured the real might catch up with me soon enough, and it did. One of the guys at our table used to work at Canter's - ten years ago - he flagged our guy- and my knish was christened with glorious deli gravy.Once the bill was handled- VERY reasonable prices, we headed up to the front. Pastries and pastrami was purchased at the counter by some of the girls in our group and we watched as a couple lookin to be in their 80s sauntered in dressed to fine-deli-dine. The way they were greeted let you know they'd done this gig before. This joint easily holds the sordid and sacred secrets of a few life cycles. We pushed open the door and went out onto the street. Business cards were exchanged. Codes would be honored. sorry but even with all the glory, minus one star for a waiter point blank telling me he's just too busy to even deliver a request. It's your JOB bozo. burn the apron and buy some clown shoes. still 4 solidly shining stars for realdeal deli food 24 hours in a funkycool neighborhood at a place that holds -and still creates- some Hollywood history.

Reviews.Author: Diana H.
Reviews.Content: Oh Canter's.  I am sorry I can't give you more than 3 stars, but I have a few minor (pastrami) beefs with you that force me to reign in my desire to bless you with a higher rating.  It hurts me as much as it hurts you, because I do very much love your chocolatey delicious Rugalach, with it's glorious amount of mini chocolate chips.  However do you get them to stay on the top without falling off??  Do you apply some kind of glue to keep them in place, that also doubles as some sort of addicting substance that forces me to eat two Rugalachs in a sitting when I very well know that I could be fine with just one?  It's all very perplexing... but in a good way.  It is really too bad that you irk me in other not so good ways...1. I don't like deli sandwiches made with dry-ish bread and slab after slab after slab after slab of meat.  Biting into a thick cookie = Lovely.  Biting into inches of meat = Disgusting.2. Sticky.  As in everything about you is sticky. 3.  I adore your thick and crusty Belgian waffle, but I don't adore that I can't get anything fruity to go with it!  I like some berry in the nooks and crannies of my waffles!  Yes, I suppose if I really want some extravagant breakfast sweet I should head over to the Griddle, but I do sort of enjoy complaining, even if it is... fruitless.  Haha.  Oh Diana H., you do crack me up!4.  You want me to pay how much?  Uhhhh.... no.  You may think you can trick other patrons into spending $15 on an omelet because they are drunk, hungry, and oblivious to anything other than getting grease in their swirling tums o' booze, but I am no drunkard, and I am not numb to your exorbitant prices.   Shame on you!5. I don't have a 5 that I can think of at the moment, but I think a list should have at least 5 items.  I suppose I could say something about the grouchiness, but I'm kind of a grouch sometimes too, so I don't take offense to a few well-placed/deserved sneers.So Canters, I do love you for your Rugalachs and waffles, and even enjoy your receipts with the stars, but my love can only extend so far.  You can sneer at me if you like.  I won't mind.  I might even sneer back a little.  I do enjoy a good nasty look from time to time.

Reviews.Author: Pavel D.
Reviews.Content: I wind up at Canters about once, maybe twice a year.  And every time I say that is the last time.  And just like Al Pacino in the kitchen scene in Godfather 3, they (or, in my case, something) pull me back in.It certainly is not the food.As with Damiano "Mr. Pizza" across the street, the list of the good - --Canters is a trusty 24-hour operation in a town without much competition, ever so unfortunately.--It has a decent matzo ball soup - served with bagel chips - that, while served 24 hours, is more often lukewarm rather than hot.--It is open 24 hours a day.See a trend developing?  Get your star sticker and paste it on your Pee-Chee folder, because the only thing that is a credit to this place is its operating hours.  Because West of KoreaTown, just how many places are open at 4 in the morning other than a McDonald's or Jack-in-the-Box drive-through?  Not many and, almost, not any.Canters has certainly become a Los Angeles tradition, and for that alone gets some sort of props.  All kinds eat here - young and old, rich and poor, music lovers from across all charts, Jewish and goyim - and everyone seems to pretty much have good things to say (especially if you ask them at 2.30AM).But ask all those Canters lovers about the actual food served there, and you will probably get a very different response.Starting with the bakery, which is right by the entrance and across from the deli counter - the baked "goods" are stale, stale, stale.  Long ago, I used to just walk in and grab a pastry or two when walking along Fairfax, and as much as the ladies behind the counter would claim that they were baked that morning - no way in hell, even if Jews don't believe in it - they were always crusty and stale.  You may ask why I would still buy them.  Well, sometimes, one just needs a little sugar snack while walking along.  The bread may be fresher, I do not know, but stay away from any pastry you may encounter behind the glass, no matter how good it looks.There is a certain charm to the place, charm about the ambiance and about the interior furnishings.  Stuck in 1961 charm.   Everything is stuck - the waitresses are struck, the coffee is stuck, the upstairs bathrooms are stuck - all in this limbo of mediocrity.  The last time I was here, our waiter was no more than 30.  THAT was something.  Progress.  Then he would disappear for 20+ minutes at a stretch, and then it felt just like the same 'ole Canters.Seriously, it is unfortunate that there is not more choice for late night food in the area and (if you think Swinger's is better, you are only barely, barely correct).      So, go here ONLY because there is nowhere else to go. Never buy anything from the bakery.  And only utilize this place for its real purpose in this town - not for the "food" they serve, but to meet and greet and look at the most interesting cross-section of characters that call the great Los Angeles home.UPDATE - Thanksgiving Weekend, 2007 - Downgraded to a One Star Establishment.  Yes, it was/is that bad.  Truly.P.S.  This does not have much to do with Canters, but it goes here, nevertheless.  Slightly out of context.  Thank you, Robert Towne.  Written, circa 1972.  Pertinent, forever.--Get out of here, or else I'll call the shore patrol!--I am the motherfucking shore patrol, motherfucker! I am the motherfucking shore patrol! Give this man a beer. --I don't want a beer.--You're gonna have a fuckin' beer!

Reviews.Author: Eyal D.
Reviews.Content: Canter's Deli is a well-known restaurant in Los Angeles that has been around since the 1930's. It's appeal tends to be a huge menu and 24 hour service, which allows people to come after going clubbing.We came in for a dinner. The place feels old, and not so appealing.  We took a seat at a booth, and began perusing the enormous menu. We placed the order and awaited the food.If you love fast food type food that has been sitting all day, then microwaved upon your arrival, then Canter's is your place! The soup tasted like it was instant soup, just broth. The Matzoh ball was huge, cold, and was definitely made from an store-bought mix. It was horrible. The brisket was tough and dry. The "vegetables" side was canned corn that was warmed up. Oy vay, it was horrible.Perhaps Canter's is more a place for sandwiches and not any hot dish.  The service left much to be desired too. On the way out we did check out their bakery, and took a couple of pastries that were pretty good.Will we be back? Not any time soon.Bakery Rating is 3.5Restaurant Rating is 2.

Reviews.Author: Selena L.
Reviews.Content: If you're the sort of person who looks forward to being a senior citizen, gumming down heartburn-inducing pastrami sandwiches and guzzling free coffee refills, then have I got the place for you! Canter's is where you want to spend your tarnished golden years, chomping on dill pickles & eating soggy confetti coleslaw. Will the potato pancakes thrill you and remind you why youth is wasted on the young? Nah, but order some as an appetizer to share with friends anyway. Located on a fairly hip stretch of Fairfax, Canter's is ideal for people watching & lingering over a rapidly cooling mug of Lipton tea.Me, I'm looking forward to death so I can haunt a better place: your nightmares.

Reviews.Author: Sarah A.
Reviews.Content: After seeing Wu-Tang in concert at the nearby Club Nokia, I was surprised to learn that Minh has never ever been to Canter's. Say waaaa!! Okay, we have to go and you have to try this place out! Parking on the weekends is hard, there is the parking lot next to the restaurant that charges you, street parking is horrible due to the other restaurants and bars. Parking in the neighborhood is a much better idea just get ready to walk a little. We were able to find some street parking off Rosewood Avenue and just walked across the street. I'm was hoping there wasn't going to be a wait since it was after 12ish and I know the bars would be letting out soon. To my surprise when we walked in there was not a wait for a table. The host asked us if we would like to sit in the bar area and listen to the band that was playing or if we wanted to sit in the dining room area. We both said dining room area please! Our server came by not long after to take our drink order.  It has been awhile since I have been here and I totally forgot how overwhelming their menu is! You have you typical Jewish bubby cooking:-corned beef sandwich-Matzo ball soup-Mishmosh (matzo ball soup with kreplach, rice, and noodles)-Lox and cream cheese (yummy, I can eat a barrel of it and be happy)-Chopped liver and onions-Potato Pancakes-Kasha Knish-Noodle Kugel (my dad's mom still makes a bomb sweet kugel with raisins)In addition, you got your old stand by's that any delicatessen has:-Grilled Cheese-Fish-Burgers-Salads-Chicken-Steak-Meat LoafAnd the list goes on and on......When the waiter came back to take our order I had a hard time trying to decided on what to order (the prices were what got to me.. yikes!)After the shock, I ordered the Pita: Smoked turkey, Humus, Cucumber salad, Tomato, Lettus, Muenster cheese. I was suppose to order a side of onion rings but for some reason my mouth said fries with a side of ranch please. Rawr!Make sure before your waiter (or waitress) leaves you table to ask for pickles; otherwise, they will not bring them. And friends of Yelp you do not want to miss out on these crunchy treats!My pita was really good, a bit messy (I bit into it and half of the insides came spilling out), and totally filling. You will be taking the left over's home with you!  The fries were your typical steak cut fries you can buy in any supermarket. They do give you a lot, which is great to share! Our waiter came around often to make sure everything was going well and to refill our water glasses.The only thing I wasn't to impressed with is their bakery section, maybe it's because I'm spoiled and I have Katella Bakery and I'm use to their larger selection but for some reason Canter's bakery didn't make me break out my wallet. Canter's is the best if you are in LA and wanting some good New York style Jewish comfort food!

Reviews.Author: Tricia H.
Reviews.Content: Great pastrami!  Hot sandwiches, pastrami Reuben and the hot dip!  From Louisiana...used to Cajun food, but this was the best!

Reviews.Author: Maria T.
Reviews.Content: The following review was written by my boyfriend in my "voice", making fun of me and my yelptastic ways as we were sitting in Canter's together at 5am.  Enjoy :)Firemen (so hot), police men (no comment), teachers, doctors, soldiers - Things we normally associate with heroism.I'm excited to report that this morning I was pleasantly surprised by the most uncommon of heroes.Stranded in the concrete jungle of LA, finding myself inhumanely awake at 430am and STARVING, I fought through blackberry's crap internet experience to find the only thing open at this hour was Canter's Deli in West Los Angeles. Much to the chagrin of my "date", we made the brave move of putting ourselves in the position of having to drive back west in rush hour traffic. Said "date" only whined 72 times on the way to the joint, and 23 times during his first cup of coffee.Okay, so you get the picture. I'm a damsel in distress. The only thing that could rescue me at this point?  Canter's potato cakes - the recipe for which I'm beginning to suspect was written on the same tablets God gave to Moses so many years ago.  This tightly guarded secret, known only to the faithful patrons of this always-open diner, were more than good.  They were my "bread of life" - my hero.(Blah blah blah observations about the ingredients/adjectives for the food, the waitstaff, etc, etc...)From the cheery, eccentric waiter to sitting at the counter side by side, to the bizare "fall leaves" ceiling tile that requires an LSD tab to fully appreciate...Canter's is, if not worth the drive going back in traffic, a totally great "experience".  Even whiny/grumpy "date" was smiling by the end...

Reviews.Author: Sarah F.
Reviews.Content: Ok, so, I never feel like going here, being that I'm not usually in that neck o' the woods, but oy vey! Love the pickles. And the matzo ball soup is simply lovely. And I LOVE LOVE LOVE looking up at that crazy ceiling! It's like, leaves? Or some sort of art deco stained glass? Anyway...Nothing compares to their macaroons. I buy them by the dozen. And then some.

Reviews.Author: Gretchen L.
Reviews.Content: Pastrami amazing- corned beef awesome- service stupendous!!! We had the lovely Anna serve us a perfect lunch. Best spot in the area hands down!!

Reviews.Author: Risa Y.
Reviews.Content: This place is ok... but after going to Katz Deli in NYC, this place can't even compare... even tho the price is about the same.We ordered a Pastrami Sandwich and a Philly Cheese steak (This was what we ordered at Katz Deli... we were subconsciously ordering the same thing to compare with Katz)  Their Philly Cheese steak was better than Katz.  The "steak" tasted SO good... I just wish it wasn't so expensive!Pastrami sandwich was pretty good too. It was definitely tasty but not $15 tasty.I may come back here again if I crave a good phillycheese steak since it is so close to my bf's house.  But I'll have to remember that this place is PRICEY!!

Reviews.Author: Libby R.
Reviews.Content: The whole point of deli food is great quality, not so expensive.  Well, I'm sorry to say that I think Canter's is Yiddish for "not so great, over priced food."Look, I'm not cheap.  I drop mad dollahs for the grub plenty.  But if I'm going blow some bucks, it had better be on something worth it, and I'm sorry to say, even with the whole "open 24 hours" thing, this place is so not worth it.I ordered the Dave Thomas.  Hot Salami on rye, coleslaw, and a pickle.  Even the pickle was meh.  And for the not so low price of over $10.  For a salami sandwich?  Hell the salami wasn't even premium!!  I even helped my sister finish off her bagel and lox.  $15 for a ho hum piece of smoked fish?I suppose some would argue that this place is a staple and historic and blah blah blah...Bottom line is, if you are in the mood for over priced deli food at all hours of the night, at least the other option around town has food that actually tastes good.

Reviews.Author: ericka L.
Reviews.Content: UPDATE: 6/29/07So a group of drunken, unruly Yelpers came here last night after the Elite event. We hogged up two huge tables and were loud and obnoxious. (Pffft, like that's breaking news.)Our server was the adorable Spencer, who was my waiter last time I came in, and he claimed to remember me. I told him in a vague way about Yelp and he snapped to attention, working hard to make us love the Canter's.He was apologetic about our wait for food, as the kitchen was backed up; he didn't flinch when Sumit* knocked a cup of coffee off the table, onto EJ's lap and then shattering onto the floor; he didn't charge us the 15% service charge even though we had more than 8 people in our party. Plus, if I didn't mention it before, he's really cute.So okay, Canter's gets an extra star. I still say get the chicken noodle soup with kreplach, though; stay away from the brekky plates!* And by Sumit, I mean me. Sorry about your burnt crotch, EJ.************************************I love Canter's, but I can't in good conscience give the place more than three stars.The service is consistently TERRIBLE. The food is certainly not cheap. The cashiers are surly, at best, and flat-out rude, at worst.BUT. The chicken kreplach soup with noodles is the best damn cure for the flu, the blues, and the what-have-yous this side of Mom's kitchen.Plus, open 24 hours? I'm so down with that.An LA institution in my book...I keep coming back for more.

Reviews.Author: Eli G.
Reviews.Content: I can't believe it took me seven years living in LA to finally come to Canter's. I guess I don't love pastrami as much as I thought I did. Came with the wife and my parents for some nice deli food and that's exactly what we got. First up were the mildly pickled pickles, perfect for my palate. yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…Yuko and my mom shared a softball sized matzo ball that was surprisingly delicious. The matzo wasn't too heavy and the broth was very refreshing on a cool day. yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…We all shared a plate of latkas that were just right in my opinion. They were hot, crisp, and went perfect with the apple sauce and sour cream. yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…Next was another softball sized offering, this time though it was cabbage wrapped meat. The meat made me want to order either a meatloaf sandwich or a side of meatballs just to have more of that mix.yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…For my main, I had a combo of liverwurst and hot pastrami and it was great! The insane amount of liver was a bit much but it did make for great leftovers for crackers. The pastrami was perfectly seasoned and on the money, way better than anything from The Hat or Jonnie's. yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…And to finish it off, we ordered about three hospital stays of desserts at the bakery for about $20, amazing deals. As far as LA delis/pastrami spots go, I give the crown to Canter's.

Reviews.Author: Love C.
Reviews.Content: Ick. Cool for all the history and all that stuff... but I sat down and ordered what I thought would be nice warm biscuits and gravy... instead, I got a half frozen biscuit and cold clumpy gravy.  Gave it back, left and haven't returned since.

Reviews.Author: Minh D.
Reviews.Content: I hear about this good things about this place. Some Los Angelenos I've met say their pastrami is comparable to Katz's Deli in NYC. "Really?" I would say. I've been to Katz's and it rocks! Let's try this place out with Sarah one late night.Parking sucks of course, you gotta find street parking. But the place is big, you can choose the loud section with live music or the quiet side. I just wanted to eat in peace that night. We got seated fairly quickly at a booth.The place looks old school, of course since it's been a landmark here forever. The menu selection is vast like in most Jewish delicatessens.I ordered the Bronx Special and a Chocolate Egg Cream.I like liver, so the Bronx Special was right up my alley. The finely chopped liver was pate-like. Thick slices of pastrami stack in between. It was full of great flavor. It came with a potato salad or cole slaw on the side. Very filling plate of food. The egg cream was sweet and delicious if you like egg creams in general.The bathroom upstairs is quite a walk, it's like walking through an exhibit at a museum.Overall the food was great and being open 24 hours is convenient for night owls. But it's not quite Katz's Deli quality, that's tough to beat.

Reviews.Author: Stephy S.
Reviews.Content: Awwwhhh Canter's.This place has been a fave of mine since I was a wee little. Not that my parents used to take me here, but because all of my dad's stories seemed to include a Canter's reference. You see, back in the day when he was a gold cadillac, purple suit wearing (And no, he wasn't a pimp) ad agency cat, he used to come here on his lunch hours with clients and they'd throw back drinks and pastramis on rye and laugh and laugh and laugh. So when I finally was old enough to leave the boundaries of the Valley, it was a must try for me.Through the years this place has served me well. Well, service here is a whole other story, but it's taken care of me. So a few thanks are necessary for my good buddy Canters....Thanks for the many grilled cheese and avocado sammiches you've served me at 3am when I was drunk off my arse and could barely read the damn menu.Thanks for the warm pastramis on ryeThanks for the Reubens, oh Reuben, I heart you soThanks for the endless supply of sassy, impatient blue hairs that seem to work around the clock to serve my dumb ass. (Do you think they just have a whole secret room upstairs with cots?)Thanks for the adjacent Kibbitz Room and for filling me with cheap cheap drinks so I'll stumble towards the Jello and into your restaurantThanks for those acid trip ceilings. I mean really, what is going on there? I'll never know, but it's charm galoreThanks for all of the idiot drunk people I've run into here and for all the lines I've received like, "If I give you a quarter will you make out with me?" and who can forget the time my BFF and I went here and got this one, "Hi" "Hello" "How was your night?""I'm a producer."Oy, I love you Canters :)

Reviews.Author: Ariane R.
Reviews.Content: I bet my girlfriend $1,000 that there was NO WAY this supposedly Jewish restaurant served bacon.Lucky me, she didn't take me up on that bet, or I would be $1,000 poorer.How the holy hell can you call yourself a Jewish deli and serve pork????

Reviews.Author: Matthew T.
Reviews.Content: I've been wanting to come here for so long and even more so when I caught a late night episode of Entourage where the guys were eating here.I should preface I came here after eating at The Golden State across the street so maybe I was operating at 50% stomach capacity.Anyway, we had the 1/2 sandwich and soup combo for about $12:Matzo Ball Soup - I've never had Matzo Ball Soup so I guess I was expecting a lot more seeing as people really love it. It tasted a lot like canned chicken noodle but at least the bagel chips were good. Pastrami sandwich - This wasn't a bad pastrami sandwich at all. I like that it was simple rye bread and sliced meat. Still, it didn't blow me away and was pretty standard pastrami sandwich all things considered. I still ate all the food so it wasn't like it was terrible but just not what I was expecting from this famous deli. It definitely felt historic and being open 24/7 is great for that area but that being said it was just okay for me.

Reviews.Author: Kai L.
Reviews.Content: I like how you can come to Canter's to buy something right from the deli and leave, or enjoy food in their sit-down restaurant. There's a dedicated parking lot a couple of hundred feet away from the entrance, so you don't really need to park right on Fairfax.Their pastries and other sweets are wonderful; I had a couple of eclairs (I really shouldn't have, but whatev) at the deli before actually sitting down to eat their corned beef and cabbage dish.Visually, CB&C at first glance seems kind of amusing, because here's this pinkish slab of beef, next to half a head of boiled cabbage, but it tastes good, so it works.Prices are low to moderate, so you can conceivably eat here several times a week without seriously damaging your vast portfolio of real estate holdings (*cough* your paycheck to paycheck bank account *cough*) Honestly, buying things from their deli is much more expensive than buying from a large chain grocery store, but there are lots of unique choices available at Canter's to make it worth your while, and worth the cost if you don't break the bank there every single day.The wait staff are attentive enough, and on your way out you can even buy some Canter's souvenirs, like a Tshirt -- sorry, seems like they only have size "Large" whenever you ask. But maybe they only stock the large because they assume you'll be so hooked on their charm, food, and service that you'll be there all the time.Hey, they're open 24/7, so why not? Don't try setting up a bed in their dining room however, it would just be awkward for all of us.The decor of the place seems like a bit of a time warp, perhaps to the mid 60s or early 70s at latest, so it's like living inside one of your parents' photographs from when they were young and cool, and not always telling kids to get off their lawn.

Reviews.Author: Ed U.
Reviews.Content: Oy!... you coulda knocked me ovuh with a paper towel. First, my flight from San Francisco was delayed four hours due to a persistent rainstorm. That meant I landed at LAX near midnight starved and grumpy. Ah, Canter's. Open 24 hours. Corned beef for days. I'm so there. It took me about twenty minutes in my Nissan rental to drive up Sepulveda and then Fairfax to get to Canter's. Midnight and the parking lot was packed. So many clubbers and insomniacs filled up this place that it looked like a scene from a 1960's Doris Day movie if she had starred in "Night of the Living Dead". Lots of plastic hanging plants. Heavy on the orange naugahyde. Big harvest gold atrium ceiling window. And probably the most densely populated menu I've seen since the Rosetta Stone. Despite my starving state and a veteran waitress who kept buzzing around me all that time, it took me a good ten minutes to figure out what I was going to eat. I needed the $6.25 bowl of Matzoh Ball Soup badly (see photo). It came with those burnt bread chips that melt into debris when you put them in the broth. I liked it, but it sure needed chicken and noodles to make the big matzoh ball fully digestible. I then had the house specialty, the $13.95 Canter's Hot Corned Beef and Cabbage with Boiled Potato. The ingredients were right, but the proportions were off. Just three thin slices of corned beef over a big, moist quarter-wedge of cabbage, and the biggest potato that's ever landed on a dinner plate (see photo). I just wish there was more corned beef to match the gigantic sides. Regardless, it was what I needed after a cold, heartless wait in the Southwest Airlines terminal at SFO. I even hung on to the unfeeling affection expressed by the waitress who kept calling me "Honey". It's sure nice to know that LA has a heart and a nice herring fillet for sale. FOOD - 3 stars...decent deli plates, thought the proportions needed work but I don't think they're much on change here AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...the land that Lyon's forgot, decor is not retro-tacky, just tacky SERVICE - 3.5 stars..."What'll you have, honey?" TOTAL - 3 stars...now I have experienced the trifecta of old LA eats - Original Pantry, Apple Pan and now Canter's

Reviews.Author: Kacie H.
Reviews.Content: Having heard great things about Canters from some buddies, fiance and I thought it would be a fun place to kill some time before we went to see There Will Be Blood down the block.  There was almost blood in Canter's...let me tell you why.We walked in and sat down at the counter.  After about 10 minutes, the large ogress behind the counter finally acknowledged our presence, hollering "It's gonna be awhile! I have other tables before you!"  in our general direction.  Fine.  We had time to kill.  Fiance procured us some menus.  We watched said ogress fill a bowl of soup and stuff the noodles into it with her dirty hands.  We waited some more.  Finally she approached us.  Fiance ordered coffee, I ordered a cappuccino with a shot of kahlua. She shouted "You want kahlua! That means I'll have to walk ALL the way to the BAR!! Why don't you just go SIT in the BAR?"  Flecks of spit flew from her mouth in all directions. Rather than arguing with Ms. Fee Fi Fo Fum, who could easily have snapped our necks with her sausage fingers, we decided to walk the 9 steps to the bar and order the same thing.  The bartender responded: "You want COFFEE!!! I have to walk ALL the way to the other side of the room to get that!!" I was getting a bit heated at this point, and may have suggested to him that getting people coffee is part of his JOB. He left, grumbling to himself, and returned about 10 minutes later with the drinks.  The coffee was cold.  I mean really COLD.  As in no warmth whatsoever.   When we pointed this out, he sighed loudly, shook his head at us and took it away without responding, then finally brought it back hot. Not impressed.  Cappuccino was gross.  Place looked like it was decomposing around us. So did service staff.

Reviews.Author: Dan N.
Reviews.Content: Great joint to get a bagel & lox, some free pickles, an egg cream, tomato juice, and some huge pastrami on rye sandwiches. Basically reminiscent of my numerous east coast dining experiences growing up with a Jewish dad. You can have breakfast at any time- that's what I want access to! Not in the mood? Have a matzo ball soup and potato knish- yum! It's a little weird that the knish comes with gravy, but it sure tastes good. My sister swears by the patty melt.This place has all the markings of a good deli/diner. Always crowded but you're still seated fast; this place is 24 hours and right by Cinefamily. Nice and clean with a good wait staff. Food is moderately priced and my favorite to grab on Fairfax after a movie. Lots of history here.. seems the older these diners are, the better they perform.

Reviews.Author: Lorraine P.
Reviews.Content: Open 24/7 and ready to serve your drunk ass deli sandwiches among other Jewish-friendly fare, is Canter's: An L.A. institution that's been here forever. I think it's safe to say that the restaurant probably looks exactly the same as it did when it first opened.  Heck, I wouldn't be surprised if some of the original waitresses are probably still schlepping food around. It's what you'd expect from an old school delicatessen: a huge menu filled with breakfast items, mile high sandwiches, dinner platters and desserts served around the clock at decent prices.  The food isn't anything amazing, but it's good and it's fast. Pastrami is definitely the way to go here.  The grilled cheese sandwich...not so much. Parking in the free lot is a crapshoot seeing as though it always looks full, but you can also snag parking on the streets.Good for:+ Late night eats+ Meeting nice, old, Jewish men (Not how I met mine, for the record)

Reviews.Author: Suzy W.
Reviews.Content: Canters is opened 24 hours and has an enormous selection of breakfast items, sandwiches, burgers and more. The corned beef hash and eggs are as good as it gets. For breakfast, Canters beats Denny's, Norm's and IHOP. Service was also excellent.You can also top off your meal with a dessert from their huge bakery up front. The chocolate scone and peanut butter cookie was yummy.

Reviews.Author: KC O.
Reviews.Content: Poetry is a deliStanza is a nickname for Kramer's palFestivus is a comingDo you have your pole?Bar in deli goodCaveman write review yesYoda a little hairless cavemanBar in deli goodSplitting huge pastramiLanger's is the standardHey fatty, hands off my halfIt isn't Tijuana outside

Reviews.Author: Rosie W.
Reviews.Content: Warning: this is the perspective of an Irish gal from San Francisco.  When it comes to traditional Jewish/Yiddish food, my knowledge is right on par with Pat Robertson... or Pat Boone. Basically, anyone named Pat.  Oh, and I'm also a vegetarian, so now you should REALLY ignore me.  But I'm not willy nilly with the 5-star review.  You should know that, too.The Mr. likes pastrami sandwiches and had been dreaming of hitting this place on our vacation, so we went.  The neighborhood looks so sad and abandoned... we went in the wrong door, identifying ourselves as tourists from the jump... it wasn't looking good.  But it all turned around as soon as those pickles hit the table.  The food and service here were much better than we'd had at some trendier hot spots.  I had the potato pancakes.  Huge portion, deeeeelicious.  Not greasy.  I also had the potato knish (yeah, I went for it), and it was lovely, as well.  The Mr. was thrilled with his pastrami on rye with swiss (that's not even kosher, right?), and our waitress was totally on point.  And the pickles!  We will be back the next time we're in El Lay.

Reviews.Author: Yelper X.
Reviews.Content: Clearly I have an addiction to Canter's Bakery. How do I know this you might ask?Simple. I have no other way of explaining how BOTH homeless guys who poach up on the late night tip at Canter's BOTH say in unison tonight, "Oh, there she is. Hey baby, how you doin'?"When you're there so often the homeless dudes see you as one of their own, not someone to panhandle a few bucks out of, yea, you clearly have a problem. Now excuse me while I cope with this realization and dive into my bag of cookies and cheesecake ($10).

Reviews.Author: Amy S.
Reviews.Content: I came to Canter's expecting it to be like Langer's, which I love. Let me tell you, when you're drunk and haven't had a thing to eat all day other than cocktail olives, the Jewish Deli becomes a wondrous, magical place-- the stuff made of fairy tales. We came with a group of 4 and devoured every bit. I had the special, the pastrami burger with fries. Holy crap. Food heaven! Their pastrami is to die for!The fries (I'm a fry person) are good-- thick cut steak fries. I actually prefer Canter's on this one. Big crinkle-cut fan right here.Service was fast and good too. Thanks for not drunk-shaming our group, Mr. Serverman.

Reviews.Author: Megan G.
Reviews.Content: It's not a good sign when you walk into a place and are immediately put off by the sights and smells.  And believe you me, I ain't no prude.  Upon landing in LA a friend said we had to go to Canter's for lunch as it is an LA must.  The next words to come out of her mouth?  "As long as you don't mind mediocre to crappy food."  I was thinking why in the f'in f would we want to go somewhere with crappy food just because it's been around for awhile?  But I was the guest so I kept my mouth closed.  An hour later, $14 poorer and still hungry I just didn't get it.  I had a coffee, a grilled cheese and some chips.  For $14!  Let me break this down for you real quick:  A delicious, melty, warm and gooey grilled cheese could be worth catorce dólares all day long.  But it was soggy and the cheese on the inside wasn't even melted!  I could count the slices they used.  For shame, Canter's.

Reviews.Author: Carlos A.
Reviews.Content: There has got to be something wrong with me! Canter's is my spot for post-late night recuperation. Serving the needs of the night owls across LA, this place is open until 6am.They specialize in Jewish delicacies. I am a big fan of their pastrami sandwich. It's pricey at almost $10 but open late and has a private lot. There is also live music next door. I've hung out here for HOURS and just talked to friends. If you're ever in the Hollywood area and need a good place to hang out and have a decent meal, this is your place.

Reviews.Author: Yuki M.
Reviews.Content: Photos Photos Photos!Same as last time if not better!Pastrami once again won me over.Corned beef was tasty and juicy.Roast Beef and Tri Tip were dry as usual but still good with a bit of dipping in mustard and au jus. The Deli Sampler came with choice of any 3 meats so logically, this was the appetizer - Pastrami, Tri Tip, and Corned Beef.Alongside the sampler sat the Roast Beef French Dip. Needed some serious sandwich to go with my miniature sandwiches.Afterwards, another giant. The Fairfax piled high with corned beef and pastrami. I didn't touch dessert but had a 2ND side order of fries while my dining companion went to town on the eclair and apple strudel.The apple strudel was fine but had raisins in it and I hate raisins.I'll order the chocolate cupcake and apple turnover next time around.Our waiter was an older gentleman named Chris and he was friendly, fast, and helpful. He was also amazed at the quantity of food we ordered. Too bad we live so far but it's a blessing in disguise. LOVE the mustards. Will have to buy some for home on my next visit.

Reviews.Author: Deana I.
Reviews.Content: Breakfast served all day and open 24 hours... what else can you possibly ask for?Boyfriend and I have been planning to visit Canter's for a while now and even more so determined when we saw it featured on Entourage.  After a couple of set-backs, an opportunity came when Marlon H. and Meghan J. wanted to meet up for a late dinner.P.S.  I was actually hoping to see Vince, E, Drama and Turtle.  HA HA HAAnyway, why do I give this place only 3-stars?  Most people would agree that it's at least 4-stars, but here's my reason...  I know this place is better known for their sandwiches, but I couldn't help looking over at their breakfast menu.  After all, I LOVE breakfast food.  So naturally, I opted for a Belgium Waffle and snubbing the myriad choices of (cold or hot) sandwiches.  Even their entrees (i.e. Thanksgiving Dinner Plate), I didn't bother with.  Although I was satisfied with my waffle (it was crispy, thick and golden brown to perfection), I wished that I ordered something else after seeing what others ordered and how yummy it looked.  According to them, it was mighty tasty.  Next visit (yes, there will be a NEXT), I'll try to avoid ordering breakfast.P.S.  I was hoping to see Vince, E, Drama and Turtle.  HA HA HA

Reviews.Author: L G F.
Reviews.Content: Their sandwiches are great BUT for a deli that does not use chicken in their chicken soup....I have an issue. I asked for extra chicken in my chicken soup and the waitress said flat out "we don't put chicken in our chicken soup." What's wrong with that picture???? And who uses beef gravy on their turkey plates?? Canter's does. EEEWWWW!

Reviews.Author: Rachel M.
Reviews.Content: 3.5 starsI received an email that said "Go Use Your Groupons." I had about a month left for Canter's so I decided to use it this past weekend. The service was 2 stars from a waiter that was just awkward. I couldn't tell if he was either rude, sarcastic, or just trying to be funny but not in charming way. I don't expect 5 star service from a deli so that didn't both me that much. The sandwiches were yummy. My boyfriend ordered the reuben with corned beef (4 stars), and I ordered the hot pastrami (4 stars). The meat was very flavorful in both sandwiches. I also liked the rye bread even though I typically prefer pastrami on a roll. Since I like skinny fries, I didn't like the fries (2 stars).I wasn't too hungry and didn't finish my sandwich. I had yummy leftovers. I would definitely return to fulfill a sandwich craving or if I'm hungry late at night.

Reviews.Author: Susan H.
Reviews.Content: It's 2am and you are feeling tipsy.  A friend suggests you go to Canter's since it is nearby.  You make the HUGE mistake of ordering matzo ball soup.  What did I get?  A big ball in water. I can make a better matzo ball soup with the box mix of Maneshewitz.  Oy.The end.

Reviews.Author: Joz Joz Joz W.
Reviews.Content: Have you ever spent 5 straight hours at Canter's?  I have!That's where I spent my Saturday afternoon-- eating, blogging, taking photos and trying not to get in Fran's way.  Lucky for me, we were stationed at the counter where we were mostly in the way of Daniel, who is a sweetheart of a server.  I've decided that any time he's there, I'm sitting in his area if my party can fit there.  Canter's was kind enough to let the LA Metblogs folks stake out some space for 24 straight hours so we could do "a day in the life of Canter's" blog-a-thon."  They are old school, so they don't have wi-fi (we used Verizon Wireless Mifi instead)... heck they barely had any outlets for us, but everything we wanted they accomodated!  From the day manager (Pam), to the various servers who were there at my shift (Amy, Andy), we were welcomed and fed well!(I had a pastrami reuben sandwich with fries... SO yum!)

Reviews.Author: Alex H.
Reviews.Content: Why Canter's?  bcuz they are 24 hrs.  Want pastrami goto Langer's.Canter's is pretty much on par or less with all the other delis in socal BUT they are first with having the most inconsistent service.  If your in a rush, try elsewhere.

Reviews.Author: Cat L.
Reviews.Content: I've been a take-out customer for years until their sandwiches started becoming smaller and blander, and their dine-in service started to suck harder. That grandpa behind the counter sure gives a mean attitude when you ask him to add some cheese on your 'wich, sheesh... and forget about asking him for a side of pickles! So what if they are 24/7? So is Jerry's.Now for some shameless propaganda:CANTer's CAN'T make good sandwiches anymore.Canter's is overpriced and impersonal.Jerry's (insert greater than sign prohibited by Yelp) Canter's

Reviews.Author: Donna S.
Reviews.Content: I feel I should give an extra star just for the history factor. I had never been here before and never really had a desire to try it. But everyone else wanted to eat there, so fine, I could mark it off my list. Everyone is always so shocked when they hear I have never been to Canter's.  And now I really wonder what in the world was anyone thinking when they said I should try it. The worst Matzoh Ball soup I have ever had. It was just broth and an asteriod size Matzoh ball. That's it. Nothing else. Even the Matzoh asteroid was super plain and kinda gummy. Even the bagel chips on the side were very dry and flavorless. Like a eating a nice corner of Death Valley. yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…Pastrami sandwich. Meh. Nothing out of the ordinary. Sandwich itself was naked. They do offer a nice selction of mustard varieties on your condiment tray. The thick crust on the rye bread was actually nice, and I don't usually like Rye bread. yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…Brisket Sandwich I couldn't even finish. Dry, dry, dry. And flavorless. No amount of awesome mustards could save this. And they didn't have any other condiments on the table to add to the naked sandwich. yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…Potato Pancakes.  Okay. Standard.  yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…Pickles: Free and actually pretty good given that I don't normally like kosher pickles. I ate a few of these. Of course, I was pretty hungry since nothing else was very good. yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…Bakery: There was a full bakery, but after the disappointing meal, I was leery about purchasing from the bakery, especially since I tried two of the samples they were giving out and didn't care for either of them (chocolate cookie and a puff pastry cookie.So, I get that its cool because it's still this kitchy place from so long ago without much change, but bland, uninspiring food from the 40s and 50s doesn't do much for me. The fact that it's 24 hours has to be its saving grace. Drunk and hungry at 2AM makes people a lot more forgiving.

Reviews.Author: Melissa O.
Reviews.Content: I admit I am a bit surprised this place doesn't have a 4 star average out of so many reviews.  I can see having some 3's if you got bad service or something, but a) that wasn't the case for us, at all and b) the food overall was delicious.That was easily the best pastrami sandwich I've had since I was a kid.  New York is what it is and it's hard to beat really good deli sandwiches there, so it's rare I find something worth ordering and commenting on.  But Canter's pastrami is so freaking good.  You can see it in my photo.  Thick sliced, tender, tangy, savory.  Outstanding.The corned beef couldn't match the pastrami for me, but it was still very tasty.  The rye bread on both sandwiches was soft and fluffy in the center, but sturdy, just as it should be.  And the deli mustard they bring to the table is a perfect topping.The potato pancakes were also a treat.  Great texture, while thin enough to not be mealy.  The open faced brisket sandwich and potatoes also looked great; I didn't taste it, but my husband said it was awesome.  Pickles were also good, as were the bagel chips and the borscht.Service was wonderful, a very friendly and helpful guy.  And when I went to pay the check, the ladies at the front, when asked, gave me and my mom a little history of the place and more info about their online presence.A highly enjoyable meal, with perfect staff and environment, especially for my old school, New York Jewish mom hehe.   I could not have asked for a better place to stop that day.

Reviews.Author: Sheridan S.
Reviews.Content: Bad, Canter's! I was gonna be fairly nice in my review... but things kept happening that outweighed your historical local charm.I have been going here off and on for a few years. I had my first latke's here, I have noshed on sammiches, breakfasts and various other things. The food has never been awesome, but I have always had a good time and left with a full belly. Today, you blew it. My friends and I were seated at 10:40 am (keep note of the time) We chatted, ordered, our food arrived.. we ate.. chatted.. then I remakred that the latke's were just not what they used to be. They were dense and almost tough. Far from the memory of my previous orders. No biggie.. then I cut into my 3rd one.. the cut off bite was kind of attached to the rest of the latke with something stretchy.. yes, stretchy. There is no ingredient in a latke that should be stretchy. ewI showed the odd stretchy thing to our waiter, who was as puzzled as we were.. he was cool and took it off the bill. I noshed on my bacon (meh.. was ok) and we continued to chat a bit.. My friend finished her French toast (which was pretty darned tasty.) We chatted a bit more (we have not gotten together in over a year) then at 11:20, a guy comes over and tells us that they have a 2 hour time limit on being there and we were well over that.Really? Yes, we had been there a while.. and yes, we were planning on tipping the server extra since we were camping a bit... but we were still well under the 2 hours. I pointed out we had not been there and that his assessment of "well over 2 hours" was an exaggeration. He said he had to tell everyone that. Now.. had there been a line of people waiting for a table, I would have totally understood that they wanted to boot out the campers and seat the new people. There was no line..no one waiting to be seated at all.. and there were at LEAST three empty booths right around us and I am sure more empty ones in the next room. Ticked. me. off. I was seriously tempted to park my ass there for another 40 minutes to use up our whole allotment of 2 hours.Dense Latke: FAILStretchy thing in latke: FAILBeing cool about that and taking it off the bill: WINJERK asking us to leave: FAIL FAIL FAILI am disappointed in you, Canters.... Very disappointed.

Reviews.Author: Amy L.
Reviews.Content: I admit it:  I'm deli-deprived.  I live in San Francisco and we have relatively nil to choose from when it comes to indulging one's lust for blintzes and corned beef!  So imagine how round my eyes got when I heard about Canter's from a friend from LA...My excitement started building just from viewing the interesting Jewish mural on the side of the building.  Then, walking in the front door and being confronted on both sides by deli cases, I knew I had come home!We were seated promptly and feasted our eyes over the huge menu...oy, every joyous Jewish delight written there, coaxing me, luring me towards defiling the intentions of my nutritionist...I finally settled on my usual, a tongue sandwich on seedless rye.  My partner got his usual corned beef reuben, and we decided to split blintzes, just to be chazers!The blintzes practically crossed my eyes, they were so delicious!  Oozing, sweet, flavorful, decadent...and of course, once we were done with them, smothered in sour cream!!!The tongue sandwich didn't let me down:  the gentle flavor of the meat with the delicate texture, so good...and I noted it was a center cut, not the grizzly, chewy end that some restaurants try to sneak into a sandwich!My partner's reuben had him moaning and barely coming up for air!  Let's just say he was a happy boy.On the way out, we picked up a few cookies, including a black and white cookie, my very favorite kind!  You can't find these in SF (or many places outside of NYC), so I always get them when I can!  It also didn't let me down, and was the perfect snack later in the day (what, you think I had room for even a bissle of cookie after such a smorgasbord?!!)!I read all of these negative reviews about this place, and I can only imagine that these diners don't know how lucky they are to have so many Jewish deli choices that they might think this one somehow inferior.  In the Bay Area, there's very little to choose from, and it's quite mediocre, Jewish-lite.  I mean, David's Deli near Union Square doesn't even sell challah and an employee at their take-out counter didn't even know what a babka is, nevermind mandelbrott!  And for those who think brisk service is bad service, hmm, you might not want to ever go to NYC, because that's what pretty much ALL restaurant service is like...it's a cultural thing!At any rate, I thoroughly enjoyed my experience at Canter's, and would go back in a heartbeat!  Now if only I could get them to move up to San Francisco....

Reviews.Author: Mona M.
Reviews.Content: It's expensive. True that. But the fish platter rocks my world.  It always satisfies. How many things can you say that about? For lunch I'm fond of the orange, almond salad, the Greek salad and the cobb salad. All at once. But I kid.The sandwiches don't dissapoint either. And if you're a little under the weather, the chicken soup is a great curative. Or you could stuff yourself on their tasty desserts and call it good.

Reviews.Author: Greg L.
Reviews.Content: You have no idea how much we need a place like this where I live (San Francisco).1 Star for being open 24 hours a day, natch.1 Star for the location on Fairfax.1 Star for the Kibbutz room.1 Star for preserving the decor over the decades.1 Star for Potato Pancakes with sour cream and applesauce.Last time I was here, 12 clowns walked in while my friend and I were eating ourselves sober. I tried to take a discreet photograph of my friend with the clowns in the background and they flipped me off.

Reviews.Author: Bebe F.
Reviews.Content: Ahhh, Canter's is great :-) .  The food, the history, the people...I love this place!On my last visit, while I was happily eating my yummy matzo ball soup, Jerry Stiller got seated next to me.  He tried to lay low wearing sunglasses inside (and it was nighttime) but laying low is kinda hard when you're wearing the shades at night, inside a place and dressed in a gold track suit ;-) .  I thought it was kinda funny.Anyways, I finished up my matzo ball soup & headed into the bakery to grab some cookies to take home with me.  They were quite tasty!I'll always return to Canter's!!!

Reviews.Author: Seena A.
Reviews.Content: The happiness when I get off work at 5am is knowing Canter's is open.The cure to any illness is their matzoball soup.The eggs benedict that comes with potatoes is my favorite breakfast treat.The first corned beef sandwich I've ever had and the only place I will get it now.

Reviews.Author: Tammy T.
Reviews.Content: This place always open and crowded. Crowded means food is yummy. Amazing customer service, whatever you request, they make it happen. Food yummy and whatever you order, cant go wrong. I had the pastrami dip a signature dish. Huge portions. Make sure you bring a big tummy. I have to go back again for desserts. My plate so huge, i didnt get to try the desserts. Soo many good desserts too!

Reviews.Author: Carrie D.
Reviews.Content: I definitely don't get it...dry bread, dry meat, small portion, at a ridiculous price! Egg salad was probably the worst I've ever had, again, at a ridiculous price. Drove a long way to try it and won't be going back. I don't write reviews very often but this was such a disappointment I had to. If the rest of these people think this place is great maybe I should open my own sandwich shop...I'd make a killing.

Reviews.Author: JayChan H.
Reviews.Content: "YOU want PASTRAMIIIIIIIIIIIIIIII?"Yeah It's that big! This is late nite nosh heaven. I took a friend here for his first ever Canter's experience and the look on his face when he opened the menu was priceless! I took the menu away and told him I'd do the ordering and he should just sit back and enjoy. We shared a Monte Cristo sandwich and a apple strudel. Way too much food for 1am! It only took my friend a few minutes to realize this was where the Carl's Jr. "...you want pastramiiiiiiiiiiii" commercial was filmed. He seemed a little miffed we didn't order the pastrami but after the Monte Cristo arrived he was satisfied! I always get pastrami and chicken noodle soup...... it was time for a change up. If given a choice between Jerry's or Canter's RUN don't walk to Canter's!  The bakery alone is worth the trip. The food is great, prices reasonable and the service is exactly what you would expect from a old neighborhood deli. YOU WANT PASTRAMI!

Reviews.Author: Joseph W.
Reviews.Content: Dirty, smelly, covered in bugs, annoying, loud, smelly, awful.And that's just the people that work here.The food is diner food, which is fine, but it should be cheaper and see the first sentence for my take on the place itself."Charm" and "Institution" are words thrown about willy nilly.  A lot of people apply these terms to Canter's because, I don't know, I think they tell you that's what it is when you walk in.  There are so many places in LA like this that survive on people thinking they're supposed to like them and because they've been around SO long people are afraid to question.  If you genuinely like this place, so be it, god bless, all that.  It just aint for me.They get 2 stars because the baked goods you can snag on your way out are delish.  And since I love them so much, imagine how much I loathe this place considering it still only gets a 2......

Reviews.Author: Steve M.
Reviews.Content: Love this place. The service, the food, the atmosphere.  We drive 70 miles here just for dinner. Can't live without canters!!!

Reviews.Author: Bill C.
Reviews.Content: When I first moved to LA, Canter's was the only Jewish deli I knew; so more or less by default it became my favorite deli.  I was living in West Covina at the time, and every few months I would make the trek into town and indulge.In 2003 life took me from THAT Valley to THE Valley and all of a sudden I had option--some outstanding (Brent's) some decent enough (Abe's, Mort's, Art's) and three I learned not to bother with (and they were all named Jerry's).By then the internet had been invented (Thanks Mr, Gore) and I learned of a whole bunch of other deli's on the Westside, and some how my old friend Canter's got lost in the shuffle.  I didn't have any reason to not go there anymore; it just worked out that way.Last month though, Canter's offered a Groupon which gave me an excuse to pay them another visit.And I ordered what I always ordered in the past, a dish called "For Dedicated Fressers Only".. That's a combo corned beef and pastrami; on rye of course with sides of both cole slaw and potato salad. It's the biggest sandwich I know of on the menu; probably about half a pound of warm smoked, sliced beef. It's one of the best sandwiches in town. The sides were both what I came to expect. This is my comfort food.  I also had the bowl of matzo ball soup; another specialty.  It's high intensity chicken broth, with a large fresh matzo ball absorbing it all.I went with a friend of mine who ordered the chicken noodle soup. After one spoonful, he told me it tasted "musty" whatever that means and pushed it aside.   Knowing Canter's and knowing my friends taste buds as I do, I am inclined to side with the restaurant.  When the waitress delivered the sandwiches, she asked if it was OK, and he just said "It isn't to my liking".  We didn't ask, but she crossed it off the billService was excellent, my Diet Coke and his iced tea came in too small glasses, but were consistently refilled.And I walked out feeling great, but also a little sad I hadn't been there all that time.

Reviews.Author: sarah beth S.
Reviews.Content: My dad comes to town and I ask him, full of pride for the culinary breadth of the city I live in,  "What kind of food would you like have while you're here?""Oh sweetie, whatever you recommend...I'm easy.""But isn't there something you can't get in Texas? We have everything here, everything!""Well....I guess if there's one thing I'd really like to have....it would be a good Jewish deli."SOUND OF RECORD SCRATCH WITH ENSUING BEAT OF SILENCE.Somehow, my dad stumbled upon the one type of food that I had zero interest in re-visiting. I hadn't even realized there was such a food that I had so little interest in, as I'm generally enthusiastic about all of it. Sushi, indian, peruvian, korean, burgers, dim sum, tacos, shabu- shabu, lebanese, russian....I would've jumped all over myself to show him the best example of any genre of food......except Jewish Delicatessen. My love of bagels with cream cheese and lox is about as Jewish as I get. My dad, however, is from suburban, Jewish New Jersey and has a constant craving for what he calls the "perfect" sandwich. Lean corned beef, turkey, coleslaw, and russian dressing on Rye bread. Trying to muster up some enthusiasm, I search Yelp for  the best Jewish delis. Langer's is the most appealing, plenty of superlatives and accolades from well respected food-porn mags. But then I read out loud the part about how the neighborhood is bit, er, dicey, and he rules it out. Bummer. "Okay, so there's also Nate and Al's, Canter's..." "Canter's! I heard of that one. I think I saw it on Curb Your Enthusiasm! Let's go there, maybe we'll run into Larry David!"And so, we have dinner at Canter's. I kinda do feel like I'm in New York, but not at a dining destination of my choosing. Dad orders a knish for us to split, somewhat dismayed that we didn't receive a complimentary assortment of pickles. The knish (if you don't know, it's kinda like mashed potatoes in a thin pastry shell) is pretty good, and hot as if it's just come out of the oven. I emulated Dad and dipped it in some "deli mustard". As for my meal. Dad just about laughed me out of the car when I told him that the only other time I ate at Canter's I had ordered eggplant parmesan, which I hadn't been too keen on. "Oh, come on! That's what you get for ordering that in a Jewish Deli!"Dad instructed me to order a sandwich that came with coleslaw and russian dressing and I could chose between corned beef, pastrami, or brisket. I chose brisket because I do like slow-cooked brisket meat (especially at a southern barbecue joint!). "Do I have to have it on rye bread?" I whimper."Yes." is his emphatic command.So, the sandwich comes and its not disgusting, I can chew and swallow, no problem.  But its kinda boring. The meat isn't as tasty as brisket I've had, say, at someone's home, this one is more like a dry, bland roast beef than a moist, tender meat. And I really, really, really don't like rye bread."What are those seeds?""Carraway.""I don't think I like Carraway."Maybe if I had wheat bread. And mayo instead of russian dressing. And some lettuce and tomato, and while we're at it, how about some cheese?I try his "best sandwich in the world" creation. It's not my idea of the best sandwich in the world. But the good news is that he is very, very happy with his sandwich. He polishes off the whole thing, carraway seeds and all. I am pleased that he got what we wanted, and then we stop by the bakery to pick up the only thing that really excites me about New York style delis, the black and white cookie. After excitedly oooohing and ahhhhing over bagels and ruggelah and cakes and buns, he gets a cheese danish to go for the next morning. "Get me out of here before I order one of everything!" On our way out, he's peering around wistfully, still hoping to get a glimpse of Larry David.

Reviews.Author: Ken C.
Reviews.Content: Came here for the Pastrami on Rye and I thought it was really good.  It's probably one of the best pastrami sandwiches I've had, but I still have to try Langer's and Cole's.The pastrami isn't too thin or too thick and it's well flavored.  The meat was piled over perfectly toasted and buttered rye and plenty of sauerkraut.  Russian Dressing was given on the side.I ordered it with a side of fries.  The fries weren't good.  I'd recommend skipping that.  I also had the potato salad and I liked it.  But my friend couldn't stand it...she said there was too much mayo for her liking.  What would keep me from coming back is the price.  I split the sandwich with my friend and we still spent $22 for our sandwich, fries, coke, and potato salad.  It's open 24 hours...worth checking out if you're out and about in West LA.

Reviews.Author: Kevin R.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is a very convenient deli on Fairfax just steps from the shopping district of Melrose. But I only come here around 3 or 4am when I'm out on the town with friends. Once you step into Canter's you see a small dining area behind the cashier. Then once you're led to your seat the restaurant opens up into a massive second dining area. Holy hell! This place is huge!Canter's is your typical deli with typical deli foods. The staff is very nice but with the "New York" snippyness. Don't come in here expecting to be pampered, wined, or dined. The chefs make the food tasty, not flashy. I judge Jewish delis on their pastrami sandwiches. Canter's is pretty good, but the mustard is what sets them apart. I have no idea what brand they use, or if it's house-made. But it's amazing. For all I know it could just be Kraft mustard that they sneakily put into a different container. *shakes fist* Those tricksters! But hey, it's great.Last time I came here my friend ordered spaghetti. Is it just me, or is that a weird choice at a Jewish deli? I thought it was weird. Then again, she's the type that orders cheeseburgers at Michelin star restaurants. Gotta love her, right?In conclusion, Canter's is better than Katz's in New York with cheaper prices. *and let the hate mail begin*

Reviews.Author: Frank N.
Reviews.Content: Wow, 611 reviews. Make that 612.Went to see GF's pal do her improv show in Hollywood and we were freaking hungry afterward. Decided to chow down at Canter's.I love this place. I got a corned beef Reuben and fries. Girlfriend got  pastrami on rye. She doesn't like pickles, so I got her's, too. Delicious. Okay, the service was a little spotty, but the place was packed to the rafters on a weekend night. We weren't in a hurry anyway.If you're in a big hurry, go to Mickey D's or someplace with a drive-thru. Sometimes, it's nice to just take in the atmosphere and do a little people watching. There's plenty of that to do at Canter's.GF stopped at the bakery counter and bought a big ol' bag of sweets. Good stuff!

Reviews.Author: Dan M.
Reviews.Content: ::Benedict::Love to get my J-Deli on... but this place actually sucked... or at least the Benedict did... flavorless!  Portions were great, but no flavor.  Has browns were good.  ::Pickles::Kick @ss pickles... snap!::Bakery::Looks much better than it tastes.::Guns N Roses::Aren't those guys like 90 now?  Jesus.  Anyway, you can buy some book about them here... WTF?  Apparently an owner knows them... total disconnect selling them at the register, and looks kind of stupid IMO... but hey, it's LA!  Got to make it cool!  Would rather the horsepower go in to my Benedict not sucking Benedict.

Reviews.Author: Roach D.
Reviews.Content: I love nostalgia, places that are open 24 hours, and great food.Two outta three ain't bad.oh, yeah.  And I adore pickles, something they do up in a most excellent fashion here.

Reviews.Author: Jena S.
Reviews.Content: It's a Los Angeles staple.If you get ever get drunk in Hollywood, you will eventually end up here.As I told the boy yesterday "if you sit here long enough, you will eventually see all of LA."This is a great place to people watch.  "When my kids get old enough, I plan on taking them here and teaching them everything they need to know about life."The night then went on to comments about the patrons:he-are those hipsters? Me (looks)-Yes. He-i knew it! Its the hats(I'm teaching him how to spot hipsters.. he's getting better at it)& Tranny spotting:He-ok im going to yell "hey fellas" and see if she turns around..There was a tall white woman that could have been my mother age wise walking around with an Asian girl dressed in old fashioned schoolgirl uniform with a piece of cardboard in her hair going around the back of the restaurant and into the bar in circles.He- she's creeping me out... I think shes in the new horror movieBuuuuuuut....All I wanted was a grilled cheese sandwich.  I'd originally wanted to go to Swingers (and in hindsight should have) but when you take 2 people who are both from out of state originally and make them walk forever around the ballpark (me being in HEELS), all I could think of was "need food.. nowish" so this is where we ended up.It was way too expensive.  $23 with only:a bowl of chili, cheese sandwich & fries, coffee, ice teaThere are TOO many choices of food on the menu.  I can't believe I said that... and as much as I appreciate that, and that they are open 24 hrs, it doesn't make up for the cost.  I should not be spending that much for dinner food for one person.. ever.And as much as I feel like a traitor for doing it, it must be done.  People come here for various reasons.. but in reality its not worth it.  Extra star added simply for being 24s + having a bit more to offer than a Denny's.  Sorry LA.sidenote: Will I end up back here again?  If you live in LA, it's inevitable unless you embrace sobriety and the nunnery.  But hey, with any luck, at least I'll be too drunk to be concerned about the price next time.

Reviews.Author: Joe D.
Reviews.Content: If you want to piss me off, tell me this place sucks and that you tried the pasta.Here is the thing.  This is a deli.  At a deli, get a sammich.  Don't get the pasta.  It isn't their specialty.  Do you go to a Mexican Restaurant and buy the burger?  Don't be dumb.  I repeat, do.not. be. dumb.I love this place and it will always be a five star restaurant to me.  My grandmother used to take me here.  My girlfriend and I tend to come here on special occasions.  I have friends who have left the city and the first place we visit on the way back is this establishment.  I've said numerous times that when Canter's closes, it is time for me to leave Los Angeles.However, I know that some people have no idea what to order when at Canter's so let me give you a bit of a guide:Good:-Corn Beef, Pastrami, various deli sandwiches-all good.  My personal fave is the Brooklyn Avenue.  Most sandwiches come without fixings and you add your own deli mustard.  The Roast Beef comes with lettuce and Tomato and all that and is amazing.- All Canter's Salads are huge and wonderful and next to impossible to finish.  They come in sizes large and small.  The large just means more lettuce.  Honestly, 3 people could get full on the small.- Reuben sandwiches- The Midnight Special Steak Sandwich- Corn Beef and Cabbage- Potato Pancakes- Little New Yorker (Bagel and lox plate)- French Fries (big steak fries)- Pickles and Pickled Tomatos- Burgers AND Veggie Burgers- French Dip- Tuna Melt- Hummus- Grilled Cheeses- Matzo Ball Soup or the Mish Mosh SoupLess Than Great:-Turkey- A turkey sandwich is not a deli sandwich and I think that is why their turkey always tastes dry to me.  Stay away from the Thanksgiving Dinner too.- Pasta - DUH!- I'm not a big fan of their baked goods with the exception of the Rugula.Accept no imitations.  I was with my father in the Canters at the Treasure Island casino in Vegas and he said, "Well, it looks like Canter's and it kinda has that Canter's feel but it doesn't have that Canter's smell"That 70 year old smell of pickles and deli meat will forever feel like home to me.

Reviews.Author: Rabia K.
Reviews.Content: First experience at Canters. I was excited to go, honestly b/c it's one of those places that you're supposed to try when you're in LA. What I experienced, though, was mediocre chili, average bread, a nice waitress - nothing spectacular. But what really bothered me was the annoying helping of racism (from the d-bag behind the bakery counter) - who saw me waiting there patiently - but chose to ignore me over and over again while assisting everyone else who was - how do i put this... certain shades lighter ...and then just stand there and do everything but help me - it's just enough to make me never come back. No thanks.

Reviews.Author: Annie P.
Reviews.Content: This place makes me wish I was Jewish and that I grew up eating food like this. Damn my Lutheran parents!!I love Canters Deli SO much, I just wrote a song about it. I  love pickles from the southI love potato pancakes in my mouthI love pastrami sandwiches that are too big I love the old lady with the wigI love havlah candy barsI love Jewish superstarsI love the picture of Guns and rosesI love the way that Axle posesI love take outI'd love it if they deliveredI don't however love the onions and the liverI love sporks I love dorksthey don't serve sausage cause they don't like porkI love their parking lotI love canters when its hotI love live band jamming sessionsI love CANTERS DELICATESSEN!!!!!!!

Reviews.Author: Erika G.
Reviews.Content: Haven't been here for 10+ years but it was a a huge part of life in LA that I thought I should review. I lived there from about 1989 to '90, yes, practically at Canter's. It's in Fairfax, which is sort of a Jewish area in LA. Coming from Chicago, I quickly became lonesome for a really great Reuben sandwich. LA is the land of arugula this, and tofu-stuffed that and nuevo "three peas and a smear of pumpkin paste" entrees. That you have to drive to. Screw that, baby wants real food.This place is oldskool. When I was there, it'd not been remodeled (though it was well maintained, there is a difference) since maybe 1963, and it was full of old people who seemed like they'd been coming there since then. I used to meet up weekly with friends, from a computer BBS (read: geeeeeks).It's got the usual array of yummy food you'd expect to find in a deli. And the Reuben sandwich . . . ahhhh, there may be a god, 'cos they created this. Giant, juicy, mounds of corned beef and tangy kraut. I think that's the only thing I ever ate there, but I did consume many. I'm not Jewish, as the other reviewer mentioned, I do love Jewish mmmmeat!No @#(*^%(*&^ tofu. The rest of LA has that . . . this is an oasis of calm in the sea of pretention that is the City of Angels. Note to the LoxOMeter: Your list is not complete without hitting this joint! :-)

Reviews.Author: Steph C.
Reviews.Content: First things first.  Canter's is an institution, and if you're looking to visit because it's one of the seventeen Jewish delicatessens listed on Wikipedia, don't be deterred by criticism of the food.  That said, bring your camera the first time, because it's only worth going out of your way for once.I've been to Canter's more than once, as it turns out, because it is open 24 hours, and it is kind of a cool spot that's not too hard to wind up in when you live in L.A.  The place seems to be busy at all hours of every day, and the clientele represents as wide a slice of the city as you're likely to see under one roof.  The decor is very old school, with Formica tabletops and framed photographs on plain walls.  The kaleidoscope light fixtures add a bit of color, but you don't really hit up Canter's for the edgy interior.And you shouldn't make a destination out of what is essentially average food.  This is especially true between 8 AM and 4 PM any day except Sunday - in other words, whenever Langers is open.  You won't find that bona fide knock-out pastrami at Canter's.  You'll get a reasonably tasty sandwich with passable rye and meat that's well-seasoned and not too fatty.  The matzoh ball soup is another Jewish deli staple that pales in comparison to Langers' version.  The matzoh ball tastes okay, but has a sort of wet paper texture and it doesn't float.  The soup itself is very salty with flavors akin to Campbell's chicken noodle.  The pickles, at least, are rather delicious.So to recap and stress my first point - don't bother with Canter's if you're in it for a great deli and nothing else.  But if you want to drag your feet over some well-worn Los Angeles carpet, do drag your ass to Fairfax - in landmark status, even Langers doesn't quite stand up.

Reviews.Author: Corazon R.
Reviews.Content: I'm a Canter's late bloomer, but for this place, it's better late than never. Don't know what else I can say about the place at this point, but the menu is AMAZINGLY varied, their potato cakes are a staple, and I forget they have liquor there too. I love the ceiling. I really do. And if you have to wait right in front of the deli counter, you suddenly have a craving for EVERYTHING. FYI on the open face turkey sandwich (hot), they use beef gravy. Needless to say...it was SOOOOOOO GOOD, especially with the buttery mashed potatoes with which it came.The ONLY reason I can give 4 stars is because my last time here I had some of the shittiest service I've ever had. On top of that, it was a special someone's first time there, too. Even a bigger bummer is that he who picked up the check that night was a bit sauced up and overtipped the negligent bastard. Oh well. Karma points for the next Canter's visit...because it won't be the last...

Reviews.Author: Victor L.
Reviews.Content: I am going to be snobby. I saw nothing in here that remotely gave me the impression that I was in a fair, well-meaning, nice establishment. I took a look at the menu, thinking that I could get breakfast at the plethora of seating available.
