I'm sorry, but when most of your menu is above 10 dollars, for this kind of place, I will strike you.But to get more specific about my experience, I stopped in here to grab a bagel and lox cream cheese. A bagel with lox cream cheese. Bagel, lox cream cheese. A bagel, mind you, that was about the size of my fist. The total? The freakin' total?!?!7 DOLLARS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!­!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!­!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!­!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!­!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!WHAT THE SHIT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!­!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!It would have been 12 if I didn't stop the guy from making a bagel/cream cheese combo with an actual slice of salmon.  Right now I'm actually getting more gray hairs. There's another one....wait for it.....AND ANOTHER ONE.The reason why I give this place two stars instead of one: the lox cream cheese was the best damn lox cream cheese I've ever had.

Reviews.Author: Joanna P.
Reviews.Content: Canters may have been awesome in the 50's but it's not so awesome anymore. I used to come here in high school since it was open 24 hours and less boring than Denny's or IHOP.My gfs and I came here the other day for dinner and we were excited about the endless selection of food. You can have anything from hamburgers to matzo ball soup to chicken pita.. They have everything.The service was slow, the food was mediocre (my beef has looked like a brick and tasted like cardboard, the broth for the matzo ball soup was too salty, etc.) and it was just disappointing. The baked goods are not too bad but some are overcooked and dry.This place used to be good but these days, I prefer Greenblatt's on Sunset over Canter's any day.

Reviews.Author: Andrea C.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is an LA establishment that is open 24 hours a day, so I'm assuming they were impressed to have late night sober patrons.  I came in to check out any place that was open late on a Sunday, and this place wasn't scary looking.  I didn't get to sit down for food, but I did get to check out their bakery area. HOLY CHEESECAKE.  There were Christmas style cakes and pies all over, as well as tiny cookies and baked pastries and tons of stuff in a seemingly small area of space.  I settled on a chocolate marble cheesecake that you buy by the chunk (YES).  It had a VERY thick texture that was hard to get through after a few bites (I had to take a break).  While it looked so alluring, once I actually had it in front of me, it was hard to get through (not unlike a lot of Faulkner novels I keep trying to read).  You look so good, and yet, you're a tease.

Reviews.Author: Bianca W.
Reviews.Content: Last time I went to Canter's my experience SUCKED! Dry ass,flavorless over priced crap sandwich. But this time I wised up! I took a Jew and he brought a Jewpon. Major improvement! I ordered the Canter's Pastrami Reuben piled w/ coleslaw(because my friend said to). HUGE! AMAZING! So good. My fries were eh and so were my onion rings, but the sandwich made up for it. After we were done fressing I ordered my fave bakery item to go. Its like a chocolate/pastry cake. SO GOOD! Its super dense. I can't get enough.

Reviews.Author: Evan M.
Reviews.Content: Great pastrami sandwich and deli style pickles. Sit at the dark bar in the back for some extra atmosphere and old school charm. I mean SERIOUS old school charm.

Reviews.Author: Erica R.
Reviews.Content: Canter's was just what the drunk doctor ordered.  This has been the ONLY time I've craved anything seafood for a hangover.  On a recent Friday morning, my friend and I strolled in.....her in pj's, me in last night's outfit.  It's somewhat dim (compared to the BRIGHT sun outside...geez sun, why you so bright?!) and the elderly patrons were right on our level (slow moving and quiet).Add a hot 1/2 coffee 1/2 hot chocolate, Eggs, onion & lox with side of hashbrowns AND an onion bagel with cream cheese and I was ready for a recuperating nap.  Side Note:  reheated eggs were NOT so good :-\   So, either eat it all there or leave it (and feel guilty about the starving children in Africa).

Reviews.Author: Perci N.
Reviews.Content: While I still lived in L.A., I might as well have been Jewish. All my friends were Jewish American Princesses who worked in the sex biz. We lived off of Ventura. Hollywood was the Holy Land. And Jewish diners were Life.Jerry's is pretty darn good, but nothing comes close to the matzo ball or kreplach soup at Canter's.  (Balls the size of your head... huge.) The latkes with apple sauce are great. The Reubens are stellar. The pastrami is more magic than Jesus.There's no place in L.A. I'd rather be at dawn, after a hard day's night in Hollywood, than sitting behind a bowl of Canter's matzo ball soup.

Reviews.Author: Marcus A.
Reviews.Content: I make it over to Canter's a couple times a year. This and Jerry's seem to be in a constant contest for most famous Los Angeles Deli. Canter's has old school charm, it's been around since 1931 and hasn't changed much over the years. The wait staff is friendly and it feels like a family diner and evokes this tremendous sense of nostalgia when you enter. Jerry's has a more diverse menu, is geared a little younger, is cleaner and remodeled, and has really hot waiters. I used to give Jerry's the advantage, because let's be honest, hot waiters make a big difference, but after tonight - advantage Canter's.No, Canter's did not hire really hot waiters but, I tried their tuna melt for the first time. I added tomatoes to mine, I always do. I have three favorite stock sandwiches - the tuna melt, the reuben, and the monte cristo. I still haven't tried Canter's monte cristo and I already knew their reuben trumped Jerry's, but now I can say with certainty their tuna melt does to. I'm not normally a fan of american cheese, but it was ooey gooey poor man's perfection on this tuna melt.  The tomatoes were cooked just right and the bread crust had just enough crunch. It was also a nice sized sandwich, not too big as to overwhelm, but hearty enough to fully satisfy. Jerry's has been my go-to tuna melt for awhile, but the tides have turned in Canter's favor.So why doesn't Canter's get a five star rating, well the menu prices don't exactly match the decor. After an added charge to throw on tomatoes, my tuna melt was 15+ bucks, pre-tax. I think it's a bit pricy for a sandwich, even one that good, when you market yourself as a family-style diner. Jerry's is priced about the same though and it just seems to be that good old Los Angeles pricing at work. Regardless of this I'll continue coming and will eventually make my way to their monte cristo, but not for a few more years, I need some reason to justify the trip to Jerry's to check out the hot waiters.PS. Hands down my favorite pickles in all of Los Angeles.  You have to order them separately and surprise, they are a buck fifty extra and not free for the table (like at Jerry's).

Reviews.Author: Adam B.
Reviews.Content: Canters has been around for ages. Seems like one of the few restaurant in LA that has truly stood the test of time. I first went to Canter's on a trip to LA late in the evening after arriving at LAX and having few late night dining options. Had the Corned Beef and Eggs and wasn't really impressed. It was OK but nothing spectacular.Recently, I came back thanks to purchasing a Groupon and decided to give it a second shot. This time, I decided to try one of my favorite deli treats. Chicken in the Pot. For those who don't know what that is, it's essentially a huge thing of chicken soup with matzo balls, carrots, onions, kreplach, noodles, rice and more. In this case, their Chix includes boiled potatoes. Something I've never seen before in a Chicken in the Pot anywhere. Didn't hep the overall quality of the pot. The noodles were OK at best, the bird was fine, but the kreplach....I guess it was kreplach....was weak and reeked of being overcooked. Far cry from what I expect in a kreplach. How do you overcook that? Obviously, Canter's does.I also tried their Onion Rings. Unfortunately, this reeked of a frozen beer batter ring I'd get at Sam's Club or Costco. That's what it felt like.The Rye Bread and Bagel Chips were also fair, at best. I also tried some rugaluch as they had some free samples from the bakery but that was only average, at best as well.Only thing that saved it from getting two stars instead of three was the service. Most of the servers who work at Canter's have been there for eternity. And it shows. They're very attentive, with a bit of good humor (must be all the comics who hang out) as well. They're fabulous and I was happy to tip them appropriately.But food is the real reason I go, and simply put I can get better deli at Brent's and other places. So that's where I'll go in the future.

Reviews.Author: Shemp H.
Reviews.Content: My brothers and I, being good Jewish boys, never pass up an opportunity to sample the fine dining at Canter's, that's for sure!You will often spot celebrities there, and you can easily imagine the waitresses smoking a butt while taking your order - they did when they could still get away with it! A little ash in a bowl of matzo ball soup never hurt anyone!  But truly this is a place to go for the experience as well as some very good food. I've been here 5 or 6 times just in the last three years. I see some negative reviews here. Ok. So don't expect it to "top" all of your endless experiences in far better restaurants. We get it: you've seen and done it all and you are offended when people enthuse about something that strikes you as average. We'll alert the media.All I know is I've never had better pastrami, corn beef or german potato salad. The soup was great, and the beer was cold. No, the waiter wasn't like an old friend but who cares. Is it over-rated? Depends on what PART of it you are rating. The Kibutz bar next door is a real dump, let's face it, but has a cool vibe and some good tunes. I just get a little hot under the collar when the onesy-twosey star givers here seem to expect to see God smiling up at them from a plate of food at a famous deli. The place has been there forever - nobody expects miracles but if you like deli, this is a good one. Go. Expensive? What ISN'T expensive in that neighborhood?!And by the way something: Denny's would be better ONLY if you are seeking a salt-lick dressed up to look like human food. Forget about it!

Reviews.Author: Toni L.
Reviews.Content: If I could give this place negative stars I would. The food is just not good! I can't say it any more plainly. Food: I ordered the philly cheesesteak. 1) The meat was tough as ALL HELL FROZEN OVER 2) The onions were not cooked enough and still had bite in them 3) the bread was like an old hot dog bun or something. Also, I don't think their black and white cookies are even comparable to those at other delis.Atmosphere: The ceiling consists of transparent fall leaf tiles that look like they belong on a polyester shirt. In fact, the whole place looks like a wormhole to the 70s and not in a good way (yes, I believe there IS a good way). Service: Rude. Just plain rude. Not even rude coming from attractive men aspiring toward Hollywood stardom, but from mumbling ladies faintly laced with cigarette smoke. The line to buy something from the deli can take forever, especially during peak hours. When you get to the front be prepared for additional rudeness.

Reviews.Author: Liza Jane J.
Reviews.Content: I like Old School - from the old time register, to the decoration and the vibe.I adore this place.  Sitting under a autumn leaf ceiling and dreaming of 5 star Rugelach frolicking from the bakery display and into my belly.  Huge portions - big salads, super sized sandwiches and delicious deserts.  An essential part of a late night repertoire or after martinis at Lola's.  Great Success.

Reviews.Author: Bong E.
Reviews.Content: Not really too sure about this place but I gave it 2 stars just because of the nostalgia in the air when you walk in.   at our booth I seen a picture of the place that was dated back in 1948, wow!  any place that's been around this long has to be decent.The only reason we ate here was because we wanted to go to flight club LA and it didn't open until 12:30p on Sunday.  i had the hot corned beef which was good, except for the fact that the waitress, who wasn't very helpful, didn't let us know it came plain and when i asked for toasted sourdough, it didn't come toasted.  the waitress didn't really have the attitude like she wanted to answer any questions or didn't come around too often either.Oh well, til next time......Canter's will still be around!

Reviews.Author: Will M.
Reviews.Content: I love this deli, but honestly I rarely get farther than the bakery take out.  I have ordered some yummy sandwhiches (e.g. corned beef on rye) in the 20 plus years I've been a customer. But a diabetes inducing bakery is what I love.  Canters reminds me so much of the many wonderful bakeries in the Big Apple. If variety is the spice of life then the selections at Canters is like hyper spice,  I mean - how can you top the five or so varieties of just poppy seed pastries?  Everytime I have to take a physical for a job, I get tempted to eat a whole loaf of that poppyseed danish to see it it could really make you show a false positive on a drug test.  OK I'm not dumb enough to do that, but I've been tempted. Actually it' would just be an excuse to eat that delicious poppyseed danish by myself in one disgusting gulp like a boa constrictor. They also have great bagels. For example, they have two types of full flavored onion bagels - egg bagels or regular whith pieces of onion on top of a great bagel.  So many bagels made here in LA are way too chewy and doughy.  Theirs is not, it's perfect.  If you like fruit pastries, there is apple, cherry, berry, apricot, and also, cream cheese - they're all here, much to the chagrin of my internist who tells me to stay away from too much white flour and sugar. But if you're restricted from too much of something, you should really eat good versions of it, right?  I love their NY cheesecake.  It's taller and lighter than the regular cheesecake. What more could you want?  Free parking?  Of course. They validate your parking too (the lot is a half block south of the restaurant.)And don't forget the many types of cookies. There are also manybreads to make sandwhiches or rolls to eat with soup or a salad.  I told the guy behind the counter I have to watch my sugar intake, but he had no sympathy for me. He says, "I'm a diabetic, but I still love to work here.  Instead of trying to make be cut back, he realizes I'm a fanand tells me some background on the restaurant. Finally, I am done with my short errand to take things back to OC. I am walking out with several bags of goodies.  I thankfully share it with my friends who are in pastry heaven.  There is nothing in OC that comes close to Cantersbakery take out in IMO in terms of just plain goodness.

Reviews.Author: Seung Eun C.
Reviews.Content: Seriously jetlagged after a trip to the orient, we found ourselves bright eyed and bushy tailed at the wee hours of 5am.  Hungry.  Starving, what's open at this time?First choice would have been Griddle but they open at 8:30.  Boo.  So we were left with either Canters and Norms and decided Canters it was.Breakfast was mediocre at best and really pricey too.  I had two eggs, french toast, bacon, ham, and a very poor attempt at scalloped potato hash.  First off, the french toast was on a plate that had a dried crusty residue on the edge.  I suddenly didn't feel like eating it and  so didn't even want to bother complaining about it either.  The potatoes were dry, hard to chew and even harder to swallow.  Everything else was just OK.My husband had the corned beef which was served like a meatloaf.  It was a large serving but I didn't think it tasted all that great, plus it was a tad dry.At this point we decided on a side of potato salad which is one of my favorites at Canters.  Yum.  It didn't disappoint.So, one star for being open, one for the food, and one for the delish potato salad.  Hence, 3 stars.Btw, halfway into the meal, we realized Dupars could have been another option.  Never been, but I hear their breakfast is excellent.

Reviews.Author: Lana T.
Reviews.Content: I was 9 years old the first time I went to New York. For some reason, one of my most vivid memories from that trip was when the tour guide took my family and I to this supposedly famous Jewish deli in Brooklyn. "Corned beef on rye with mustard and a pickle," he said. "That's the only thing you should order." I remember that flavor as being one of the most amazing of my life--foreshadowing my future existence as a Yelper, maybe. For whatever reason, the next Jewish deli I went to was over 10 years later at Canter's. I still remember that flavor. I was pretty excited to come because I'd heard a lot of good things about this place and I was looking forward to recapture that moment on my tongue again.Came here with my Jewish friend from NYC. He got lox and a bagel, I ordered the pastrami and corn beef on rye with coleslaw.It was... okay. Pretty good, and pretty expensive, although I won't necessarily hold the price against Canter's considering this is LA. I was reminded but not convinced. Service here was definitely not so great, with the waitress complaining about giving refills on the coffee and saying she had already given us two when she hadn't given us any. It goes without saying that the ambiance was that of a typical diner. My friend said this place reminded him of New York but was more expensive and not as good.Also, being the nerdy grad student I am, I tried to study here once.  No outlets or wifi, but my friend and I thought that might help us concentrate. Anyway... I definitely don't recommend it. Our waitress started complaining after we were there for 45 minutes and then the manager came over several times to ask us to leave even though we hadn't finished our food yet, presumably just because we had our computers out. I know this is a diner, but if I'm paying $15+ for a sandwich, I deserve at least an hour of uninterrupted mealtime, especially when there are plenty of empty booths around...One major plus is that this place is open 24/7. Definitely the best option to hit up after hours or after a night out. During the day time though... I'm still looking for my long-lost sandwich.Sorry Canter's... I'm going to have to go to my boy Langer's.

Reviews.Author: Mikey H.
Reviews.Content: DAMN! I LOVE THIS PLACE!I lived in Torrance for two years and used to stumble into this place after a night of carousing and shenanigans.  This place never failed to satisfy, and every now and then, you'd spot a minor celebrity here and there.  It has changed quite a bit over the years.  However, they still have the leaf ceiling lights and deli-counter.  I'm sure some of those cute old waitresses have retired...or died.One drunken night, I couldn't get out of the car so my friends left me.  Apparently, I missed meeting Anthony Kiedis and friends who sat in the booth across from them.  I guess they could've came and got me, but then I'd probably make a drunken fool of myself, or barf on them.  Ahhh, memories.  Since we were playing tourist, I really wanted to stop here, and the partner had never been.  The food here is all comfort and if you like, very Jewish.  The servers are usually some great old gals who call you "hun" or "dear" and make sure you are fed.  This place is far from gourmet or some California cuisine shi-shi diner.  The menu has changed...they never used to have penne pasta...lol...I ordered a turkey club sandwich and the partner had a blt.  Both were pretty good.  If it wasn't so late, I would've had a dinner, especially the turkey.I love the memories I have of this place.  However, "And I don't ever wanna feel like I did that dayTake me to the place I loveTake me all the wayAnd I don't ever wanna feel like I did that dayTake me to the place I loveTake me all the way yea yea ye-yea"Oh, and one more thing, by all means, stay away from the other room near the lounge.  If there's a band playing you won't hear yourself or anyone else talking.

Reviews.Author: Marc L.
Reviews.Content: After watching one of the ugliest USC-UCLA games in recent memory (USC 28 - UCLA 14), my friend and I trekked all the way from the Rose Bowl over to the Parsons parking lot in Old Town Pasadena. It took an hour of walking through the winding neighborhoods of the Arroyo Seco, but we were able to beat the traffic getting out of the stadium.It was midnight so we though that most of the people who attended the game would be gone by then- we were terribly mistaken! Barney's Beanery had lines going down the block and most other restaurants in Old Town Pasadena were also full. We decided to go elsewhere instead of wait around, so that's how we ended up at Canter's.As many Yelpers have noted, the menu here is encyclopedic- there's so much to choose from! This time around I ordered "For Dedicated Fressers Only" - a large corned beef and pastrami sandwich piled high on rye bread, with a full side order of potato salad and cole slaw. It cost $14.95, but the price was appropriate for the amount of food I got- the sandwich was HUGE!I also ordered a knish- a hefty ball of dough filled with hot potato filling. I remember seeing knishes featured in an episode of South Park (Season 11 - "The List") and was curious about what it tasted like. The thing was as large as a child's fist and very filling- I can see how a few of these could be a meal in itself!The service here, especially at 1 am in the morning, is great. Our waiter was a cheerful middle-aged Asian American man who just so happened to have attended UCLA! Throughout the night we engaged in good-natured smack talk, while bemoaning the mediocrity of both USC and UCLA's football and basketball teams. Aside from that, the guy was constantly checking up on us and refilling our drinks- even though the soda fountain was on the opposite side of the restaurant!Not the cheapest place to nosh, but Canter's is always an experience... Great food and great people! If you're lucky, you might even spot a celebrity- the last time my friend was here, he sat across from "the Mayor of the Sunset Strip", Rodney Bingenheimer, who always has a booth reserved here!

Reviews.Author: Ryan J.
Reviews.Content: It's late night, and I'm drunk again.  Went to the Dodgers game, and had a couple of dogs (and I'm pretty sure that's what they actually are), but I'm hungry.  Again.  I need a fix.  Something to soak up the beers.Canter's is one of the true LA landmarks when it comes to delicatessens.  I eat there, just like my mom did when she was my age.  They have a menu that encompasses just about everything you could want, from patty melts to breakfast to matzo ball soup, and the list goes on and on and on and on.  Is it the world's best food?  No.  Does it fill the void?  Yep.My favorite part?  The entrance.  And I'll tell you why.  When you walk in the front door, there are stands to your right and left.  On the right?  A huge glass display case entertaining any smoked fish fantasy in which you've ever engaged.  And on the left?  Oh my god, heaven.  That's what's on your left.  Every kind of cookie, pastry, bread or bagel of which you've ever dreamed.  I can never walk out of here without a huge box of cookies.  And yes, I wake up feeling sick in the morning, but it's totally my own fault... I have no one else to blame.  Except Canter's.  Perhaps they put something in the air.  They make you hungry.  And if you're like me, meaning that your eyes are bigger than your stomach, you aren't getting out without more cookies than one man (or woman) should possibly purchase.  But it's cool.  Because they're delicious.Prices are reasonable, they're open late, and they have a diverse menu.  Oh, and they have cookies.  Lots and lots of cookies.  So I'm really giving 3 stars for the food, and 4 stars for the cookies.  But the cookies make it a worthwhile stop even if you aren't eating a full meal, so they get the heavier weighting in this review.  4 stars.

Reviews.Author: Frances L.
Reviews.Content: Sometimes it's the places you love the most that you forget to write Yelp reviews about. Canter's is one of the best Jewish delis in the country--so great, that it's been welcomed into deli royalty by various authors who have chronicled the history of the Jewish deli alongside some of the greats in New York like Katz and Carnegie. While the prices might look steep, what you get can feed two! My favorites include the corned beef sammy (piled high and served with a choice of 5 five different mustards...5!) with a side of their thick steak fries as well as the Fairfax sammy, which is half hot pastrami and half corned beef. Legit, traditional joint with awesome wait staff, lots of character, bagel chips, deli counter, bakery counter, and even those amazing bottles of Dr. Browns and plates of huge kosher pickles at every table. Open 24/7, always a good time. A nice place to bring out of towners for some L.A history. Don't forget to drop by the bakery counter after you've filled up on corned beef, potato pancakes, and so on--- you NEED some chocolate chip rugalah and one of their famous black and white cookies. Cold, rainy days this fall...add their matzo ball soup to the mix. You won't be let down. Canter's makes this Catholic Filipina girl feel at home every single time.

Reviews.Author: Leslie M.
Reviews.Content: Dear Canter's,Thank you for putting up with my drunk friend Alan last night.  He doesn't remember causing a scene or buying a whole chocolate cake, but I certainly remember eating some of it and damn, it was delicious.Love,Leslie

Reviews.Author: Grant K.
Reviews.Content: I Canter believe anyone fucking eats here...Good drunk spot.  That's it.  Matzo ball soup sucks.

Reviews.Author: Eduardo X.
Reviews.Content: Another LA institution that I can't stand.Given how many customers they have, you'd think they could clean the place up.  Seriously.  Why would I eat in a dirty dump?  End of review.

Reviews.Author: Timothy L.
Reviews.Content: I have been going to Canter's for the past 20+ years. When I was a kid it was fun to go there after a long night out...order pastrami and eggs and sober up.  I honetly can't tell you how the food was or how the service was..back then.Now, there is nothing special about Canter's. Yes, it's historic.  Everyone must go there one time...and thankfully for the owner's that means the restaurant will be there for many years to come.  They deserve it...they did create this landmark.But the food is not good.  The service is not good.  The restaurant just seems dirty.Kinda sad that I have to talk badly about such a great iconic restaurant that I loved as a teen.

Reviews.Author: Erin O.
Reviews.Content: Pickles, ick. I'm a pickle person and will never ever eat one from here ever again.Kugel, weird. Too much cinnamon and dried fruit?Matzo Ball Soup, good.

Reviews.Author: Claire H.
Reviews.Content: When you date someone, you know how you end up with your own little special date spots where you'll go by default if you're not feeling adventurous, have your usual things you'll order, and perhaps even know the waitstaff by name? One day I was telling my roommate how, even after a handful of pretty ugly breakups with people with whom I'd go to Canter's regularly, I never associated Canter's with any exes."That's because Canter's belongs to everyone," she said. She is right.Canter's feels like home. Their Brooklyn Avenue sandwich is the stuff dreams are made of. Walk in, and it has that wonderful smell of years of pastrami and fresh rye bread being made. I remember the first time I came here with my mom for mish mosh and chocolate egg creams, she kept marveling over how much it reminded her of New York.I hate hearing people bash Canter's. I'd be so sad if anything ever happened to the place. Restaurants that last this long are such an anomaly in L.A. Yes, it's pricey. Please don't come here, order spaghetti, and talk about how much you hate this place because their spaghetti sucked.Canter's salads are also surprisingly good. My boyfriend and my usual is to split a garden salad (which comes full of fresh vegetables, peppers, chickpeas, and cheddar cheese) and the famous Brooklyln Ave. I am convinced their pastrami is an aphrodisiac.Ask at the counter for an odds 'n ends bag on your way out and you'll get a big bag of rye ends that weren't big enough for sandwiches - for a buck and a quarter!

Reviews.Author: Max M.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is a relic from the early days of Hollywood. It was one of the first places that I visited when I moved to LA in 1999. When was the last time I visited Canter's? You guessed it: 1999.This place isn't even cool in a retro-kind of way. I find it to be depressing in a retirement home kind of way. Otherwise, I could forgive the food which strikes me as what truck stop quality diner food might be like. You are better off at Nate n Al's. Should you unwittingly allow someone to persuade you that eating at Canter's is a good idea (it most certainly is not!), you might as well drop by The Kibitz Room, a dive bar next door. That place is more worthy of a visit. Sorry mate...Canter's has neither the food nor the mood for this Yelper.

Reviews.Author: Brittany K.
Reviews.Content: This place can be totally gross. That's why I love it.  It can also remind me of being at my grandparent's house growing up, eating the yummiest Jewish food ever.  Canter's is a staple, it's adorable, it's historical, it's your typical Jewish Deli, and some things they have here will knock your socks off.  I love the bakery case too!The matzo ball soup is the best ever here.  Ever.  Everytime I'm sick, I order it and it makes me feel better.  It's better than my grandma's, honestly.  I order the mish-mosh, which is matzo ball soup with noodles, rice, and a kreplach (dumpling.)  Yum.The cheese blintzes are killer, and the latkas (potato pancakes) are delicious!  Sometimes I eat them with sour cream and apple sauce, other times I'll sprinkle some salt on them and dip them in ketchup.  Depends on my mood...Grilled cheese on challah = bomb.  Get a grilled cheese, some latkas and some soup, and you'll be singing hava nagila in no time.Oh and of course, the bakery case!!! Hamentashen are great, bu the best thing in there are the rugula.  I love the chocolate chip, my bf loves the cinnamon, but they're all good.

Reviews.Author: Julie F.
Reviews.Content: Jewish comfort food!I'm not really a fan of their sandwiches (Langer's is my favorite), but I do like their matzo ball soup, potato pancakes, cheese blintzes (mmm), coleslaw, potato salad, and pickles.  Got a stuffed cabbage on the way out.Next time, lox and bagels!

Reviews.Author: Arnold G.
Reviews.Content: I love pastrami and I love sauerkraut, but I've never really been a fan of Jewish delis because I've always thought they were overpriced. I ended up at Canter's against my will the other night, but approached it as an opportunity to give the place another chance. I've been to Canter's a few times before and was never really impressed by the food, but honestly, I don't think my palette or my food knowledge was very good back then. Plus, I was usually poor, so any sandwich that cost over $10 was a big problem for me.My wife and I split the Reuben sandwich. We got it with pastrami and it was really good. Not melt-in-your-mouth pastrami like at Katz's Delicatessen in New York, but still very good. The sauerkraut was excellent and was easily my favorite part of the meal. For dessert, my wife ordered the blueberry pie a la mode, which she thought was just okay because the filling was more like a blueberry jelly than actual whole blueberries.If you like pickles, they're free at Canter's, and they bring you a plate of them when you're seated. If you're in a drinking mood, you can order most mixed drinks at your table and i think they come from the bar next door. If there's a band playing at the bar, then it can get a little loud, so you may want to sit in the room near the main entrance if you want to have a conversation. Our waitress was cool and very accommodating of our group of 10 and had no problem handling separate checks.The one thing I really hate about Canter's is the parking, especially in the evening. There's a small lot adjacent to the restaurant that's usually full, so unless you're going to hunting for street parking, you'll have to wait till someone leaves before you can park. Luckily this process moves fairly quickly since people are always coming and going, and while you wait, you can admire the mural that's painted on the side of the building chronicling the Jewish struggle in Los Angeles.

Reviews.Author: Jess T.
Reviews.Content: I'm going to have to say that this is by far the best Jewish deli on the West Coast. I beg, and plead to go to this restaurant the minute any one suggests going anywhere near down town LA. The service is always entertaining - no matter what time you go, the server will most likely be an older woman who does not have time for your silly ignorance of the menu. Who reads those things anyways?! While entertaining, I never felt the service was rude or lacking.The matzo ball soup is great. Bagel chips and pickles come with sandwiches. The sandwich will be as big or bigger than your head. You really can go wrong with anything here. YUM!

Reviews.Author: Geoff K.
Reviews.Content: Breakfast: Lox, eggs, and onions scramble.Lunch: Pastrami on rye, yellow mustard, and a vanilla egg cream.What could be better?  Minus a star because this place started the trend of vastly overpriced deli food.  BTW it's a crackup that they call it "Kosher-style deli" when it serves bacon.

Reviews.Author: Desiree G.
Reviews.Content: Yes,a bit overrated but its an L.A institution that is a must try.PROS:OPEN 24 HRSLarge portionsaccommodating for large groupsCons:a bit priceyservice can be iffydark atmosphereMy favorite sandwich is the Avocado Melt- avocado, sauteed mushrooms, cheese, alfalfa sprouts on white bread =D

Reviews.Author: Janet P.
Reviews.Content: Finally made my way here after driving by this place so many times.I wasn't really sure what to expect after hearing all the hype, but all I knew was that I wanted to definitely have matzo ball soup. Mainly because I've never had it before and I figured I should go to an actual Jewish deli for some.I ordered the half sandwich special, so I got a pastrami sandwich along with the matzo ball soup. We also ordered the "mishmosh" soup, which seemed to basically be a chicken noodle soup on steroids. My eyes definitely bugged out when I got my matzo ball soup. The matzo ball (singular) was about the size of my face. I thought the soup itself would have veggies in it, but it was just a plain chicken broth. I enjoyed the texture of the matzo ball, but felt that overall it just lacked some flavor.  The pastrami sandwich was good, but it wasn't anything I would come back for.The mishmosh soup was basically just the plain chicken broth with various types of pasta (rice, noodkes, kreplach) added to it.  Once again, nothing spectacular.I'm not sure if we just ordered the wrong items, or if this is indicative of all the food served here, but it's not a place I would go back to again unless A. it's convenient, or B. I get a very very odd random craving for a matzo ball the size of a baseball.  However, I did enjoy getting to finally go to this market, and can cross it off my "to-go-to" list.

Reviews.Author: keith k.
Reviews.Content: What can be said about Canter's that hasn't been said already?Nothing, that's what.There's a reason this is not just a Hollywood staple, but a SoCal one as well. It's legendary. And not just because of the name-dropping you can do after your lunch. It's not just a hot spot to be seen- it's a place to go for killer food. The matzo ball soup is something you'll be telling your grandkids about.If you survive the hot pastrami sandwich, then you didn't put Beaver's deli mustard on it.And don't get me started on the complimentary pickles. That's right. Complimentary pickles.

Reviews.Author: Luis M.
Reviews.Content: It's hard to find vegetarian dishes here as you feel like you are surrounded by slabs and slabs of meats, and it always gives me this weird old dusty feeling. Yes I know it's an L.A landmark since the 1930s, but that's no excuse to keep the same waitresses who are utterly and completely rude. I am serious they are all over 60 and even my first time there trying to decide what to order, one of them just walked away.Miraculously, I did discover their really good Avocado Veggie Melt, but that's about it. DON'T get any ice cream with hot fudge, it has this weird after-taste/texture, there were even bits of like hard rocks in it which was gross. However, many people come back because they have the best corned beef and pastrami in the Los Angeles Area...or so I've been told. There's also a bar there, bakery, deli and lounge area but it seems like too much.The service here is at best decent, and takes forever to bring you refills. Now only that but it's rather pricey too and the parking sucks. There's only one tiny parking lot that is almost ALWAYS full when you go, so you might have to find parking on the street or in the residential areas.However, they are 24hrs and the wait isn't bad, but that's about it. We ONLY visit when we have to.

Reviews.Author: Seth G.
Reviews.Content: A classic, classic Jewish deli on Fairfax. I hadn't been there in months, but I had a hankering after a screening of The Dark Crystal at Cinefamily last night. They recently tweaked their menu, but there's no way Canter's is gonna change all that much after so many decades. They did a "Mac Attack" sandwich, with Mac N' Cheese, Cheddar, and Bacon on Sourdough. It's as wrong and delicious as it sounds. Plus I split a side of potato pancakes with my friend. So yeah, it was basically a meal that consisted almost entirely of cholesterol and carbs.The staff always has personality (which sometimes means attitude), the place has been there forever and feels like LA history, there are old-timer regulars always dining there elbow to elbow with young rockers and hipsters, and they have some of the best deli sandwiches in the city. Eating at Canter's is like coming home.

Reviews.Author: Ann C.
Reviews.Content: One of two defaults after a night out.  The latter would be Fred 62's on Vermont.I recommend the Monte Cristo or the quesadilla.Oh, the chicken soup does not come with chicken.  It's more like hot chicken broth.  Chicken is an additional charge, but the crackers that they come with are free (so help yourself to more).

Reviews.Author: James S.
Reviews.Content: At times overrated. At times a great surprise. Why can't they get it together so I can like them or leave them?Eat there and you may get good service. Or you may go gray while you wait. Take out is as reliable as the stock market, and sometimes as palatable. Inspect what you get before you leave!Everyone can make a mistake. But I find that when I do take-out at Canters, there's always a problem. This last time there were many.I ordered the Chopped Liver, Corned Beef and Cole Slaw from the Deli. When I got home, the CL was awesome; the CB very good, and the Cole was more like Ole Slaw. Wilted, overripe cabbage that must have soaked up the mayo from 5 days ago.  Had I inspected it at the time, I would have never gotten it. The Bakery really blew it. I steered my way to the Blond mature lady to take my Bakery order as the younger guy next to her was busy picking his nose. Yes, really, he was.I got the Rye Bread, which is always first rate; a Challah, which is always velvety; and some cookies etc. Got home, and noticed the Challah was a brick. Diagnosis: Oven must have been too hot, cause the entire exterior was overdone. Then, the rye bread---WTF? Bland and with no texture. So after tasting the Old Slaw, and seeing these two lackluster breadstuffs, I was just pissed enough to call and tell them about it; and their nose-picking bakery dude. Drove back, returned the crap, and I am reminded what a crap shoot Canters continues to be. No excuse for that cole slaw, period. Bakery blunders---? Oy. CB and CL were great. But worth the aggravation? You decide.

Reviews.Author: EJ K.
Reviews.Content: This is the only Deli in Hollywood for me baby.A bad date took me here seven years ago and while we didn't fall in love at the deli, I feel in love with Canter's.  Love their reubens, yummy fries, delish Dr. Brown's sodas and yummy pickles.  The service is always what it is, not necessarily prompt but they get you your food.It's really bustling at 3 or 4 am when all of the drunkards are needing their fix.  Last time I was there the place was packed and these drunk SC guys were throwing things at some ladies.  The ladies got up and nearly kicked the guys asses for being so annoying.  Where else in LA will you see that?Do not forget to pick up some halvah on the way out.  It's a tasty tasty treat that will do more to clog your intenstines but it's so good.  Only kvetch (yeah, my inner jew is coming out) is that parking can be tricky sometimes.  But whatever, it's worth the little hassle.

Reviews.Author: Eric E.
Reviews.Content: I go to the best Jewish Deli in all of Los Angeles and what do I get?  A cheeseburger.  But it's a goddamn GOOD cheeseburger, and the fries are the best I've had in ages.One of my friends had the pastrami which is absolutely fantastic and has the give and texture of butter as you sink your teeth deep into its juicy goodness.  They take care of you at Canter's...you get more food than you could possibly hope to finish and should you dine in, then you have the pleasure of enjoying your meal in a restaurant with personality that has withstood the test of time.Our waitress was a cute older lady who was so nice and friendly that we couldn't help but want to do shots with her at the Kibitz Room nextdoor.  It was especially cute when she explained to me what a cherry phosphate was.  (Sorry, I grew up in the era of Cherry Coke).  It wound up tasting not unlike a cherry Tums.The menu is huge and diverse--go with a group so everyone can sample eachothers' dishes.  How could you not want to?In conclusion--this place is far more awesome than my little five star review can convey.  Shit, I'm starting to like Los Angeles.

Reviews.Author: Ilan J.
Reviews.Content: as mentioned parking lot ois small but a 2-3 min wait and a spot opened.  Food is amazing and prices are fine.  Loved the soup and the sandwiches.  On a diet so I avoided even looking at the bakery.  Viewing alone will add 4 lbs.

Reviews.Author: Marian B.
Reviews.Content: I would've been better off going to Denny's or Norms for a late night after clubbing grubfest. This place looks old and waiting in line by the deli ruined my appetite. I saw things I don't think people should be eating. Globs and blobs of stuff. Really grossed me out. Food tasted whatever. Dry and just not appetizing. Usually after a night of dancing and drinking I'm ready for some of the greasy good stuff but this just didn't cut it for me. I knew I should have just bought an LA dirty dog!!!

Reviews.Author: Dave G.
Reviews.Content: You're visiting your friend who is a high-powered Los Angeles attorney famous for defending C-level business executives that have been charged of killing endangered baby animals with fully automatic assault rifles. "Your honor!" he routinely exclaims. "Well I ain't no big-city lawyer, but I can tell you this much. Long as he didn't have a SCAR-H with a holographic sight equipped, ain't no way he could've teln if he was shootan at liddle penguins versus the penguin-like tarhgets he set up in the same area those otha liddle penguins was loytterin at!" He plays a lot of Modern Warfare 2."I got money in my pocket. I got money on my block. I got the money and the power" he casually tells you as you get into his Darth-Vader Black Bugatti Veyron EB 16.4. He roars out of his private garage at 987hp and upon exiting, immediately plows over a passing pedestrian. "Well, aigh't nothing you could do about that!" he chuckles. He will take you, at around 150mph, to Canter's, where he tells you they make" the biggest and best-damned sandwiches in the world." Then, in your disbelief, he will order the Mish-Mash, a matzo-pasta combo served in a tiny bowl with mini-crackers. And you will laugh at him. Because they do make the biggest and best-damned sandwiches in the world And he ordered a Mish-Mash.

Reviews.Author: Katie K.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is a rather recent discovery of mine. I know what you're all saying right now, "recent discovery?! does she live under a rock?" Yeah, well, I guess I must, because when I went to Canter's, I immediately regretted that it wasn't the FIRST THING I discovered when I first entered Los Angeles.I love Delis. I don't care how they look inside, or if the same waitresses are celebrating their 50th anniversary of working there, I still love them. I love sandwiches, and I especially love knowing that my meat will be freshly sliced off that big hunk of meat behind the counter specially for my sandwich. It makes me feel a little bit important.Another thing- Canter's has bagels and cream cheese. Bagels and cream cheese are also up there on the list of my top ten most favorite things in the world. I like to get lots of them to bring home. I kid myself by saying that my dozen bagels will last me a week. I'm lucky if it lasts the evening.Finally, Canter's biggest selling point: they have a ::drumroll:: PARKING LOT! Wow! What a treat! Being able to park RIGHT NEXT TO the building, go inside, buy my stuff, and NOT HAVE TO PAY TO LEAVE! What a novel idea! It's like an oasis in the middle of a parking-lot-less city.... It's like... well... Heaven.

Reviews.Author: Shaun W.
Reviews.Content: Came here once about 5 years ago with a Jewish friend who said it was awesome. Lies!!! Came here a few days ago... and it STILL sucked.----------------LOCATION----------------Both times I've been it was after midnight. 1am and 5am.Located near Melrose, on Fairfax, near Fairfax High... trendy little spot.When you walk in the DELI is the 1st small room you walk into, filled with baked goods, then you walk into the main dining room. There are private rooms located off to the side.The ceiling is stained glass like in a church, very autumn colored.----------------THE FOOD----------------The menu looks intriguing, pastrami, sandwiches, etc, etc but just like JERRY FAMOUS DELI it's over priced and nothing special. Forgot what I got years ago but I remember it was disappointing.~ SAN FRANCISCO JOES - It's a Spinach, Mushroom, Onions and "meat" mixed with eggs. I choose SALAMI for $2 more and it was terrible. The eggs were overcooked, slightly browned, which I hate. The flavors didn't really do anything, it was subpar. Tried some EGG-SOMETHING TOAST, which was decent. The butter was the best part of the meal -_--------------AND SO-------------This place sucks. I think I had a Pastrami Sandwich before and was disappointed and last weekend was the icing on the cake cause it sucked again. Avoid this place like the plague..... I'll never come back unless it's free... and even then... fool me once, shame on you, fool me twice, shame on me... fool me 3 times.....

Reviews.Author: Jaina D.
Reviews.Content: What more can I add? It's all true--the good, the bad, and the pastrami.I always get the matzoh ball soup and a "Rube Ruben" (extra cheese). I've been there with nerds, rockers, clowns, and my grandmother (who's been going since it opened)!Downside: I'm not sure they have a wheelchair-accessible bathroom.Bonus activity: watch the bread slicer in action!

Reviews.Author: Liz S.
Reviews.Content: Matzo ball soup.   Pastrami,  brisket.  Huge portions.   Fast service, with a smile and a hint of a smirk.Stuck in time.  In a good way.Open late.Classic.

Reviews.Author: Andy S.
Reviews.Content: My personal preference among the LA Deli's, Canter's adds a layer of novelty with its classic decor and lit from above painted-glass ceiling. It just reeks of welcome to Los Angeles, circa the 50's and or 70's. They still have telephone jacks in the booths near the cashier.Anyway, I go here when I need my Corned Beef fix -- which I order on an onion roll, with a matzoh ball soup and a Cherry coke. Hits the spot, and I always end up with half a sandwich to take for later.

Reviews.Author: D- M.
Reviews.Content: Food was good, service was nice, business was crazy-busy good, but I could not enjoy at all. The place screams for a renovation and new dishes. The place is dingy and the FLOOR is VERY DIRTY. I am disappointed that so little real efforts has been put into up keeping the place for such a great business flow. I could not enjoy the food when the dinner is so dingy.The service was cool.

Reviews.Author: Michael C.
Reviews.Content: I'm surprised I only gave it four stars before. This place is an institution (and I know my way around an institution). I've taken a lot of friends here, and some of them weren't too happy. From one perspective, they have no one to blame but themselves for their experiences. But I also feel like a bad friend for not intervening on their behalves. I was remiss, distracted; partly by a morbid fascination with their poor menu choices, and maybe, possibly, by the fact that this 24hr spot often closes out a night of vice and dissipation (which it does exquisitely). Nothing like some soup and bagel chips to soothe the sting of potentials squandered in the damp corridors of one's favorite dive.You don't go into a Jewish deli and order a turkey melt, or a Philly cheesesteak -- do they look like they'd make a good cheesesteak? The turkey melt was dry? I wouldn't know, because I'd never order that crap here. They're just padding out the menu -- like adding a go-nowhere romantic subplot involving Dexter Morgan's sister.It's all about the roast beef, liver, tongue, and cured meats. Classic shit -- stuff invented before refrigeration. If you want some ahistorical all-American fare, Denny's is that'a way, good sir or madam.The place itself struggles to clue you in that it resides in a time bubble (like the "Shining" house); with a decor and sassy waitstaff both owing a debt to the '70s.If you read this review, and you still order the Hawaiian Burger, or Teriyaki Bowl, I don't have any words of consolation. Instead, I'll match your disappointment with my own -- in your lack of cultural savvy.

Reviews.Author: Liz S.
Reviews.Content: One star is generous. Half a star is because it is an institution, the other half is because the ceiling and booth panelling is this amazingly tacky & awesome fall foliage pattern.The food sucks. Its horrible. A huge waste of money, time, chewing energry. I know this not Chowhound but come on. How does a cook fuck up hummus? I have not had food this bad since 1999 when I drove through Green River Utah. The roasted chicken was drier than a bone. My husband had to give me some spaghetti sauce of his plate, and I heflty used the salt and pepper just so I could make it eatable. I am not being mellow dramatic - it was really that bad. I would go to swinger's late night anytime over this place.

Reviews.Author: Ashleigh Q.
Reviews.Content: MEH!Not up to the hype, yes, it's open 24/7, no, it is not the place Jesus would go to eat.The food is inconsistent, waiters get your order wrong half the time (not complicated either, mainly you ask for a side of potato salad and get not potato salad, then they argue you did order the other thing rather then get you what you order.) The cheesecake is nasty and dry, everything is over priced, and when you do get a good meal it's overshadowed by all the other lame ones.Go once, then move on.

Reviews.Author: Kathy O.
Reviews.Content: The sandwiches have gotten smaller, prices have gone up and the days of endless pickles are over.  Sometimes we're lucky if we get one plate of them.  For those not familiar with the building, it used to be a theater back in the day.  They're trying to overhaul the menu for younger customers, but really alienating the rest of us.  As for the service, it's been famously known for the most unfriendly servers since the doors opened.  Some of us remember the old pink uniforms they used to wear with the little white caps.  I often chuckle to my family I'm from NY and couldn't be that rude if I tried.  But that's not all their servers, just some.  It is what it is.  The food mostly is good, just know that it's not what it once was.  Either make the portions smaller, or raise your prices, but doing both isn't right.

Reviews.Author: Danny F.
Reviews.Content: Parking is free for 1.5 hours with validation if you eat at the restaurant but I parked on the street since it was late and free.A completely casual deli that looks like it has never been remodeled or redecorated since it opened.  Even the cash register is ancient.  I had the California burger with fries.  It's a restaurant style burger with mushrooms, avocados, lettuce and tomatoes. The burger was thick but dry. It taste okay after adding some spicy mustard, pepper and salt.  Was not impressed. My fiancée had their pastrami on rye.  The meat tasted good so definitely order this if you're going there.  I for one do not like pastrami on rye as rye is too dry.  I still prefer the pastrami dip from The Hat.The complimentary pickles tasted funny.  The water they had them sitting in might not have been the cleanest.   The service was good. No complaints there.  The hostess and cashier person both were really nice too.  They even gave us a coupon because it was our first visit.

Reviews.Author: Bob S.
Reviews.Content: One big plus for Canter's is that it found close to the Grove. So if you are looking for some variety to the Grove's offering, Canter's will give you that. If you are in the area and your posse can't decide on what type of food to eat, Canter's has a huge menu that will satisfy everyone's cravings. Canter's is not a gourmet deli by any stretch of the imagination. I found the food to be satisfying but not great.  Canter's offers a big selection of average food with the highlight being the  24/7 hours. What more can be said?

Reviews.Author: Jess B.
Reviews.Content: The waitress was snarky.The pickles were crunchy.  And tangy.The matzoh balls were giant and chewy.The rye bread was soft and pillowy.The corned beef was warm and salty.The coleslaw wasn't mayonnaise-y and seasoned sweetly.The rugalach were chocolatey.The Dr. Browns diet cream soda was exemplary.The waitress, however, perhaps the most exemplary.  And Brooklyn-y.

Reviews.Author: Ian C.
Reviews.Content: People have legit gripes about the spotty quality of the food and service, but this is THE place I'd always go to eat with my dad in my whelp (not Yelp*) days.  The day after Father's Day, you best believe it's get anything less than a perfect rating, even if this review will be useless to you.Personally, I don't know why anyone wastes their time with anything other than the brisket, Russian on the side (Ian C. makes pointing gesture to the skies, like baseball players do after hitting home runs, or football players do after TDs).

Reviews.Author: Alex B.
Reviews.Content: Best matzo-ball soup I've ever had. (Just don't tell my grandmother.)Canter's on Fairfax is not only a great place to eat, but a part of history. As of this year, Canter's Delicatessen and Restaurant is celebrating 80 years of service! Amazing.This place may seem a bit pricey, but the taste of the food items you receive are worth every penny. A friend of mine and I just went. We each had matzo-ball soup, and spit a pastrami sandwich on rye (Served with 6 large slices of dill pickle) and a plate of french fries. The bill came out to around $31, roughly $15 per person. The deli sliced pastrami had the perfect fat to meat ratio, and was melt-in-your-mouth good! (Nothing is worse than pastrami that too fatty.)In all, Canter's offeres wonderful Jewish and American food as well as a full service New York style deli 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. You also get a fun dose of Hollywood atmosphere. Who knows who you'll see at 2 AM on a Wednesday night?This place is great!P.S. Have a hamentashen from the bakery! (It's a delicious filled cookie.)

Reviews.Author: David S.
Reviews.Content: I admit, when I lived in H'wood in my early 20s, I frequented Canter's after getting my drink on in order to get some greasy, satisfying food in my belly. Then I sobered up (literally and figuratively).Why would I want to 1) fight for a crappy parking spot at the lot next door or face a long trek to the restaurant after having to park on the one residential street where there is an available spot; 2) get in and wait for some surly old bag to show us to our dirty, smelly table next to some dirty, smelly patrons; 3) wait an eternity for another grumpy old crone to come by and get drinks, begrudgingly take our orders, and finally, serve them up; 4) eat poor quality, overrated food that can only satisfy someone with a BAC over 0.15; 5) and then suffer the biggest insult when you get the bill and they expect you to pay for this experience?!I'd rather pay the premium to go to Jerry's or just do it up right at Fromin's.I did dig the little bar area in the back, though....

Reviews.Author: Denis S.
Reviews.Content: I really like this place.  But it's important to remember when its appropriate.  It's not a good "date place" nor is it fine dining or healthy.  It's a deli that's open 24 hours a day.  It has an enormous menu that is guaranteed to clog the arteries.  And if you're still alive afterward, it has an even more amazing dessert selection, with more cookies, cupcakes, breads, and pastries than you'll ever know what to do with (though eating them is a good start).The servers are nice to you if you're nice to them, the place can get somewhat crowded and somewhat loud, and the people are as varied as LA has (old, young, westside, downtown, hollywood, etc...)

Reviews.Author: Amy K.
Reviews.Content: As a vegetarian, I can't review the pastrami, matzo ball soup...or a lot of other things.  I've had the latkes, and they were ok (got a bit of ribbing from the server about putting ketchup on them, I swear I'm not a gentile!), and last night I had the avocado sandwich: avocado, sprouts, tomato, hold the cheese for me.  I was pleased that they loaded on the avocado and didn't give me two inches of sprouts.  It came with fries or chips; I asked if the fries had been prepared in the same oil as animal products; the server told me I didn't want the fries.  Chips then, for me.  The sandwich was what you'd expect, in that it wasn't particularly special, but satisfying.I was with a group of 20, which Canter's handled well, and they had us off in the side room next to the Kibbitz Room, where other patrons were shielded from us and we could hear the live music from the bar.  Our food came out quickly and everybody was happy.  I couldn't resist visiting the bakery counter; everything looks so good it was tough, but I ended up with one of those large cookies with a chocolate dollop.  It was ok, I've had better.  Probably won't stop me from picking something ELSE up, though.  I still don't get why some people think Canter's is a mecca.

Reviews.Author: Forrest D.
Reviews.Content: I've only eaten here in the middle of the night when I was working in Htown, so I was usually tired and hungry which may have made the food taste better than it actually was. It's still pretty good though, and i'm a little biased because I always ordered the Monte Cristo but changed the meat so they'd call it by my name all the years I'd come in. Suck up to those customers:)Never really had to pay for the meals because it was comped from our company but the prices are fairly high even for deli food. I'd probably rate this a 4 star for the food, but dropped it down for the rather high prices.Plus this is an LA institution, so it's worth visiting just for the history.Cool bar next door, actually it's just a room and it's kindof a dump but its got good vibe. Good desserts in the deli, and there always a good people watching scene even at one in the morning.Food - B+Ambience - BService - B+Value - C+

Reviews.Author: Danster L.
Reviews.Content: My friend is going to hate me for giving Canter's a two-star rating but I had high expectations since a MSN article stated that Canter's deli had some hot pastrami sandwiches and bread. My friend and I tried the chicken breast and pastrami sandwich and both were bleh. The bread was hard, dry and nothing special. The place looks like something out of the 60s and the worst part was you have to pay for parking! But I think parking is free if you do eat at Canter's if you show the receipt I believe.The biggest complaint has to be the prices. The prices are crazy and I cannot believe we paid 35 bucks for two sandwiches. I rather go to a fancy restaurant and pay that price for a higher quality with superb ingredients and bread. Nothing special here other than a stained glass ceiling which looks like it lights up at night making the restaurant look like a disco club.

Reviews.Author: Lisa B.
Reviews.Content: I have been going to Canter's since I was old enough to walk.  As a person who has been relatively without roots my whole life...this kind of history warrants some respect.Every time I go there, I have the same thing...my husband and I split pastrami on rye, matza ball soup, green tomatoes and wash it all down with a Heineken.I can't count the number of times I've spent post-party at the edge of .08 satisfying my alcohol induced munchies.  If you want a true twilight zone experience, it's best to wander in between 4AM and 5AM where the extreme revelers sit ,often with their dark shades on quietly wondering, "How did I get here?".Canters also houses a true Los Angeles institution...The Kibbitz Room.  Everyone from The Doors, Hendrix, Guns & Roses, etc. have played in this small, dingy and beloved watering hole.The food is yummy, well-priced and I still wonder how the hell they figure out what they need in stock to support their tome of a menu. If you're feeling at all dizzy...take my advice...DON'T look up at the ceiling.  If you haven't been there...GO!

Reviews.Author: Torie Y.
Reviews.Content: That was a mean pastrami sandwich! The meat was piled high on that nice rye. I couldn't stop eating the bagel chips that came with my friend's matzo ball soup. I'd never actually had it before, but now I see why it's considered comfort food. Add those spicy little pickles and you've got yourself a satisfying meal.Service was great. Our waiter was patient with us while we perused those huge menus, and was fast and courteous.The desserts in the display cases looked delicious. Too bad we were too full, otherwise I would have loved to try that black & white cookie.

Reviews.Author: Lloyd B.
Reviews.Content: Five, ten, fifteen, even twenty years later this place has always stayed the same...absolutely amazing. The food is great and the service is super friendly.I order breakfast just about every time I eat here. Today was no different. It was the corn beef hash and hash browns with eggs over hard and the oh so simple but unbelievably wonderful chicken noodle soup. The corn beef hash looked like a brick but it was so savory. It was slightly crispy on the outside and on the inside. It was just plain delicious without being salty. The hash browns were comprised of scalloped potatoes. Their edges were slightly crispy and cooked perfectly.The cup of chicken noodle soup was exactly how you expect it to taste. Lots of noodles and flavorful without being salty.  The bagel chips provided with the soup are great for dipping.The dessert counter to the left as you walk in has an incredible selection of cookies, pastries and cakes. The gentleman behind the counter was funny, friendly and offered numerous samples of everything and anything.BTW, this place is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Another great place for comfort food.

Reviews.Author: Christopher B.
Reviews.Content: I happened to be in the area and it's tough to not stop in and get a sandwich. It was a little cool out so I was completely craving a matzo ball soup. Not to mention that I like the kitschy atmosphere that takes me back several decades (or more!). The matzo ball soup was pretty much spot on. I don't know if it's the best I've ever had but it's pretty close! We ended up getting the Brooklyn Ave, which is a corned beef and cole slaw on rye. You could actually get other meats but this is what we opted for. I just absolutely love the fresh bread with the crunchy crust! That is what arguably makes the sandwich but everything inside of it is delicious as well. I never thought this combo would do it for me (I'm not a big cole slaw fan) but this is one of my favorite options!It's hard to rip on this place as every time I go it's fantastic! I know it could be a bit pricey but it's legendary and they could probably justify charging a bit more than other similar places. That's okay... I'm more than willing to pay more for a sandwich like this!(And yes, the pickles are damn good!).

Reviews.Author: Phil R.
Reviews.Content: I grew up walking by Canter's every day on my way home from Laurel Elementary School to my family's apartment on Orange Grove Ave. I'd pop in to buy gumballs and play with the machine that sold those little horoscope scroll thingies just so I could smell the bakery smell. I loved that smell. I go every six months these days. The line is never that long. The hostess is always maternally gruff. The waiters are always colorful and friendly. The Brooklyn Ave (Pastrami and Coleslaw on Rye) is predictably awesome (especially with the Russian Mustard on the table and those uniquely acidy pickles that this place serves). The pastrami is lean and just at that perfect temperature, and the rye bread is chewy and crusty. The potato pancakes are crispy, plump in the middle, served with thick sour cream and apple sauce. On the way out, picked up Rugelach  from the bakery counter. For the uninitiated, it's an awesome Jewish cookie thing that is the perfect combo of crispy, doughy, sweet, and either fruity or chocolaty (depending on the flavor). Grab a bag. Some notes - Try to sit in the main room (not the side dining area) so you can get a view of the 60s stained glass ceiling and mirrored old school desert counter. - Check out the telephone outlets hidden at each table behind the napkin dispenser - this place was Hollywood way before cell phones! They would bring a big old phone to your table and plug it in for you if you had a call. Talk about classy.- They have a crazy low price on Coors Light Drafts. I hate that beer but always drink it here because it just 'goes' with the place.- Make sure to use the bathroom, located upstairs. It's straight out of a 30s movie set and the winding hallway leading to it is covered in articles about this place printed over the decades.- Don't forget to pop into the Kibitz Room, the bar attached to the place, to check out a totally psychedelic black light mural.

Reviews.Author: Raphael C.
Reviews.Content: After 60 years, Canter's Delicatessen is still around. And it probably will be around long after you are dead. So say what you will about this place, like a giant tortoise it will outlast you in the long run. People come to this Los Angeles Landmark for several reasons.  They come for the nostalgia of the old golden age of Hollywood, or have hopes of seeing an aging celebrity, or bumping into a Yiddish Hip-Hop star, but not really for the food.  The Décor is what you expect of an old diner that has seen its glory days pass long ago.  But the ceiling is quite fun.       This Jewish Deli serves food that is simple and traditional.  Nothing on the menu is anything special, but some dishes are better than others.  You may be tempted to order the "World Famous" Corned Beef and Cabbage with boiled potato. (Bland and mediocre)  or the Pastrami Sandwich (extremely dry) or one of the many dishes named after dead celebrities and areas of New York City.  But for $15 a plate, I would invest my hard earned money elsewhere.  Avoid these items like you would your estranged sibling.I do recommend the Chopped Liver and Onions on Rye, the Stuffed Cabbage, the Matzo Ball Soup, and the Roast Tongue with potato pancakes.  Far better than the other stuff and I feel less ripped off when I get these dishes.And last time I went here I ran into the Mayor of the Sunset Strip himself... Ladies and Gentlemen Mr. Rodney Bingenheimer.  Not surprised but I still bow in reverence.      So, its overpriced and the food is not spectacular. But when its 3AM and you feel like getting a decent home-style meal in an old school joint you have came to the right place.  The Food has remained the same for 60 years. Regrettably the prices have not. Recommended

Reviews.Author: Kelly B.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is a superstar of classic LA dinning. The low budge (but not low budget) environment has remained consistent in my lifetime -which is just a wink in Canter's history- complete with the beyond kitschy backlit autumn leave printed tile ceiling, surly waitresses, free pickles and flirty old men.Kosher-style delicatessens are notoriously non-vegetarian friendly... but latkes are notoriously delicious. I always get a disapproving look when I ask for no sour cream and extra apple sauce (but I would never put ketchup on them, sorry Amy K. but that IS inappropriate) One bummer is that the cookies from the bakery cost more if you want to eat them sitting at table. Seriously my friend bought them at the counter and the waitress freaked out and asked her for more cookie money when we tried to sit down.... lady it's just a cookie.

Reviews.Author: Christine C.
Reviews.Content: Canter's pretty much serves its purpose of being a decent 24-hour deli and bakery in LA. Their menu can be confusing as they list items all over the place and have an overflowing menu of items to choose from. While not terrible, the food is just alright. It's nothing really spectacular, as if you really wanted good pastrami or breakfast items there are far more superior choices in the city, however they won't be open at all odd hours of the day.Speaking of odd, be prepared for a lot of weirdos that hang out at the place, especially at night and in the early morning hours.Also of note, the Kibbitz room hosts some pretty good musical acts and is regularly gigged and attended by seasoned session musicians and noteworthy musicians.

Reviews.Author: Nick Y.
Reviews.Content: For true, old-school Los Angeles, and I mean from the old days, you have to come to Canter's.  My parents used to come here on dates when they were my age, and I highly doubt that they've changed a single thing about this place since then.I have been back and forth across this country of ours and I have never found a corned beef or pastrami sandwich as amazing as here at Canter's.  These sandwiches are just piled sky-high with meat and are incomparable to any sandwich of its kind I've ever had.  I will make the trek into West LA just to lay my hands upon them.  And make sure to ask for pickles, as no good corned beef sandwich would be complete without a side of deliciously cold and crisp pickles.  The matzo ball soup rounds out this perfectly complete deli meal.Being West LA, prices are higher than you'd expect from your average delicatessen, and snobby folks are probably going to complain about the service and decor.  But look, if you're going to just order a cappuccino, you need people doting on you every five minutes, or are the type that you're afraid to get your hands a little dirty... don't come here.  If you want a true old Los Angeles experience, then by all means make the trip.  You won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Author: Keila N.
Reviews.Content: I used to go here a lot more when I was younger.  This place has a great deli/bakery section.  I'm not much of a deli fan, but I absolutely love the matzo ball soup here.I make my own matzo ball soup, but Canter's kicks it down old school.  Its matzo ball soup is hearty with lots of noodles and huge matzo balls.  It's very filling.  Its corn beef cabbage is also excellent.

Reviews.Author: Linda C.
Reviews.Content: Canter's, you can, I can, we all can!Honestly, I should probably wait till I get a sandwich from here to be plastering my unwanted review all over yelp...but oh well -- shoulda, coulda, woulda! So, I'm going to subject you to my madness!moooooooo-ha-ha-ha.Scurry! Anyhow, the parking lot is nice at this place but still ALLLLLWWWWAAAAAYS packed -- but where in LA is it not, right? The surrounding area on Fairfax is kinda interesting. Not that it isn't safe, but I found it surprising that there weren't more people around on a Sunday afternoon. Oh well!I mainly sampled from their baked goods case and the almond paste bear claw was super yummy and huge. The service was sweet -- the guy reminded me of a quirky family member, commenting on how I should just pick a pastry, because i'll "love them all". LOLI'm going to give a generic 3* rating until I can come back and try the food at this location. First impressions are good, but now I have to find some new friends to get my drink on with so I can come to Canter's at 3 AM for some Matzo Ball Soup and a Pastrami! :P

Reviews.Author: Teresa N.
Reviews.Content: I expected so much more from an establishment that's been around for so long. We ordered the Reuben, hot corned beef, and side of onion rings. The Reuben sandwich is pastrami with Swiss cheese and sauerkraut on grilled rye. It was arguably the best dish we ordered. The problem is it wasn't even that good. Oi! The hot corned beef is two slices of rye bread with beef. I took a bite and the crust was freaking hard! It seriously scratched my palate! A wave of nostalgia swept over me just by looking at the size of the sandwich. I thought I was back in kindergarten and carrying peanut butter and jelly sandwich for lunch. What the hell did I just pay for?! The onion rings were delicious but please serve more than six rings.I might come back for desserts but I think I will pass on the food.

Reviews.Author: Dianne C.
Reviews.Content: I absolutely LOVE LOVE the MISH MOSH here, the MATZO BALL and broth in it is completely to die for! We drive all the way from OC just for this! A meal itself considering the portion size. Also very convenient  that this deli/restaurant is open 24/7!!!!

Reviews.Author: Ruth A.
Reviews.Content: Comfort food:  Canter's corned beef on rye with lots of mustard.    It's somehow better at 3 am, I don't know why.  Ogle the stuff in the bakery counter.  I have never eaten any of it, but I have sure had a good time looking at it.   There's every imaginable Jewish baked good, from babka to rugeleh.  If you crave those things, this is a good place to look for them.Some folks don't like Canter's.  It isn't kosher, it's past it's prime, it's too this or too that, blah, blah, blah.  For me, it's an LA treasure, somewhere to go and get my bearings.  Or some more of that cole slaw.  Whatever.

Reviews.Author: Lynn C.
Reviews.Content: The biggest thing is the price doesn't match the quality. But both aren't all that bad. The price is not to bad and the quality is not that great. I just like the old time feel. The menu does have some hidden gems though.Take your chances, its sometimes fun to leave it all up to fate. And hey, anything tastes good after having drinks in the kibitz room and then sauntering next store to this hollywood staple.

Reviews.Author: Stephen T.
Reviews.Content: I have been here at least five times.  On two separate occasions, in 2005 and in 2008, I thought I was letting out a harmless post-meal fart, and I pooped in my pants.  But it wasn't poop, it was clear viscous fluid.  This has never happened to me anywhere else but at Canter's.  I did some research and wonder if they use Olestra or some other fat substitute.  But I do love this place otherwise.  I just need to wear a diaper if I go.Update:  I was reading some of the reviews on here and found someone else who also got sick.  We both had the reuben.  This may or may not be a coincidence.

Reviews.Author: C S.
Reviews.Content: We used to have a morning business meeting here - though the wait staff are all lovely and helpful, the management is a surly, unpleasant woman who would go out of her way to be unhelpful and treated her staff like crap.  Frankly the food is also mediocre - storied history or not.There are much better Jewish delis out there - food and atmosphere-wise.

Reviews.Author: Mr. Ra Ra A.
Reviews.Content: Out late with some friends and family, we needed to grab a late night bite before heading home.  The majority of our party was Jewish (I stood out like foreskin), and from out of town, so they were dying for the world famous Canter's.  Who was I to say no?I love this place... This and Jerry's are my two faves in SoCal.  My mouth is watering over my favorite thing in the world... an old-fashioned patty melt!  Saliva is dripping on the menu.  The waitress is not amused.But oy, look at the time!  I think it's been six or seven years since I could down a patty melt loaded with onions at 3:30 in the morning and then head right off too bed.  When I try that nowadays I have weird sex dreams about Ralph Nader.  No, I'm not having sex with Ralph, but he's watching. [shudder]So I wuss out and go for the grilled cheese.  But at Canter's, it's still yummy.  And in my dreams it's only Roseanne Barr watching me have sex.  With Ali Larter from Heroes.  Life is good.  Thank you grilled cheese gods.

Reviews.Author: Jon H.
Reviews.Content: My buddies and I used to go here in the wee hours of the morning to grab a bite to eat. More than often we left full to our ears and we couldn't go back to sleep anyways.Get the pastrami/corned beef stack, and the potato salad. We've driven out at 3am just to get a potato salad- its THAT good. Its also real famous, been in a ton of movies, and its been open for like 90 years, 24hrs a day. Gotta love the abrasive old lady staffing as the waitresses, people calling you "honey", and the really great quality food in a great environment.Love Canters. Get a t-shirt and enjoy it.

Reviews.Author: Ryan M.
Reviews.Content: This place, for the lack of words can only be describe as a Marty McFly....yeah I said it, no Michael J. Fox with Parkinson's disease. A 70's esque diner, opened to patrons from wee-hours in the morning, to the night owls of the evening, it's a deli to be reckoned with. Steve and friends (including myself), needed to come here after our encounter with the House of Blues scene on a Friday/Saturday evening, over the summer time.All that alcohol, in my sewage system needed some kind of absorbing efficient material to gather dilute and pollute the toilet sometime later, and this was the spot to do it. We looked though the menu and ordered the following:-1 order of French Fries-1 order of French Dip Sandwich-1 order of Pastrami Sandwich-1 order of Canter's Reuben.Excuse my ignorance (or lack of knowledge for a better term), but considering another place I procrastinated on writing about my views may be a bit skewered so here we go. The fries, nothing special something I can order from Denny's. The French Dip, according to Steve was alright...the beef was a bit dry on his part, and considering the dryness to the bread it did not help either.
