My Pastrami sandwich, it was large in portion....grilled texture was on point. The Pastrami, a bit excessive considering the humongous portion (and I believe this goes along with all their sandwiches). No wonder it costs me almost a fine penny to sink at least half of it in the dwellings of my stomach. As for the Canter's Reuben.....it was decent, kind of smooth with the mixes of meat (I think it was the corn beef that did the trick), but not my type of thing.Overall, we spent a whopping $54.00 on four different sandwiches and a side of fries, with some drinks. Wow...and I thought Sandwiches were supposed to be cheap. If it wasn't for the novelty, and maybe the good consistent service...this place would have gotten a two from me without a doubt. The bread needs to be grilled...instead of toasted to accommodate to the dryness of the meat being stuffed. That's just my opinion all I could recall is getting repeat orders of water because it was that dry, not my cup of tea.Canter's you would do well, in my book of the meat and bread wasn't so dry for the most part. I'll give you a shot the next time I'm in the City of Angels to redeem yourself.

Reviews.Author: Nick P.
Reviews.Content: A reason to fall in love with LA again.  I started going here about 12 years ago, and even then it was THE place to be in the evening after a night of partying.  My favorite place to sit has always been the middle room, so adorned with 70's style record-looking-thingies on the walls.  Lately, however, I've been eating in the main dining room, the same room used in a recent Carl's Jr. commercial.  Finally, don't forget the Kibitz Room... a fun place to hang out on a weekend evening when they have live music.  The food is mediocre, and the service can be horrendous (some of the waitresses may very well be as old as the restaurant itself), but the atmosphere is the reason to go.  You just feel like you're in a 1960's LA.

Reviews.Author: Alexa B.
Reviews.Content: I think I kind of had my hopes up for this place after being told by an 86-year old, long-time LA-resident that this was the equivalent of NYC's Carnegie deli. I'm here to tell you that it is not. In no way is this a deli. It is a diner, serving diner food at restaurant prices. I would not spend a dime here on the dining experience again... even if it is a landmark (there's absolutely nothing special about the decor, and does not give you the experience of being at a "landmark" deli).I have, however, not tried the bagels. Having not had a really good bagel in years and years, I will come back and pick up a couple and see if they can do justice to their reviews. Next time...

Reviews.Author: Morgan D.
Reviews.Content: Why I love Canter's part 1:I had an interesting conversation with a retired bra manufacturer that I can't exactly remember because I was drunk and it was in the wee hours of the morning.  I only remember the way he walked.  Well, not so much walked as slowly shuffled.  I ate a sandwich and he talked about the glory days of underwear.  It was magical. Why I love Canter's part 2:The waitresses don't mess around.  They can even be described as bitchy, but in a charming sort of way.Why I love Canter's part 3:I had 3 roommates when I lived in LA and we were a diverse group.  Canter's pleased a Gentile, a Jew, a Korean, and a Filipino.  Come on, that's pretty good.  Why I love Canter's part 4:Waking up the next morning to find a pink bakery box of goodies in the kitchen that I forgot I purchased the night before.  Why I love Canter's part 5:Open 24 hours.  It looks used and lived in, like Vegas during the day.  That is part of the charm.

Reviews.Author: Wayne H.
Reviews.Content: I get the deli, I get the bakery.Maybe what I don't yet get is the Jewish diner concept.  When I think diners I think Frisco's, malt shoppe and roller skates.   But any place that serves pastrami in massive quantities is alright with me.The place is a Los Angeles landmark.  Years ago, when I was working in entertainment analytics in mid-Wilshire, I'd tag along with a few coworkers on their weekly Canter's runs.  The matzo ball soup and pastrami reuben were always popular with us.  I never do like coleslaw.You might have also noticed that its interior was featured in movies and television shows. I've had the honor of dining on several occasions at the table featured on Entourage.

Reviews.Author: Karl K.
Reviews.Content: Visited this place a few months back, after prior drive-by's (and hearing about its storied past).  All in all, an OK establishment.We split a pastrami and corned beef sandwich with one order of chicken and noodle soup, and one kreplach.   Pro:It's open 24 hoursPrivate lot with parking attendant (I think you have to pay a few bucks, but at least someone's watching your car).Con:The food was only average (compared to Jewish delis in New York).The kreplach (small piece of chicken dumpling wrapped with a matzo coating) was uninspired, and the noodles in their chicken noodle soup tasted factory made.  The pastrami pales in comparison to Katz's in New York.Indeterminate:They did have two impressive display cases of pastries and traditional delicacies (such as smoked pike fish), but we weren't hungry enough to take the plunge. I suppose this place is worth checking out at least once.

Reviews.Author: Anthony S.
Reviews.Content: Now, this place hails to a time before there were supermarkets. You can go here for your deli needs. The bread. And if you fancy a swig of the booze, it's here too.Where else can you go at any hour for a little lox on the bagel. Here!This place is, by far, one of my favorite places to go, but I hardly go there. Sad to say folks. Let this be my honorable mention.

Reviews.Author: Iron M.
Reviews.Content: How this place doesn't get 5 stars I'll never know. The best thing is the pastrami on rye with steak fries and sweet tea... you can't go wrong! This place has been here for like a thousand years and has NEVER skipped a beat. Go solo, go on a date on Saturday night, or anytime during thew week, you won't be disappointed. A real Jewish deli and bakery feel... almost a taste of New York right in Los Angeles... Love it! OBTW, I've been a loyal customer for decades and I highly recommend Canter's!

Reviews.Author: Amy S.
Reviews.Content: When it's late, when you've been drinking, when you're wandering the city hoping food will appear, someone will eventually say, "well, there's always Canter's." And you hem and you haw, and sometimes you just end up here. It happens.Their food's okay. It's nothing spectacular, but it's nothing awful. I'm a sucker for blintzes so I'm always happy. But why is it so freaking expensive? It's mediocre deli food! Mediocre deli food should NOT cost so much!Regardless though, I am glad they're always an option.

Reviews.Author: Megan N.
Reviews.Content: I love Canters. They're always open, huge menu that rarely (if ever?) changes, so all of their dishes are well prepared. I've never had a bad meal here and their portions are enormous! The ceiling is kinda trippy. The first time I ate here it was at like 3am and I had been drinking and it was all I could do to not stare at it!! Good service, VERY eclectic crowd (I saw trannys here for the first time!), celebrity sightings, 5 minute drive from my apartment & easy parking too!!It's one of my favorite places!

Reviews.Author: Pete R.
Reviews.Content: So I'm deliberating between 3 and 4 stars here... the food quality is pretty good, particularly their specialties - corned beef sandwiches, matzo ball soup, mish-mosh. Service is generally good, they serve cocktails, and they're open 24 hours. All of this puts it in the 4-star range.But for Pete's (my) sake, why is it so goddamn expensive?!! I know this place is famous, but let's not forget what it actually is: an old, rundown diner that serves standard Jewish-diner fare. In an old rundown diner, how can a reuben sandwich with potato chips (not even fries!) cost $14? Or a grilled cheese for $8.75?Now, I love sandwiches more than I love some people, and I'm willing to spend a little extra for a great one. But in 28 years of life, I have yet to come across any sandwich that's worth $14. Come on guys, that's ridiculous.Price gouging pisses me off. 3 stars.

Reviews.Author: Eric M.
Reviews.Content: I awoke to a sore throat, a congested sinus and a cough bad enough to justify calling in sick on this Wednesday. After flipping in between the Price is Right, Rachel Ray, and the same Sports Center over and over again, I became hungry. My number one remedy to put a halt to a on-coming cold is the matzo ball soup at Canter's.I arrive before the lunch crowd and while I have been to Canter's dozens of times I still marvel at the unique ceiling as if it were my first time. The matzo ball soup arrives with a side of bagel chips. I sip the broth and like magic, I am breathing clear once again. I eat a piece of my huge matzo ball and my mouth begins to hum "Fly Me to the Moon" by Sinatra. I don't know what goes into making this matzo ball but its seasoned so delicately that the salt comes to you in small refined bursts. After finishing my soup, I am feeling much better and am ready to go back home and take a nap while I have The Godfather plays in the background. And who knows, if I still feel sick later tonight I just might be back for more matzo ball soup.Overall, Canter's is an L.A. institution that serves the best deli food. The corned beef sandwich is scrumptious, the Cobb salad with blue cheese dressing is fantastic, and the breakfast items after a night out in Hollywood is a perfect way to end the night or begin the morning, if you will.

Reviews.Author: Phil T.
Reviews.Content: 2 stars. what a diappointment. I was expecting really great deli food. Guess I got caught up in the hype of this LA legend. I ordered the corned beef and cabbage, which is a dish that I love but dont have too often. For some reason I have a hard time finding place that serve this dish. The corned beef tasted fine but man was it watery. I had a puddle of water on my plate. I guess they dont drain the cabbage when they plate. The corned beef was ok. Not the greatest and certainly not what I was expecting from such a well known deli. This was a disappointing meal. I wouldnt bother to come back. Too far from where I live and not worth the hassle.

Reviews.Author: Taryn E.
Reviews.Content: Yummy Comfort foods and my favorite place when I have a sweet tooth craving!  I like to try one of everything in the bakery section.  Such a vast assortment of cookies & other savory baked sweets:p  As for the deli section my bf & I always go for the Canter's Fairfax Sandwich- I never would have tried it had it not been for my bf's persistence.  I always stuck with corn beef sandwhiches on (the best) sourdough bread or the good 'ol classic Reuben Sandwich:)  I'm sorry Jerry's Famous Deli but Canters is now my late night cravings ultimate go-to.  I'm never dissatisfied with Canter's.  My next deli to try is "Langner's" - I saw it on the food channel and according to the bf it too is a treasured legacy if I want to go all out & indulge in the greatest Pastrami Sandwich ever.-T

Reviews.Author: Michael E.
Reviews.Content: They didn't have corn tortillas, hence, they don't serve tacos.  And ordered a screwdriver which was served in a small glass full of ice.Not worth the $6.  Plus, they don't serve tacos.They do however have some damn good meatloaf and mashed potatoes,and that is something I recommend to you. One star for their pickles. One star for their meatloaf. And one star for being openwhile all other places are usually closed.

Reviews.Author: Sam G.
Reviews.Content: KATZ Deli = 5 StarsCanter's Deli = 0 StarsHaving lived in LA for 40 years, this was my first try eating at Canter's.  It was the worst $17 sandwich I ever had.  This place is a tourist trap and way OVERRATED!  It is open 24/7, therefore, there is really no time to clean anything, so the place is super dirty.  We sat down that had to flagged our server down to take our order, the service was horrible and they seemed a little arrogant, I guess we are no movie stars or anybody famous.  As for the food (pastrami and corned beef) both were dry and really that flavorful.  The rye bread was hard and cold, was not impress.  On top of that, I caught a stomach bug from eating their food.  Avoid this place, save your money, go somewhere else.

Reviews.Author: Heather H.
Reviews.Content: I have been to Canter's once and only once in my entire life, on a road trip in the middle of the night.  I vaguely remember thinking that a too old woman was singing in the lounge and that there were lots of old men and lots of smoke.  Here's the thing though, the thing that would make me drive into L.A.: my father used to bring home their cheesecake when he was driving from Santa Clara to Phoenix.  I crave their cheesecake.  I try to describe to New Yorkers what kind of heaven this cheesecake is, that the deli sells it by length and weight, that it is unlike the cheesecakes made in New York.  No one gets it and everyone is skeptical.  Well, they can bite me.  Even when I eat the best of what NYC has to offer, I dream of Canter's.

Reviews.Author: Beth W.
Reviews.Content: Despite the neighborhood looking like a dive, we still drop by here for a delicious Jewish deli meal!  Huge mounds of pastrami on rye, matzo ball soup with broth that you can only dream about, bakery items that we purchase by the pound and carefully take back to NorCal....this is what I'm talking about folks....The hubby, who is from Redondo Beach, first introduced this NorCal gal to Canter's a million years ago....fast forward....bringing the kiddies to Disneyland via Canters and a tradition was born!  Despite the tired cafeteria looks, the place still delivers on taste and aroma.  Its kitty corner from the world famous Farmer's Market and CBS studio.  Park in the validated lot adjacent to the deli and make sure you have the waitress get your tix validated before you leave.  The neighborhood has really gone down since my first visit but that does not deter our family from going here....during daytime hours only.....not interested in going here at night....Rugalah, seven layer cake, mandol broit (small biscotti like cookies), all kinds of delicious breads and pastries....they are all worth trying!

Reviews.Author: Matthew C.
Reviews.Content: I came here with very low expectations.  I am a recent transplant from NYC and have the bias that good pastrami can only be made within the confines of Manhattan.I was pleasantly surprised.First, the rye bread.  It was fresh, redolent of caraway seeds and had a terrific crust.  Really good.We had pastrami and corned beef.  The corned beef was excellent.  The pastrami was better.  Flavorful without being too fatty.  Spicy.  Incredible.We also had the matzoh ball soup.  I think that they used real chicken fat in the matzoh balls and they were really tasty.Service was very nice.

Reviews.Author: Adriana K.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is a much loved staple of the Fairfax District.  Cultural landmark.As well it should be!While my grandmother passed quite some time ago, I still remember walking with her to Canter's when I was a child.  It seems to me that it's been here forever.  I took Canter's for granted for many many years - driving by and assuming that it's still the same cafeteria type fare.  But recently, friends started suggesting Canter's as a late night place to grub.  Plus, Canter's is the only place I know of that knows how to make blintzes, latkes, and brisket well enough to satisfy even the most particular of Jewish peeps.  So so good!  And the portions are ginormous.  Plus, the waiter gave us a plate of deli pickles to snack on... nothing quite like crunchy kosher deli pickles.  I liked our last server, an older man, who reminded me of a straight-faced comedian - and made us all laugh a few times with various comments.Usually, I wouldn't like it, but here I like the fact that people at the next tables are all in your business (in a friendly way) and chit chat with you during brunch.  As a half-Jewish girl, I feel a sense of coming home when I go to Canter's. My favorite is the brisket, but I had the Avocado Mushroom Swiss omelette last time and it was yummy. Love that you can specify your bagel type - some places look at you like they've never heard that question before.Plus, they have an attached bar area and live music on the weekends.Don't miss their fantastic desserts - you could come just for that and the variety would pop a spring in your brain it all looks so good.

Reviews.Author: Lindsay H.
Reviews.Content: I don't mind vintage, but even my grandmother got rid of her ancient furniture and decor about a decade ago. (and her house doesn't smell as musty).I've ordered a few different sandwiches now and have yet to be impressed. Sure, they pile on the meat, but it's a damn expensive sandwich! And those complimentary pickles... now, I love pickles, but I can't help but wonder if the ones they just placed in front of me were left over from someone else's table... or the table before theirs... Canter's only saving grace is their bakery. And the free parking.

Reviews.Author: Bernadette H.
Reviews.Content: I had the Fairfax special (pastrami and corned beef sandwich) with my guy.It's probably the best pastrami and corned beef sandwich I can get outside of New York.  I really hate salty cold-cut sandwiches (too many of them taste like salt blocks to me), but this one was so perfect.  I didn't even get a sodium-induced headache, which happens when I eat something very salty and full of MSG.It was so big that the both of us were full after eating our halves.  And we're both big eaters, so that's saying a lot!Bonus points for the Guns 'N Roses photos on the wall!

Reviews.Author: Sam L.
Reviews.Content: A classic LA institution...I had a Groupon for this place... and since it's so classic LA it's always been a place that I wanted to check out.Honestly, I think the sign outside is the best part. It's adorable... vintage... old-fashioned... now if only everything could look that way... ::sigh::Anyway...The inside... is kind of old. Classic diner... but maybe more along the 80s-ish. The booths are more "beige" than retro 50s red... but whatever. There's also a lot of dark wood beams and paneling inside.At the very front, there is a deli counter and a bakery counter. No cannolis. Sad.Now for the food:Pretty spot on deli.I had a the downtowner.... which was pastrami on rye with melted swiss. Yum! The pastrami was perfect. Tender. Not too fatty. Yum!I think Pumpkie had the Fairfax? He had both pastrami and corned beef in his sandwich. I had to taste the corned beef... since I haven't had that in years. I've become way more of a Pastrami girl since then... but yeah... it was good too.The food was good and this place is open all night... which is good to know if I need to satiate some late night Pastrami cravings..However, I think I'll stick to Brent's as my regular go to deli place... since this place is a bit out of the way for me.

Reviews.Author: Daniel H.
Reviews.Content: Great breakfast joint. Got the corned hash with hash browns and eggs sunny side up with a side of short stack pancakes. Mix in the corned beef hash with the hash browns and eggs. Pour on the ketchup and tabasco for flavoring. It may not look tasty but it is zee bomb.

Reviews.Author: Tim R.
Reviews.Content: If you are a tourist, this is probably on your to see list but don't think its a must unless you're in the area (Fairfax District). If you are a local, you have probably been here. If not, worth visiting if you want that OG Jewish deli feeling. I've been here many times and I'm sure I will be back again. Its like a part of my annual visit to the Fairfax district.  The menu has your typical Jewish deli selection. Many sandwiches, Jewish delicacies, and soups, including the matzoh bowl. They also have some hot dishes, burgers, appetizers, and breakfast all day long. I usually get the half sandwich and half soup combo. This way I get to mix things up. Get my protein and veggies. My grandma always told me that soup is good for you. I hope I'm making her proud on every visit.  Everything that I've ever had here is good but not the best deli food I've had. I would say its average amongst other similar places I've been to. I just come here for that feeling of history and LA. from 1930's onward.  This place also has a full bar. Located on the right side of the second dining room. They do happy hour.   The service is whatever so don't come here expecting to be wowed or anything. Most of the waiters are retired women that don't seem like they want to be there. There a few exceptions that are very nice and sweet.  Make sure to ask for pickles to munch on before your food comes out and leave room for the sweets. They have many cakes and pies to choose from. They also have ice cream, floats, and shakes.On your way out, stop by the deli or bakery counters. Get some goodies to go. Perhaps a bunch of cookies and treats for you co-workers or something. Worth a visit.

Reviews.Author: Heath R.
Reviews.Content: A great place to stop for a bite after a movie at Cinefamily, which is just a block or two away. We hesitated by the cocktail lounge entryway, through which some jazz singing floated, but we went to the main dining room.I had a chocolate phosphate (!!!) and a hot corned beef sandwich. C. had water and the avocado, tomato, etc. sandwich. The corned beef sandwich, at $12, is basically a heap of meat, with two slices of rye bread for handles. Not sure if it was worth the money, but it was delicious, and I'll return to try other items.The pickles are on the sour side -- not as garlicky and cucumber as my faves in New York -- but get a plate, regardless.As good as the food is, and as skilled as the wait staff is -- these are hardcore, career waitresses -- look around at the other patrons and eavesdrop a little, if you can. To our right was a guy who was going to court to fight an eviction and restraining order. And a ways away were three felas who'd just gone to the comic shop (Golden Apple?). After making their buys, they went to Canter's to read and flip and chat.Open for 24 hours. Spend at least 30 minutes here.

Reviews.Author: Jennifer N.
Reviews.Content: One of LA's Historic venue.. love the feel when you're in there. But I didn't find the food as tasty as people claimed it to be. We had the tuna melt. $12.99 sandwiches and fries. They are not too generous on the fries.. haha. soda's are $2.50 a cup.. I think its overpriced for a diner type restaurant. Then I went to the bakery and wanted to get some pastries to go. They have no prices and no name tags and a lot of different varieties. What else am I going to do except for asking the cashier what it was, how much, is it good?.. etc. Outcome: Rude and impatient cashier at the bakery, the cashier was not friendly, no smiles, or thank you. Like she hated her job and it includes the customers. The waitress that serves us at the restaurant wasn't very friendly either... what's up with the place. Are they that stuck up or are they just racist because we are Asians?? Don't know what to say. I will never return again even though its open 24 hrs. P.s.- the pastries I bought home wasn't too tasty either...... aarrgg!!

Reviews.Author: Stacey S.
Reviews.Content: This place can be a pricey, but it's worth it (when you can afford it).Their bakery area is a place where you must stop by when you visit Canter's.I've heard their sandwiches are pretty ace, I personally can't weigh in on the matter because I fancy their giant bowls of salad and baked goods.I love the pickles they put on your table as you wait for your food (try eating only a plate full, I dare you).If you're looking for a home style restaurant open 24 hours, this is your place.

Reviews.Author: Kelly P.
Reviews.Content: I had the corned beef reuben. It was stacked with corned beef on delicious Jewish rye bread. It was nothing short of incredible. The matzo ball soup is a must-try. The matzo ball is a generous portion and very tasty. The bagels and lox are a nice compliment to any main course. I love the fact that Canter's is retro in terms of decor. I love the atmosphere inside. I can spend all day there. A sign of a great restaurant is amazing food and decor that stays the same in quality over the years. If a restaurant has to change its decor in order "to keep up with the times" it is not a good sign. It shows the owner is worried about staying open and just pulling out desperate gimmicks that really won't help. You are terrific just the way you are, Canter's. Stay classy and don't ever change! Btw prices are very reasonable considering it's open 24 hours. Similar restaurants are the same price. Great quality and portions for the money. Nice staff too.

Reviews.Author: Joie P.
Reviews.Content: A delicatessan delight.Truly memorable all hours of the day or night.  A surprising mix of people, waitress's that you won't find in just any other diner & the food does not disappoint.  Right down to the mega-flexible, tasteless kosher pickle.  Peppered beef, liverwurst, borscht, chopped liver.  How many places actually give you a choice of cheese for your grilled?  And how many have muenster just lying around for it?  Or how about nine different types of fish?  Maybe in a sushi restaurant but I have yet to see that many options on a diner or deli menu.  There is absolutely NO way you can go to Canter's and NOT find something to eat.  My fav is the BLT with a Jack n Coke.  If it's one of those windy, rainy, cold nights I'm more into a Hot Roast Turkey and Kahlua and milk to wash it all down.Comfort food.  It's what's for dinner.

Reviews.Author: Reza B.
Reviews.Content: I've been here a few times now and I come here because it's a landmark, not because the food is exceptional or because the service is memorable.  I think if you're looking for either of those you're better off going to Golden State (across the street) or Animal (a few doors down).I had the Corned Beef on Sour Dough and Roast Beef Sandwich on some other kind of bread plus some fries.The Corned Beef was not too shabby, but the Roast Beef was bland and the opposite of delicious.  The fries though were crispy and tasty, so... if you go there maybe get the fries why don't you.Anyway, overall, not a bad place, but unless you're coming off a tear through LA's bars and are craving comfort food/any food late at night, this place should not be #1 on your list of options. Canters is cool to experience, but should never be your go-to spot.

Reviews.Author: Chris A.
Reviews.Content: OK, I knew that lots of people would have written reviews on Canter's, actually I'm surprised that I'm only number 11, but if you've been to Graceland and other people are talkin' about Elvis, you gotta kick in!In a way, it's not right to actually rate Canter's.  I  mean, it's kind of like rating the Taj Mahal or the concept of religion.  Canter's was here BEFORE us, and it will be here AFTER us.  In fact, Canter's and cockroaches may be the only thing in this world that last long enough to see peace in the middle east.I LOVE the Pastrami and the pickles at Canters.  I also love the grumpy old waitresses.  In fact, here's a case of age discrimination for ya:  I get kinda sad when I get one of those new young servers.  I don't want a SERVER, I want a 900 year old WAITRESS!!So back to the food.  I'm not much for most the breakfast dishes - but arguably doing to a deli like Canter's for anything other than Pastrami might be a crime.  However, they have kick-ass waffles.  Yeah, believe it or not, their waffles rock!So in closing I say, Canter's may not be a real kosher deli, but it's TOV MAOD to me!

Reviews.Author: James P.
Reviews.Content: awesome, awesome, AWESOME SO GREAT!Went here last night for a show (they have an attached bar where bands play) and ended up eating a hot pastrami sandwich on French roll with provolone and lots of mustard.  Side dishes included ungodly good cole slaw and potato salad.  Its WAS a bit expensive - $13 but SO WORTH IT!  The deli guy was awesome, he let us sample EVERYTHING and we nagged him for more and he was more than happy!  For shits and giggles we got a sample of liverwurst and he gave us ye ol' stink eye.  He then scooped an ice cream ball size scoop of it and made us eat it. HAHHA he was great.nom nom nom,James

Reviews.Author: Randall T.
Reviews.Content: I had the Canter's reuben, with pastrami, and a chocolate egg cream to wash it down. The pastrami was SO good. Dare I say, better than my go-to deli, Mattern's. The egg cream was pretty good, too. It's the only place I've seen that actually serves egg cream.It was EXPENSIVE, though. My sandwich plus egg cream came out to just under $20. Their menu is also very, very busy. Check out my pictures for an example.

Reviews.Author: Shiggity S.
Reviews.Content: Sandwich was good, the service was sub par. A girl that wasn't our server refilled our drinks and then asked "was there anything else we needed." We said yes, we need some to go boxes and some pickles. She said "oh, let me get your sever". Don't ask if we need something else if you're not going to help. I kind of got the feeling that if you weren't a regular or rich and famous. You are just a second hand customer. Although the food was good, I will never return. Plenty of other good pastrami out there. The Hat never fails me.

Reviews.Author: Bruce M.
Reviews.Content: Deli Tradition in LA.  This is the warhorse of LA delis. This is the smell of eons of pastrami and baking the best rugulas on earth.I could go on but I will skip to the next chapter...There are some deli phobes and new york transplants who seem to get off ragging on this place.Go back to NY.  Stay away from my Deli.Now I get that people who love Deli food can be VERY opinionated.  Gee, that would be me !  "Their" deli is always the best deli and others all suck.  Did you get hit in the head to many times playing dodgeball?I dont look at it that way.  I believe that every restaurant has its plusses and minuses.  It's history or lack of.  It's ingrained taste bud and smell-a-thon vibe embedded into your food obsessed brain.  So you see that Canters holds that eternal history of Deli for me.  Crap on it if you like, but realize that if it's going strong after 60 or so years, it has to be doing something right for a lot of folks.  My favorites:Pastrami Sandwich.  - not as good as Langers but when the boys in the back get it right, this sammy rocks.  Nice rub and flavors.  Not to dry or fatty.  The rye bread is also tops.  Nice crust , soft flavorful center.Potato Salad. - Yes, this is the best fucking potato salad Ive ever had.  OK, I have had some other "new trendy" ones that are excellent, but this is an old school style that just rubs my buds the right way.  Like a fine wine, you want to eat it slowly and savor the flavors.  Anything in the Bakery.  They make it all upstairs and it is classic jewish favorites.  You want a chocolate and butter overload?  Ask for the "chocolate racetrack".  This stuff is ahhhhhmaaazzzzzinnngggg!!!Matzhoh balls.  Bowling balls.  If you like em, they are tops.Pickles - These are some of the finest homemade deli dills ever.  Sometimes they are a bit on the "new" side, sometimes just a perfect medium spicy but still crunchy.  Ask for them dark if you like and they will try and pick em out of the bin for you that way.Huge menu but i would stay towards the deli favorites.  Dont stray or you might not be happy.  Not that its bad, but those items are more standard stuff you can get anywhere.The wait staff all have attitudes which also adds to the authentic deli vibe.  You dont fuck with an institution so dont try.  Old man Canter used to be roaming the place, cutting up fruit.  Dont see him anymore.  May have passed on to the big rye bread in the sky.  If so, he and his family have provided generations of Angelino's and worldwide customers fresh, real good food prepared in a homestyle way old classic restaurants only know how to do.This is the ultimate comfort food for many.  And the bar (The Kibitz Room) is this tiny , seedy, smelly  classic that has bands play at night.  Where else can you go at midnight and get an awesome brisket dip sandwich ,  a fresh made egg cream or cherry coke and listen to some crazed local band and it all gets washed down to your ever perky brain cells that are now very happy...Dont know if this made sense but maybe you get the pickle...

Reviews.Author: Victor K.
Reviews.Content: The first time I came to Canter's I ordered the avocado and swiss sandwich, or something like that, while the rest of my group ordered various kinds of reubens. Don't get me wrong, the sandwich I ordered was very good but all I could do that meal was stare in envy at the rest of my table.So the next time I went I made sure to order a reuben. Zomg. I'm usually the kind of guy that has to try EVERYTHING on the menu atleast once. Of the ten or so times I've gone to Canter's since, I have only ordered the corned beef reuben. Yar, it's that fookin delicious. The corned beef is so piled on I always have to make the corny joke "would you like some sandwich with your corned beef?" XD Anyway, I'm not going to go on and on about how the delicate balance of spices and ingredients tantalizes my tongue and feels as if a rainbow is spewing forth from my mouth and eyes - no, all I'm going to say is that if you live close, do yourself a favor and go try it. In fact, don't wait. Do it now. Why aren't you doing it now? Pfft fine, lame asses.Since you're all so intent on finishing my review I'll talk about the service and stuff I guess. Oh but before that - the pickles. If you like pickles this place has amazing ones. They serve you pickles sort of like how other places will serve you bread before a meal. Yar, even the pickles are that amazing. Oh, and they've got their own brand of mustard that's so good I can eat anything with it.. And I mean anything - pears, pineapples, whatever, put that mustard on it, and I'll eat it.Okay, service, this is where I had to take away a point from this place. The waiters aren't quite the brightest crayons in the box. Here's the dialogue from when one of my buddies tried to order a sandwich."I want a blah blah blah on sourdough""Oh, sorry we don't have any sourdough here.""Uhhh... yes you do.""No. We don't.""I come here ALL THE TIME, yes you do.""Ohhhh. The sourdough!""Yes, on sourdough.""Well, you know, our dough isn't all that sour... so."And no, the waiter guy wasn't kidding. He was dead serious. *cartman face* The one waiter I've had that was good. Is the kramer looking guy when he's having a good day... but if you catch him when he's not having a good day, that guy is scarier than a woman scorned.Anyway to wrap this thing up, from a scale of om to OM NOM NOM NOM (the caps count as a point XD) I give this place an OM NOM NOM NO... Yar, I had to take away the "M" cos of the service. God, I'm so heartless.

Reviews.Author: Chris O.
Reviews.Content: Maybe it's my Jewish heritage that makes me like Canter's so much.  Because realistically, I'm not sure if I would be terribly thrilled with it otherwise.  First off, for someone who lives in the Valley, it's not the most convenient place to get to.  Parking can be a real pain if the lot is full, and the same homeless man always sits out front begging for change.  And the last thing I want to feel before indulging in some old-fashioned Jewish eats is guilt.The food is pretty good, and most of what I've gotten here, I've really enjoyed.  Their brisket is really great, and the portions are ginormous.  I don't remember why I got it, and I think the size of it may have actually wiped out some of my memory, but I do remember some salivating and some rubbing my belly with a smile on my face.  The pastrami at Canter's is tasty too, and so is their matzoball soup.  And while neither is necessarily the best in the LA area, both will satisfy a craving if you don't have many other options available.  Now is the food quality above that of your average diner? Mmmmmmm.... maybe not.  But it's open 24 hours a day, and in a city that would like to never sleep like its wicked sister in the east, that's never a bad thing.This place also has seniority as one of the oldest and most respected Jewish establishments in the city, so they'll strive to impress you.  The waiters and staff are all very nice, and you can't beat the bakery food at the front.  Freshly made bagels, rugelach, cakes, cookies, and varieties of other Jewish pastries... This place has everything.  Well, everything but knishes.  I've forgiven them for that though.The atmosphere is very reminiscent of an old, vintage diner.  Now when I say that, I'm not talking about the bottles of Coke on shiny counter tops, plush red seats, and "Mr. Sandman" playing over the jukebox in the corner type of vintage.  This place has a different kind of personality, much like old diners that my parents used to take me to in North Philly when I was little.  Lots of soft earth tones.  Nothing visually overwhelming.  It's just a nice place to hang out and grab some grub, especially if you're one of the... how should I phrase this?  Chosen people. ;-)

Reviews.Author: Maggie S.
Reviews.Content: Ah, Canter's. I've been going to this deli for over 10 years and I keep coming back for several things: 1. their pastrami reuben sandwich, 2. their salads, and 3. they're open 24 hours. 1. The reuben comes piled high (though not as high as it used to be) with soft, juicy, flavorful pastrami, Swiss (I think) cheese and loads of sauerkraut, sandwiched between some tasty grilled rye bread. To this day I have never found another reuben sandwich that tops Canter's. It comes with potato chips and if you want fries (trust me, you're gonna want the fries) it's a dollar more. I do love it but my friends and I have it less often these days because they've raised their prices and it's hard to justify spending $16 (incl. tax and tip) on one sandwich.2. Their salads are only slightly less expensive but I give them a thumbs up for their freshness and size. I usually order the chopped salad and by the time I'm through I'm pretty stuffed.3. Although there are quite a few 24-hour places in L.A., Canter's is one of my favorites because they never seem to care how long we stay. Once a friend and I rolled in around 2am and didn't leave til after 6, and they never once said anything to us. Probably because the restaurant was pretty empty, but it's nice to know there's somewhere we can go if we're not ready to go home yet.People complain about the service but honestly, I've never had a bad experience there. Some of the older waitresses are gruff but it's never to the point where it's unpleasant to me. I think they just have a reputation to maintain, so what's the harm?The Kibbitz Room bar next door is divey and the drinks are the cheapest I've ever had. But sometimes if they have a band playing it's hard to hear your mates when you're sitting in the next room over having dinner. So you might want to request a table in the first room.Rodney Bingenheimer has a regular booth here, and you never know who you might see. My favorite celebrity sighting here was ELVIRA!

Reviews.Author: Mike D.
Reviews.Content: I have been a big fan of Canter's going back to the 80's. We used to race here after a night out to eat and get those last drinks before 2 am. Well, even when I didn't live here anymore I traveled back regularly and would always stop at Canter's. Bagels and Lox platter, Potato Knish, Blintzes, Reuben, it's all great! And the waitresses are just as friendly and helpful as ever. It has pained me to drive by without stopping a few times lately... on my way to an appointment. But we enjoyed a nice Sunday brunch the other day finally. The only reason I'm not giving 5 stars is that both the restaurant cashier and the bakery cashier just kept repeating to sign the CC check, "when you're ready", over and over like robots. We were talking and/or looking or something, and it was not busy, and there was no line behind us. We heard you the first 2 times. Anyway, still enjoying the baked goods we took with us. Will be back soon, with cash. Pics... flickr.com/search/?w=170…

Reviews.Author: Katy W.
Reviews.Content: I confess that my cooler-than-thou friend is the one who introduced me to this place, but I am now claiming it as my own, damnit!This place is just so homey. I don't know how to explain it. In the past year since I moved to LA, I have started going whenever I feel down. It's like getting a home-cooked meal. The decor is totally 1972, the service is casual and more interested in being efficient than in chatting you up. The pastrami is, of course, the main attraction. So good! The matzo ball soup is the other thing I always get especially if I need a pick-me-up.The other thing you absolutely NEED to get is dessert. Their 7 layer chocolate cake is to die for. Plus, I always annoy the ladies by pointing at random cookies whose names I don't know. In addition to the food, I love that there is a great mix of people who go there. It feels very "LA" to me.

Reviews.Author: Ruth C.
Reviews.Content: Parking's iffy even past peak hours, but the wait wasn't too long.  Friendly service, but if you sit down just before the servers change shifts you may have to flag someone down for what you need.  By no means can I confirm the authenticity of the food, but you get what you pay for-- hearty portions, interesting flavors.  Pickles are crunchy, but not crisp.  Excellent location and feel.Two menu selection reviews:Mishmosh, with chicken - if I wanted more turf and less surf in my clam chowder, with a chicken noodle soup twist, this would be it.  Variety of textures.Monte Cristo - french toast damped in syrup, featuring two kinds of meat... so kind of a glorified McGriddle.  Settles heavily on the stomach, and I'm told that it's better at Bennigan's.

Reviews.Author: Heather C.
Reviews.Content: HeloooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooAwesome food here. Deli style, Matzo ball soup to DIE and all the spicy pickles you can handle.  When your feeling sick- come here for the Matzo Ball soup and you will be healed. Stay away from the baked goods though...  blah.

Reviews.Author: Joanne G.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is totally the old school the type of place that my dad loves, complete with the elderly wait staff, outdated decor, and hearty portions.  And Jewish deli food- a rarity for those of us who live in the Bay Area!  Which is why every time we're in town, my family makes it a point to stop in.  Usually we sit down for a meal of massive pastrami sandwiches, matzoh ball soup, and top that off with all the pickles and bagel chips we can stuff down.  This time we were just driving through on the way home and so hit the to-go counters before hitting the road again.  The list was long:  pastrami sandwiches on rye, knishes, lots from the bakery: rugelach, mandel bread (similar to biscotti) and other cookies, a variety of sliced "cheesecake", loaves of sliced rye bread.  (hey, my last visit to LA was eight years ago and my next visit might be just as long!).  The consensus:  the pastrami was really fatty (should've asked for lean, oops), but the rye was incredible.  Two pounds of rugelach and mandel bread disappeared in seconds and we fought over who was keeping the rye bread.  But the cheesecake?  Yuck.So lots of awesome and some not so great.  But all pretty damn amazing when compared to...um, absolutely nothing, which is what we have here in SF!

Reviews.Author: Steve V.
Reviews.Content: This is a classic deli and bakery. Old interior, feels like 1970, lots of old people. You can get meats and sides and pastries to go. If you get Daniel, he's a great server and good at telling it to you like it is.I had the corned beef and pastrami sandwich and they pile the meat onto it. The bread was just right and the pickles they give you while waiting is a nice touch. My wife had the avacado melt which I tried and it was excellent. Great choice for vegetarians!There is a bar attached with live music and perhaps we will come back and experience this and breakfast at some point. Validated parking for 1.5 hours in the lot next door, but can get crowded.

Reviews.Author: Andy O.
Reviews.Content: Pretty good, but I wouldn't wade through the hassle of driving here, fighting through the cluster-fuck of a parking lot, and waiting in a line to sit, then again to pay, then again to order some pastries to go, and then again to get your keys back so you can leave. You feel like an insignificant piece in a big, Jewish, food-making carnival. It is open 24 hours, so it'd be an excellent spot to stop by at four in the morning, when I'm assuming there's less of a crowd. Otherwise, all the waiting around and being confused makes me sad. I don't like being sad when I eat. Because then I cry in my food.

Reviews.Author: Kristina R.
Reviews.Content: Great sandwiches and baked goods! Reuben's sandwich is especially awesome here! And in the bakery, they have this marzipan cookie that is AMAZING!I have to say though.. I tried their Monte Cristo sandwich, and did not like that at all. It wasn't a real Monte Cristo.Overall, Canter's is a great place to go with family. It's been around for a long time and gained a great reputation with it. Portions are definitely generous and good for sharing. Service is very friendly also!

Reviews.Author: Matt M.
Reviews.Content: This new addition to Dodger Stadium (field level only) is the bomb! It's a little tough to eat sitting in your lap, but it's just as tasty as getting one on Fairfax. Of course, you're gonna pay a whole lot more. Try $11 for a sandwich. They also have tasty waffle fries and mazzo ball soup!Pass on the turkey dip sandwich. It's dry and the dip isn't all that.

Reviews.Author: Circe L.
Reviews.Content: Ok so we know the owners very well. But I have to tell you no other Knish in town can touch this action. Great portions, fun staff, excellent and essential Hollywood icon of culture and happenings for many years, biased or not Canter's is legend.

Reviews.Author: Marc D.
Reviews.Content: This is a review based off a handful of trips to Canters so it might not be justified and if I do choose to go back... I'll attend. Two problems - food isn't amazing and prices aren't greatThe ambiance is there but as far asl 3am places go the value just isn't present

Reviews.Author: Dave D.
Reviews.Content: Basically, I think these people need to get over themselves. That's what happens when you get too popular. I think they're up to around $11.00 for a pastrami now. If I wanna go skiing, I head to the mountains, not Fairfax. Translation: STEEP. There's no law that says "Must Go to Canter's." In my opinion, Langer's near downtown has a better pastrami. They're a lot friendlier, too. And if you bring a little extra cash, you can buy a fake I.D. or social security card from one of the "merchants" on the street. What could be better than eating a good sandwich and assuming a new identity?

Reviews.Author: Oren G.
Reviews.Content: There just ain't nuthin' like a steaming bowl of Canter's mish-mosh in the wee hours of the morning.  It's damned near a religious experience.Many here rightly call Canter's an L.A. institution.  Originally founded in East L.A. back in its Jewish days, Canter's moved to Fairfax to become the hub of the district.I've been here hundreds of times over the past 15+ years, and have never had a disappointing meal.  The pastrami and corned beef are piled high and succulent, the pickles are home-made and perfectly seasoned, and the corned beef hash for breakfast (or after a late night) can move one to tears.The fact that many of their wait-staff have that grandmotherly appeal sure doesn't hurt.Canter's Deli.  Try it.

Reviews.Author: Abel A.
Reviews.Content: Say it with me?.. OVERRATED (clap-clap-clap) OVERRATED (clap-clap-clap)Seriously people. I think that we are brainwashed with the reputation and history of this place. It is a Hollywood landmark. Perhaps I'm not being fair. But When I was an omnivore I had their sandwiches and matzo or whatever soup. I wasn't impressed at all. Kind of bland. I think it's just the hype.

Reviews.Author: Ingrid H.
Reviews.Content: Dear Canter's Brisket Sandwich, YOU ROCK! :o)Love, Ingrid H. p.s. pickles, don't be jealous, my taste buds love you too. Oh and I was there last week and received EXCELLENT service. Server lady (wish i had written down her name) was very attentive and nice. Dude at cc register was meh. and gentlemen at the pastries stand was AWESOME! i didn't have cash to pay for $2-$3 worth of little cookies and was about to hand my debit card when he said "don't worry about it". :o) how sweet is that?! cookies were REALLY good too. ate them all (8 or so) before i hit the street light. :o) tee hee. I'LL BE BACK!one more thing: i like their ceiling.

Reviews.Author: Candy S.
Reviews.Content: This place deserves a solid 3.5. The service was great, the staff or who I believe is the owners family are incredibly funny and friendly, but the price for the food...oOo wee thats a high price tag, and what is up with your cashiers!!!Eddie Canter's Delight had so much going for it. Turkey, ham, corned beef, swiss cheese, rye bread, and a side...it really is "a meal in itself." It practically has all the food groups!! It scared me when my meal came out. Four huge piece of this monster laid before me and I couldn't even dent it. I was only able to eat one and a half pieces. It was insane. Although this monstrous meal was a great sight, my taste buds beg to differ. It was a very dry sandwich that required lots of deli mustard and mayo. Plus the combination of corned beef, turkey, and ham is honestly...a horrible combination. As a result of being stuck to its counterparts, my corned beef was room temperature. Eek. Plus, it wasn't that tasty to begin with.Reuben with pastrami. Oh I am too spoiled by Langer's. Sorry Canter's, I admit your pastrami is really good, but after having a taste of Langer's famous #19 I just have to place you in second. Although the taste and texture of your pastrami is amazing, I just love the thick cuts of meat Langer's give in every sandwich. That, my friend, is the deal breaker. Give me a thick slice of meat and maybe, just maybe, I'll be yours.Matzo ball soup. This was my first time having a matzo ball soup. And if I knew it was going to be so filling, I would definitely have ordered something else. Darn you yelpers for convincing me otherwise. And to those misleading photos. Not only is the Matzo ball ginormous, but the amount of soup they give you is very generous. Plus, it comes with slices of baked bagels. A very good combo indeed. I would definitely order this when I'm sick or on a rainy day. Love it!The Cashiers.....really now? I don't know if this happens on a daily basis and if this is how its been run ever since they opened, but WOW. Canter's has two dinosaurs working upfront. They have two lines, one for cash and another for credit cards. A majority of the people are paying with their cards, including me, and boy was that line long and slooooow. She had to calculate everything with a calculator, including tip, and write allll that down a a piece of paper. My goodness. While she's doing this the other old lady taking care of the cash line has nothing to do at all, but stare into space. HELP PLEASE! This docked you down a star. For being opened for so many years, I would think they would have came up with a better system.

Reviews.Author: Neuro G.
Reviews.Content: Decent Kosher Deli gnosh.  Bustling, retro ambience.  Great corned beef, pastrami.  Matzah ball soup has massive balls, but the soup-base tastes like a mix and is uninspired.   I really like the place, but it seems every time I go I get a jar of  horseradish that expired one month ago.  Are they trying to tell me something?The place gets a star for being open all the time, but parking is a pain if their small lot is full.

Reviews.Author: Mandy Z.
Reviews.Content: A trip to Canter's is just like a visit to my Gramma's. The kitchen is always open, the menu is full of items I'm too embarrassed to say out loud, and there's usually a plate full of pickles waiting for me on the table when I sit down. And just like at g-ma's, the service at Canter's is hit or miss, too. Most of the time the ladies who wait on you are real cranky and make it hard to keep your cool when you've been waiting forty minutes for your coffee, but every so often you get a totally sweet one that blows your mind with attention, quick service, and a great attitude. Service aside, the food's pretty good if you know what to get. You shouldn't go there for the salads, but if you do, they're delicious (I'm a chopped vegetable). The sandwiches are tasty too, obviously, but only if you really like meat, and you appreciate applying the condiments yourself. Although on a personal level, since I'm not a huge corn rye fan, the sandwiches are usually a no-go for me. The can't misses are the: matzoh ball soup, bagel chips, and blintzes. They're all sensational.Just a word of caution: skip the dessert counter. Everything looks delicious but almost nothing is. It's a total trick of the eye.

Reviews.Author: Daniel M.
Reviews.Content: I love sandwiches. Which is why I think Canter's is delicious. I was visiting my cousin in LA and this was the first place he took me to for a bite. I had no idea what it was or what to expect, but I am really glad he took me here. This place definitely has a homely feel to it. The waiters are very friendly (but apparently if you don't order your sandwich with Jewish Rye, they give you evil eye. I'm not sure if that's true, but that's what my cousin told me). So naturally I ordered my corned beef sandwich on Jewish Rye.The meat was STACKED HIGH in my sandwich. I actually had to take out some of the meat and eat it as a side because my jaw couldn't open that big. Sooo delicious, especially with a side of fries. I'm definitely gonna stop by here again when I visit. Interesting side note: Jonah Hill (Seth from Superbad) was standing outside this place when I visited. Puh-retty cool if you ask me.

Reviews.Author: Mico C.
Reviews.Content: Primo location in Fairfax village and once home of many a movie star like Jack Benny, Lizabeth Taylor, and Marilyn. Decent layout of booths and tables in two separate rooms but seriously requires a Hollywood facelift. Wish the waitresses smiled more. I pray you don't get stuck with the testy matzo ball with legs- Fran. About the corned beef & pastrami here- it's costly and won't curl your toes. Avoid the stoned homeless bums and cockroaches outside! For a supremely better meal try Izzys and Juniors on the Westside. Go Now! Open 24 hours except on Yom Kippur & Rosh Hashanah. beverly and fairfax, north of the Grove.The Kibbitz Room bar, connected to the diner, features local rock n roll talent during the week and end. Excruciatingly small venue where the audience is practically standing on the stage leaning on the guitarist.

Reviews.Author: Alex N.
Reviews.Content: Canter's tastes pretty good at 3 AM when you've just started sobering up after a night of barhopping. Any other time however, I'm not so sure. Its authentic deli feel and '60s decor are inviting, but things start to fall apart once you sit down. The booths occasionally have ripped vinyl seats, sometimes repaired with duct tape, while the non-booth tables have really uncomfortable, old chairs. Unless you're willing to drop $11-14 on one of their deli sandwiches, everything else on the menu (which is a mess, btw) is your typical diner fare. You'd be just as happy eating at a Denny's.The last time I was here, I didn't want to spend more than $10 on a late-night meal, but still wanted something that would give me that authentic deli taste. So I ordered the Matzo ball soup. It was essentially just a ball of packed bread crumbs in a bowl of some kind of broth. The soup itself had no taste--it might as well have been salt water. The matzo ball tasted just how it looked, stale and dry. Even after it had soaked up most of the broth it still managed to taste dry. I'm really not sure why we eat here.

Reviews.Author: Ken K.
Reviews.Content: Maybe it was because I had low expectations, but I really enjoyed the (Brooklyn Ave) pastrami sandwich here.  Why did I have low expectations?  I've come to frown upon thinly-sliced pastrami because I've been spoiled by the hand-cut pieces at Katz's and Langer's.  From my experiences, hand-cut equals juicy and thin-sliced usually equals dry, chewy, gristly and/or too fatty (and this is coming from someone who LOVES fat).  But at Canter's, the pastrami is just about as juicy and rich in flavor as the ones at the aforementioned places and I like the hard crust on the rye bread.  I know I'm being high maintenance about this, but hey, I want to ENJOY what I eat and I know you do too.  So take my advice and eat here (or at Langer's) if you want good pastrami.  It boggles my mind when people say they love The Hat; I shudder at the thought of eating there.And it's a definite plus that Canter's is open around the clock.  I'm not usually out late, but it's nice to know I have an option for good food should I ever need it at three in the morning.BTW, we unknowingly entered through the north end (next to some night club/bar) and were seated right up against the wall adjacent to that bar while some band was blasting away.  Needless to say it was loud.  If you'd prefer a quieter scene, I'd recommend you enter through the south end or at least request to be seated in the next room over since this restaurant is quite spacious.

Reviews.Author: Scott A.
Reviews.Content: We just stopped in for a quick bite and split a Pastrami Sandwich.   My expectaions were high at  $13+ , but I wasnt disappointed. The meat really melted in your mouth and the swiss cheese was also very good.  My 12 yo son also loved the Rye bread, that was unusual so worth mentioning.  The place was crowded, but the service was very fast.I will return to try the Corned Beef soon.

Reviews.Author: Andrew F.
Reviews.Content: So.. Langer's or Canter's? Pepsi or Coke? Jedi or Sith?I came here with my friend Tim H., my groupon, and two huge appetites that wanted to eat the night away. When we got there, we sat down and spent probably 15 minutes just staring at the menu, not knowing what to get.We finally resort to asking our server what he'd recommend. We ended up splitting a Greek salad, a beef brisket dinner platter, and an Eddie Cantor's Delight [ECD]. Unbeknownst to us, the Roasted Brisket of Beef came with a matzo ball soup along with a soft drink, and DESSERT!The ECD came in three pieces - a towering heap of pastrami, corned beef, ham, and turkey, all piled on a triple decker. Eating 1/3 of it nearly knocked me out, and we still had everything else to eat. I felt that the sandwich was a little on the dry side, as the cheese and the bread stole from any moisture there may have been from the meats.The brisket wasn't amazing, but the fact that it came with a soup, a drink, and a dessert sure made it somewhat worth while. The beef lacked seasoning and taste, as it just tasted like cooked beef. And that's it. The potato cakes were pretty good, but pretty greasy [which is why they were good].The Greek salad didn't seem anything special. Both Tim H and I agreed that we could have gone without it.If you're comparing pastrami alone, Langer's easily wins out, as theirs is more moist and succulent. But the overall value of the meal, service, and presentation of everything, Canter's wins out. The servers were extremely friendly at Canter's, very patient, and knowledgeable about their menu. Our water/drinks were always filled and the servers would come by periodically to check on us, sparking some chitter and chatter to make sure we were good.At the end, the bill was reasonable only because of the Groupon that I had. I'm not quite sure I'd come back on any other occasion, as the food, as good as it was, was not great enough for me to drive all the way out to Canter's for, and not wowing enough for me to spend that much without a Groupon. You're good, but you're not great.So who wins? Canter's for the overall experience. Langer's just isn't worth the trouble nor the cost.

Reviews.Author: Graham S.
Reviews.Content: A haiku review: Real good pastrami Matzo ball soup was OKKinda overpriced

Reviews.Author: Jerry H.
Reviews.Content: Once you get passed the long line. Canter's makes me feel like I'm on the Upper West Side (Sans the tripped out ceiling.) @ a joint where you know the Reuben's bomb and the garlic infused pickles will do you right. The Corned Beef is piled on and cut to order everything's fresh and you will love it. The history is on the walls, literally. Throughout the upstairs and downstairs there's all sorts of newspaper & magazine clippings to let you know this place is where you should be for the Jewish Deli experience. Our waiter was zany & kooky just how a waiter in L.A. should be.

Reviews.Author: David D.
Reviews.Content: Salty as FUCK and prices that suck!I understand it's a Los Angeles staple, but so are liquor stores and pot shops on every corner. My sodium intake after a small overpriced lunch were through the roof.The Guns 'n' Roses booth is kind of cool, I guess??

Reviews.Author: Ed C.
Reviews.Content: Ditto on what everyone else has written about Canters. Their chicken matzoh ball soup is to die for and has saved my flu-ridden ass so many times, it's not even funny. Go there now.And dig that weird, autumnal stained-glass ceiling.

Reviews.Author: Caitlin T.
Reviews.Content: I love me some matzo ball soup and a good corned beef sandwich. I have been craving these for months while in Hawaii, who doesn't seem to have a Jewish population. I look forward to my trip to LA for my fix. This time we requested a stop here after being picked up from the airport. We always get the matzo ball soup and the Brooklyn Ave sandwich with corned beef. Words can't describe how warm my heart feels after a spoonful of that soup. They always come with dried bagel crips that you can dip in the broth and pickles for the table. The sandwiches are pretty big. We usually share the soup and only eat half of the sandwich, but I like it that way since I have more for later. The servers aren't always the friendliest and the bathrooms are quite old, otherwise this is a great place.

Reviews.Author: Josh L.
Reviews.Content: I haven't been to Canter's on over 10 years.  Man I was shocked at how the prices have freakin' shot up though.  There's not much on the menu for under $10.  I'm a cheap bastard so when I was there last night with a buddy of mine, I was immediately biased.I love sandwiches, I love delis, and I especially love NY/Jewish delis.  Canter's is that but throw some LA into it.  I orderd the 'Danny Thomas' because I like salami and ... Danny Thomas.For $10.50 you get a salami sandwich between two slices of smallish sized rye bread, a small cup of cole slaw, and a few pickles.  You do get a ton of meat though (but when I say ton I don't mean a ton in regards to Jewish delis - that's pretty much standard)...and the salami was really good too.I have to say I was satisfied, but I don't think it should have been $10.50.  I truthfully think that all the prices should be knocked down 15-20%.  They are good, and it is an LA landmark, but one of two things has to happen to make it great:  The prices should be a little lower, or the food should be EVEN better.It would have been great to see this place in it's hay day.  It seems that this place lives on more for it's history than it's present existence.  I'm not dogging that, but it's awesome if a place can be legendary in it's current time.I'm not loving it.  Only liking it.  I think my only reason for coming back here in the future would be if I was out in Hollywood at 3am and needed food...even then, there are other options.  It's good but not great.

Reviews.Author: Liz X.
Reviews.Content: While Canter's rocks for so many reasons and is very good especially if you need your New York deli fix, it's not the BEST deli in LA (that honor goes to Langer's in my book).  Although it is pretty damn good...especially at 3 in the morning when you and your friend just happen to notice it on your way home from a debauched night out on the town.  I always go for the pastrami because that's just what you get when you go to a NY style deli.  The pickles are crispy and crunchy and are a bit more garlic-y and not quite as pickled and sour as most deli pickles.  But that makes them that much better.  And the stale bagel chips?  Now I know you're thinking to yourself, "why would anyone ever eat stale bagel chips?"  But you're only thinking that to yourself because you're sober right now. The matzo ball soup/kreplach gets a whole paragraph to itself.  YUMMM!!! And counter-intuitively filling as well.  Get it...you won't regret it.  The best part about Canter's besides the harvest gold, orange, and brown decor/70s motif is the staff!  The servers are these old ladies who look at all the Hollywood hipsters, drunk kids, and homeless dudes with disdain.  You half expect them to be wearing a pink outfit, with a white apron skirt, smacking gum and telling you to "kiss my grits" as they slap your plate on the table.  You gotta love it...One more thing, Canter's was featured on a "Curb Your Enthusiasm" episode where Larry is sitting with a bunch of adults with Down's syndrome after a carwash fundraiser...hilarious.  That makes me love it even more...

Reviews.Author: Adam W.
Reviews.Content: I don't even know why I bother writing reviews of these firmly entrenched LA establishments that already have hundreds of reviews.  Nonetheless, I feel like it's my duty as a native New Yorker to weigh in.  I guess this review is really for New Yorkers and people who use Russian dressing as a condiment.I should note from the get-go that Canter's is not a kosher deli -- it is a kosher-STYLE deli -- they serve distinctly non-kosher foods like cheeseburgers, for example, like the Carnegie Deli.   Speaking of, Canter's is not as good as the Carnegie Deli or even the 2nd Ave Deli.  It's more like a Stage Deli.  But it's totally legit in every possible way. The sandwiches are nowhere near as big as Carnegie's and their pastrami is not as good.  But the guys from Broadway Danny Rose would assuredly eat here when gigging out west. When I go to Canter's, I feel like I'm home.  I can't put my finger on it because the decor is so blah. Those old phone jacks at the tables, and that bizarre balcony thing...  it's anachronistic but it's lovable, like a jukebox or drive-in.I think it's the just the overwhelming aura of corned beef, matzah balls, fresh rugelach and Dr. Brown's.  There's a Junior's here in LA on Westwood.  As a Brooklynite, I had to go but it really doesn't measure up - in fact the Juniors in Brooklyn isn't so great to begin with.  And Izzy's was really disappointing.  So Canter's is really the one that stands out to me among all the kosher-style delis in LA. The last time I was  there, a prostitute (who had a striking resemblance to Jacke Harry) bolted through the door and grabbed a bag off the bakery counter and said, "I almost forgot my hamantashen!" So, take comfort in knowing it's the number 1 source for hooker hamantashen at 4AM. With an endorsement like that, how can you go wrong?One small criticism: one of the cashiers was extremely rude to a cousin of mine who was visiting from NY. She bought a Canters t-shirt as a souvenir for a friend (size small) and the cashier looked her up and down and had the nerve to say, "I think you'll need a larger size." So, that basically ruined her entire experience.  The girl just ate chicken soup, a Reuben and a knish and you're going to make her self-conscious about her weight?  Uncool dude. So, be careful of that one "bitchy" male cashier -- otherwise, the service is fine.

Reviews.Author: Edward C.
Reviews.Content: This review again is intended for the 'late night crowd'one review based on one visit..at 3am.but at least i was not drunkinstead i was bothered by the company i was with.and this is important because even a waitress who is tolerating the 3am crowd, managed to see through my mood.and cheered me up.she was a sweet ol' lady.the best part was... that the company that was causing some drama was still siting across from me.be this sweet ol' lady made sure i didn't let it get to me.instead she did recommend the rueben  sandwich(which was freakin awesome!) hooked me up with fries (SWEET!)and never let me cup of coke reach half empty. (or half full for you optimist out there)So come here for a late night meal and don't be surprised if you run into some rock stars around here.

Reviews.Author: Calvin H.
Reviews.Content: I know this place is a piece of LA history blah blah blah but does it have to be so expensive? I really liked my pastrami Reuben. The sauerkraut had just the right amount of moisture removed, the pastrami was great, and I like that the sauce is on the side. But for over $15 after I subbed coleslaw for potato chips? Not doing that again.I also tried a bunch of other things. Matzo ball soup--great. Bagel chips--great. Corned beef--great. Pickles--great.The food is great. The service is great. But so much $$$ for such simple meals!

Reviews.Author: Tricia R.
Reviews.Content: Terrible chicken noodle soup.Quite possibly the best chocolate eclairs in town.Love their ranch dressing!!Not the best deli delights in town, but I love the history here, always great people watching, always open.  Kinda pricey in my opinion.The bakery is the main attraction for me.

Reviews.Author: Kokoro I.
Reviews.Content: Bartender's guide of what's still open after 2.I have to say that this is the best 24hr open cafe/diner in the whole LA! forget Jerry's deli, Mel's diner, and yup norms and Denny's. the food here is really really good!I got their stuffed cabbage and stuffed baked potato, very good and both of them is like $6 each, hey! they have so many small veggie main apps here and i can order a little thing here and a little thing there and make a meal out of it. Although we went there like 4 in the morning, the server, older Asian gentleman, was super super nice. he thought we order way too much food so he kept saying "are you sure? that's alot of food...", very considerate. checked on us quite often to see if we liked the food. fast and sincere service, big up!So why doesn't this place get all the 5 stars if the food and service is so good???? well, the bathroom and the cashier. bathroom is upstairs and so far and you pass like 200 doors, no more like 5 but felt like it, just to get to your stall! the stairs are kinda narrow and steep and if you got them heels on girl, its not safe.You pay at the cashier not at the table, old school. and the cashier has real old school system there. and that's all okay with me as long as they put somebody that can add and subtract and without the bitchy queen attitude. that was a huge turn off.But yup ill mos def go back there for after work food!

Reviews.Author: Keith R.
Reviews.Content: What you expect from a Los Angeles institution:- Good, greasy food- Open 24h- Limited parking (this describes the city in general)- Not exactly value-priced...and yet, I come here every chance I get. Pastrami on rye, substitute coleslaw on the side and those pickles, man!4 stars because I would love to buy a sandwich in LA for under $10 some day...

Reviews.Author: Toby W.
Reviews.Content: (Insert redundant "I'm from New York so I know what good deli is" comment here.)This is the closest thing I've found to an authentic New York style deli in So Cal. The prices are high, but that's also the case at Katz's, which is the best deli in the world. If you want a cheap sandwich, go to Subway.

Reviews.Author: Michelle C.
Reviews.Content: My coworker gawked at me when I told her I'd never been to Canter's, and the lady behind the register asked me if I'd "ever been to California" when I informed her that this was my first Canter's experience. Did I somehow just miss the memo? I definitely don't consider myself as one who lives in a cave...So armed with a Groupon, of course I order Canter's famous Hot Pastrami and Matzoh Ball Soup. Both had good flavor, but I sadly wasn't wowed by either. The Pastrami Sandwich was filled with tender peppery meat between soft and chewy rye, while the Matzoh Ball Soup had a light, flavorful broth with a ginormous matzoh ball. Again, good flavor on both but I wasn't wowed. I did however, really appreciate my waitress Sue, who like an energetic bumblebee serviced all the customers on her turf and still managed to check in on me at exactly the right moment. She boxed up my slice of carrot cake to go (the cake was a bit denser than I like my carrot cakes, perhaps due to the nuts and raisins in the batter), and speedily gave me my check when I had to rush back to work.A+ for customer service! I'm not sure if I'll be back, but who knows since Canter's is open 24 hours...

Reviews.Author: Stephanie T.
Reviews.Content: To quote my boyfriend, "This place met my expectations, but it did not surpass them.  And it's way too expensive."And that's that.

Reviews.Author: Lily E.
Reviews.Content: Being a Jew, you'd think I would have a multitude of Deli-going experiences.  Psych---I totally do, but a surprising amount has been on the more low key scale, many of them hit or miss.  Canter's was my first on the larger scale of Deli's (apart from Jerry's, but we won't go there).  I have to say I truly enjoyed my experience at Canter's Fairfax.Maybe it was the fact that I was STARVING, as I had saved my special meal here as my only one before heading to the late shift (no rest for the wicked).  It could have also been that I heard tales and fables about the big names, and was excited. When I came in I instantly felt "at home".  I'm not sure if I can explain myself, but everything sort of fell together - the decor of browns (perhaps to match all the meats and sauces?), the fun architecture, the sassy, saggy waitresses, and the mixed crowd.  Totally random, too, from surfers to old men with bandaged foreheads (from a lanced boil, no doubt), to a random Asian couple.  Another thing I appreciated was all the no-holds-barred, unselfconscious eating that was going on.Enough of this, though.  On to the food!  I admit I was tempted to get the usual sandwich, but I really wanted to try something a little off the main path so I ordered the baked eggplant parmesan.  It came with cheese bread which was made out of marble rye.  Very classy.  This dish was SO GOOD.  The tomato sauce was perfect, not too sweet and not acidic.  The portion must have been the entire eggplant, and it was appreciated for it's texture and taste.  The chicken kreplach soup was nice too.Afterward I engaged in some banter with the cherubic man behind the bakery counter who gave me a sample and asked me to guess what the flavor was.  Turned out to be prune.  As I left I felt super giddy.  I called my dad and mentioned I had eaten at Canter's on Fairfax.  "Watch out, the food's gone south there" was his remark.  I have to say I disagree.

Reviews.Author: Steve G.
Reviews.Content: Canter's... you have GOT to be kidding me!   I have been hearing about this "legendary" Canter's Deli ever since I moved to LA about a year ago.  I had heard it was going to be on the expensive side but I was prepared to shell out my hard earned money because it's supposed to be a local gem.  After being seated we were given glasses of lukewarm tap water, with no ice, in a dirty glass.  This should have been the 1st sign.I ordered a sandwich called Matt's Special (Turkey, muenster, coleslaw, and Canter's dressing) served on toasted egg bread.. the sandwich was messy, mushy, and had a pile of FAKE turkey (processed turkey roll)  I would have expected fresh carved or at least Boars head.  It was like biting into a thick slab of gooey, fatty, sweaty chunks of raw animal flesh.My friend ordered a grilled ham and cheese..  Soggy, thick, spongy, bread that had hardly been toasted.. The cheese was a half melted craft single and  again, processed garbage ham that would make Oscar Meyer seem like gourmet... This sandwich was accompanied by a cereal bowl of stale, bottom of the bag ridged potato chips.Now here's the kicker.  This inedible pile of junk, including tip, came to a whopping total of $40.  We are both sitting here with stomach cramps and empty wallets.Do yourself a favor... save your money and your belly by avoiding Canter's.

Reviews.Author: Sarah C.
Reviews.Content: This place is great! Everyone is friendly, food is priced reasonably, and the food is so good!

Reviews.Author: bran p.
Reviews.Content: Oh Canter's how I do love thee, especially after a night of heavy drinking, and The OC reruns.  The avocado melt is the most vegetarian friendly sauteed mushroom bit of goodness this side of heaven.  A pickle is a pickle is a pickle, but the pickles here are PICKLES.  I don't know what I mean by that, but I mean that they're good.When I was a carnivore, I loved the monte cristo.  They still serve the monte cristo.  It's not just a great book, but also a divine sandwich. Eat it.  Just tell them to hold the turkey, and the ham.  It's chill, low key, and absolutely perfect for a late night craving.  Hell, it's open 24 hours.  Damn them.

Reviews.Author: Madeleine C.
Reviews.Content: I'm over it.My mom used to frequent Canter's when she was a twenty-something, and I'll never forget the first time she brought me as a small chil--it was with such pride and nastalgia.When my husband and I moved to this side of the continent, I was excited to share this LA landmark with him.  But the truth is, it's just not that great.  I feel like we're always getting mediocre food here, but we let it off the hook because it's Canters.So we came here last night because we were with a friend from out of town, and it was the only thing opened after mid-night.  Our friend grew up eating white fish and was stoked at the idea of getting this rare treat.  Well his meal came out, and let's just say I still get ill thinking about it.  He let me try it, and we both took a bite at the same time.   It looked just fine, but I'm pretty sure the fish was old and rancid.  So gross.  I Also ordered an eggplant salad.  Also not good.  My husband ordered a cream cheese/lox bagel with a chocolate shake.  This was by far the best meal on the table.Overall, I feel like the food here is dirty and old.  I think they rely on their name, and don't focus on the quality of food and hygeine--that's sort of a deal breaker in my book.  So it would be great if they spruced up the quality a bit!

Reviews.Author: Travis B.
Reviews.Content: Well after 18 years of eating here and recommending them to everyone who visits or lives in Los Angeles, I will neither tell anyone to go there, nor set foot in the "establishment" again.Yesterday I had the most ridiculously rude encounter with the waiter, followed by the manager, and ending up with the owner arguing with me on my way out!My wife and I have basically narrowed down their enormous menu to two main things we eat regularyly, their submaine sandwich (if in the mood for a cold sub) or their French Dip (when seeking hot meaty nourishment). We opted for the later yesterday which is more often than not, what we get.
