I am used to the unfriendly staff but today we couldn't get an actual word out of the waiter (an older tall guy with white hair), just a grunt.Our sandwich came out shortly and as never before, there was a strip of grizzly fat down the edge of every sliced piece of briskett on the sandwich.  I am totally cool with a bit of marbling to enhance flavor but this was a gross 1/8th inch of gelatinous fat on every piece, which could have easily been cut off prior to slicing and piling on the bun.After dismantiling the sandwich and doing our own carving session the waiter finally came back, saw what we were doing and asked if everything was ok... we told him that this was the fattiest thing we have ever gotten here (or anywhere in sandwich form for that matter).  His shoulders sagged and he did a very exaggerated look away and rolled his eyes at the table next to us and then just shot his arm straight out stating "Here".My wife HATES having to give up her meal once it is delivered and with his actions I was already offput... we told him it wasn't necessary, we already had spent the meal up to this point carving the sandwich so we opted not to send it back but we did ask him to tell the manager about the situation just so it could be prevented on future sandwiches.  He slapped the bill down and we asked him if we could see the manager since there were no further words forth-coming.An older woman named Dawn came over and preceded to tell us we could not have the sandwich free.  Whoa a second,  no one asked for a free sandwich but an "I am sorry that it wasn't up to par" or even a tiny bit of concern would have been good.  NO, she preceded to argue over something we did not ask for ten minutes and then said she would go get the owner.  After nearly ten more minutes we got up and paid and were on our way out when the owner, another older woman, came up carrying our plates with all the cut off fat!  She said "That is not a lot of fat!  I should take a picture."   I was completely taken aback, first off I don't want to look at that gross gelatin sickness anymore, second I already paid my bill and had enough arguing with Dawn over whether the sandwich was good (by the way, Dawn insisted they do NOT have chefs there, just wokrers and it is not their job to cut the fat off the meats they serve, even in sandwich form!)I told the owner I could not believe she was going to argue with me over the amount of fat and that I did not come to an establishment that I have frequented for 18 years to have the owner start yelling at me!  I told her I had already paid the bill, to confront me now was just rude and insane.  I said I hope you are happy because I am leaving upset and wont be back.I did not want a free sandwich!  I did not even care if they took money off the bill, I just wanted some concern about the one time in 18 years where their consistency slipped and instead they lost a long term customer for life and obviously made me upset enough where I had to sign up to Yelp to let others know.  Why would you argue and yell at a customer who was bringing a problem to your attention?  in 18 years of eating that sandwich I have never had fat like that on any let alone every piece of meat, I am not trying to make a big deal of nothing but had they apologized and been nice and concerned and care to converse with their customers instead of berate and yell at them, wow what a difference it would have made!

Reviews.Author: B B.
Reviews.Content: I can't believe I have never reviewed Canters.  This place is a staple of my childhood and whenever I am feeling like some good old fashioned jewish comfort food I come here.  Outside of new york I can think of no other place where you can get the entire assortment of "jew food" items done right.  Their matzo ball soup is spot on the way grandma used to make.  Go there in the morning and you can get yourself a really nice omlette for the gentile in you or begals and lox for the jew in you.  Their breakfast menu is really good but the real attraction is their sandwiches and their pastrami in particular.  Their rye bread is absolutely fantastic so you better order the sandwich on rye.  Is it the best pastrami I have ever had?  No, but it's pretty close.A word of caution -- most sandwiches are served plain and there is some house mustard on the table to put on it.  Dont use that mustard.  Ask for their assortment of other mustards and try them all out to see which one you like best.Another word of caution -- don't you dare put anything other than mustard on your pastrami sandwich.  It is simply not done.  They do have something called russian dressing you can put on there but I strongly caution you to resist that temptation to order it that way.  Pastrami is a cured meat that is so flavorful it deserves to be treated with some respect by not overpowering its flavor with a heavy dressing.  Also it is sinful to put mayo on pastrami.  There is an old saying "every time someone puts mayo on pastrami a jew dies."  My people have suffered enough because of you gentiles so leave our pastrami alone!

Reviews.Author: Anh T.
Reviews.Content: A historic and notable LA diner, I would recommend trying out this place at least once for the experience. However, well aware of their popularity, the owners don't care to impress customers with outstanding service. The service is comprised of a bunch of slow, old ladies who forget you exist and don't hesitate to reply with snappy comments. On the other hand, they do open 24 hours and the food is good.I love meat. So it is not a coincidence that the ruben sandwich, stacked high with pastrami and served with fresh homemade pickles, is my entree of choice. The matzo ball soup with bagel chips make a delicious light meal for after hours.Awesome bakery selection. I've never had anything bad. The best rugula in town. Chocolate chip, apple cinnamon, raspberry...I don't care, they're all yummy in my tummy.

Reviews.Author: Eric A.
Reviews.Content: I love the Fairfax Special!!I think this is the only spot where I will pickles off a plate and not scowl and actually enjoy them!Best corn/roast beef sandwich I've had on the west coast!!

Reviews.Author: Jim H.
Reviews.Content: "C'MON FELLAS, LET'S GET IT TOGETHER." The shout at me and my friend from the guy behind the deli counter defines my visit, and if it's not his job to keep track of orders, then I may be in the wrong deli. Rewind about an hour and this trip to Canter's had perfect bookends of terrible service. It began with a waiter who seldom visited our table (and served cold, unseasoned food), and it ended with the deli counter guy yelling at my friend and me because I tried to pick up both of our orders with both of us standing there together. How is that confusing, deli man?I also heard this place has a lot of history. Next time I'm looking for history, I think I'll head to a museum.

Reviews.Author: Porsche C.
Reviews.Content: This is a dining experience.  I feel like I am in a time warp whenever I come here.  There are big booths, a lunch counter, and historical snapshots.  This is a deli like those that used to pepper the city.  I like the pastrami.  The meat is fresh, seasoned, and authentic--like back when people bought their meats from a butcher instead of prepackaged crap in the grocer's refrigerator.  For the hefty eaters, you can enjoy a sandwich and a half without the shame of ordering two sandwiches.The parking is horrible but where is there good parking in the area?  I like to people watch here.  At lunch there is nothing but suits, ties, and blackberrys.  At early dinner, retirement village stops by.  After the clubs let out, every youngster looking to stave off a hangover stops by.

Reviews.Author: Lin G.
Reviews.Content: Delicious!  Old school Jewish deli like Langer's but with bigger portions.  The pastrami, while good, was not as high of a quality as Langer's.  The place just FEELS like an old diner but it was big.  And on a Monday night, pretty empty.  I could only eat half of the pastrami sandwich (the way it SHOULD be!).  The black and white cookie, oh my god, was delicious!  I scarfed it down the next day in between bursts of gleeful giggles.  Parking available with validation.  It's like $1 if you stay for more than 90 minutes.  Still thinking about the cookie...

Reviews.Author: Sharr K.
Reviews.Content: In the mood for big hunk'a matzoh ball soup? Go to Canter's. I assure you that thing is bigger than a softball and enough to feed two people. I love the crunchy bagel chips that comes with the soup. I also like their Corned Beef on Rye.....although I don't think it does any justice to compare but it takes me back to my first visit at Carnegie's Deli in NY. The bakery in the front is awesome, a little overwhelming for me as I want to try eveything. And I always go home empty handed. Too many choices mean....no choice at all. The menu is really extensive too. I get a headache reading through it all. That's why I always end up getting the same thing:  matzoh ball soup with lean corned beef on rye, and sometimes an order of knish or a cheese blintz.This place is pretty old school.....I mean REAL old school, could use a little make over and a happier/nicer/younger wait staff. But I guess that's part of the charm.

Reviews.Author: Sarah R.
Reviews.Content: If I was rating their bakery alone, I'd give Canter's a 5 star review. They have the most amazing bakery with such good cookies and pastries. I always come out with a big bag of cookies. Everything is so cheap too!As far as the actual restaurant goes, I do like that it's open 24 hours. The place looks like it hasn't been changed in years, really old fashioned, but it works. The waitresses also look like they've been there for the longest.The food is not the best thing in the world, but it's good and it's one of those places that you have to try at least once. They have good breakfast food, and really good french dip sandwiches. The corned beef and cabbage is delish as well.They validate parking and have their own lot which is awesome, especially in that area.  Ugh, now I'm craving their cookies..

Reviews.Author: Gena U.
Reviews.Content: A bit pricey -- had the half-sandwich, half-soup option.  Matzoh ball soup is a given, although I wasn't wowed.  :\  The pastrami was delicious, although the rye bread was a bit too chewy for my tastes and probably should have been either fresher or toasted to hide the chewy-ness.  The pickles were extremely dill-y.  I'm a pickle lover, but had a hard time with the strong dill flavor, so they're not for everyone.Chocolate chip rugelah on the way out.  YUM.  As good as grandma makes them!  Parking is a bit of a drag, as the street is full (even on a Monday night past the dinner rush) and their designated lot is full... I parked almost three blocks away.   Not complaining, just putting that out there. Loved the booth, loved the service, loved the old school feel.  Being open 24 hours a day means I'll likely be back late one night.

Reviews.Author: Reina G.
Reviews.Content: As an aspiring Jew, I've eaten my way through many a deli. I was schvitzing all over myself with excitement as I walked onto the hallowed ground of Canter's delicatessen. The second we sat down, the waiter/actor asked for our order. It was my first time at Canter's and the menu is mammoth. I said we'd need some time. Cut to two minutes later. "You guys ready yet?" Nope. Rinse. Repeat. Two more times. Finally we're ready for Mr. pushy pants to take our order. I had my heart set on a Reuben, but I didn't want to pay $15 for a whole one. Pushy pants refuses my plea for a 1/2 reuben, so I was relegated to a 1/2 corned beef sandwich and some matzo ball soup.Food arrives. Bread was thin and soggy. Meat was stringy and over-salted. Matzo was blah. The meal was totally over priced and I wasn't digging the "more hipster than thou" attitude. Get over yourself, Canter's. I think I might like this place if it was late and I was drunk with oodles of money to throw away. This is the only circumstance under which I shall return.

Reviews.Author: Erin P.
Reviews.Content: I really do love this place.  It is a good thing it is in LA and I am in the OC, because I would spend all my money here and I would be poorer than I already am.  Don't let the decor and service fool you, the food is fantastic.  Corned beef/pastrami sandwich is amazing. Giant matza ball in tasty soup.  Plate size pancakes.  Basically everything I have had here has been great.  How can you go wrong with home made dill pickles?  Did you know that they make their own bread too?  Well they do.  They have an entire bakery upstairs.The only thing I can complain about here, besides it being a bit pricy, is the size of the cups of water.  They are the smallest glasses I have ever seen!  I have to get it filled like 5 or 6 times during a meal.  One time I actually asked my waiter for a bigger glass because I would drink the whole thing as soon as he filled it. The best part is that they are open 24 hours, so any time I get a craving I can feed it.

Reviews.Author: Krisztina V.
Reviews.Content: MEAT!  MEAT!  MEAT!! MEET ME HERE!!This place is one of my all-time fav's.I LOVE deli.These are the Greats: 1. Potato salad2. Plate of Pickles3. Hard Salami sandwich4. Liverwurst sandwich5. Pastrami6. Beef Dip7. Egg Salad sandwich8. Turkey sandwich with Cole-slawThe food is not only the great thing here.  Its the fact its 24 hours!!!!  I love late night food, especially after a night of party-times.

Reviews.Author: Kelley B.
Reviews.Content: After finishing a great Monday night of improv and randomness, where to go?  Friends suggested Canter's...and I was happily transported back to my corner NYC deli/diner.  (If my corner Gemini diner had grown to at least six times its size and was adorned with a blown glass ceiling in the back room)  Hmmm, so there were a few differences, but overall I was in heaven...a gritty NY-style heaven.Happily smiling as the waiter came over in a grungy tshirt and skin tight pants, slapping down waters, and taking our order immediately even if we weren't quite ready.  Even more excited by the generous plate of pickles and menu of deeply fried and troublingly meaty choices (which I rejected for a reasonable greek salad...I am so broken!).  Top it off with my favorite NY-style game of tracking down the waiter for the check, because if you don't they will never bring it.  Add the token black & white cookie and poppy seed struedel at the door and experience complete.Makes me crave home, but its nice to know I can get a bit of it in LA.

Reviews.Author: Leonardo H.
Reviews.Content: I don't know why I even bother writing this review; there's already 500 others --and who doesn't know of this joint?As an occasional visitor to LA, I've come here every single time I'm in LA with my band. My bandmates and I all love it and it hasn't let us down.My singer likes it for its rockstar cred: Guns N Roses  used to kick it here, apparently. They even sell a book written by the owner's son or something like that.I like it for their yummy Balls, Matzo Balls, and the chill late-night atmosphere. We usually dont have much choice for food after playing a show, so it's a really good thing that Canters is always open to feed us.

Reviews.Author: Daniel G.
Reviews.Content: "I've never had a $15 sandwhich before, I wonder what it tastes like"That was my reaction when i saw the menu. $15 for a freakin sandwhich and a SMALL side of coleslaw or potato salad? Granted, that was the most expensive sandwhich on the menu, but come on. I ordered it out of curiosity, it was the John Canter's Special or something like that, the one with corned beef, pastrami, turkey, ham, and cheese on rye. This was a large sandwhich, probably enough meat to make 2-3 sandwhiches at another deli, but still, it's probably like $3-4 worth, so how do you get to a 500% markup on that? I don't know. Seems like a rip off to me. And it wasn't even anything special, just meat, cheese, and bread. Big whoop. A nothing special sandwhich.I understand that this place has a lot of history and i'm guessing that's what you're paying for if you come to eat here. I've read that they do have some great waffles and monte cristos, but i'm not really into those dishes... oh well. What i tried was just so-so.One cool thing was that we came here with a group of almost 30 people and the accidently put in 2 extra orders of potato pancakes to the kitchen that no one ordered. So after everyone was served, they were just sitting there on a cart by our table. After we were done eating, i asked the waitress what was going on with them, she said that they were extra...and asked if i wanted them. i was going to ask her for them, but she offered them to me anyways. I thought that was pretty cool. We had a bunch of potato pancakes for a midnite snack that night thanks to the waitress.

Reviews.Author: Christa A.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is one of the great things about Los Angeles.  This deli to me is the motley crue of delicatessens. It is run down a bit and the service isn't always the greatest but it is definitely one of my favorite places to go. The pickles are perfection, the two egg breakfast is the shit, the fries are amazing and to bring it all home, the black and whites are sinfully delightful and highly addicting.

Reviews.Author: Stephen D.
Reviews.Content: Look at you! You sexy Beast!Bless your pleather booths with high backs. Bless your latka, oh how delicious. Breakfast is out of this world and the kanish? Outstanding. Dr Bronners Black Cherry soda, black and white cookies.. All of it was good enough to pass Heathers fathers Bronx-bred Jewish test. Combine that with the fact that they're open 24 hours and it looks like a time machine, and you have a winner.

Reviews.Author: shannon r.
Reviews.Content: Oh Yelpers. I have to say. I feel a little let down.I also have to say that 3-star rating is very generous, and in large part to our amazing waitress, who flawlessly handled a crowd of 50.  I've thought about Canter's for a long time. I've waited for the right opportunity to go-I've ignored the naysayers, and patiently waited to check it out for myself.I kept my order simple. Matzo Ball soup and a half of an egg-salad sandwich on rye.  How can you screw that up, right?  Well. You can.First off, I have nothing against a softball sized matzo ball... when it tastes good. This one was boring and just unimpressive outside of it's freakish size.  The broth tasted like it was either out of a can or possibly a denny's. I've never had chicken broth at denny's but it's a safe bet, this is what it would taste like.  Now I *know* it's called matzo ball soup... but c'mon.. no little egg noodles? really? just me. the giant ball. and the yucky broth. Now, the sandwich. The egg-salad itself was edible, the lettuce was fine, but there must have been some rye bread mishap in the back, because I had two small pieces from the edge of the bread, that had been flipped over so that the fact that they were mostly the heal was concealed. oh well!I'm just more accustomed to DZ Akin's Jewish Deli in San Diego, where the food is actually worth the hypeyelp.com/biz/dz-akins-sa…

Reviews.Author: mike j.
Reviews.Content: 3 stars by day, 4 stars by night.During the day, this place really isn't worth the trip. Expensive & none of the food is that great.But, if it's late and you want some grub, it becomes a semi-contender though I'd still rather Fred 62s or something (though they don't really have deli stuff). 2 things I've found great there:1. their philly cheese steak was one of the best I've had in LA2. their bakery- obviously, pretty awesome.

Reviews.Author: Cynthia G.
Reviews.Content: A good stop after the clubs since this place is open til super late. It's hard to make a choice since they have about anything you can think of on the menu. Breakfast, lunch, dinner, you name it. But one of my faves is the Matzo ball soup and the Potato Pancakes. Potato pancakes comes with apple sauce and sour cream as a topping. I def need to start cooking these myself! Service is OK.. just basically a huge restaurant full of people. Atmosphere is OK as well.

Reviews.Author: Stephanie R.
Reviews.Content: My husband LOVED this place!!! He said this was one of the best Pastrami sandwich's he has had, next to Katz Deli in New York. I, on the other hand, am not really a fan of Jewish Deli's. I ordered the stuffed baked potato and it was good, not great. Parking was hard to find, but that is to be expected in LA. And service was less than friendly, again to be expected considering how popular this place is. I am sure we will be back here, only because my husband loved it so much. Please note: Do not ask to substitute your side orders, you will be painfully shut down and left with only cole slaw and potato salad to mask your humiliation.

Reviews.Author: Carlos V.
Reviews.Content: Canters Fairfax is awesome! Onion rings are great! Great selection of pastries in the bakery!

Reviews.Author: Jessica F.
Reviews.Content: I wish I could give Canter's 2.5 stars instead of 3, but since I can't, let's throw the extra half in there because it's open 24 hours.  The pickles are fun.  The soups are good.  The Reuben wasn't too bad.  Again, if you like nostalgic trips down memory lane for what used-to-be, this is a good choice.  I don't find the food that good here.  The service is slow, crotchety, and pretty much the most colorful thing about going.  You could do worse in this neighborhood, and you could do better.  Make sure you go to the Farmer's Market when you're over there.  The Grove is there too...maybe you'll see Mischa Barton buying something expensive and ugly.

Reviews.Author: Jaime T.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is a classic LA diner.  The decor has been the same throughout my lifetime (which isn't long in Canter's history) complete with a 1950s era coffee maker and decor.  Plus, you can't beat the surly waiters and waitresses that have probably been there since shortly after the deli opened.  And, how can you turn down free pickles??They have great cabbage soup and matzo ball soup and their potato pancakes make you wanna slap someone's mama because we all know we can't slap our own!Sandwiches are always filled to the brim with meat and they never let you leave hungry.  When you go to pay your bill, you have to pass by the bakery section and the rugaleh always calls my name.  You can't leave it behind especially when it screams "eat me, eat me, you know you want me." Alas, I am weak and can't resist....

Reviews.Author: Kai P.
Reviews.Content: Stepping into this place is like having one foot in a coffin, the other in 1980s Amarillo Texas. So I'm already freaked out by the atmosphere- I keep imagining "The Shining" or "No Country For Old Men."  Our waitress, bless her heart was equip with mullet, gaudy lipstick and picket fence teeth.  Hungover and hungry, we order sweet potato fries (on account of the table side advertisement regarding them as the 'healthy alternative' to regular fries.  I guess when given a choice between the devil and his minion, go with the lesser evil.)  They were decent, given the circumstances.  Of course we got the pastrami- best I've ever tasted, hands down.  The meat was perfectly seasoned, juicy and didn't have that annoying accordion- style fat distribution.  The bread was spongy, baked with flecks of oregano.I also had the spinach, jack, and mushroom omelet.  Maybe the mushrooms they used were awesome, but this thing was soaking wet. Like someone had sent the eggs down a water slide. And believe you me, slimy eggs on a queezy stomach just wasn't going down.  What the omelet lacked, the hash browns more than made up for. Sliced Au- grautin style with a crispy exterior. I rushed to evacuate them from the flooded plate, doused them with salt and went to town.  I can't even recommend this place on value. I'd much rather spend  little more and get better quality at any Hollywood status (insert name here) sidewalk cafe.

Reviews.Author: Mike I.
Reviews.Content: 3am trip here was totally worth the guilt I feel today. Super good Reuben.I don't why I did, but I ordered chicken noodle soup, pretty bland. Good onion rings and fries.

Reviews.Author: Eric B.
Reviews.Content: Corned beef on rye with mustard. Side of cole slaw. Side of dill pickles. Oh. My. God. Follow that down with some coffee and you are in food heaven. Hmm, two "religious" references about a Jewish deli. hehe. But hey, that is what their food is like - it's a religious experience. It's that delicious.It starts the minute you walk in and see their bakery on the left. Then it really hits you when you sit down and see the menu with a million items on it. Then you just about peak when you take your first bite. And then, on your way to grab a smoke, you walk by that bakery and grab a few dozen treats. (I don't smoke, so the treats are just as good!) The thing I really like about this place, well, besides their food, is the fact that they are open 24 hours. So, it makes an killer place to stop when you are out in LA and need to chill out after a fun night. The service here has always been great, even late at night. And don't forget to validate your parking before you leave. They have the stamp up front by the bakery. Just do it yourself.

Reviews.Author: Ron N.
Reviews.Content: You gotta love places that are open after clubbing nights.  My taste buds must be off because I ordered what the waiter recommended ("Pastrami Reuben") and I honestly thought it was disgusting.  I thought it just might be me, and so I asked one of my best friends what he thought and he said the same thing.  If anything I enjoyed the potato chips more than the sandwich itself.  Since most people on here have favorable reviews about it, it may just be me.  It looked like a lot of care was put into making the sandwich which is always a plus.I did really appreciate how nice the staff was.  Walking in I felt a very home and welcoming type of vibe.  I'll most likely come back another time and try something else on the menu as many people seem to like this joint.

Reviews.Author: Jessica S.
Reviews.Content: :( I wanted to like this more.  We went for breakfast bc every other good brunch place in the area had an hour+ wait and my bf and I were fighting about the waits since we were both hungry (relationships are fun like that).  I got the fairfax...half pastrami and half corned beef sandwich on rye. The rye was not toasted like I'd expected. Instead, it was a bit soggy.  But my sandwich ordered toast w his meal, so I used that and my sandwich was good.  I liked the pastrami more than the corned beef. I also was picturing a reuben in my head, so I ordered some thousand island and sauerkraut on the side to make my sandwich more like a reuben (sandwich was $13.95 and they charged $1.50 for my toppings...).  Bf got corned beef hash.  Looked different from most corned beef hashes I've eaten. Breakfast plate wasn't anything special.Breakfast was $40.  OJs were like $4 each.  Definitely overpriced. I'd only go for the corned beef or pastrami sandwiches. O-open 24 hours :)

Reviews.Author: Kenneth W.
Reviews.Content: The interior seems more dated each time I go here. The food is pretty delicious if you like deli food. I think the bakery in front is pretty awesome, too. They do offer non-deli like food. I've never disliked a meal here. I'd go back if I found myself nearby.

Reviews.Author: T A.
Reviews.Content: I'd give it 5 stars, but as others have said, the prices are rather high.  Service can be a little bit spotty as well - unless you are seated in Fran's section. Fran rules!Really, though, Canters is a little slice of Heaven. Perfect turkey on rye, every time. My husband's favorite is the Eddie Cantor (I refer to it as the Gout Special). Pickles are out of this world.  The coleslaw is decent, even - and I don't care much for coleslaw. We usually grab a loaf of rye bread and some treats to go from the bakery on the way out.  Do not leave without buying baked goods!  So yum.

Reviews.Author: Tiffanie L.
Reviews.Content: This is, by far, my favorite late night hangout. A lot of great memories throughout the years are associated with this place, as it is usually the end-cap for a lot of adventures/misadventures.Once you're seated, you'll be given just enough time to contemplate what you want, as a casual perusal of the colossal menu will always make you rethink the mish mosh soup or Marilyn Sandiwich you were craving on the way to the diner. My favorites include:The fruit cup (always fresh and tasty!)A "side" order of steak fries that'll probably take a few people to finishThe tuna meltThe MarilynThe avocado meltLox and cream cheese on a bagelThe humongous caesar saladMish Mosh soup (Mazta Ball/Noodles/Kreplach/Carots)The waffle sundae (you might as well skip dinner for this feat...)Cheese blintzes Potato pancakesMost of the time, the waiters and waitresses are pretty friendly and chill; they'll leave you alone to yap the night away, but will always swing by to refill your water. Besides being a great late night hangout, Canter's is synonymous with great people watching. There are a lot of characters late at night, and if you check out the booth to the very left of the main cashier, you might see Rodney Biggenheimer in his reserved seat! As of late, I've noticed that the wait staff doesn't automatically set out a plate of pickles after seating patrons, so if you want to get your pickles on... make sure to ask.If you're not stuffed after dinner, try some pastries from the bakery! On my way out, I always pick up a carrot cake for my mom, but never anything for myself because the sight of sweets will make me nauseas after eating a filling dinner. So, if you're like me, buy your pastries beforehand...!All in all, a great place for comfort food and good times.

Reviews.Author: Mark B.
Reviews.Content: I love taking out of town guests to Canter's. No one expects any place in LA to be comfy or to have any sort of history. I'm from the midwest, where we love us some comfy greasy spoons. In fact, we REFUSE to eat anywhere unless 1) there's a few coats of bacon grease evaporate on all visible vinyl surfaces and 2) all waitstaff are women over 40.The pastrami and corned beef here are fantastic, piled mega high, and served with your choice of no less than 5 different kinds of mustard if you ask for it. I like the Fairfax sandwich, it comes with both meats.The matzo ball soup cures you, magically. When I slurp it, I can imagine how Link feels in Lengend of Zelda when the fairy is filling up his heart life meter. Ahhhhhhhhh.Usually diner pickles suck hard, and I can usually tolerate about zero bites. Not so with Canter's bad boys. I get my pickle on hardcore up in that mug. Super crisp and garlicky. As I'm sure many have mentioned before, it's great for people watching. Half the people in there looked like they walked in out of Ghost World - the comic, not the movie.The psychotic tree-themed ceiling tile pattern is also a key part of the experience.HELPFUL TIP: If the lot is full, park a block west of Fairfax on Hayworth. You'll find a spot.

Reviews.Author: Dee C.
Reviews.Content: Even Denny's would've been better...Over-priced meals that could've been made a lot better at home type-of-deal. I got the corned beef/pastrami Reuben... Not bad but not great. They give you an appetizer plate of pickles... yes, just pickles. I would say this was probably the best thing there. I was super excited about their macaroni salad which ultimately disappointed me. Big venue, awkward decor with random plants on the top (you'll know what I mean when you're there), odd mosaic ceiling... Got a few cookies/pastries...wasn't that great either.BLAH

Reviews.Author: Claire K.
Reviews.Content: GROSS!!!! I'm not even going to begin with how I dragged to this place at 4am, I'm just going to stick to the facts: 1- It smelled like MEAT. I'm no vegetarian here, I'm just saying that is smelled like how I envision "Meatball" from "Aqua Team Hunger Force" smelling after he's run a marathon, played football, and not showered for a week. This was no "steak on the grill/ turkey in the oven" smell, this was FOUL. 2- The fiance ordered a hot chocolate and it was SWISS MISS. I don't remember how much it cost, but I remember thinking that I could buy a whole damn box of Swiss Miss for that price. 3- We split a peace of cherry pie and it was more fake and synthetic than the Hostess "fruit" pies they sell at the gas station. GROSS!!! 4- It seemed pretty dirty 5- What's with the "leaves." Like I remember the decor has all of this weird fall foliage, faux stained glass stuff. Wtf? 6- Every other dish I saw looked gross. We will NOT be back. 7- Service wasn't good for friendly either.

Reviews.Author: Scott M.
Reviews.Content: First of all, it's a 24/7 restaurant.  That already makes it a joint to be reckoned with.  Especially given the location, it's not a horrible schlep from much of the east side.  That means good food at 3am, no matter where you're partying.Canter's has an awesome roasted turkey reuben.  It was huge (justifies the price, sort of) and delicious!  They put enough 1,000 island on the side to douse the thing - which is exactly what I did.  My friend had a matzo ball (veggie fyi: cooked in chicken broth) and liked it a lot as well.It doesn't really look like the kind of place where you go to order the more complex foods, but for deli food, Canter's is solid!I can't give this place five stars until I visit a couple of more times, but I am planning on giving it that distinction asap!

Reviews.Author: Terry G.
Reviews.Content: I know this place is iconic, but it was really just eh...ok.  There are a lot of homeless outside begging got money and they will follow you to your car so watch out for that.  I got a pastrami sandwich and it was ok.  The pickles are really gross, but I'm not used to those authentic Kosher ones.Also, DO NOT use their bathroom. It's nasty.  Plus it's upstairs so I wouldn't recommend this restaurant to anyone who is disabled.Best part was my black and white cookie I got from the bakery in front. Now THAT was really good.  I'd say, it's worth going just to say you've been there.

Reviews.Author: Kelsee I.
Reviews.Content: I can't say I loved this place... It just doesn't seem like my type of place. I honestly didn't think that the food was very good and when you combine that with the price it really isn't good. To me, the food just didn't have good flavor. Instead of eating a normal amount of something delicious, there is a lot of mediocre food.It's cool that it is in a vintage building, but the decor is vintage with it and I'm not talking about cool vintage. The staff wasn't particularly nice or mean - just there, but that's probably because the place is huge and they must have lots of tables.Overall, just not my type of place and I won't be returning.

Reviews.Author: Ben W.
Reviews.Content: I love the pickles! The food is ok to good. The matzo ball soup was very good today but sometimes its too salty or very bland and funky. So I say it's inconsistent sometimes.I just like thinking that I'm eating where the rock legends have eaten.

Reviews.Author: Shauntemarie G.
Reviews.Content: All Im gonna say is.......French Dip.... Tha BIZZNEZZ

Reviews.Author: Hayley H.
Reviews.Content: Your Jewish Grandmother would approve. If you want to do classic Los Angeles the right way, a trip to Canters is required..nothing beats the original. I love the Matzo Ball soup, and the pastrami sandwich. The hubs prefers the meatloaf or the thanksgiving dinner. In my opinion if you are going to eat at a deli, order the freakin deli food. Some people come in and order burgers, quesadilla , or salads. What the?!  I love the pastrami in my opinion you cant go wrong.  I watch to many people come here and order the wrong stuff. Visit the bakery, everything is amazing there. Get yourself some hamentashen bakery along with rugelach and you wont be sad. Parking can suck, you can on occasion get a cranky waitress but it is actually part of the charm.

Reviews.Author: Ashley Anne B.
Reviews.Content: Absolutely horrible! Please do not spend your hard earned dollar here.  I ordered a Chile mushroom omelet with cheese and my boyfriend ordered the Turkey pastrami sandwich. The omelet was wet and looked like the chiles and mushroom were from cans! I tried one bite hoping it wouldn't taste as bad as it looked but it was so bland I didn't even eat it.  My boyfriend said the sandwich was also bland and dry.  We left very unhappy, thank goodness we had a groupon!  I would have never paid full price!The only thing good we can say is that the women (I think her name was Carol) who rang us up was apologetic,  and so was our server.  Our server took off the omelet and apologized for the inconvenience. The omelet was $12 plus tax!  Need it be said, we will not be returning and I hope this review prevents others from going as well.

Reviews.Author: Maria Y.
Reviews.Content: I think the worst addicition for women and men are carbs. Just thinking of rye bread gives me the shivers!!!FRESH RYE BREAD! END OF STORY!This is what every pastrami should taste like.  Theres other stuff on the menu, but you cant come here and not order what theyre famous for!DO TRY:matzo ball soupReuben sandwichCorn beef sandwichpastrami sandwich END OF STORY GOOD MEAL GOOD TIME DUH!

Reviews.Author: Jed M.
Reviews.Content: This is going to be my initial rating since it's the first time I've been here.  There's a lot to experience at this one place.  Don't let it deceive you because there's a little more than meets the eye when you enter.What you'll encounter?  Their baked goods... cakes, pastries and pie to capture the wandering eye.  And as you walk in a little further you'll see the entrance to the seating area for the restaurant.First impressions?  Definitely vintage with some old poster advertisements and a few colorful stained glass separators to tingle your 1960s and 70s sensibilities.  No, this isn't Grease or Happy Days, but you'll definitely get a little friendly service.So what's the food like?  I had their Monte Cristo.  A turkey and ham sandwich cuddled between two thick slices of french toast and doused with a generous helping of powdered sugar, served with syrup and some jam.  Sounds tasty, right?  It was actually a  little dry and when I say dry I'm referring to the turkey meat.  Ham, you can almost never get it wrong, but you either really love the way the turkey meat is prepared or you don't.That particular day, I wasn't too excited about it and a Monte Cristo I did have elsewhere had delightfully juicy turkey meat, but it also had bacon.  And we all know bacon just seems to make everything better!But I can't speak too poorly of their food because they do have a Reuben sandwich and it was one of their specialties.  One of my friends had ordered that and another friend ordered their pastrami. The generosity of meat you get would make your veggie friends cry.  And the dipping sauce they offer you isn't in a little tea cup either... it's served in what looks like a large ceramic breakfast bowl.  And what my friends wanted to say...they couldn't.  Why?  Because the Food Federation was in town and their mouths were stuffed with sandwich-- Kobayashi is jealous at this point.  So you do, for the most part, get what you pay for.It would be nicer if you didn't have to pay for parking, but if you're not staying for too long they do validate parking.

Reviews.Author: Pea M.
Reviews.Content: Best deli in town!!...and i can walk to it!!....and i do...every week. I usually get a Reuben, pancakes or omelets and have had the brisket sliders... all excellent. I also get a lot of food to go... and the guys that work the deli counter are the best. I highly recommend!!

Reviews.Author: Andrew L.
Reviews.Content: Coming from a Jewish family with a long history in the food business, trust me when I say that I have had my fair share of deli. After reading some of the other reviews, I am surprised by some of the dishes that people order -- pastrami on a french roll with provolone?? That's truly Annie Hall w.a.s.p status...Nevertheless, after trying deli from New York to Chicago to San Francisco to LA, for me Canter's has and should continue to reign supreme.  The food is awesome -- go for a hot pastrami on rye bread with mustard.  That's all it needs.  Or switch out pastrami for corned beef or tongue. The pickles are amazing.  the sides are great.The bagels are the best in America, no joke, and their selection of smoked fish is excellent.I love their kishka as well.  It's something you can't find everywhere, and although I don't exactly know what it is made out of (and frankly I want to keep it that way), it sort of is like a smooth and bready sausage type of thing.  Finally, the baked goods are all great, especially the hamentachen and rugalach, and i have fond memories of them giving me free sprinkle cookies as a little kid.The location is cool and funky, right on Fairfax, and parking isn't a problem.  Forget Jerry's or even Carnegie's, Canter's is where it's at.

Reviews.Author: Wes G.
Reviews.Content: Jesus, every last one of you is insane.  I consider myself the king of diners.  As my friend once explained to these girls we were trying to seal the deal with, diners are like porn to me.  This one though is like bad midget porn on a VHS tape that needs serious trackin adjustment. The food is shit, the service is shit, the prices are shit.  I have NEVER had a good experience here.   And I've given Canter's about five chances to prove me wrong over the years.  Well, no more.  Ashonda, Canter's!  You shmuck's.  If you want some good late night dining nearby, go to Swingers near Fairfax and Beverly.

Reviews.Author: JJ W.
Reviews.Content: My friend David would take me here all the time. He liked this spot especially late night. Given my love for pastrami I had no problem and since he always insisted on paying as he would end up at his preferred destination made no sense of things what so ever. As for the food I cannot complain. The prices are not bad not for such a sandwich. They pile it pretty high and the table mustard is good. Everything else on the menu seems pricey to me aside from the sandwiches. I only come here for pastrami and maybe a brisket sandwich. Cheesecake if necessary but it is not the best. I also like the take out as they will slice it for the amount you desire. That goes for any meat you would like. I also like their pickles and will take some to go. For you fish lovers they have the pickled herring or whatever is it you eat, lox, green tomatoes I think and good cream cheese. The bakery is on the other side as you enter and they have babkes, racetracks, black and white cookies, fresh bread and so many other assortment of baked goods. I would say it is something your grandma would make for you. Nothing here is inexpensive but if this is the food you crave then there is no reason not to come here.

Reviews.Author: Angela K.
Reviews.Content: I wish Orange County had a deli that could come close to Canter's (yeah, Jerry's deli, not so much). Their reubens here are pure heaven. I've tried a reuben at Carnegie Deli in New York and it compare to Canter's perfection.  The meat is piled so thick I can barely fit it into my mouth. And the pickles are perfect, a bit spicy and perfectly crisp. Yeah service sucks here but that's all part of the experience so that's not an issue with me at all. I can't bear taking away a full star for this because the food is so good but be prepared this place is pricey! Its pretty hard to get out of there for under $25 a person.Make sure to stop by the bakery and grab some cookies to go. They have a huge selection and they're all good.PS: This place is extra awesome now that I know Guns N Roses hung out here all the time in the 80s.

Reviews.Author: Hannah S.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is the spot for sobering up after a few drinks at the Dime. The night staff looks like the cast of Rocky Horror Picture Show and there's been a few times when we've met the most random characters there.Portions are generous, prices are a bit much, and the food is yummy. I love the Marilyn sandwich. Service can be a bit slow, but if it's after one in the morning I don't blame them.

Reviews.Author: philip s.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is one of the few institutions that remains untouched by time.  They (along with Musso & Franks) are two places in Los Angeles that serve up not only the kind of food they are famous for, but also serve up "the Kitsch" (atmosphere) that somehow makes the food taste better.First being Jewish myself and originally from New York, I KNOW DELI.  No matter what you've heard or think you know.........New York deli isn't the end all of end alls.  They get their meat from the same place but each place puts their special "take" or "spin" on an old favorite and so it becomes kind of "self promotion" and word of mouth either adds to the reputation or it doesn't.Being Jewish in a deli is an advantage much like going to a Mom and Pop Mexican restaurant with someone who knows the food.  Mexican food isn't just about tacos and Jewish deli isn't just about matzah balls.So with all of that being said, I'm glad to say that Canter's is still the same.  It hasn't changed one bit:  Still owned by the same family for nearly 90 years, the waitress' still fall into the two main divisions: the one's that call you "honey and deary" and the grumpy waitress with the long face and "sore feet".  It's part of the "deli experience".I used to live within walking distance way back when in the 1970s and the only change like with everything else..........prices have gone UP.If you want cheap (goy) pastrami, go to "The Hat" and be ready to hail and bail (throw up) afterward.There are some things to consider: My date (who is not Jewish) wanted certain things which added to the bill but since she wanted it..........cost wasn't a concern.But be forwarned:  Onion rings are $5.95Matzah ball soup is the same priceA soda or tea $2.95These are all priced higher than they should be.But I digress.  A pastrami reuben which is basically a grilled cheese sandwich with a lot of pastrami and goodies inside was $13.50 which is about the norm.  Fatty, greasy but full of flavor and pepper served on rye bread that falls somewhat short of New York rye and Langer's rye bread........but it's gooooooooooooood!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!The bill came to $45 (not including tip) which my date commented on as being "somewhat expensive" but with a GROUPON, it knocked things down to a more "mouth watering" $25.A couple of last thoughts: When you go to a deli, ask for extra pickles.  Jewish pickles are like no other.And if you're so inclined......Canter's has a full bar.  A draft beer goes great with the pastrami reuben.And.............you'll take home enough for lunch the next day.Unless you're a "chazer rye" (big eater)

Reviews.Author: Phil Y.
Reviews.Content: Canter's has always been a place that I have heard good things about, but, have never visited until today.   I came here with the coworkers after working in the area.  It was tough work, we were all hungry.The service was excellent.  The waitress promptly took our orders.   Both the manager and the waitress were routinely making the rounds refilling our cups with soda or water.  We were well taken care of.  While waiting for our food, they gave us a plate of pickles and a bunch of mustard.  The pickles were okay.   We all took the lead of the gringo.  He added mustard to his pickles.  Surprisingly, it was good.  Lunch came soon after. I ordered the pastrami sandwich.  I forgot to tell the waitress that I do not like rye bread.   Since I was the one who stupidly made the mistake in ordering, I didn't complain and ate my sandwich.  Needless to say, I didn't like my sandwich.   I thought the pastrami was dry, and the rye bread was very rye.  I wasn't impressed with the pastrami.I can't write this restaurant off since I made the mistake in ordering.   Since I liked the service, and pickles, I'll give it 3 stars.   If I make it back here again, I'll have to get their sandwich on white, or on a roll.

Reviews.Author: Clay H.
Reviews.Content: We go to Canters anytime we're anywhere near L.A. Best pastrami in the world! I always make myself a dirty pickletini, which is kinda odd, cause I never have one anywhere but here.

Reviews.Author: Amos J.
Reviews.Content: This is a good place to go and get some streight up good old food.  I've only really eaten there once and it was on Christmas day. It was pretty much the only place that I could find that was open.  I ate an omlette that was pretty good.  The lady that waited on us could have been mistaken as being rude but I think she just had a no no-nsense attitude.  When I said that the omlette was good she said, "of course it is."Another cool thing about this place is the Kibitz room.  It's a little bar in the back where bands play sometimes.  I seems like just a hole in the wall type bar but i think it's a freindly atmosphere.  If you're in a band its a cool place to play because they won't charge your friends admission and some people will just walk in off the street to watch the bands.  So even though it might smell wierd in there sometimes, Canter's is still a good place to go.

Reviews.Author: Chris C.
Reviews.Content: Canters has been one of my dad's favorite eateries in Los Angeles since before I was born. As a result I have very fond memories of this place, along with a few colorful ones...including the one where I called my dad  a ba$t..in front of everyone (including some of his friends)...he promptly escorted me to the bathroom for an impromptu a..whoopin'.Canters has recently started to "freshen" up their staff, which is a bittersweet affair. My childhood memories are filled with their signature waitresses...but some of their new staff is very good.Overall the food at canters is good but I end up going there for the corned beef on rye. I like having a side of pickles (often free) and on occasion I'll go for some bagel chips and matzah ball soup.

Reviews.Author: Big M.
Reviews.Content: My review of Canters will be very similar to my review of Damiano's Pizza which is directly across the street.  These two places are ghetto-fabulous, and I say that in a good way.The neighborhood has changed a bunch throughout the years.  I literally grew up a few blocks away on Edinburgh Avenue and moved the f*ck out of LA to get away from the craziness.This place used to be a normal, I mean.. it blended into the neighborhood.  Now, with the advent of the fancy fancy " GROVE, " we have a bunch of n00bs moving into the neighborhood with more money than brains.  People who want fancy eateries and cant appreciate a place that has been around forever.  Yuppy scum.Anyway, I wont rant anymore about the fake Los Angelinos who criticize Canters for being ghetto.  Canters has a lot to offer, deli & bakery with lots of goodies to chose from.  Want to dine in?  Huge menu with soups & sandwiches.  You may want to make note of the hot pastrami sandwich and the matzos ball soup, things that I *must* order every time I visit.  I dont even care to try anything else because this is just so damn good.Its a shame to hear people talk bad about this place, really.  You dont have to be Jewish to appreciate this place, you just have to like good food and appreciate this place for being around as long as its been.  If you criticize this place you may want to think a bit longer and harder about how many decades this place has been around for.  Dont forget, its open 24-7/365!!!If you're a spoiled brat, go up the street to Jerry's Deli near the Beverly Center... they'll happily rip you off and serve you overpriced garbage.  You can blend in with the rest of pseudo-rich yuppies squawking on their cell phones not paying attention to the overpriced garbage their paying to eat.  Dont forget to lube up before you get banged because you'll need to valet.

Reviews.Author: alex v.
Reviews.Content: This place is legendary; iconic really.  I've never eaten here until recently.  It was a late night stroll through the city and drinks that brought me to Canter's.The place looks like a bit of a shoddy cafeteria.  Or, if that visual doesn't work; think of Canter's as that husky voiced broad whose best years are behind her.  You see her at the bar taking a drag from her Virginia Slims.  You know she knows she's old and weathered, yet you're still intimidated, because you know she'll show you the goods and make a man out of you... Or a woman, you choose.Plainly put, this place is open twenty four seven.  I had the Pastrami Reuben... Yum.  A slice of heaven at 2am.  We are not treated this well in OC, normally we have to treck somewhere far off to have late night loveliness or settle for Norms or Denny's.  Bluuugh!!Worth every bite, imo.PS.THere was a live band playing the space adjacent to the restaurant.  Interesting... Moreso if the band didn't suck.

Reviews.Author: Num Y.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is resting on its laurels as a Hollywood landmark.  Food-wise they aren't doing anything that someone else isn't doing better.  The service sucks and the servers all seem like they are in a huge hurry to drop your plate on the table and run away.  The decor is . . . well . . . old.  Oh, the prices are outrageous to begin with AND everything costs extra.  Want butter for your bread?  Extra.  Onions in your eggs?  Extra.  You get the picture.  As much as I like delis, there are better options than Canter's.

Reviews.Author: Jeff F.
Reviews.Content: My friends and I were in Hollywood at a volleyball tournament. After it was over we were looking for a place to go that had great desserts and good food. I remembered this place from when I used to live in Hollywood, so we went for it. It wasn't as fantastic as I remember it, and that could be because I was always a bit intoxicated when I went here (we used to go after going out to clubs). When you sit down, they give you a plate of pickles, much like you'd get a basket of bread at a restaurant. They're famous for their pickles, and they were damn good pickles actually.I had the Reuben with Pastrami and Roast Beef, and it had the other typical Reuben stuff (sauerkraut, 1000 island dressing, swiss cheese) on Rye bread. It was huge! There's no way to eat it bite by bite, unless you're Andre The Giant that is. It came with french fries, which were pretty good. I also had a chocolate milk shake, which I highly recommend getting. The server was an older woman with a bitter demeanor, but she was actually quite funny - I think she just played the role of a tired old woman. For the sandwich and the milkshake the bill came to $16. It's not cheap, but I saved the other half of the sandwich for the next day, so it was kind of like having two meals. In that perspective, it wasn't as expensive. But if you're a big eater, be prepared to pay a bit more.

Reviews.Author: Heather H.
Reviews.Content: If you're looking for an experience, this is the place to go.The people aren't going to wow you with huge smiles and peppy explanations of specials. If you want that, go to Applebee's. They will wow you with the history all over the walls, the main courses, and the DESSERTS. The desserts are to die for! Did I mention the desserts?I had a nice bowl of Matzo ball soup with the biggest, fluffiest matzo ball I've ever seen. I had two nice slices of Challah on the side and a pickle.  I was so full of that delicious lunch that I had to take home the BIGGEST Homentash I've ever seen for dessert later. Did I mention the desserts?I'll add some pictures so you can see what I'm talking about, but if you're in LA for a short or long time, don't leave without going here at least once.Advice: Order something you normally wouldn't, look at the walls, and SAVE ROOM FOR DESSERT! :D

Reviews.Author: Sean P.
Reviews.Content: You know Canter's is a real class act! They forgot in our delivery order a potato Kanish - I called them they were very nice about it an sent one out quickly and included some cookies with it. Thanks Canter's

Reviews.Author: Marina S.
Reviews.Content: My husband and I went yesterday for our favorite sandwich as part of a final day of holiday feeding before we start a round of dieting before Christmas...Our must have is a pastrami ruben with coleslaw instead of sauerkraut. Soooo yummy.Also the coffee is fantastic and super hot. So appreciated. I think that I had the best service there that I have ever had!

Reviews.Author: Marisa J.
Reviews.Content: I've wanted to try this place since I moved out here. There's nothing like Jewish-style deli food. I had high expectations going in, and for good reason. I come from New York City, which is a mecca for places like Canter's. But, boy, was I disappointed. The menu is sprawling, which is always a good sign. As someone who currently does not eat meat, but is okay with dairy, I was able to choose from several options on the menu.The vegetable soup was pretty good. The soup wasn't overrun with salt and you could taste the vegetables. It was hearty, and I was significantly full with just half a cup. The egg salad half-sandwich I had with my meal was a different story. What looked delectable was actually a virtually flavorless concoction of extremely "yolky" egg salad. The rye bread wasn't anything to write home about, either.I have yet to experience anything from the bakery and might possibly consider returning just to test it out, but I'm not itching for another shot at the deli food.This turned out to be a truly disappointing $18-for-lunch-and-coffee affair.

Reviews.Author: G A.
Reviews.Content: Second and last time for me.First time was after a night of clubbing and anything taste good after that.This time I was sober and had a Groupon, we both ordered the Pastrami. If you love fatty meat, then this is for you. Service was fast because it was empty and waitress Debbie had no charisma. I'm not sure why I left a 25% tip but I did. We only ate half and took the rest home.To me, there is nothing really special about this place -- it's an over-priced, dark diner.

Reviews.Author: Asteroid C.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is an icon of the Hollywood/Fairfax area that is known across the country.  For what, I'm not sure; it can't be their food, service, or attitude because those are all abysmal.  Here is the breakdown:FOOD:  I tried this place out when I first moved to the area.  Seeing as how it was a famous Jewish deli, I decided to try the motzah ball soup; huge mistake.  This was the blandest motzah I've ever had and for a place that trumpets its Jewish cooking, I was simply shocked.  I had to leave it unfinished.SERVICE: Slower than you could possibly believe.  I could understand if this place was packed with customers but to be honest, it was nearly empty.  By the time the menu came, I was thinking of just going someplace else.  At least that was how my first experience was.  I went back at later one point to try out just the pastry counter.  The woman behind the counter was incredibly rude and acted put-out at every request, even complaining about me to other customers while I was still standing there.  Not a good way to entice return trips.PRICE:  I'll just say this: for the quality, the food should not cost this much - not even by half.  It's not necessarily the best feeling in the world when you feel the need to add up the numbers on the bill to make sure they're correct because "it couldn't possibly be this expensive!"AMBIANCE:  The decor of the place is pleasing since it is the original interior this place has had since the 60's but that doesn't mean the stains need to be vintage as well.  The seats, tables, menus, everything was filthy.  Bring some Purell.TOTAL:  Skip this place.  Hollywood needs 24 hour diners, it's true, but not a place that gives you the experience that you're eating sub-par, over-priced food on a dirty table while the people working the counters act annoyed with your every question or request.  I made a promise to myself after my second visit never to go in again.  I would advise you to do the same.

Reviews.Author: Tony O.
Reviews.Content: A classic LA dining experience. Our server Andy was spot on. Great ambiance. Eating a slice of LA's history.

Reviews.Author: Drew J.
Reviews.Content: This place is AWFUL.Gross, Dried up Old food that has been sitting there for days probably.  They charge WAY too much for their food probably because its sort of a "well-known" place so they feel they could get away with over charging so people feel like they're getting something better.  On top of that, The people are just rude.  I asked for a bagel and asked if I can have butter on it.  The lady said, "I don't do butter, you can bring it to some other place and ask for butter!" and then practically threw he bagel at me and was visibly pissed off as we exchanged the money and change.  GEEZ!  Is it so wrong to think that a deli would slice your bagel and put butter on it?  Even Starbucks does that!Oh and P.S. The bagel tasted like it was sitting out on a dusty shelf for a week.Horrible Place.

Reviews.Author: Ryan L.
Reviews.Content: My quest for the perfect Reuben has reached fruition.  The Jewish heaven this sandwich sent me to was by far the best experience corned beef and sauerkraut could give a man.In its traditional fashion, the reuben was stacked high with delicious mouthwatering corned beef, and finished with sauerkraut that one could only guess was made in house.  It was like a swingers party in my mouth, and the only invites were beautiful lipstick lesbian porn-stars that were knee deep in an extacy binge.On top of the delicious food, I was very happy with the choices of atmosphere that i was presented.  I could go with the more traditional sense of deli-food and eat in there cafeteria style dining area, or I could take a few steps to the side and enter the wonderful, dark-lit world known as the KIBBUTZ ROOM.  In the Kibbutz Room I could pony up to the full service bar and enjoy my orgasmic reuben while drinking a scotch and listening to the live blues/jazz musician that generally resides there.Be warned, in keeping with tradition of a Jewish Delicatessen, the prices are quite traditional as well, but don't let this keep you from selling yourself short of gastronomical glory... Consider it an investment in the emotional well-being of your taste-buds... and you will not leave disappointed.

Reviews.Author: Kaycee C.
Reviews.Content: Very disappointed in this restaurant. I make better sandwiches and salads than them. I've heard about Canter's, it seems like an LA staple but after going there, I have NO idea why. All the pastrami sandwich was was pastrami (while delicious, not uncommonly good) and bread (not toasted, not homemade, not butter, NOTHING). Coleslaw, basic. Split pea soup reminded me of Campbell's soup.My boyfriend got the turkey melt -- toasted bread, dry turkey, kraft single american cheese. and ruffles potato chips for $13 (not including tax and tip).My bf's mom's cobb salad was huge (about the only reason its worth the money). But again, nothing special.All and all, this place is good if you're about to die of hunger and you don't care about overspending.

Reviews.Author: Lauren P.
Reviews.Content: Oh, Canter's. If I lived in LA, I would be in you EVERY SINGLE WEEK.You don't need me to reiterate what hundreds of other Yelpers already have. This place is fun, tasty, and open 24 hours. Go. Eat their matzo ball soup and get a chocolate malt. Be happy.DONE.

Reviews.Author: Marleine P.
Reviews.Content: I love this place.  Classic east coast Jewish deli, something I miss have grown up outside of Manhattan.  It's got familiar comfort food favorites, like towering pastrami sandwiches, amazing matzo ball soup (order the Mish Mosh with veggies, chicken and noodles), and crispy potato pancakes served with sour cream and apple sauce. Holy hell.But what kills me are the pastries. The Chocolate Russian Coffee Cake will level you, and Canter's is the only place I can find these little rainbow cake cookies layered with marzipan, raspberry jam and chocolate. So homey and delicious.And I can walk there! :)

Reviews.Author: Lauren V.
Reviews.Content: BEST DELI IN LA!!First of all , the heaping bowls of pickles are essential, and they keep refilling it like it's a soft drink.THANK YOU CANTERS!matzah ball soup =WONDERFUL, add in some kreplach=EVEN MORE WONDERFUL. Also great cabbage soup, you goys may think that sounds nasty but its delicious.The sandwiches are outstanding. if you want to explode get a reuben and enjoy every moment . if you are a pussy get half or something .everything here is so good and authentic deli. i miss it, i need to go back to LA to pay respects to it's goodness

Reviews.Author: Ming Loong T.
Reviews.Content: 24 Hours of GOODNESS.Bakery, Cafe, Delicatessen.Pastrami and Corned Beef on RYE BREAD served with a side of their potato salad. YUM!!!I have to say, though, the texture of the potato salad is NEVER consistent. It always tastes AWESOME, but sometimes it's a bit too broken up and watery.Their service is always on the mark. I've always had a pleasant experience coming to Canter's to dine.The people that work the bakery counter, however, sometimes leave a lot to be desired. The past few times I went, the service was nice and I enjoyed myself. Most recently [last week], there was an older [I'd say 40s] fellow working behind the counter. He was neither very friendly nor very nice. His greeting and service were all blatantly perfunctory. That aside, I always have a pleasant experience and would recommend Canter's to anybody who loves a good Jewish deli. I think I'm going to try and study here and see how that goes.

Reviews.Author: Jennifer A.
Reviews.Content: My mom and I braved the awful Fairfax traffic to have lunch at Canter's before a visit to LACMA. I have to say, I loved the food and the retro style! Canter's probably hasn't been redecorated (fortunately) in the last 40 years, although they are currently celebrating their 80th anniversary!I had the mishmosh which is matzo ball soup, but loaded with more carbs - rice and noodles. The soup is huge and delicious and the matzo ball was the size of a softball. I think next time I'll stick with the regular soup instead of the mishmosh because it was very carby and I was stuffed after. I also had a few bites of the beef dip, which was also excellent. None of that deli style thin roast beef here! You get big, thick, tender slabs of beef between toasted buns. I think the au jus could have used a bit more salt, but other than that it was great.Of course we picked up a few things at the bakery to take home. I'm not exactly sure what I ordered because I just pointed, but I think it was chocolate babka. Whatever it was, it was so good! It almost reminded me of a chocolate croissant, but richer and more dense. Can't wait to wake up early tomorrow because I still have half saved for breakfast :)

Reviews.Author: Pegah Y.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is pure excellence. I came here for the first time today after a very long hike and the service, the food, the atmosphere, and just about everything is really excellent.  I had to gulp down 3 cups of cold ice water after my long hike and our waitress was completely understanding and kept bringing me water.  Awesome :)  She gave us plenty of time to order and wasn't rushing us or anything.  She was really helpful and gave us suggestions as well as brought out a little of the turkey salad sandwich out for us to try before we decided what to get.  My friend and I both got the half sandwich deal.  For $11.75 we each got half a sandwich of our choice, a little bit of coleslaw or mashed potatoes, and a cup of soup of our choice.Though the meal wasn't large it was certainly filling and delicious!  I absolutely loved my tuna salad sandwich, my vegetable beef soup, and my coleslaw!  The pickle topped it all off.  I definitely want to go back there and get their matzo ball soup and their corned beef sandwich.  I absolutely adore this place and it is instantly a favorite.  I can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Author: Ari M.
Reviews.Content: I was very disappointed when I visited Canter's on Christmas Eve. I'd even say I'd have been better off at Jerry's (and I'm no fan of Jerry's). The service virtually ignored my table for about fifteen minutes after we were seated. When we were finally approached by a waiter, we discovered our options were very limited despite the large menu. We asked if there was any side to go with our sandwich sampler aside from potato salad or coleslaw. The answer was an exhausted no, as though people have been asking for a side that wasn't drowned in mayonnaise for years. Trying to make the best of the situation, I ordered a bowl of matzo ball soup and a potato knish. I'm happy to report that the knish was very good. Made me want to take a trip to New York for some Mrs Stahl's! One of my friend's got some latkes, and enjoyed them. So, at the very least, Canter's knows what to do with potatoes! Unfortunately, the matzo ball soup was a bit... well... pathetic. It was a tasty enough mazto ball, but the broth was bland and there was nothing else in the bowl! No carrots, no onions, no celery, no chicken, no parsnip and no noodles. Nothing! Just broth and ball. BORING! The price would have been right if it had been a substantial bowl of soup, but for that little cup it was far too expensive. Then came the sandwiches. The turkey sandwich was just lettuce and extremely dry turkey. The roast beef was okay, but again, very plain... and the pastrami was just awful.In the end, the food isn't good enough, the prices are too high and the service needs a lot of work. Lucky for Canter's, they also have a bakery. Their chocolate chip danish has been a favorite in my family for years, and I also like their black and white cookie. I'd give the bakery three stars on its own, but only one star to the deli. As a whole, two stars.

Reviews.Author: Kevin N.
Reviews.Content: I decided to just stroll in here for a late night meal. After reading all the reviews, I decided to go with the Matzo ball soup with chicken. For $8, you get a huge soup bowl. Also, add in the garlic crackers, and it's pretty hard to finish it off. I decided to grab a sundae, nothing special, a rip off at $5. Nice ceiling tiles and quick customer service.Essentially this place is your typical jewish deli, nothing out of the ordinary, a bit overpriced but it's okay.

Reviews.Author: Rachael K.
Reviews.Content: Occasion: Catch-up sesh with Danielle and Eileen What I Had: Half Sandwich MealCanter's Reuben (corn beef sandwich) Matzo Ball Soup w/ChickenPotato Pancake (Latka) Napoleon (from bakery) Food Review: Thumbs up to the matzo ball soup! I've made and eaten latkas in the past, but this was my first time ever having matzo ball soup, and it was fantastic. It reminds me of having an Asian fish ball, except it's in chicken soup. Not too salty either. I tried one of Danielle's potato pancakes as well, and it was a little too crunchy on the edges and not as soft as I'd like on the inside (perhaps it wasn't thick enough when they cooked it?). The corn beef Canter's Reuben sandwich was pretty good too, but I'm just not a huge fan of sauerkraut. Eileen had the pastrami sandwich which looked good, but I think just judging from the same bread used in the Canter's Reuben, Langer's trumps Canter's. Service Review: The service here was actually really good! Our waiter was very attentive, but not excessively so, and he was very good about making recommendations for us from their extremely extensive menu. Venue Review: The restaurant is located right by a small parking lot that we did not have to pay for (I think because we were there later at night). There is mostly booth seating in the restaurant itself. Upon entering, there is a bakery on the left hand side and the deli on your right. Overall Impression: Their corn beef sandwich and latkas weren't my favorite, but I really liked their matzo ball soup. However, I certainly give them credit for their above average service, especially for such a busy venue. For SC students: Langer's is closer and in my humble opinion has the better superior sandwich, but definitely give Canter's a try to mix things up!

Reviews.Author: Justin R.
Reviews.Content: Came by with my coworkers after a long night. I really enjoy old school delis and some find this one a legend of Los Angeles. It's a good late night spot but I didn't think it was as good I thought it would be. It could've been me, I was probably expecting too much. Maybe I ordered the sandwich?I had the Canters Fairfax sandwich. It's a great creation of pastrami and corned beef. The meat was tender but it was bland. The whole time I kept on comparing it to Langers. Although the number 19 and Canters Fairfax are different sandwiches, Langers tastes so much better. The fries here are pretty weak. From now on I will no longer order fries from Delis. It should be a rule. The price is perhaps on par with their contemporaries but not good enough in taste. $15 for a number 19 is expensive but it tastes so good and you never think twice about the price until it's gone. $13.95 for a Canters Fairfax, not that great and the whole time I asked myself "why are they so expensive?" I've managed to scratch another place off the bookmark list but I was expecting more.

Reviews.Author: Jeanette S.
Reviews.Content: So finally I went to the famous Canter's Deli, and was not super impressed. Maybe it's my own fault, for not ordering a Jewish specialty, lol, but still I was expecting more. Let me start off by saying that I hate pickles!!!! So I was pretty disgusted by the huge plate of pickles placed on the table, haha. Everyone else loves pickles though, just not me. I ordered a club house sandwich with avocado, and figured I couldn't go wrong with that. The sandwich was huge and looked so delicious, but was simply alright, not great, lol. First of all, it was too huge, it was hard to hold and take bites out of not matter what I did! I know seems like a stupid complaint, but still it was annoying. The biggest problem though, was that the turkey in the sandwich was so damn dry, ugh. It was very disappointing, but the avocado was delicious, really made the sandwich that much better.Then we went to the pastry section and I saw all these yummy cupcakes in the window! I fucking love cupcakes, I honestly thought there was no such thing as a bad cupcake, until I ate this one, haha. I should have listened to my friends and just ate cookies and cheesecake.  Oh and yes its true, LOTS of hipsters and rockers. Well, mostly hipsters, lol. There was an old skool punk band playing in the bar, lol, when we went, so the waitress said we should sit on that side, because we look like "rockers," haha. So yea Canter's is pretty great for people watching and late night food, just don't order the club or eat their cupcakes, lol. Just brace yourself for lots of jews, pickles, hipsters, drunks, and other loads of Canter's fun.

Reviews.Author: Frangelo A.
Reviews.Content: The Food Network channel made this place out to be much nicer than it really is in person.  I was expecting a super clean and warm place for some good pastrami or corned beef.  What I got instead was a not so clean and not so warm place for great pastrami and corned beef.Eva our server was the greatest.  Much like a long lost grandmother, she guided us in our decision making. "We have good pastrami and corned beef."  Out of the hundreds of other menu options it was down to those two things.  Luckly the bf had one and I had the other.Free pickles were a pleasant surprise and definitely complimented the mustard that I would later dip my corned beef on rye sandwich in.  I love me some mustard!My only regret is that I wished my rye was toasted and that we didn't order the cheese fries.  Oh and I wish I wasn't too full to miss out on their cheesecake.Overall, a great place for great pastrami and corned beef when you're in the mood for it.  That it's open for 24 hours is also a plus! Just don't expect Mr. Clean to be too happy with it.  But give him a sandwich and he'll ignore the dinge!

Reviews.Author: Suzanne S.
Reviews.Content: I'm embarrassed to admit that in all the years I've lived in LA, Friday evening was my first visit to this dining institution. I'm a fan.We lucked out on parking in a nearby lot and were seated right away when we entered the deli. Score!The waitstaff is friendly, but slow ... which was a-ok because they were speedy with the drinks. There are pickles and sauerkraut to nosh on (to my delight and hubby's disgust) while we waited for our dinner.Hubby enjoyed a French Dip sandwich and I ordered The Marilyn. Both were a-ok. It was a lot of food! What really rocks is the bakery area ... where we went a little nutty and got a ton of stuff to go. The black and white cookies were heavenly, the chocolate rugala was amazing without being too heavy, and the eclair was flaky, fresh, and fantastic. Yes, we pigged out, but it was over the course of a weekend so it's not quite as bad. ;)They still kick it old school with the cash register ... they have a handwritten ledger and an antique register. There are two lines ... one for cash and another for credit. Choose wisely ... they like to keep it orderly.Overall I would definitely be back!

Reviews.Author: Laura Y.
Reviews.Content: Awww, who's been going here since she was nine years old?!!?I can hardly be critical of the food because I've been eating it for so long it has passed into nostalgia and comfort.  Kind of like how you can still talk a mile of smack about your mother but at the end of the day you'd lie down on train tracks for her, or at least give her five stars because you couldn't bear to give her any less. Mishmosh.  Pickles.  Hummus.  Boiled cabbage with meatballs.  Mishmosh.  Pastrami.  Monte Cristos.  Egg creams.  Cel-Ray Tonic.  Mishmosh.  Mishmosh!!I have broken many a bagel chip with dear friends here, peered at the strange ceiling, and supped a solitary bowl of salt blast soup at 4am after a long night of clubbing, all under the watchful eye of the ancient savvy waitresses.

Reviews.Author: Marina S.
Reviews.Content: Canter's served as the 2:30 am recovery and rehabilitation center for my friends and I after a late night of dancing and dehydration.You've just shaken half an inch off your waistline, what better way to gain it all back than at Canters!The matzo ball soup was a surprise: you get a medium bowl of plain broth, with a humongous BALL in the middle, and the ball is taller than the sides of the bowl, so be careful or it might just roll away! I'm used to matzo ball soup having smaller matzo dumplings and clearer, more flavorful broth but it's hearty and it'll do.The Pastrami sandwich comes on deliciously moist rye, piled so high your jaw will hurt until you've squished your sandwich down to the appropriate size.

Reviews.Author: Paula L.
Reviews.Content: Canters looks old and outdated, but I think that's part of the charm!First off, this location is HUGE. Two dining rooms and a 2nd floor?! I also love the deli & bakery right at the entrance to tempt you. I was too full to get anything from the bakery but next time I'll be prepared!I just got back from NY so Katz's is still fresh in my memory. Canter's does not beat Katz...nor Langer's in my opinion, but it still is a delicious sandwich!Katz' pastrami is fattier and thicker cut than Canters'. I loved that Canter's had a half sandwich option (with soup&cole slaw) cause I could never eat a whole one.The rye bread was delicious.
