I personally thought Langer's bread was strong and Katz not at all rye like..but here there was great balance!The french fries here are also steak fries. Bonus points!Parking is easy since it has its own lot. You need to get validated by the restaurant though.I would recommend Langers over Canters because I think their quality of meat is better but since their hours are sooo horrible Canters is a great alternative (open 24/7).

Reviews.Author: Alexander R.
Reviews.Content: It's an LA classic, man! Canter's Cant fail . . . actually that's a whole different place (never mind) Anyway, i love getting a good deli sandwich here. Touristy? Yes. Overrated? Yes. Overpriced? Yes! yes, yes, yes but it does it for me! Maybe I'm dumb, maybe I have my own secret reasons.Get on that pastrami, man!

Reviews.Author: josephine v.
Reviews.Content: I think I'll have to give this place another try. It was late at night, just had a few drinks at the dime, so my taste buds were ready for the usual drunk-chies. What could have been better than a large pastrami sandwich with chili cheese fries.. Mmmmm. Sadly, even intoxicated I left feeling up satisfied. After hearing such good things about this place, I think I may have hyped it up in my mind. What I ordered: pastrami Reuben with chili cheese fries. First of all, now that I think about it, the plate of pickles was the best thing ever. Lol. I'm a fan of pickles so just imagine my excitement when the first thing they bring to your table is a whole plate of pickles, so points just for the pickles. Now that they've buttered me up a little with pickles, I'm thinking "hell ya, this pastrami Reuben and chili cheese fries is going to hit the spot." The food took awhile, so i wasn't too happy about that. The pastrami, was not great, and I say that because I've had some pretty freaking bomb pastrami. There was a lot of pastrami grilled together with the sauerkraut in between two thinly sliced rye. I think what threw me off was that it was a little sweet, maybe that was the sauerkraut, but I didn't love it. It was just ordinary, nothing extraordinary. And now the most disappointing part, the chili cheese fries.. I love chili cheese fries. What threw me off was the the fries were like thick cut wedgy fries, I don't like that! Maybe I'm just biased. So points off because of the fry. Next the chili, I really disliked the chili, mainly because there was soooo many big beans In there, I really started to pick them out. And i got them because another guy at a different table said it was the best chili ever... No sir it was not. And on top of that, I think the chili lacked flavor, and it sure as hell was not cheesy enough.Now, when you are paying, the bald guy at guy at the canter. Soooooo rude. All we wanted to do was split the bill accordingly to what we ordered, but honestly he made it seem like the biggest inconvenience to him, and rudely asked what we were tipping so he could factor it into our totals. That guy rubbed me the wrong way. I'm sorry it was such an inconvenience to split the bill into two. Jees.Anyways... All in all, this place doesn't excited me. I wouldn't all of a sudden say hey let's go to canters. I would try it again, maybe in the future. And maybe I'm biased because I like my pastrami and chili cheese fries a certain way.

Reviews.Author: Margaret L.
Reviews.Content: Super Delish Food. That night my friends and I managed to go that place three times that night. So we ate a lot of food. I got the pastrami sandwhich, wow, and I did not regret that and later some fresh fruit. We ordered watermellon and they just cut us a huge slice of it. I swear it was a 1/4 of a watermellon. I am really glad that this place exists and not replaced by some run of the mill chain place.

Reviews.Author: Meredith W.
Reviews.Content: Me-Yow. I always question reviewing places like this that have a gajillion reviews but what the heck. Jewish deli's are my kind of comfort food. I don't do it all the time, but sometimes you just need to stuff your face with sodium filled meats and cheeses. yesterday was such a day. I was hungry and indecisive. I picked up a friend and we drove up from orange county. Amazing and delicious - this place hit the spot. I ordered the Brooklyn, (or was it the Manhattan? cant remember)  you get your choice of meat (I like pastrami) on rye with coleslaw and canters sauce (a yummy thousand island).  Add Swiss cheese and a side of coleslaw (yes i needed more! Their coleslaw is creamy and delectable) and i was in hog heaven. They serve free pickles, and people watching here will never leave you disappointed.

Reviews.Author: Kori S.
Reviews.Content: Reuben with corned beef for sure. Never a wait but that's probably because I only swing by at odd hours of the night. Come to think of it, I probably wouldn't eat here for a dedicated, non-drunk meal... is that a bad thing?Canter's actually reminds me of Tommy's on Rampart. People from all walks of life come here to commune in late-night foodery. Makes for a random, lovely atmosphere. And I can't help but shake the feeling that I'm being secretly filmed for an upcoming movie... anyone else get that?

Reviews.Author: Lisa B.
Reviews.Content: Visiting L.A. and having worked for years at a N.Y./Jewish Deli in Wa., I had to check out one of the delis in the L.A. area while there. Langers was closed already, so we went to Canter's. Glad we did! I loved it! Much bigger and a huge selection of baked goodies, etc. than what I expected. The decor itself is a little dreary and dark (except for the ceiling), our server had no personality, but the food made up for all of it. We had some sandwiches and they were piled high with great pastrami, ham, corned beef. The flavor was awesome and I took half of it home (to the hotel). Daughter had the matzo ball soup and said it was great too. For dessert, we had some macaroons, black n white cookie & strawberry cheesecake (it was soooo good.) Gotta try it if you go there. It was a slow time that we went. Service was quick, food was quick. Downfall is that the bathroom is up a bunch of stairs and it wasn't the cleanest. Rest of the place is clean. Definitely check this place out. Great food to eat there or take with you. So many goodies, we couldn't pick what to take home. Rugalach looked good too.

Reviews.Author: Johnny M.
Reviews.Content: Who doesn't love Canter's!? If you have never been, you should be ashamed of yourself! Canter's is a staple of Fairfax and has been for ages. An old school deli that's HUGE and serves up booze.. who doesn't enjoy a little booze with their deli food!? As if that weren't enough, they have a bakery that is awesome to say the least!Anyplace that gives you complimentary pickles when you sit down is already off on the right track. Big, spicy, crispy pickles that let you know you're in for a real treat. A big menu with all types of deli foods, sandwiches and breakfast.. my favorite item on the menu is probably the philly cheese steak. I'm not sure why because they have tons of tasty food but for some reason every time I come here I get a big craving for their philly cheese steak and end up going with that. You always gotta leave room for dessert though! As I said earlier, they have a bakery in the front that creates unique sweets that look and taste amazing! They almost always have some free samples sitting out on a plate for you to try- I've discovered plenty of new sweet treats this way. If it looks tasty, try it! It most likely is. The bar is located on the North end of Canter's. It's long and narrow but they serve up some potent drinks here. On the weekends (and sometimes during the week possibly) they have small bands play here. I've seen some good shows while liquoring myself up here. Order yourself a whiskey sour and you'll be hardcore buzzed after one or two, promise!Parking can be alittle tough sometimes. They have a lot a few blocks south towards Beverly on the West side of the street. Other than that there's a lot of meters around if you can find an open one.

Reviews.Author: charles l.
Reviews.Content: Nine million pounds of corned beef and 24 million bowls of chicken soup later, Canter's Delicatessen still stands and is open all day. That's right! 24 hours just for you, in case you have a 3am craving for a corned beef sandwich. The beef is classic satisfying fatty fare, served between two slices of soft rye with a chewy crust. It is quite good. I wish they had more 75th Anniversary Specials where the entire meal (sandwich, potato salad, pickle, and chocolate rugula) was only 75 cents!

Reviews.Author: Letty D.
Reviews.Content: I heart Canter's! There is a little Hollywood in a bit of everything at Canter's. The bartender has amazing charm. It all began when he remembered my name just from looking over my ID. They are open 24 hours! The best part is that one of the great legends of radio can be found hanging out in his booth. You'll  find all different walks of life and that's a great thing. Canter's gives you that home away from home feeling.Food wise, I don't really like the lox. It's ok. When I special ordered  a grilled cheese sandwhich with mushrooms it was done in no time and with a smile! yay.

Reviews.Author: Thanya S.
Reviews.Content: I don't know what it is but I LOVE this place. Who wouldn't love the matzo ball soup with balls the size of your head? Who couldn't love the overstuffed pastrami or reuben sandwiches? I remember the days when the waitresses were really old and crotchedy with 60's bouffants. I love the cozy pleather brown booths and the way cool back-lit ceiling with the photographic leaf patterns. You might even see someone famous here. We thought we saw a nude-faced post-operation-nose Ashlee Simpson, but I wasn't sure since she looks so generic now. But the real reason I love Canter's are the thick potato pancakes slathered with sour cream and apple sauce. My heaven!

Reviews.Author: Javier J.
Reviews.Content: This is the big boss of Jewish Deli's. The one and only place you will need to know of when you think to yourself  "Hmm, I want a sandwich on rye, where should I go?" It's Canter's and it's Delicious. If you're thinking of a place to grab lunch or drunk off your ass at 2 in the morning, this is the place to go. They'll service your group that's out on the town with ease and a smile. They have these layered chocolate cakes with everything you're not suppose to eat or you'll break every diet you could possibly be on. You know the types. The ones with real eggs, tons of flower and sugar that just make it rise and be stacked to the sky. One slice of that and you're down for the count. Simply put, that as instant diabetes and worth every bite.When not tempted by the Fairfax special, you'll be tempted for a burger. No matter how you cut it, you can't beat Canter's. Their pastrami and corned beef are just amazingly good. If you're in the mood for food after temple, Canter's is your one stop to fill that hunger.

Reviews.Author: Deborah C.
Reviews.Content: The service sucks, and their matzo ball soup is weak, but their Reubens are simply heavenly!!I will go out of my way for one of Canter's Reubens, on Rye bread with plenty of mustard.  They're huge, stuffed with a ton of pastrami and sauerkraut. They're not exactly low-cal, but boy are they worth it....Oh!!  Plus the whole 24-hour thing....A Reuben at 3AM?  mmmmmmmmmmmmm.............

Reviews.Author: brian p.
Reviews.Content: This place is delicious!!! It's far from my house but I'll absolutely come back, love their pastrami sandwiches!!

Reviews.Author: Jon E.
Reviews.Content: Admitedly the first time I was here I was completely plastered but sober this place is not too bad.Great for late night after you're done partying.  Food wise its not bad.  Their corned beef sandwich is pretty good but as with every deli is over priced and includes no sides (although the sandwich can stand on its own). Perhaps my favorite is to go for the breakfast special with a side of corned beef hash (amazing) and probably the best plain coffee I've ever had.Wait staff is varied and interesting.  To avoid lines go during off hours (i.e. not lunch/breakfast/after hours) but for the best people watching go after 1:30AM on Friday and Saturday and Sunday morning during the brunch hours.It's one of my favorites but don't think its one of the best.

Reviews.Author: Seth G.
Reviews.Content: Does it compare to Carnegie Deli or some of the famous East Coast Delis? Not so much, however, it is the best Deli I have come across in LA. They even know what a corned beef special is - something that Jerry's [In]famous deli didn't. When you walk into the place, it has the 'right' smell associated with a good deli. I can't say how the burgers are. I can say the deli foods that are de rigueur are good. The sandwiches are substantially sized and well priced; the quality of the bread and meat is also good; the matzo ball soup is tasty, too. For the nocturnal, the 24 hours a day is a plus. It is a great place to go after a concert or show.The service was decent as well considering is has been busy the dozen or so times I have gone.

Reviews.Author: Lindsey K.
Reviews.Content: An LA classic.To live/visit/exist in LA and not eat here at least once would be an experience missed. It is filled with legend, kitch, and grease up the wazoo.The atmosphere is straight out of the 1970's mixed in with bits from the 50's and beyond. The wait staff are a colorful bunch... don't expect all of them to smile and be eager to refill your coffee, but sometimes you'll catch a gem who will. Despite Canter's Jewishness, it is not kosher. I had a waitress ask me if I wanted cheese on my pastrami sandwich (I did). Its a bit pricey. Some things you know were not made here, rather reheated and slopped on a dish. The portions are ample though. I had the California Burger and it was STACKED with mushrooms and probably 4oz of avocado... mmm.... What always brings me here is it is an excuse to stop by the bakery on my way out to indulge in the chocolate rugelach (roo-gah-la). Dozen, two dozen? They are fantastic fresh and stay delicious for a few days, so feel free to go overboard.

Reviews.Author: Ana Ruth J.
Reviews.Content: Gia: are you hungry ? Pam and I : No, are you? Gia: no Gia: do you want to eat later? Pam and I : up to you(10 minutes pass) Gia: are you hungry? me: lets go get food cause u are hungryand on begins our adventure to Canters. Gia and i had been wanting to come here... we love doing the late nitght food runs at new and exciting places. She had always driven by but had never gone.So we got there and walked and waited to be seated.. mind u when we walked in there was a dispay of pies and goodness :) Finally we get seated and we have a huge menu in hand... what to get what to get its midnight hmmmm what can i have... oh yes here we go canters famous Reuben... As the waiter had told me you cant come to canters and not have the Reuben, so of course i ordered it. By the way the waiter was great even though he wasnt too happy with gia taking forever to order a grilled cheese..After a few minutes of people watching our food came out....steak fries and a reuben mmmmm. I picked up the sandwich bit into it and was taken away for a few moments. Pam ordered the meatloaf which looked pretty good too! Gia's grilled cheese looked like a grilled cheese nothing special haha. The only con i had about Canters is that its a bit pricy..but hey we tried it and thats all that matters. so if you are lokoing for some good eats at any time of the night stop by canters...its pretty yummy!

Reviews.Author: Kristin M.
Reviews.Content: My fiancé got me hooked on this place and I have to say, best pastrami sandwich EVER! I usually get the "Brooklyn" which is a pastrami on rye with coleslaw, and it is delish. I've never really had anything else here, if i'm going to drive an hour to get here i'm not going to try something new. Plus the pastrami is just waaay to good. It's not greasy like Jerry's deli either.For the people who say this place looks too old inside, that's the charm and history of it! The stained glass ceiling is so awesome. I wouldn't want it updated or changed at all.

Reviews.Author: Rebecca A.
Reviews.Content: I was really sad to have to give Canter's two stars, but I've definitely experienced better delies, honestly, I even feel like Jerry's deli is better.LOCATION: okay the location is mediocre; it's on fairfax, i think between beverly and 3rd or between melrose and beverly. IT's across the street from Fairfax highschool. It's not the nicest location, but it's still okay..... the good thing about the location is that once you've eaten your mediocre, non-satisfying meal here, there are plenty of more delicious restaurants and cafes nearby like on 3rd street, on beverly, or on melrose....so you don't have to drive tooo far for some better food, but sadly i feel like almost anything would taste good after eating here.FOOD: the food was okay.......kinda boring. okay so i'm a vegetarian so i ordered the vegetable soup which the waiter highly reccommended. It was okay, i mean it tasted alright, but it was wayy toooo salty and it didn't have enough vegetables in it. The best part about the soup was the bagle chips that came with it, and half of the chips were burnt.....very dissapointing. The friend who i came here with ordered the corned beef sandwhich which is supposed to be famous and really good, but he said it was very sub-par. My friend just said the sandwhich was nothing special, and tasted kinda bland for meat that is supposed to have a good strong flavor. Also, everyone raves about the pickles they bring you at canters, but the pickles they brough us tasted wierd. I mean yes they were crunchy, but they also tasted funky......and they weren't salty enough. ATMOSPHERE: there are two rooms to sit in at canters. We sat in the lower level room which was especially dingy, depressing, and dimly lit. I felt like i was in a gross, nasty college dining hall. They other room looked a little b it nicer, it had high-edged, plush looking booths and better looking tables and chairs than the room we were in. The room that we sat in actually kinda made me loose my appetite, I think they really need to take care of the disparity between the atmosphere in the two different rooms.SERVICE: the service was just okay. Our waiter was nice enough, but he was kind of jumpy and hyper. He also treated us like little kids (i'm 19 and my friend was 20); my friend asked for more pickles, and the watier told us to finish our last slice on the plate before he brought us a new plate. I just felt like that was really rude, i mean my friend was going to eat that last slice of pickle anyways, but the fact that our watier ordered us around really bugged me. Also paying here is a little wierd, the waiter brings you the bill, and then you have to get up and go to the cashier to pay for your food. And then if you want to leave a tip, you have to go back to your table and leave it there or find your waiter/waitress and give it to them. This system seemed a little wierd. overall, I think Canter's fame is not really deserved. It's famous because it's like the oldest deli in Los Angeles, and it probably used to be good, but not so much anymore. The food is edible, so i guess if you're super hungry, and every other restaurant within a mile radius is closed, then you could come here (yeah, the fact that it's open 24 hours a day is pretty nice, but it would be nicer if the food was delicious). I honestly wish that Canter's was better, I want to like it, but i honestly just didn't. If you want a good deli, go to Langer's and order the #19, or go to Art's Deli in studio city and order anything and you will be much happier than if you came here.

Reviews.Author: Felicity M.
Reviews.Content: Okay... so for $22.22 we received the following:2 eggs with a side of potatoesa deli meal which consisted of:corned beef hashmatzo ball souprye bread and butterbagel crispsgreen beans and carrotsa cup of coffeestrawberry ice cream.Not to mention the waiter was the FRIENDLIEST server I've ever encountered! I think we tipped him like 40 percent or something... and I still felt like we under-tipped. Let's just say that he rocked. Hard.

Reviews.Author: Jonny B.
Reviews.Content: Open 24/7. Average everything. Nobody can ever identify exactly what is that smell.

Reviews.Author: David M.
Reviews.Content: Man, it's been years since I've been here! I was having a late-night craving for matzo ball soup and pastrami on rye, and Canter's fits the bill. I do wish there were noodles in the matzo ball soup but it was still tasty. The pastrami was awesome and there was a lot of it piled up on the rye. Their dill pickles are just ok; I like 'em with much more dill. They have lots of stuff for dessert and can get anything in the front bakery section brought out to your table. I got the chocolate russian coffee cake and it was sinfully rich, if slightly dry. Still, I'd come back here in a heartbeat, provided the pastrami doesn't stop it first.

Reviews.Author: Daniel N.
Reviews.Content: Enough good things have been said for me to stop here.Try it and you wont be dissapointed!

Reviews.Author: John P.
Reviews.Content: This is my favorite deli in LA.  Actually it is the only deli in LA that I can think of that I actually like.  While the food can't really touch the great delis in New York, it is passable.  Even if the food wasn't good, Canter's has enough character to make it worth visiting every once in awhile. The Kibitz  Room is the perfect place for a pre-Largo drink or five. Great friendly bartenders who serve up cheap and strong drinks. The pickles are also the best in the US, maybe the world.  If you are still hungry after the show at Largo you can always cross the street and have a decent Reuben.I saw Uncle Leo eating here a couple years back. I couldn't tell if he was wearing that watch he dug out of the trash or not.

Reviews.Author: D G.
Reviews.Content: What's Jewish for "mmmm good" ?  Whatever it is, that's my new quote.  I was born and raised in LA - and proud of it most of the time.  I'm especially proud to be from LA when I think of it as the home the best Tuna Sandwich on the planet.  Don't forget the pickles on the side.  And the spicy mustard of course.  This place has your fill whether it be Matzo Ball soup that is just bowl with the largest Matzo Ball I've ever seen; a Latkes made with just right about of oil..mmmm; or their Black and White Cookies.  It's all awesome except for the service.  Which, I think, is worth it.  It's what makes Canter's a no frills, yummy thrills kinds of place.  so just smile when Denise throws your plate down so hard that it may have cracked.  And simply wink when you order your Diet Soda with a little bit ice to ensure you actually get it.  It's all worth it though.

Reviews.Author: Soo-Jin L.
Reviews.Content: Best reuben pastrami I put in my mouth. I only had a bite of my friend's but that was enough for me to be converted. The toasted bread (probably rye) was just wet with enough butter but crunchy. They must put magic juices into the sauerkraut. Huge fan of sauerkraut. I ordered the Matzo Ball soup. The ball was the size of a soft ball. I think the food is flavored well.The atmosphere is a little depressing. But I would go back for that reuben.

Reviews.Author: Jon G.
Reviews.Content: Ive been here a couple of times, both with questionable experiences. It looks to me like they have a great selection and a wonderful deli, and theyre open late. I think they charge one to three dollars more than they should for a number of things, but I have been pretty happy with what Ive ordered.Now, one thing I look for is the quality of the food it's self, not it's garnishments. People in this country eat food for the condiments. Not me. If Im ordering something, it better be good on it's own, with no need to mask or enhance the flavor by adding to it. I find it hard to order a sandwich anywhere because people always want to put mayonnaise, mustard, pickles, or some other ungodly substance on them, and this establishment is no exception. I ask for no pickles, not even on the plate. what happens? Pickles on the plate, soaking into my fries and bun, ruining the whole experience for me. I often have to argue with waiters because I dont want them to put those things on my food, and most of the time the menu neglects to mention that they are gonna put it on your sandwich.OK, so that aside. Be sure to specify these types of things. Ive gotten attitude from people there because of my dislike for pickles, which is kind of counter productive when running a business.Food takes a long time to get to you, and the overall experience is pretty slow. Also, some nights they have a live band play at the bar, which is connected internally to the restaurant. So imagine youre at a deli enjoying a sandwich, and all of a sudden theres a live band playing at full blast about 20 feet away from you. Not a great experience.There are enough delis around town to where I dont think this one would be anywhere near the top of my list.

Reviews.Author: Justin D.
Reviews.Content: I came in on a gorgeous LA thursday afternoon with a good friend who actually has been to Canter's before and she and I decided to do lunch here after walking around the old LA zoo & coming here definitely made me appreciate more of the old school diner feeling. I had the delicious hot corned beef sandwich on whole wheat with old fashioned cold slaw on the side, the meal was delicious, felt very homey & the ambience was definitely the best because you feel like your in the old days of the diners experience. I would definitely come back for the delicious meal experience and ambience. Anyone who likes the old diners feeling, definitely check this place out if you haven't yet.

Reviews.Author: Joy Y.
Reviews.Content: Eat here if you are ravenous and don't mind eating in a diner that is as OLD as your GRANDMA (maybe a little bit older). Imagine Denny's 50 years ago. The overall feeling there was OVERWHELMED! The menu is extensive. Whatever mood and craving you want: Breakfast. Sandwiches. Salads. More corned beef. Corned beef and pastrami combos. And, entree meals. You start confusing yourself what are you really hungry for. The sandwiches were huge to the point that I almost thought how do people walk after this meal? They were tasty, but not too memorable. The salads were again huge and full of romaine lettuce and a ton of toppings! They do not skim here. Yay, for no iceberg lettuce! I'm not hating this place, but it's not my favorite place. It'll be fun with a group of friends or late night eating.
Reviews.Author_Location: Playa del Rey, Los Angeles, CA

Reviews.Author: Mato W.
Reviews.Content: This is one LA's best historical places to eat 24/7.  Always great home cooking and service here.  The turkey dinner was the best!!! Parking is available at the lot next to Canters.  Beware of the homeless people who hang out in front and harass anyone who doesn't give them money when you pass by.

Reviews.Author: Aaron A.
Reviews.Content: I'm hoping to give 5 stars to something other than the obvious (and deserved) items that all the great reviews here have covered.Here's 2 menu items I think are amazing:The Mish Mosh. Basically, this is matzoh ball, noodle AND kreploch in Canter's really amazing chicken broth. You can order carrots and chicken to be added...but I find adding just the carrots is a better idea. The chicken sort of interferes with the other items...I can eat A LOT, and one bowl of Mish Mosh kept me stuffed for days. I've taken friends of mine from the East Coast here for the Mish Mosh and they were really blown away by the broth, and overall quality of this soup.The Marilyn.Grilled Swiss on Rye with tomato...I have to admit. If I ate the same sandwich in a different setting, it may just taste pretty good. Ordering it at Canter's is somehow magical...maybe I'm a sucker for old Hollywood glamour and the dream that back in the golden days of Hollywood, a grilled swiss could heal the same wounds it can today.

Reviews.Author: Richard G.
Reviews.Content: This has got to be my all time favorite joint in LA.When we first moved here, we wanted to try all the spots and of course we wanted the Hollywood in places.  So we did Jerry's Deli in Marina Del Rey & at the Beverly Center a few times and we thought this place was great.  That is till we went to Canter's.  The first time we heard of  Canter's was when it got closed due to the sanitation issue and it was the big news in town.  Even though the joint got closed down it was still getting great press. Once it reopened and I was next in the neighborhood, I took a trip over to the Fairfax district to check it out.Man O' Man, am I glad I did.  The corned beef and pastrami were almost like butter in my mouth.  We immediately made comparisons to Jerry's and realized that we had been wrong about Jerry's.  Jerry's pastrami and corned beef are like chewing leather compared to the succulent melt in your mouth meats at Canter's.So over the years, we have visited time and time again.  Enjoying all sorts of things on the menu.  My wife likes the latkes and my daughter likes the mazzo ball soup, but me and my son always want to put our mouths into some of that great pastrami or corned beef.  I have had quite a few menu items and was pleasantly surprised one night by a super fresh and great tasting Cobb salad.  But as I said it's not the other items that make Canter's great to me, it's there corned beef and pastrami on homemade rye, that makes my mouth water for some of that great deli flavor.

Reviews.Author: Dan W.
Reviews.Content: Excellent food, excellent atmosphere! It gets a little crowded, and sometimes the service is a little slow, but it's quality otherwise.The salad with the avocado on top and garbanzos (I think it's called the mixed greens salad) is fabulous and filling! The latkes and blintzes are spectacular too.If you're there late at night, make sure to ask for Doug "with the hair." You won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Author: James N.
Reviews.Content: I make it a point to stop at Canter's each time I visit LA. An LA institution. From an out-of-towner's perspective Canter's is a much needed oasis as one crosses the desert Los Angeles sprawl.TIP: As you enter the restaurant look into the glass cases on your left for a display of desserts. It will help you navigate the menu later.Worth the stop and a return visit.

Reviews.Author: Leigh S.
Reviews.Content: I am fortunate enough to have earned the title of Honorary Jew among my friends. My boyfriend is Jewish. Some of my best friends are Jewish. What is another thing they all have in common? They would all punch their grandmothers for a meal from Canter's.It's almost inevitable: if I am in LA, there is a 99% chance that I will end up at Canter's with a full belly and a serious food coma. If you have not tried their corn beef reuben, please stop reading this and go right now. Wait, not yet. First, order some hummus with pita bread. And at least TRY the pickles (warning: they're strong). OK, now you can go.Their service is alright, and the place could be cleaner, but that is all part of the Canter's experience. In the end, you will have had some amazing food and probably overheard some oddly interesting conversations from the tons of old people sitting around you.

Reviews.Author: Jeremy E.
Reviews.Content: I feel guilty giving a lower rating to Canter's restaurant. I mean, there has to be some reason it has been around since the early nineteen thirties. The reason is because I have a hard to justifying the cost of going to this restaurant. It is not terrible food and the servings are on the larger side. And it may have been a little hyped up for me before going, but I just don't see what is so special. The coolest thing this place has going for itself is that it is a hardcore vintage restaurant. I was expecting the Brady Bunch to bust in that place and Bingo to be playing in the back room. With all the wood panels, I felt like I needed pilot glasses and a mustache just to eat there. Unfortunately, the vibe and food did not live up to the style of the restaurant. All of the customer service seems to be on the older side, but not particularly friendly. Honestly, that is the missing piece of the whole shebang. If the service made me feel retrofitted to the seventies a little more, then I would love this place. But, it just kind of comes off right now as "meh." One last benefit to Canter's anybody in Los Angeles could easily appreciate: virtually free and easy parking.

Reviews.Author: Steve M.
Reviews.Content: Oh, how the mighty have fallen. My mother used to take me here when I was 10 years old almost 40 years ago. I have gone off and on during the years but haven't gone for a while as I now live in San Diego.I had to go to LA for work and decided to stop in here on the way up. I ordered a corn beef sandwich, which was huge as always, but a real disappointment. It was dry and pretty tasteless, just not good. And at $12, it's overpriced. The bakery is what gave it more than one star. They have the best bakery and the choc chip danish are AWESOME! The woman behind the counter was very nice and helpful, giving me samples to help me choose.The strangest part was the customer service. The sandwich went on my expense account for work, but all the extra bakery stuff was on my dime. Therefore, I needed separate receipts and asked for such. The guy behind the deli counter where they made the sandwich (I got it to go) got all weird and whispered "they don't like to do separate tranactions." He then had me pay there instead of the cashier to avoid some sort of restaurant armageddon. I'm trying to get a sandwich and I feel like I'm doing a drug deal ("Hey, I'll take a dime baggie of corned beef"). Give me a break.

Reviews.Author: Michelle I.
Reviews.Content: My family and i visited my brother in LA and he took us to this restaurant. The sandwich i ordered was great, i wanted to save some for our ride back home but i couldn't help my self and ate it all. I love that they serve you pickles as a appetizer, i never had that in a restaurant before but it was great. the pickles had a different taste then the usual pickles i've had before and it was so yummy in my tummy.Before we left we also bought some pastry's which was deliciousWhen i visit again i would love to come eat here again. .

Reviews.Author: Dee F.
Reviews.Content: Canters is another LA institution.The people I was with are LA born-bred and they are so-so on this place.  I thought it was a great Fairfax Experience.Food:  4/5.  Standard Jewish Deli Fare.Drinks:  NA   Service:  Good.Price:  $$Interior:  3/5 (Old School Diner)Exterior:  3/5 (Americana)Park:      3/5  (Lot/Street)Go Back: Always.Recommendation:  If you're in the area.

Reviews.Author: Woger W.
Reviews.Content: A Pastrami Reuben Focused Review This was the latest stop on my adventures sailing across the seas of Pastrami Reuben sandwiches at Los Angeles Delis. Canter's now has claim to the crown of serving the best of them all (however in Los Angeles I have plenty more delis to try).It is not really the quality of the pastrami, which is very rich, a bit gamy, and not too flavorful (not that richness isn't a flavor, it sure is here). Sliced thin, and overall the antithesis of the serious quality of Langer's, Canter's Pastrami, however, balances perfectly with the rye bread and swiss cheese, and isn't overwhelmed by other things (such as the flavor of sauerkraut at places such as Langer's).  So we are talking almost perfect balance here.The only caveat with Canter's sandwich is the presence of sauerkraut was not as noticeable as it could have been, the lack of flavor of the pastrami (still you are impressed by the richness) and the skimpy offering of sides of pickles (not too uncommon but compare with Nate n Als which gives glorious pickle and sauerkraut side supplements).Sorry I'm not reviewing anything else at Canter's but I have tried other things in the past and there is no dispute that Canter's is a classic and comprehensive and quality deli.

Reviews.Author: scott s.
Reviews.Content: Came here for the history.The Food is meh.

Reviews.Author: Sarah D Z.
Reviews.Content: A staple food source in Los Angeles. I have been coming here throughout my life. Try the Matzo Ball soup, corned beef or pastrami sandwiches, and stuffed mashed potatoes. The fries are pretty hit or miss. The bakery in the front of the restaurant is the soul of the joint, and every little sweet morsel encased behind the glass window is absolute heaven.

Reviews.Author: Chris M.
Reviews.Content: Ah Canters!  The service may not be the best and the food may not be all that great ... at least the prices are high.

Reviews.Author: jay k.
Reviews.Content: We had to figure out what all the hype was about.  The BF and I both ordered sandwiches, which were just sandwiches.  Good, but nothing to get excited about.The waiter was nice.It was a little pricey just for two sandwiches and a cup of tea.But to top it off, the man who rung up our order at the counter was extremely rude.  There wasn't a single person in line behind us and he acted as if it were the end of the world and rushed us to get out.  Before paying we asked if they accepted american express and he yelled at my BF for not getting his credit card out of his wallet fast enough.  He said, "hurry up, just give me anything!"what the heck?  did we do something wrong?  just ate a quick meal and paid for it at the end.  isn't that the norm?  why were we getting scolded!yikes!  not going back there again!

Reviews.Author: Simon L.
Reviews.Content: Classic deli :)24/7 which is a plus.Kibbitz Room, which is their bar is pretty cool too. _S

Reviews.Author: Sarah B.
Reviews.Content: I remember the first time we walked into Canter's Deli.  I remember sitting in the booth and looking at the giant tobasco sauce and the deli mustard and wondering if the phones on the table really worked.I also have flashes of staring up at the ceiling and thinking I was having an out of body experience...but I digress.Good solid food.  Service is almost always spot on.  If you go on the weekends, ask for Jeannie.  She's been there forever and she just adds to your experience with her perfectly coiffed red hair and raspy voice.  The top contenders that I always order (even after 10 years of coming here):The Rueben with corned beefcorned beef hash and eggsVegetable Beef soupmmmmmm.

Reviews.Author: Jeremy A.
Reviews.Content: Holy crap, this is one of those place that I would go to every single day if I lived close to it.Canters is without a doubt one of my favorite jewish delis in all of the US, including NYC. The sandwiches here are a religious experience and are sometimes stacked higher then your head. Don't be discouraged by the high price tag because rest assured you can share your food with a small army. If you're visiting LA or live there, get over to Canters. It's the best!

Reviews.Author: Marcin M.
Reviews.Content: This is not the place for those who are counting calories.  This is the type of food you want to eat after a night out so that all that grease can soak up the alcohol.  Fortunately, this place is open 24/7 so you can satiate that need for grease at any hour of the day.The food is pretty decent.  I usually go for the Reuben -- either with corn beef or the pastrami.  I can't complain with the choices.  It's pretty tasty, fills me up, but you do leave feeling a little uncomfortable digesting all that sodium and calories.  But at least, I'm digging my own grave on this one.  The best part is the refillable pickle plate -- those are some tasty pickles.Service is pretty good but it depends on how busy it is.  As with all places, you'll wait more during busier times.  Duh.One of my favorite parts of the restaurant is the ceiling with the tree patterns -- it's so psychedelic looking.  It's the type of ceiling that you look at when you're really drunk that sends you spinning in circles.  Awesome.

Reviews.Author: jonathan s.
Reviews.Content: Having just been to Langers for the first time about a week before I was not sure that Canters pastrami reuben would be able to compete. Well, it was able to compete......it just lost. It was still a real good sandwich. Coleslaw instead of kraut. Sandwich was slightly smaller than Langers and fell apart a bit while I was eating it. I have no problem paying $13 for this sandwich at 3am.

Reviews.Author: Chris C.
Reviews.Content: Good corned beef, pastrami, latkes, matzo ball soup, bagels, and a bakery - and it's open 24/7.  Yessssssss!  It's like being in New York, but with LA weather and a large validated parking lot.  Canter's spot on the list of venerable LA institutions is well deserved.

Reviews.Author: Betsy R.
Reviews.Content: I felt like I walked into an East coast Diner!! Complete with the old school cash register, hand written tickets, and a waitress that looks like she has been there since this placed opened. No lie straight from Alice's Diner!! LOVE IT!!!! Just like any diner there is a little bit of everything - eggs, pancakes, blintzes with real fruit, and many other options for lunch and dinner. And they have fabulous desserts, cookies, and rye bread you can purchase to take home. They also have a deli where you can purchase sliced meats, cheeses, and thin breaded chicken patties - all you east coasters know what I'm talking about. And for the drinkers, this place is open 24 hours - just like any east coast diner. My hubs and I usually come here every Sunday to pick up a few AUTHENTIC NY bagels with a container of scallion cream cheese. The bagels and cream cheese taste like to you were in any random deli in Brooklyn. If you think you can find a better bagel in LA, forgetta bout it - Canter's is the real deal!!!

Reviews.Author: Noelle J.
Reviews.Content: The World According to NoelleAllergic Girl's Guide to LifeWe came here last Sunday and it was pouring rain, the Canter's Parking Lot was 'FULL'. The Parking Gods smiled down on my hubby and I and we scored parking right in front of Canter's. We didn't have time to eat lunch but we were able to purchase our baked goods for ourselves and our family.items purchased:Joyva HalvahBraided ChallahBlack and White cookiesRugelach (Raspberry, Apricot)Mandelbrot (Jewish verison of Biscotti)Poppy, Chocolate, Prune Hamentashen The restaurant was packed! The bakery was uber busy :) Everything we purchased was super delicious with the exception of the chocolate hamentashen- it was not very tasty (so definitely skip this flavor).Noelle's NotesDon't forget to get your parking validated at the restaurant or bakery section!If you're looking for the best corned beef or hot pastrami go to Nate n Al's in Beverly Hills!

Reviews.Author: Randi M.
Reviews.Content: So, so dissapointed.  I'm Jewish and I love a good deli( although I dont eat beef).  First, the restaurant looks so dated and really, really dirty.  Everything felt so gross to me.  I wasnt that hungry, so I ordered a half sandwich( tuna) and matza ball soup.  I consider myself a matza ball soup expert and this soup was nasty.  The broth tasted like it came out a packet.  Like the lipton noodle soup broth.  It was tasteless and the broth was cloudy.  There was also NOTHING in the soup.  No carrots, no chicken, and no noodles.  Oh, you had the option of adding all those things for a price.  I think fifty cents for the carrots, 1.00 for the noodles and I think 1.00 for the chicken.  I just added noodles, but I ended up returning my soup.  I couldnt stomach it( and that says a lot).  The matza ball was hard too.  I ended up with a whole tuna sandwich because I didnt want another kind of soup.  The tuna was bland( needed salt) and the tiny amount of potato salad they gave you was bland too.   The pickles were the best part of the meal.  My partner had a BLT, it was nothing special.  Way overpriced at 10 bucks and it came with NOTHING.  No fries, no coleslaw, no potato salad, nothing.  If you wanted a side, you had to pay 1.00. This is a major fail for me.  I did use a groupon that I paid 11.00 for( worth 22.00).  I' had to pay another 7 bucks.  Just so not worth it.

Reviews.Author: Ryan A.
Reviews.Content: I can honestly say that was the best sandwich I can remember eating..."For Dedicated Fressers Only" was able to feed the 3 of us. Melt-in-your-mouth pastrami and corned beef and bread.  So simple, yet so incredibly delicious!  Slather on that mustard, chomp down on the pickles and you got yourself ...happiness.  The coleslaw and potato salad were perfect as well.  Dessert counter is incredible.  I really wanted to try it all, but limited myself to some delicious raspberry/raisin tart thingy.  It was great - even 1 day later.Service was superb.  Filled with workers who definitely LOVE their jobs, you feel right at home with the hospitality.

Reviews.Author: Sarah D.
Reviews.Content: Grossest restaurant bathroom.  Ever.  Last time I ate here, I got sick.  After seeing the ladies' room on my most recent visit, last night, I can only imagine what the kitchen is like.  (I shudder at the thought.  Ew.)  My boyfriend got corned beef and pickles to go.  (Thank God.)  Both were really, really good: tender meat and slightly spicy, crisp dill pickles.  But, sorry, I still can't get over that dirty restroom.

Reviews.Author: Narumi O.
Reviews.Content: I used to go to Canter's when I was in school. Last Saturday, I decided to go to this old diner and I felt melancholy a little.There were a couple asking for better seats and I was thinking"this is a diner, not high-end restaurant! "Seriously, it's an old diner, what did they expect?We had:Mishmash soupPastrami Reuben sandwich$1 extra for coleslawCelery sodaI think this place is bit over priced. The soup and sandwich were pretty good. The coleslaw should come with sandwich.My husband grew up in New York and he said he used to drink the Celery soda. It tastes good, but I know it's bad for you.I am sure Galco in Highland Park carries Dr.Brown's Cel-Ray soda!

Reviews.Author: Sean R.
Reviews.Content: Not really known for their burgers but WOW are they great :)Gluten free Too :+)top notch delivery too ..

Reviews.Author: Randy M.
Reviews.Content: Many detractors will downplay Canter's because it's not an authentic Jewish Deli- which is kind of obvious (not many Jewish delis serve cheeseburgers in my travels).  But if this is your only qualifier to an eatery, yes, there are better, more Kosher places you can go. If, however, you are looking for a great, sit-down restaurant that's been in operation for decades, that caters to everyone 24-hours a day, Caners is a must-go. The sit-down restaurant itself offers a variety of foods ranging from traditional Jewish standards, to all-American favorites. Generally, you can't go wrong with whatever you order, but I recommend my two favorites: Matzo-ball soup, the Meatloaf dinner, or a Rueben sandwich. All, of which are delicious.Looking at the prices, you would expect the portions to be small. Not so. Depending on what you order, chances are, you'll need a to-go box to take away a third of what you couldn't finish (highly recommended- the food holds up well for a next-day leftover lunch). Then there's the kosher deli- which holds quite a variety of choices. However, these choices are a bit on the pricy side. So, unless you live in the neighborhood or you have a taste for a certain items such as gelfite fish, you may wish to consider other places.The bakery is a wonder of far too many dessert items, all of which are delicious. But again, they are on the pricy side. So it's your call. Canter's is, without a doubt, a great Los Angeles dining experience- especially late-night/early morning. Check them out.

Reviews.Author: Phil E.
Reviews.Content: Although I lived for a majority of my life in Los Angeles, I had never been to the famous "Canter's Deli" before. That changed yesterday on the way home from a taping of "The Late, Late Show with Craig Ferguson". I managed to convince my picky sister to stop at Canter's for dinner on the way home by telling her of their famous Matzoh Ball Soup I had heard about. She is a big fan of Matzoh Ball Soup and I was a big fan of eating dinner as I was hungry. So we stopped...The staff was great, the decor was awesome - retro Hollywood. It was like stepping back in time. Only without a Delorean - although we did see one of those on the way back home. I ordered a corned beef sandwich on rye with coleslaw, she had a turkey burger and we shared a bowl of their Matzoh Ball Soup. And, of course, a bowl of pickles. You can't go to a deli and not have a bowl of pickles. It's like going to a place of worship and not dropping your pants.Our food came quickly and was quite tasty. While I was expecting a sandwich and some cole slaw on the side, what I got was a sandwich with cole slaw on it. That's not a complaint - I'd eat cole slaw on some ice cream. Hell - I once drank an entire bottle of A-1 at a Denny's on a bet. The bet? 2 burritos from Taco Bell. Obviously, I'm not exactly Albert Sergio Einstein. But, if you take anything away from this ponderous paragraph, it should be that I enjoy cole slaw and condiments.My sandwich was tasty, the pickles were great, as was the Matzoh Ball Soup. I was just in New York a few months ago and had the "Woody Allen" sandwich at the famous Carnegie Deli. And, I must admit, that sandwich was better than the one at Canter's. Hence the 4-star rating. But all in all - nothing to scoff at.I must admit that I couldn't resist the rugula from the bakery on the way out. I picked up a bag of them on the way. Holy crap.. Now those were heaven in a pastry dough. By the time I got home I was bloated, full, and happy. But was guilty about it.

Reviews.Author: christina a.
Reviews.Content: The only thing I actually liked here was the pastrami sandwich. That could also be cause I was so wasted when I was eating it but from what I can remember I thoroughly enjoyed it.What not to have:Matzo ball soup: it's so blandChicken Noodle soup: because there isn't  actual chicken in the soup. No carrots eitherThanksgiving dinner: apparently also not goodUPDATED 3/5/07OK, I always end up here for the COOOOOOOOOKIESThe cheesecake is also quite divine. So I've decided they earn one more star.

Reviews.Author: Jessica H.
Reviews.Content: I feel like we drove for an hour for this awesome landmark restaurant that turned out to be crap with a capitol C.. sad huh? The food was.. bland.. plain.. nothing special. The service;eh. I think their only saving grace is the sweets, which were BY FAR my favorite part of the experience. So, to recap, the food as a whole is nothing even the most inexperienced home cook couldn't duplicate or even make better, but the bakery counter is worth the wait in line if you're already there anyway.

Reviews.Author: mariel v.
Reviews.Content: Before this past Saturday night/early Sunday morn, I hadn't been to Canter's in about 5 years.  After going out with some of my friends for a girls' night out, this was the only place that served 24 hours that I could recall in my semi-tipsy state.  Plus the friends I was with had never been there.  Sad to say, but this was not the Canter's I remember.  The floors were not that clean, the food was not that great, and the prices were a little too high.  Our server, was really sweet though, and was sort of the saving grace of the night.  A friend of mine had their matzo ball soup, which she insisted was better at Jerry's Deli.  Another friend had the California Burger, while I had the Patty Melt.  I actually really enjoyed my patty melt, although it was a little too much on the rare side of medium rare.  Plus the fries (which cost a $1 more instead of going with the chips they usually come with), were pretty awesome.  There was also a table of annoying d-bags that wouldn't stop waving at my table.  It was as if they had never seen girls in their life before.  The clincher for me though was the line to pay, which seemed to last forever... making me want to stab myself repeatedly.  They have a cash only, and then a credit card line... both were equally long.  I think Canter's is decent, but it may have to be another 5 years, and a major upgrade for me to come here again.

Reviews.Author: Ava C.
Reviews.Content: I love this place. There aren't many places in LA that feel like home when I walk into the front door like Canter's does.  I visited this historic diner two weeks ago on a Saturday night/Sunday morning. My boyfriend ordered the "Thanksgiving Dinner" enthusiastically and I had one of the best bagels ever.  The waitress was so sweet and the atmosphere was just what we needed (minus the table of smug, catty girls next to us).  Canter's is among one of the authentic, old-fashioned places I truly love about L.A.  It's easy to get lost in the nostalgia of yesteryear in this place.

Reviews.Author: Fiona H.
Reviews.Content: I appreciate that this delicatessen has a significant history behind it, and the triumph from its establishment has become such a success story that this diner has been featured in several movies and TV shows.  Canter's Delicatessen is no doubt a classic hot spot in the Fairfax District of Los Angeles.  Unfortunately, as much as I enjoy its historical significance, when I choose to eat at a restaurant, I prefer it to be clean, not too noisy, and has amiable service - sadly to say, Canter's Delicatessen doesn't cut it at all.  When I had lunch there, one thing that vexed me was the darkness of the restaurant.  It was a sunny day, so it was just weird to immerse into a dull and gloomy atmosphere when the weather is so perfect outside.  I understand how dim settings could make the environment more romantic, but this is a deli, not a romantic steakhouse.  Casualness, noise and darkness are definitely not a good match, not to mention the tackiness of the decor.  I acknowledge that it is good to preserve historical embellishment, but it is better to upgrade and change. As for the food, the menu consists of a hefty selection of food items and around half the descriptions were pretty much the same to me.  Conversely, I had trouble deciding what to order.  The darkness and noise didn't help.  The waiter coming around nagging and asking if I was ready every 30 seconds didn't help either.  I ended up just picking whatever and hoped that it was good enough.  Mediocre.  I felt like the waiter couldn't wait for us to leave.  Well, I honestly couldn't wait to leave either!All in all, regardless of the deli's eminent background or however 'classic' this restaurant is, this place just isn't my cup of tea.  Quiznos anyone?

Reviews.Author: Tida C.
Reviews.Content: So I've been to Canter's twice only but both experiences weren't good experiences. First of all, their food is seriously overpriced. A cheeseburger is 10.50. If you want fries its a dollar more and they don't even give you that much. The last time we went, my friend ordered a beef brisquet (sp?) and it was super dry. Not only that but a shake is $5!!!Throughout the whole time we were there, the waitress came to our table for a grand total of 3 times. Once to take our order, once to give us our food and once to give us the bill. We were sitting there trying to find someone to get get us a refill, but no one came or took notice of us. It wasn't even busy and I know it can get really busy. Also when we got the bill, she over charged us 10 dollars. I'm not saying the food didn't taste good, it was just extremely overpriced average food.

Reviews.Author: Anonymous Female S.
Reviews.Content: i like canter's because 1. i am a jew, and 2. it reminds me of old, old la.i only went to the bakery because i was depressed and needed sweets. SUPER EXPENSIVE, but they have FANTASTIC BROWNIES. 3 tiny brownies and 3 large black and white cookies came to 13.75. the black and whites were pretty good by california standards. my parents from queens, said they were pretty good but still not nyc quality.what i like about it here is that the servers dont stick their breasts in your face, and dont look like they are trying to get on a reality show any time soon.canter's is what a diner should be.yeah the food is a bit expensive, but i live next to a similar place out here in the valley, and it isnt much cheaper.you are paying a bit more to be in a "historical spot" and probably most of the food isnt that great. you can probably get better food a block away at a less famous place.

Reviews.Author: Elizabeth L.
Reviews.Content: MATZO BALL SOUP is all I ever get here with chicken n noodles. Love the noodles. Love the Matzo Ball n Broth.  The chicken is white meat so its ok for me.  This soup definitely warms the soul after a cold night out in the hills watching the fireworks over culver city.It's also open 24 hours which is a plus.  The portion is big enough for me so that there's left overs for the next day!! Yippee!!

Reviews.Author: Lynn C.
Reviews.Content: I love the vibe of this place - the booths, the characters who work and eat there - like any Jewish deli, they have great pickles and mustard.  I went in knowing exactly what I wanted - their famous Monte Cristo; unfortunately, they wouldn't let me order it without meat (or on the side) so my vegetarian husband could split it with me; I knew it was going to be a behemoth of a sandwich and didn't want more leftovers crowding the fridge so I kept looking... I went with the Hot Corned Beef Sandwich on Rye; The Jewish deli sandwiches in Los Angeles are much more manageable than the ones in NYC - you can actually fit your mouth around them - but there's still A LOT of meat! I dipped mine in two giant blobs of mustard.  Not the best corned beef sandwich I've ever had; it was pretty dry and needed more seasoning.Surprisingly, my husband's vegetarian sandwich was a lot better - Avocado Melt with Sauteed Mushrooms, Tomato, Swiss, and Alfalfa Sprouts, grilled on Whole Wheat.  The big steak fries were great, too.Seems to be hit or miss.  The waiter recommended the corned beef to me, though, so I'm a little confused.  Guess I'll have to go back for the Monte Cristo and see if it's worth the hype.Bonus points - parking lot with free validation.

Reviews.Author: Rob D.
Reviews.Content: Amazing authentic Jewish deli. The chopped liver with pastrami was outrageously delicious. Best chopped liver I've ever had. Service was top notch and friendly. Can't wait to go back someday.

Reviews.Author: C.C. S.
Reviews.Content: This place is a staple of Los Angeles - I put it on my "Must See Tour" when friend's come in from out of town. It's a deli with a lot of history and personality and it's open 24 hours for WeHo hangover prevention.It has a huge dining area that is just past the bakery of fresh breads and pastries at the entrance.  Tons of booths and a lot of bustle at all hours.The menu is too large - it's one of those menus where you're distracted by the number of offerings that one place can provide.  For my money, I go with the Reuben or the Tuna Melt.  Both are the best of their kind.  The rye bread there is the best I've ever had and the Reuben is a perfect balance of meat, sour kraut and rye goodness.If you do half-sandwich, half-soup - go with the matzo ball.

Reviews.Author: Peter K.
Reviews.Content: Matzo ball soup and corned beef with pastrami with coleslaw all over it...!that's the usual for me... plus extra pickles!just wish it was closer..I love their sandwiches cos it's not to salty... they have a waiter named vincent... he's funny! kinda awkward...never really tried much of the bakery stuff... the black and white cookie was not really that good...great food after a night or driking/partying!

Reviews.Author: Chris C.
Reviews.Content: 491 reviews already, but I still feel compelled to tell you that their corned beef is pretty dry. And pricey too.I wanted to back Canter's. I even wanted to buy a "I HEART Canters Fairfax" tee shirt, but sadly I could not.This place should have received one star from me, but the bakery redeemed itself sorta. Chocolate chip rugalas (sp?) are pretty tasty.

Reviews.Author: lyra l.
Reviews.Content: Food is marginally ok but atmosphere is depressing as hell. From the waitresses with methface to the sad-looking and garrulous clientele, old decor too nondescript to be kitchy, lackluster flavors and food/silverware that looks and feels a little icky even if it's not, go here if you'd like a side of sadness with your meal. I'm on a bit of a pastrami kick and thought I'd give Canter's a try. Less than halfway through my meal, I boxed it all up and gave it to the nice homeless man outside the deli. Everyone in the restaurant was kind, but I just couldn't stomach being there any longer. My pastrami was marginal, my friend's chicken plate looked institutional, the fries alone were decent but the food in general was sub-par and enhanced the ennui already in the air.  Apart from the post millenial pricing, I felt like I was in Catcher in the Rye or some other wistful 1950's novel about a once good place with good-hearted folk who haven't noticed that they are well past their prime and slowly yet surely going to seed.

Reviews.Author: Nick S.
Reviews.Content: Over-priced mediocre food: CheckTerrible service:  CheckI mean, really.  I've been here many a times and I've never even seen a glimpse of what makes this place so "legendary" or whatever.  It's so average it's sick and the only thing saving it from a 1 star review is it's proximity to my friend Anthony's place and the fact that it's 24 hours.  Other than that you're probably better off saving a couple bucks and going to Dennys.

Reviews.Author: Dottie D.
Reviews.Content: Am I seriously review #834 for Canter's? Fine, short and sweet . . .This place is magic and if I could I would marry it. Even the briney smell of the beef and pickles makes my toes tingle with joy. WHERE ELSE DOES CANTER'S MAGIC HAPPEN, PEOPLE? Show me a huge 24-hour Jewish deli, with an attached bar and the most delicious chocolate-chip cheesecake, with upwards of four kinds of mustard and YES THE MOST DELICIOUS REUBEN EVER, where I also happen to run into celebrities (okay, they average C-list, but hey, that's so LA). I know it's expensive and the service is hit-or-miss (I prefer the term "charmingly casual"), and that the place is probably overrated due to its, um, LEGENDARY status. But nothing on Earth will ever change my mind about it!

Reviews.Author: Scott J.
Reviews.Content: Delicious pastrami.  I love it with grainy mustard.  Honestly, it's the only thing on the menu I've ordered.  I love the pickles, I love the sprinkle cookies, the silly fluorescent light covers that look like a canopy of fall-leaves and I love this stretch of Fairfax.  Even with the sometimes difficult parking and persistent panhandlers, it's a great L.A. icon to visit.A good pastrami sandwich is right up there with good barbecue.  Yumeroo.

Reviews.Author: Pathu S.
Reviews.Content: Canter's reminds me of my college days. Eating late at night during a "study break" or going for some grub after a night of drinking. I love that they serve their breakfast 24 hours and better yet that they are open 24 hours. This is probably the best 24 hour joint in all of LA. Bold statement right? Try their foods and you'll see why.Their famous Reuben is melt-in-your-mouth-delish! They serve you pickles also and their wait service is always nice even during the wee hours. Don't expect horrible Denny's service here. They have great bagels + lox. I love their omelets. I always go for the avocado, mushroom, and swiss. Their avocado sandwich is also good. Surprisingly, they have a good amount for vegetarians to choose from.No matter how stuffed you are, you must try something from their bakery. A lot are sugarfree and all are delicious. If you're wary, you can also ask them for a sample. Bakery prices are very reasonable, thus, leading me to go home with at least a box full..

Reviews.Author: Shirley M. J.
Reviews.Content: When Johnny Carson was alive, I would see him eating at this Jewish Deli restaurant around 2 AM.  It became a habit eating here after working at a film studio around LA.When my daughters, Joy and Kris were with me traveling, visiting LA, Kris would always crave eating a Kosher dill pickle; I'd take my daughters to a late night pig out here.The food is wholesome and fresh; the bakery is off the hook!  The loxs and bagels they serve are humungous portions.  I always have to ask for a doggie bag because I can't eat the meal in one sitting.I have been returning to this restaurant for well over two decades because Larry Parker's in Beverly Hills closed down, so that is why I began eating at Canter's.As Adam Sandler would say, "Not to shabby~"

Reviews.Author: Nicole C.
Reviews.Content: Pastrami!!!!!!  My Pastrami on Rye was right on!  Had a sandwich and a half with potato salad.  Where is the BEST pastrami sold in all of Los Angeles....I believe right here.If you have any other suggestions, please let me know but Canters has always ROCKED with all of their sandwiches.Huge menu with other great items.  Parking lot conveniently a few steps down from them.

Reviews.Author: Lisa D.
Reviews.Content: I love this place. . always consistent with quality food, prices, and service!

Reviews.Author: Ghimie Q.
Reviews.Content: I really like this place. My friends and I walked in around 2-3am after a night at the club. It is a great place to end the night with some late night goodies.The waiter was really helpful and nice, though I suppose the late night shift must be easy to work and explains how he was able to easily accommodate all our needs.I had some eggs and bacon and other breakfast goodies. And toast and cream cheese. Deliciousness.But yeah, anyways, I'm sitting at the booth and I look up and I see ahead of me Michael Cera.At the time I only knew Michael Cera through Arrested Development as the ever awkward George Michael Bluth. This was before Superbad and before he would be propelled into hyper recognition.Anyways, I didn't know his real name, I only knew him as George Michael. So I didn't bother walking up to him, because really, how annoying must it be to be only known for a character and not your self? So I just gawked from afar as he sat there with his posse and asian girlfriend.This place is pretty cool.Oh yeah, watch out for the bum outside, he followed us to the parking lot.

Reviews.Author: Shawn S.
Reviews.Content: Meh. I'm not Jewish, nor an East Coast transplant.  I'm more of a Midwest truck stop diner kind of guy.  Maybe that's why I couldn't give two shits about this place. I get the nostalgia factor, but the place looks like no one has decided to do any upkeep in the past 30 years, and I don't mean that in a cool retro way. And the food?  Other than the fact that it is delicatessen food, I don't know what's great, or even good about it.  It seems like all the items a deli needs are there, but without the care, love, or flavor that I'd like to see in a place that I'm going to pay money to eat at.

Reviews.Author: Charlie T.
Reviews.Content: I'm not sure what the hype is all about! Maybe it's that Canter's is open 24/7 and well situated for late night eats but frankly the food here was not good and definitely not worth going out of your way. I'm a fan of pastrami on rye accompanied by a good chicken noodle soup,and this pastrami on rye was just so-so and the soup was awfully bland - Campbell's puts this to shame. Service is also haphazard, probably because business is still hoppin' with the late night crowds.A better alternative, in my opinion, is Jerry's. The best option (and probably worth going out your way for) is Langer's! Alas, Langer's isn't 24 / 7 but oh my, the pastrami on rye is good!

Reviews.Author: Nicholas H.
Reviews.Content: Canter's on Fairfax is truly as good as it gets. Really.So being fairly new to LA (and not having actually settled here yet), my boyfriend and his father are always showing me new places I should get acquainted with - the best place to get an oil change, the best place to grab a bowl of pasta, etc... When I asked about pastry, I was immediately steered to Canter's as LA's best Jewish bakery and I've never looked back. Apparently, in the 50s, the boy's father used to come here and get sandwiches and cookies with his friends - and the place is, in his words, "just as wonderful as it always was." I have a peanut and soy allergy, which makes it really hard to eat basically anything I don't prepare myself, and my first question upon walking into the low-key storefront was "do your products have soy, of any kind?" The gal checked with the chef with a resounding "Nope! All of our baked goods are made soy free. All natural." That in itself was enough to make me give this place a 5 star review, as many bakeries/delis/whatever often will just say "no soy" without even bothering to check with the chef. Now I can't testify to the deli part of Canter's, but the bakery is phenomenal. So far, I've tried every kind of rugelach (yes, that is the real way to spell it), both the plain and cheese-filled croissants and their poppy seed strudel, and they have all been outstanding. The poppy seed strudel, which was basically a sweet poppy seed-filled filo dough roll, is by far the most delicious, amazing melt-in-your-mouth pastry I've ever had in my life! They're kept in the leftmost case on the pastry side of Canter's when you walk in, near the top. Buy some!Prices are totally reasonable for natural, fresh-baked pastry, and the best part? They're open 24/7! Munchie-fiends and late-night nibblers alike rejoice. Canter's is the real deal.

Reviews.Author: Cha-cha C.
Reviews.Content: I love me some jew food, and I love Canter's.  I've been going here forever - since my single-partying days until now, with my family.  EVeryone should go to Canter's at least once - the food is pretty darn good too!  Its a very groovy atmosphere, and many of the servers have obviously been there for decades.I love their simple Matzo Ball soup, so that's what I recommend for lunch or part of your dinner.  Their breakfasts are really good, but thats coming from a person who's very partial to breakfast foods.Canter's is a good place to sit down, eat and sober up late at night.  But like I said, its even a good place to bring your family with kids.  It's gotten pricey though!

Reviews.Author: Jennifer N.
Reviews.Content: I recently trekked up to LA for a shopping trip with my friend, Esther. We were starving when we got there, as neither of us had eaten a thing that day. We stumbled on Canter's Deli, and both of us totally enjoyed the people watching. We were transported back to the 50s/60s. There was a large senior citizen contingent there, for sure.Esther and I, for once, managed to control our over ordering. She ordered the pastrami on rye and I ordered the turkey club. We shared half of our sandwiches with each other. The portions were very generous, so we were glad that we didn't order the potato latkes and soup on top of it all. I have to tell you though, that the table directly in front of us did order soup as a starter and it looked steaming hot and oh so delicious. That'll be for another time!The pastrami was on point. I loved how flavorful the meat was, and they really crisp the bread for you. The sandwich was served with a thousand island style dressing, which I really liked, especially because we also used the dip for our potato chips as well. This sandwich was an explosion of flavor.The turkey club was nothing special. The bacon was thick and smoky, but the turkey was dry. The sandwich is huge though, so you might have a hard time fitting it into your mouth.Overall, we had a great time because we felt like we were transported to another time, and who doesn't love a deli!?

Reviews.Author: Barry B.
Reviews.Content: Whenever I am in the area, which isn't often, I stop by Canter's to grab a corned beef sandwich. It's the only thing I've ever eaten there, so I can't comment on the rest of their food. The corned beef sandwich is incredible! It's so big I can barely put it in my mouth. It's cut super thin and is very moist. I usually put a little bit of mustard on it, but nothing else. I sometimes get a side of cole slaw or potato salad depending on my mood. Both are excellent, but these two items could be hit and miss with some people since everyone has their own idea of what these should taste like. They also bring out a side dish of pickles, which are some of the best I have ever had.The service has always been great for me. They have a unusual mix of servers here too - from what looks like college students to the very elderly. But even the geriatrics can hustle pretty good.The decor here seems to be locked in the 50s or some other time period. Just not anything recent. You know they don't put all of their money back in to decorating the place. Even though it appears to be old here, it is very clean and makes you feel very comfortable hanging out here.I didn't give Canter's a 5-star rating because they have raised there prices a lot over the last few years and it is getting ridiculous.

Reviews.Author: john n.
Reviews.Content: So far the best Deli I have found in LA. Open [24x7x365 -  some Jewish Holidays]. Very friendly service, delicious food and a robust bar on the side. Featured on Entourage, I've never seen a celebrity in here but my classmates (USC) claim to have. I don't think today waif like ingénues could make it past the pastry shop but I'll still keep an eye out for the girls from Pretty Wild. And so it is. Never had a problem parking on the street. A must for any visitor.

Reviews.Author: Jane A.
Reviews.Content: Went there with a friend and I don't usually go to downtown. The place is located on the corner of Oakwood and Fairfax, Canter's owns the validated parking lot on the corner a few yards away from the actual deli. The lot was small and full so we had to look for parking off of Oakwood in the residential area on a side street. The deli is attached to a bar, both are called Canter's, the entrance to the deli is the southern door or the first door you'll encounter when you're walking up from Oakwood.There is a bakery by the entrance, the line begins towards the right from the bakery. The place is showing it's age, the employee's are showing the place's age. I think the only reason this place does so well is because the patrons appear to be enamored with nostalgia. It took almost 30 minutes to get our order in and then it took almost another 30 minutes for our orders to arrive and the people who took our orders kept editing our orders for us so we only go 75% of what we ordered the way we ordered it, we kept having to fix our orders.When I finally got my Philly Cheese Steak, I got a couple kaiser buns with over-cooked cubed steak, triangular onions, and green peppers smothered in cheese. There was more cheese than anything else between those buns. If I wanted a pizza I'd order one. I had a side of onion rings that was so greasy I saw the oil pooling in the fried batter on my plate. My friend had the club sandwich, fries, and pickles. I watched her pick out all the turkey, and other parts of her sandwich. She got a few cups of coffee and a palmier cookie and I could see the cookie was dry from where I was sitting.Here's the kicker, it cost me almost $30 for my mediocre meal. What?! Yes, it was $17 for my sandwich and you have to order all your sides separately.Why?! Why, is it that hard to cook the food the way it's supposed to be cooked? It's an insult to call what I got good food. Foodie's do yourself a favor and stay away.The worst part was the guy who was handling the credit card payments (there are two lines, one for cash on the right, and credit card payments on the left) was overwhelmed when there was more than one person standing in front of him. He couldn't focus and had a melt down when I asked him to add up three things on the check. He freaked and said that we should've asked for a separate check. We didn't know and he was sitting in front of  a calculator. Really?! Is it that difficult to punch the numbers into the calculator that's sitting right in front of you? Plus, the more he freaked, the more people were getting in line behind us waiting to pay. My advice here is bring cash and be careful. Ridiculous, disorganized, shabby, bigger than it should be deli/diner.

Reviews.Author: Zod Z.
Reviews.Content: I used to go there all the time because it's always open, so I could always count on ol' faithful after leaving the Silent Movie Theatre. My favorite plates are the Matt's Special (turkey, muenster, and slaw), the California Burger (loaded with mushrooms and avocado),  the French Dip, and of course, the Corn Beef Sandwich. Every plate is loaded with heaps of yummy meat at a slightly expensive price.I no longer visit because I got sick of the attitude from the cashiers that work there (and I mean all of them). I don't have any recollection of a pleasant smile or "how was everything?" Just give me your damn money, and get out.One day, I ventured over to Langer's, outside of down town. Everyone made me feel welcomed and was happy to be the recipient of my hard earned dollars. The food is comparable to Canter's, if not better in many respects. Check that place out, you won't regret it. It's good to be king.

Reviews.Author: Greg F.
Reviews.Content: i stop here every couple of months to carry out food for a cooking free weekend.  Came in before 10:00 on this Saturday morning - no other customers in the take out section.  I picked out foodstuffs on the bakery side - and went over to the deli counter.  There were seven workers behind the counter.  Yet I waited over ten minutes  for anyone to help me.  Two workers were clearly working, the rest were standing in the corner talking.  With so many other excellent delis in town, I don't think ill be back.  To ask a customer to waste his/ her time for a valid purpose is one thing...but this was a blatant disregard for customer service.

Reviews.Author: Kursten O.
Reviews.Content: My husband has been bringing me to Canter's, about 50 miles from home, since we were dating. He has a total love affair with this place. Me, ehhhh....The service at Canter's has never been great. We have never had an issue with promptness but I like my encounters to be more friendly. The prices at Canter's are horrific!  The decor is OLD!There is some good to Canter's such as the tasty food.  It's not tasty because it's seasoned to perfection or anything; it's just simple, good quality food. Portions are average.  They also have an amazing menu selection, like kind of overwhelming.  I know I will be back to Canter's plenty of times in my life and I'm cool with that because it's yummy. I just need to be sure we have recently come into a decent size sum of money to afford the experience and that I'm not in a super good mood and wanting to chat ;/

Reviews.Author: Diana O.
Reviews.Content: I tried this place for the first time yesterday and i was pleasantly surprised!When you walk in, the place is obviously old. It's a charming diner and even has a REALLY old manual cash register, which I found super neat. But anyway, getting to the food-The waitress immediately recommended the Reuben. So, my husband ordered the Reuben while I opted for the smaller-sized portion of half pastrami sandwich and soup.  There were several choices of soup, but I decided to go with the classic chicken noodle soup.The chicken noodle soup kind of reminded me of the Campbell's chicken noodle that I used to eat growing up, but it was slightly better.
