It wasn't too salty and it was everything you'd expect from your classic chicken noodle. It hit the spot for me.The Reuben was delicious and by far the best thing we ordered! The toasted bread, sauerkraut and pastrami were all very tasty.  I sometimes find the pastrami to be over-powering in a pastrami sandwich because it's so salty and they usually load it on there.  But the pastrami was perfect.  It also came with a side of Russian dressing which made the sandwich even better.The bread on the half sandwich wasn't toasted :(  It did come with a small side of cole slaw which was good.The bill came out to be a little more than what I expected.We also ordered a diet coke and I believe the total bill was close to $36.I'd definitely go back though for that Reuben!

Reviews.Author: George V.
Reviews.Content: Pastrami me baby!!  The times I have been here are during the late hours, a great place to catch up with an old friend!

Reviews.Author: Renuka V.
Reviews.Content: Ordered a reuben sandwich to go and had to wait for my turn and overheard the deli guys curse the customer in Spanish-Mexican!Service was slow although there weren't many people in line at all. Also ordered $2 worth of bagel chips (after overhearing another customer picking some up!) and a cuppa coffee and total bill was $20 EXCL tip and service charge since it was to go!! Had it the next day and it tasted delicious!! Minus one star is for the price which worked out to $10 per pax since 2 of us shared the sandwich+chips which is not cheap!Recommended if you have the $$!

Reviews.Author: wendy s.
Reviews.Content: ma and pa kettle ventured into the big bad city to see the mavericks at the el rey and needed a little fried sustenance to prepare them for the journey home over the hill. thus, canter's.24 hours is a plus.a veggie burger, also a plus.having ingredients stated on menu not occurring with aforementioned veggie burger is a minus.sweet server who brought lots of pickles, a plus.having only fat steak fries on the menu that were just so so, a minus.bathrooms upstairs on the dilapidated side, a minus.parking lot, a plus.prices, a minus.garage band playing 80's covers in the lounge might have been a plus, but fresh from the mavericks show, and raul malo's lovely, lovely singing voice, it was a washi was never a math student, but i think it all adds up to good enough!

Reviews.Author: Brittany F.
Reviews.Content: Perfect place for great service and disgusting food. I had the chocolate chip pancakes...gross! No flavor and made with poor ingredients. And the syrup was imitation syrup , i think it was Aunt Jemima . Basically if you want to pay $10 for food that cost them .50 cents to make, Canter's is the place to go!

Reviews.Author: Lindsay M.
Reviews.Content: I used to come here a lot with my friend.  We would hide in a booth in the back and hang out (and order food of course).I always get the same thing, corned beef sandwich on rye.  It's just so good!...plus I hate the idea of trying something new there and regretting that decision.  The prices are a bit steep, but my love for corned beef overrides any thought to not dish out the cashola. But my favorite favorite thing about Canter's that makes it 4 stars and not 3, is the bakery!!  Everything is delicious and unlike their sandwiches, everything is really inexpensive.  Mmmm rugula.  I always get a bag of goodies to take home and devour while I watch Undeclared episodes. Plus, one time the guy at the counter gave me a free slice of cheesecake because he thought my friend and I were dating and he had just treated me to dinner.  We weren't actually dating...but for free cheesecake, we were that night!  **Open 24 hours, major bonus for all you googly-eyed late night freaks like me.

Reviews.Author: Marina V.
Reviews.Content: I've been to Canter's many, many, many times, and I love that they're open 24 hrs.Food is regular deli/diner food, but the bakery - the best poppy-seed-danish-like pastries EVER in the whole world! :)and.. Guns N Roses used to hang out there quite a bit.Enough said. Great place! :) and a historical landmark of Los Angeles:)

Reviews.Author: Pink G.
Reviews.Content: Living in LA thought I had to at least give it a try, right? Well I have been here at least 5 times just so I can prove the reputation.One word to summarize my experience: OVERPRICEDDon't understand the facination about this place, true famous people have dine here, which makes me think these people haven't had good food if this is a go to place.

Reviews.Author: Abegail A.
Reviews.Content: I really wanted a pastrami sandwich and wasn't ready to settle for just any sandwich.  My brother insisted that we come here because of their sandwiches and promised that I wouldn't be disappointed.  I ordered the pastrami sandwich and some matzo ball soup.  So good --- I really wasn't disappointed, instead, I was pleasantly surprised.  The pastrami was so huge and great tasting, similar to the ones I've had in NYC and comparable.  The soup was also fantastic and went really well with the toasted bagel chips that they served with it.  I guess they have been around for quite some time, my only disappointment is that I didn't discover this place sooner.  I now have a place to go when I crave really great deli sandwiches.

Reviews.Author: Colleen T.
Reviews.Content: OH MAN.Appetizers: Matzo Ball Soup! Amazing broth. Perfect for a cold night to warm the bellyPotato Knish with brown gravy. Beats any mashed potato n gravy type food any day.Onion rings. expensive for the amount you get but they're light and super crispy. w ketchup and tapatio. As good as if you went to the fair.Main Course:The Fairfax on a kaiser roll substitute potato salad instead of coleslaw. Pastrami and Corn beef piled high. Add Gulden's Spicy brown mustard, which you might have to ask for.Dessert:Cheesecake with a sour cream frostings. Creamy, slightly tart, great graham cracker crust.Choc Cheesecake. w chocolate chips and a choc frosting. Not as good as the original but still yummy.The two of us ordered all of this w a lil to take home. w tax n tip and WE WERE STUFFED =~$45. Sometimes the servers aren't so nice (but its all about the food anyways) but this last time our was GREAT. I forgot her name but she deserved a good tip.Parking is free w validation @the pay counter.

Reviews.Author: Craig S.
Reviews.Content: This is one of those places that you feel like if you give it a bad review, the whole world is gonna come down on you. But fortunately, it looks like Yelpers have been pretty unbiased with their reviews.That being said, the place has lost a little and gained a little.Its lost some of the flavor on their brisket and gained a few dollars on their prices.The average sandwich and side is around 14 dollars, and although the sandwiches are decent sized, its the reputation you are paying for when you dine here.Nothing we've ever had has been bad, but you DO walk out feeling like, for that kind of money, you should have been a little more satisfied.The bakery up front though is top notch and we always get stuff to take home from there.

Reviews.Author: Kimberley C.
Reviews.Content: PuuLEEEEEEZE!       Don't come here unless you AB so LUTE ly have to!  The food SUCKS!    in a very big way.But if you are out late.  It's a funny place to get some eats.  Sometimes you'll even see a party animal like Gerard Butler there..... But the band in the very very back of the restaurant, in a separate room, tucked away,.... that is FUN!  Even if they can't sing, its still music and when you are drunk, why would you care if the music is good or not.....it's entertainment, pure & simple.Come to the little "secret" back room and you will be guaranteed a good time with a whole bunch of old cronies who have been hanging out there like dinosaurs for decades.Oh and BTW, Canter's has been around since 1931, that's longer than Yelp has been around and most of the Yelpsters out there.  So Canter's survives through thick and thin.  You think they are serving an underserved market???  Yep.

Reviews.Author: Jerome P.
Reviews.Content: One Star for the young male waiter with glasses that saved the day! Tried to anyways...The worst experience ever at a restaurant with a group of people. The "dinosaur" waitress has a big attitude, just nasty old lady. When I tried to get a different waiter the "dinosaurs" that seat you or at the cashier say "Well that's how we do it here" Um... ok that makes no sense.When they had brought the orders they were setting them on the table really fast and mumbling what the dish was. I asked them to slow down because no one will know what is what her response was "well if it's cold you all can blame him" that came out loud and clear. Not to mention no one got any sodas/water till they had already finished there food and the water cups were for little kids one sip and you are done. What I had was a turkey sandwich which had no flavor and was extremely dry with week old bread.I think this place is family owned and I guess they need to give ALL their family something to do but seriously if you cant carry out 2 dishes you should not be a waiter/waitress leave them as a greeter or a cashier or even washing dishes... OR NOT EVEN THERE AT ALL.Horrible place will never come back and will NOT RECOMMEND to anyone.

Reviews.Author: L. T.
Reviews.Content: I ordered the corned beef and it was kind of dry, I liked the pastrami I ordered to take home.  The pickles are the best that you with you Meal.  The rating would have been better but the lot was full and it as super busy and parking in the neighborhood is nearly impossible. The matzo soup looked great!

Reviews.Author: Shane V.
Reviews.Content: It's all about the latkes. And the matzo ball soup. And the cupcakes. And the bagels. And the pickles. And the ceiling.Yes, the ceiling. Take a second and look up from stuffing your face and being patronised by the waitstaff. This restaurant is perfectly preserved and perfectly Los Angeles.

Reviews.Author: Karl M.
Reviews.Content: I've only ever eaten here in the wee hours when pickings were slim, so maybe I'm not seeing Canters at its best, but if there was an early breakfast alternative I'd gladly go there rather than here.  One certainly feels like one is walking back through time in here, but in this case I'm not sure it's a good thing.  Maybe it's the dingy brown-dominated decor, but I can't help imagine that a good steam-clean would do the joint a world of good.  Bakery ain't too hot either.  Still, if you're not ready to call it a night and can't find anything else open, this will do.

Reviews.Author: Alan S.
Reviews.Content: I've been here a dozen times and the food is good, no doubt.  I have one major complaint....dining room cleanliness.  What Canters really needs to do is close for a few days and clean the dining rooms from top to bottom.  I mean EVERYTHING.  Why you ask?  Well, my laminated menu arrived with some sort of stick substance all over it.  All I could think of is some kid with a runny nose had the menu before me.  I thought "if the menu is not clean, what else?"  I didn't have to look too far.  I took a look at the space between the end of the booth and the wall....YIKES.  Straw wrappers, gum, dust and pieces of bread and crumbs from every sort of meal that came to that table for the past 10 years.BTW...check Groupon for a coupon.  Paid $10 for a $20 coupon.  Not a bad deal at all.

Reviews.Author: saucy i.
Reviews.Content: Had the pastrami on rye & pickles. Pastrami was tender but really fatty. Rye bread was good, but crust was as tough & chewy as a shoe. For a leaner and more tender pastrami, go to Art's (Studio City) or Katella Deli (Los Alamitos).Pickles were excellent. I had 5 of them.

Reviews.Author: Nikko O.
Reviews.Content: First time here, arrived around 11pm.Got seated within 10 seconds of entering the restaurant.Prices: bring at least 20-25$ for the good items.I ordered a Hot Pastrami sandwich, BEST pastrami I ever had. $11.75i got tricked into buying fries because i didn't know they were $4. On the bright side, they were steak fries and they gave a lot. They have a lot of items on their menu. But if you're a first timer, I suggest getting the Hot pastrami sandwich, or the canters reuben, which is a sandwich with sauerkraut and cheese with your choice of meat. That costs around $13-14.Great ambience as well, the service was good, food was good.

Reviews.Author: Steve C.
Reviews.Content: Ok, the food is excellent as usual.  This is a deli, so I don't know why people are going to a deli and ordering "restaurant type food".... oh well.  I have been going to Canter's forever.  The quality of the food has not changed at all. My favorite thing here is the Fairfax sandwich (.5 pastrami .5 corned beef).  I try to get them to make the pastrami lean, but sometimes not successful.  I am willing to pay extra for lean pastrami if required..no problem.  The matzo ball soup is real, flavorful, delicious and the way matzo ball soup should be; simply a matzo ball in a bowl of chicken broth...nothing else.  The humus and potato knish is good also.  I would be giving this place five stars if we had better service...really any service would have been fine.  Our server seemed like he did not want to be there at all.  He was fairly rude, which I do expect from the older Jewish servers (part of Canter's charm).  The biggest issue is that he was very inattentive.  We had to flag him down all the time to either take our order, bring the potato knish he forgot to order for us, refill our water, etc.  Really ruined it for us, but that won't keep me from returning.  You know, we are fine with the rude/grouchy service from Canter's servers....that has been their reputation for decades, but if you are going to be grouchy and rude, at least be attentive....k?

Reviews.Author: may k.
Reviews.Content: Love this place!!!This is one of the places that me and my boyfriend just can't get enough of! We are suckers for Jewish food especially a good Jewish deli. My boyfriends favorite food in the world is a Reuben, literally if he sees it on a menu anywhere he will order it. So of course canters is one of his favorites!!! Me personally I go just for the pickles and the matzo ball soup, which are soooooo good!!!! The pickles remind me of my baba and the matzo ball soup is awesome best I have had outside of winnipeg. Also the cocktails here are gay bar strong so watch out!!! Writing this I'm now craving  matzo ball soup! CRAP!!!!!

Reviews.Author: Katie D.
Reviews.Content: My first Canter's experience was in Las Vegas (in TI) years ago. Now I make sure to stop by everytime I'm in sin city.  So I was pretty excited to finally check out the OG LA location.  This review is for their sandwiches.  Their baked goods/pastries looked to die for but I had my fill of sugar for the day.  I came here on a Friday night..  They have their own lot and parking is free.As for the food... Wow.  Pure Disappointment.  They have quite an extensive menu but they don't have my favorite chicken fingers!!??  The prices here were also much higher than the Vegas deli.  Anyway, we got the Turkey Pastrami (I usually get the regular Pastrami in Vegas and it's delish!) and Egg Salad Sandwich.  The Egg Salad Sandwich was MEH!  The Turkey Pastrami was a waste of $12.  Yes, $12 for a dry COLD Turkey Pastrami Sandwich!!!  Yes, it was cold and very dry.  Definitely nothing like their regular HOT Pastrami sandwich but their crowded menu didn't specify that it was COLD.  The sandwiches DIDN'T come with a free side either!  I'll be saving my Canter's cravings for the Vegas location.

Reviews.Author: Angel C.
Reviews.Content: Canter's has a hypnotic quality about it that draws me in- it could be the tree branch ceiling light panels, or the rows of pastries at the entrance complete with the friendly baker... I haven't decided.Being a chilly winter day (which for Los Angeles means below 55F), I had a craving for something that one of my former employers got me hooked on- matzo ball soup. Extra hungry, I thought that I could tackle the Mishmosh, which is the matzo ball soup with noodles AND rice, and a potato knish. I was wrong. I almost, but did not make it through to the end of my knish. My companion had the regular matzo ball soup, kasha vinishka, AND a stuffed cabbage. Ambitious indeed. The soup was just as comforting as expected, but it turns out the carb overload would defeat both of us in the end. Did that stop us from making a beeline straight for the bakery counter? Oh no, it did not...After being offered sample after sample of the many choices at the bakery counter, I think their strategy worked, and we got one of all the mini danishes to take home with us. The pastries were not the over leavened, over fluffed factory-like pastries that you get in conventional grocery stores, but more resembled traditional European baked sweets- substantial and rich.For a busy diner, the server was surprisingly friendly and attentive, as were the cashier register staff. And the baker at the counter reminded me of a favorite uncle that I wanted to stay and just hang out with all afternoon.With the massive menu and so many choices and possibilities, I will undoubtedly have to plan some repeat visits to Canter's to work my way through it. And to try the rest of the baking...

Reviews.Author: Robert R.
Reviews.Content: Solid old school Jewish deli been around in family for years.  Owner Eric has a new book out about Guns n Roses.  How do I know this?  It's on the website, posters on several walls, signed copies at the register and on the back of the menu.  Always be closing, because coffee is for closers.Any way, ambiance is a little loud but just great deli style, seat yourself, take Visa/MC (seems like a lot of places I've been this week are cash only), and food great.Was torn but based on my companion's suggestion went for breakfast.  Cheese (jack) omelet, potatoes and rye toast.  All of which were delicious and best rye toast ever.  Coffee was good diner coffee but not great unlike the original pantry coffee which set the bar high.From what I the sandwiches are huge and look amazing.  Only wish I had another meal here this trip to try one, so definitely left me wanting to come back.If you're staying in Downtown, expect a 20-30min cab ride around $30-35.  Worth it but probably better if then heading a Few blocks north and then east on nearby Melrose.

Reviews.Author: Heather H.
Reviews.Content: Great food, drinks and a back home feel!! Mushroom, green chili, jack omelet is great!! Love this place!! Plus they validate!!!

Reviews.Author: pat s.
Reviews.Content: What is all the hype about????1!!!! Overpriced and underflavored meats, and boring sandwhiches with all side items at an extra price. Don't go there expecting NYC style deli. Boooooooring. The only redeeming quality is that you might see a famous person there from time to time. Totally over it.

Reviews.Author: A. A.
Reviews.Content: -Great Matza ball soup-huge menu-generally good stuff-inside is old and outdated, which they do on purpose -Little bit pricey, but comparable to other deli's that are well known and have been around for a while.-Be careful going there late on the weekend, it will be packed with young drunk people.

Reviews.Author: Erwin R.
Reviews.Content: After a exhibit opening at Known Gallery I decided to take my family to Canter's. Heard tons about it but have never been. My daughters very picky and if she can't eat there, WE can't eat there. The menu was very kid friendly so that was the ice breaker for us. I decided to try the Fairfax Sandwich which is a mixture of corned beef and pastrami. Probably one best sandwiches I've had in sometime. Big portions and big flavor. My girl had the meatloaf. OK, meatloaf tends to be greasy and flavorless. Not this one. It was probably the best meatloaf in LA. Hands down. The fixings were just enough and man we ended up taking allot of stuff home.

Reviews.Author: Josh d.
Reviews.Content: I grew up at this place. I remember when they first put in that tile ceiling in 1978.  (Yes, I am not a young person.) You know, the one that has hidden swastikas in the intersecting branches? Don't let this sway you from going though. I'm sure no one meant to have that happen at a Jewish deli. The great thing about reviewing Canter's on Yelp is that no number of positive or negative reviews will stop people from going-It's one of the great non-chain all-night places in Los Angeles. What makes it great? The food? Nah. The food's OK. Pretty good, depending on what you get. The chicken matzo ball soup is pretty trusty, though salty as all get-out. Matzo Brie is great, a dish I force (or nudge) my non-Jewish friends to try here if they've never had Matzo Brie before. My grandma used to call it "Matzy Brow" for some reason. It was the only thing she could cook. Really, my grandma was a terrible cook. We were all so relieved when she stopped cooking for Thanksgiving. Unbearable. I should get back to talking about Canter's, because this is not a review of my grandma's cooking- a review I cannot write because A) she is not a business and B) she is dead.How are the prices? Not super-duper expensive, definitely not cheap. Unless you're used to Jerry's Famous Deli. Then it's cheap. If your boss wants to take you to a deli, and you want to rake him over the coals, take him to Jerry's and order a sandwich and soup, and one more item. That guy will be in the poorhouse before you know it.Is the service great at Canter's? Not by a mile. It's actually improved since the 80's and 90's, when most of the staff was aged Jewish women who DID NOT TAKE ANY OF YOUR SHIT. We used to say the secret slogan at Canter's must have been "The customer is rarely right". Now that most of those older women are gone, it's younger people working there mostly. I miss those older women. They were like my Grandma- never accommodating, always in a bad mood, but still lovable. By the way, I should mention here that any comments about service are about the service late at night. I've been to Canter's hundreds of times (for reals) after midnight over the last 35 years, because as I say, it's one of the few great late-night eateries in LA. I've been maybe 3 times during daylight hours. There's other places open!I actually worked at Canter's for a summer during college. One of the best jobs ever. I was a host. I was like the mayor of Canter's in the summer of 1990. I was going back to school in the Fall -locally, at UCLA- so I offered to work 20 hours a week, instead of the 50 I was able to work with no school. I think they weren't OK with that. One day, Jackie Canter called me in during the daytime (one of my few times there in the day) and fired me. She said I ordered too many eggs on my lunch breaks. It was a totally weird lie. Here's how much I love Canter's though- I didn't even consider not going there anymore for one second.So why is it great, you may be wondering? It just is. I guess I could say it's the atmosphere. But it's something more than that. Late at night, everyone seems to go there- cool-ass overdressed drunk club idiots, wisecracking goths/ex-theater majors, weird families from countries you can't figure out which, everyone else. I think something that I love about Canter's is that fancy-pants club people who go there after the bars have closed just can't pull off being really snooty here, something I wish I could say about Swingers, which is down the street, and has better food overall. But ridiculously attractive people are more daunting in that space. So it's harder to enjoy the food as much.I don't think I've convinced you properly why Canter's is great. You should just go. If you don't, you'll be missing out on one of LA's treasures. They'll still be packed without you.

Reviews.Author: Mike L.
Reviews.Content: Pretty good, fun 20th century ambiance.  The table servers were friendly but the register/bakery people were mean.  We went during off hours on saturday afternoon and the baked desserts were a little stale.  Pastrami/corned beef was decent although they weren't as good as some of my NY experiences (perhaps it was due to the off-hours during which we visited).

Reviews.Author: Aimee K.
Reviews.Content: Honestly, I've read the mixed reviews here and I have to agree:  with them all.  First of all, this place is imbued with the magical drunkenness of my college rage and the sensible me that sees things as they are.  In its favor, Canter's is already a fixture in L.A. culture.  Been there forever and... hello, try finding a solid Jewish deli open when you need a turkey pastrami or matzo ball fix!  I'm not going to rave on and on about how succulent the cured meats are or how decadent the desserts are or even how classic the matzo ball soup is.  They're not.  The menu is immense so I can't claim to have tried a fraction of their offerings, but I'll always come back here for the weak coffee, the indifferent waiters/waitresses, the wonderfully dense and huge matzo balls, the stacked turkey pastrami with the wisp of iceberg pressed into the top rye slice and last but not least, their appreciation of being awake at 2 am and craving any of the above.  I love it all.

Reviews.Author: Danny F.
Reviews.Content: I went to Canters a couple of days ago.  I just finished reading through a few reviews here and there.  Too many haters.  I saw a trend on the reviews, those who went for the "hype" seemed the most disappointed and consistently gave low reviews.  I don't think those are objective reviews, so please ignore ;).  Now here is the correct review (j/k).I've only had the Reuben and the Pastrami sandwich, with the occasional sides (macaroni, potato salad etc....plus pickle of course...gotta have pickle!).  The Reuben was AWESOME.  They put this sauerkraut on it.  I don't even like sauerkraut, and I (for whatever reason), grabbed a pinch of that to taste separate from the sandwich and that alone was sooo flavorful.  Needles to say the toasted rye with some garlic/butter spread(?) toasted and pastrami (I opted for pastrami instead of corned beef), was delicious.  I didn't give full ratings only cause the price.  It is quit pricey.  But the historical aspect, and ambience are worth an occasional trip.  It's far for me, but I know I'll head back over there.Kampai!

Reviews.Author: Alla P.
Reviews.Content: Just had "Potato pancakes w/ sour cream and applesauce  $8.50."  Worst I've ever had. Here is why:1) there is almost no potato taste - they put too much flower. Real potato pancakes are done with only potato and egg, maybe very-very little amount of flower to absorb the moisture.2) 3 pancakes are very small. They should be 2-ce bigger each.3) Overcooked - brown and NO golden color in them - sower in taste.

Reviews.Author: Margaret C.
Reviews.Content: When my now 20-something son and daughter were young, during a wild family trip to Disneyland and other California delights,  my mother suggested that we all go for a mid-afternoon lunch at Canter's during a day we ventured out of Orange County and into Los Angeles.  We are a Jewish family, and thus we understood that this was a more culturally authentic Jewish deli than any in Colorado,  our home then and now.So just for that cultural authenticity alone, including the somewhat rude waitresses and cashier, we were smiling with grateful joy.The baked apples were my favorite among the food I ate at Canter's that day.  This was my childrens' first experience with a real Jewish deli and they seemed...well....unimpressed.  My daughter maybe enjoyed the baked apples, like I did.  Seemed like everyone else got some sort of piled high meat sandwich.  I heard no complaints.We stood in a long line to pay with a credit card on the way out.  Just as we got to the front of the line, a disshevelled man with a wacky look in his eyes came into the lobby, pulled out a gun, and basically was doing an armed robbery about 5 feet away from us.  The cashiers at Canter's were unperturbed.  "This happens all the time," one of them told us.  "Stay calm."So we finished paying for our food and calmly left.  One of us went to a pay phone (there were no cell phones at this time!) and called the police to let them know about the robbery, and the rest of us went to our rental car.  We all made it back to the hotel in Orange County safely.  I hope that Canter's neighborhood has improved since then.  The kids thought the armed robbery was exciting...more exciting than the food!Oh...and we saw some female celebrity there, with a few men, but I can't remember now who she was.  So life goes on....

Reviews.Author: Jude F.
Reviews.Content: I can't believe I forgot to review Canter's!  I come to this place whenever I am in LA, which is all too often.  The matzho ball soup is to die for, the potato pancakes are crazy good, they are open 24 hours, they have this insane Napoleon pastry dessert that you can split with two other people, and, and, AND. . .they have Rodney Bingenheimer!  Eleventy one!!! See this link if you don't know who he is:en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ro… It may be a freaky coincidence, but he's *always* there when I go, which is just too cool for words.  I'm such a lame fan girl sometimes.

Reviews.Author: Alex D.
Reviews.Content: The legend: attracting strange bed fellows for a looong time! The food is very tasty, the bakery is insane (although not as insane as some of the patrons) and the decor is very delightfully kitsch! Who doesn't love plastic foliage against  faux stained-glass while watching the most bizzare collection of characters any city could every produce in one place: Ron Jeremy in one booth, next to another mid-western expat who thinks he's Axel Rose, next to the yuppie-hipster, next to the hip-hop dudes very loudly spoken and dressed, next to the pale German tourists and Japanese hipsters, next to an overly make-up'd hollywood old-timer still trying to look hot...WOW!!! This place is a buffet for your palette as well as your eyes....LOVE IT!!!Particularly interesting Thurs-Sat late nights after 2am when the club goers start pouring in.

Reviews.Author: Cindy W.
Reviews.Content: Good for colds, late night hungers, or if you just have a hankering for chicken broth, the matzo ball soup at Canter's is the dish to satisfy this creature of habit. You can typically make a meal in itself with the big matzo balls, but remember it's never complete unless there are bagel chips to go with it. Unfortunately, more than usual by nightfall they usually run out of bagel chips. They have a pretty big menu, but to me, the items on their menu can be a hit or miss. There's no point in going to Canter's to order salad because for one, their salad isn't that great. I suppose their pastrami is great but I've personally never tried it.My usual dishes there besides the matzo ball soup, is the potato knish, the turkey pasta warm, and of course sweet goodies from the delicatessen afterwards.(Begin useless but interesting observation now...)BTW, anyone ever noticed the ceiling decor of Canters? Beautiful photo collage of branches and the sky, but in the center of each repetition almost looks like it forms a swastika. Highly unlikely, but who knows...

Reviews.Author: Amorn B.
Reviews.Content: I'm ashamed to say that after years and years of frequenting the original Largo on Fairfax, I only started eating at Canter's a year ago.  From the moment that pastrami and corned beef hit my tongue, I became embittered with Flanagan. He not only moved my beloved Largo to La Cienega but also force-fed Largo's "honey chicken" to my underage self for years, thus depriving me of the appetite to cross the street over to Canter's.The Fairfax (their signature pastrami and corned beef piled high on rye with a side of cole slaw or potato salad) has been a staple in my late night diet since I first started eating at Canter's in 2010.  Sometimes I'll deconstruct the sandwich and get a side of au jus to dip the rye in.  Sacrilege, I know.  The staff is always prompt, and the retro decor provides great ambiance.  Late on weekends, you'll have the privilege of watching boozed-up, aging Hollywood rock fiends wander in from the adjoined Kibitz Room.  Canter's is where I go to satisfy my hunger for cured meats at ungodly hours.  I hope the gout is worth it.

Reviews.Author: Erin H.
Reviews.Content: I heard that this is probably the best deli for pastrami, and while I am no connoisseur, I really did enjoy the sandwich! We arrived around 6:30pm and just barely beat the rush! This place was poppin!We ordered:- pastrami sandwich (split between the 2 of us): lots of meat! It tastes really good with the deli mustard too!- coleslaw & potato salad sides: cold, fresh, slightly sweet- matzo ball soup: we ordered this per Eli G's review recommendation. It just tastes like.. chicken soup. I always though matzo were just the flat cracker things, but I guess they can be balls in soups too :p- onion rings: OMG I LOVE ONION RINGS, and these tasted awesome! They seemed a little bit.. fermented/alcoholic? but it was a really interesting taste :] yum yum yumJust remember to track of what you ordered. Our waitress thought she brought everything, and I completely forgot about the onion rings. She brought them a few minutes later haha oops! There's even a little lot right next to it for easy parking. Yay!

Reviews.Author: Vicki G.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is the first place I think of when I think of LA Jewish delis-  So it is the perfect place to take my friend to experience a good corn beef sandwich and matzo ball soup. Entering the establishment you feel that you stepped back in time as probably not much has changed since it opened, including the waiters. My waitress was a cranky old woman, but it is what is expected there and adds to the ambiance of a Jewish deli.  Of course I ordered the matzo ball soup and split the hot corn beef sandwich. The matzo ball was delicious, but a little disappointed in the broth as it was plain.  There was no disappointment with the corn beef sandwich- every bite was great.  I did order a side of potato salad which was unnecessary and kind of tasted like coleslaw.  Don't forget to go to the bakery on the way out. I am not really into sweets, but I had to pick up the black and white cookie. I recommend this place if you want to experience a true Jewish deli without flying to New York. It was fun taking my friend there to show him Jewish cuisine.

Reviews.Author: Mia N.
Reviews.Content: First of all Jewish delis are overpriced.  I paid $65 for 4 people to eat sandwiches and fries.  Second, this place was stuck in a time warp back in 1969.  Place looked decayed, greasy, nasty, with it's Brady Bunch yellow mustard wallpaper or vinyl booths.  Don't know what was yellow exactly, but that's all I remember.  I was expecting Dick Cavett and Dinah Shore to show up and sit next to us, it was that 60s/70s with yellow tones to it.   They need to jazzy up their decor so it appears to be CLEAN.  Baltimore was overpriced too with its deli.  I will never eat at another Jewish deli for as long as I live.  I would rather go to Subway's.Then the people who work there are cantankerous as was our 70 year old waitress.  Then I went to buy sweets at the bakery.  Their hard assed cookies and cakes.  The lady behind the counter was a true witch who told me to take my screeching two year old out of there.  I shoulda complained to Am Express to refund me my $65 for rude service, but I didn't.   TOURISTS, do not go to this deli.  WASTE OF MONEY and this place is a NASTY LOOKING DUMP.  Better off buying pastrami and fresh french bread at Wholefoods and going to Griffith Park or wherever you can go in L.A.

Reviews.Author: Stella J.
Reviews.Content: It's an LA landmark, but it lost its luster years ago.  It's too busy, too many trendoid posers, and the food is so-so.  They're coasting on their reputation.The best thing I can say about Canter's is that they're open for 24 hours.  So are a lot of places in L.A.It's just not worth the visit.  The food is plain, the bread is not real, traditional rye bread.  It's also overpriced.  It's not even really a good old-school, historic, traditional L.A. dinner.  Anyone who thinks it is comes from somewhere else.  Skip the coffee:  trust me.Sorry, Canter's.  You have some serious work to do to improve the place.  I miss the old place when the food was great and the service was perfect.

Reviews.Author: Raymond R.
Reviews.Content: "It comes with fries.'Four words that doomed my drunken encounter at the expansive 24 hour dining institution Canter's Deli.  I came in with pretty high expectations of this joint, and a fierce hunger after too many beers on St. Patrick's Day weekend.  Apparently I didn't get the luck of the Irish on this night.I was contemplating a Pastrami sandwich (which I was later told they are known for), but a beef French dip was brought to my attention.  Having trouble deciding in my hazy state of being, I left it to my waiter."What do you recommend, the french dip or the pastrami?""Well, they're both good, but the french dip... it comes with fries."After that I was doomed to a plateful of regret...with a side of fries. Ok, that was a little dramatic, but the meat needed more taste and moisture, which the dip didn't make up enough for the lack of.The plate was about 12 bucks, but the cost was much more: a wonder to what could have been.3 stars... with a side of fries.UPDATE:  After another late night visit to this spot, I knew I had to get some pastrami.  I ordered a pastrami reuben, and among the four people I was with, everybody agreed I had the best order of the night (judging by the amount of bites they took out of my sandwich).  This experience was a 5, combined the previous 3, the new score is a solid 4... with a side of saurkraut.

Reviews.Author: Charlsy C.
Reviews.Content: i'll write my review short and simple,hands down the best pastrami & corn beef sandwich in los angeles!

Reviews.Author: Benjamin W.
Reviews.Content: This is a real delicatessen. It is not a pseudo one, like Jerry's. The food here is real. It is not Nate and Al's. The food here is good and Larry King will not be seated here. The best corned beef this side of the Hudson (don't tell the Morristown Deli in Morristown, NJ). The matzoh ball soup is the best in LA despite the fact that Los Angeles Magazine thinks Nate and Al's is, they clearly don't know matzo ball soup. The pickles are actually pickles, crisp, fresh, the right amount of dill and garlic. I think I am home in NY. Thank you Canter's, I hate LA but I love you.Having just read Daniel G's review and the other guy who says the food at Norms is better, I ask the two of you and others like you to please stay away from Canter's. You clearly have no idea what a deli is. You do not go to a deli and order a patty melt. Go to Mel's drive in or somewhere else. You order a paddy melt at a diner, try Fred 62. You clearly have never been here before and please do not come back. Why is the homeless guy an issue? Who cares. Give him some money or ignore him. There are homeless people all over LA.You want take-out, there is a side that deals with take-out. You want to eat in, then take a menu and order from it. It is not that difficult. And to Daniel G who thinks he knows "important people." You don't know anyone. Major studio executives and some of the most important people in Hollywood eat regularly at Canter's. Sorry your little vegan friend "Hollywood elite" didn't fit in, maybe the problem is, it is a place that treats you as you should be treated and you didn't like that. Sorry, go put on your clubbing shirt and head back to the line at Area. Oh yeah, your rented Ferrari is due back by noon tomorrow.

Reviews.Author: Sean E.
Reviews.Content: CANTER'S REUBEN. Need I say more. This is the best Reuben I have ever had. My only complaint about this place, is that it is a bitch to get to. Parking isn't bad but it can take 20 mins to get here from the freeway. ANNOY.

Reviews.Author: Ryan M.
Reviews.Content: Thumbs Middle. (c) SA.I vouch for the Matzo Ball soup, but none of the other 4,175 items on the menu.

Reviews.Author: Patrick L.
Reviews.Content: it's nice that they bring a sample of the corned beef and pastrami to the table before you order for you to try.  but, im definitely a bigger fan of langer's.  the meat is just more tender.  i ordered the liver and pastrami, thinking it would be in a sandwich together.  the amount of liver was overwhelming--not complaining bc i could share with my dining partners.  the pastrami was good, but again langer's is more tender and more flavorful.

Reviews.Author: Amanda G.
Reviews.Content: Canter's Deli and I have a pretty solid love/hate relationship going on.Canter's has been around FOR-EV-ER, which is a definite draw; it's one of the food staples of Los Angeles.  And, sure - there are a few things about Canter's that kick a lot of ass.  First off, they have some effing great pickles (Yeah, I'm weird. Bite me.).  Second,  they're open 24 hours a day, and like most places that never close  - their food tastes better at 2am than 2pm.  The Kibitz room in the back is a fun little dive bar to stop into, and to top it off - it's really fun people watching.But all that aside, the menu is huge and overwhelming - with almost nothing that I would eat, less a traditional Caesar Salad.  The service can be slow, especially if there are a lot of drunks having issues holding their liquor at the next table.  And yeah, it's a little bit over priced.I wouldn't make Canter's my every day go-to restaurant - but if you're leaving The Dime or Rosewood Tavern and need something solid to snack on before you go home; why the hell not?

Reviews.Author: Peter C.
Reviews.Content: My review is based purely on the Reuben Sandwich. I love Reubens and Canter's is the best. Get it on sourdough with fries, not chips. The fries are thick and delicious. The blintzes are great too.I saw Canter's on an episode of Entourage lately, and the wait staff was beautiful. Don't expect that. You're not gonna wanna date any of the staff. They are very nice though.

Reviews.Author: Bryan T.
Reviews.Content: Parking lot is quite small and tonight it was tough getting into a spot. Also, the local streets were pretty occupied too. Took me about 40 minutes before a parking spot opened up in the Canter's lot. I ordered a Monte Cristo to go. Canter's version of the MC is a French toast with some shredded ham and turkey. Canter's also skipped out on putting the jam with the Monte Cristo and gave me a dill pickle instead. Defiantly wasn't worth the 16 dollars.With a small lot that was full, high prices, and abnormal dishes, I'd just skip out on returning the next time I'm in the area.

Reviews.Author: Juan M.
Reviews.Content: I'm sure many moons ago canters was a great place to eat.   Now it reminds me of an old dog waiting to fade out.  The sandwiches are average with not so average prices, the dining area has that old man smell, but on the plus side it still has a great bakery.   Langers is the best.

Reviews.Author: Gretchen T.
Reviews.Content: Had a hankerin for a tuna melt, which only hits me about once a year, so I wanted to go to the most authentic place. My all-knowing cousin, who I was visiting in LA, didn't even hesitate before taking me to Canter's. I think most people go here at 3 am, and I betcho if I'd gone then that I would be able to give it 5 stars, so disclaimer: this is a sober review. This is the opposite of how I normally eat and the restaurant is tried-and-true old school, so I could not ding it for having canned-tasting barley soup and too-sweet cole slaw. The pickles that they bring liberally to the table were a good tide-over snack, but a bit wilty-looking. However, I was there for the tuna melt, so I waited in anticipation.... Instead of the dark rye I expected, it came out on some kind of cornmeal rye. BUT, it was big and cheesy and and hit the spot, however I have to say I like the Jerry's Deli version far better. I enjoyed the ambiance and experience, but probably wouldn't beg to go back.

Reviews.Author: Sandra C.
Reviews.Content: I must have been either really drunk when I came here, or it just wasn't that great...because I don't really have any idea what I think about this place. BUT I know that I came here because Yelp said I checked in...but...really? I don't remember.I'm going to go and say this place is not that great since nothing obviously stood out enough for me to remember.

Reviews.Author: Andrew Y.
Reviews.Content: When I'm desiring specific home-cookin', I guess I should consult first, haha.Traditionally not a deli-eat kinda guy, however, the location, time, and moment fit heading to this place for a (what I hoped) decent apple pie with a potential ice cream dollop on top...So, I tried their Russian Apple Pie, tasting like stale crackers drizzled in liquid sugar and layered with a pretty bland apple filling. Then tried their Apple Turnover - exactly the same, only in puff pastry. Ha, I just can't win. Similar to my view on Jerry's - come here late at night, after a long night of standing (or drinking). It seems preferable, with its yellow glow and absurd ceiling design, to not sit at a typical dinner time and wait in the hopes of an excellent eat. It does have its charm, its age, and I'm sure its history, just not an ideal location for good conversation and incredible food (the noise of nearby chatter alone bounces around you in this acoustically challenged restaurant) - it's not "bad", just...more of a late-night place to feast...Wil I be back? Well, depends on the context - if nothing else is open at 1am on a weekday, I may consider it. I just don't know that it will be any time in the near future.

Reviews.Author: Jeremy C.
Reviews.Content: I came here at approx 2:30 AM. If you didn't already know.. In LA bars close at 2AM. Therefore I really don't remember much about this place except for the fact that I checked in on Yelp and ate food while I was in there. I"ll have to go back and rate this fairly sometime. I do remember that it's open 24 hours and it was full of other late night shady characters such as myself.

Reviews.Author: David G.
Reviews.Content: While Canter's is maybe a notch above your average deli, it's far from the best in LA. That said if you're willing to spend the Jewish Deli price tag on a meal for some slightly above average Delicatessen treat's then by all means come to Canter's!The corned beef and pastrami sandwich is a mountain of meat just as you would expect at a deli like this, and the quality/taste is about as tall as the sandwich. (It truly is piled high!) The overpriced bakery in the front does also offer a pretty good strawberry cheesecake for anyone who hasn't gone into cardiac arrest yet!

Reviews.Author: Eli B.
Reviews.Content: What's a girl to do after a hard night of bar-hopping, when no-one's ready to call it a night just yet, we're all hungry,  and it's probably not a bad idea to get some chow to soak up the alcohol?I want pierogies at Veselka,  and then I remember that I live in L.A. and it's 2007. So I do what I've always done- go to Canter's. Being (in case I did not make it abundantly clear) a New Yorker, I'm picky about deli. Canter's makes a very decent sandwich (not sure on the pastrami as I do not rock pastrami, but the other sandwiches are good) and an authentic matzoh ball soup served by cranky older waitresses. Most of all, Canter's has real personality and is not a soulless chain like Jerry's Deli.Right after the clubs close down it can get colorful in here, too.

Reviews.Author: Ken W.
Reviews.Content: Not the best but far from the worst. I'd rather eat at Nate & Al's in Beverly Hills, or brave a trip to Langer's, but Canter's is open 24-7, which is handy at 4am when you're anywhere near the Fairfax district and feel like a corned beef sandwich on rye with dressing and coleslaw.I've only had a fraction of what's on the huge menu; it's sensory overload, but I have a feeling that only a fraction of what's on the menu is really, really good: chicken soup, towering sandwiches, the lox plate, Jewish deli things like that, but when east of La Brea, Canter's is definitely one of my go-to places.Is it Kosher? I don't know. I've seen Orthodox Jews intheir black suits all over these parts, but never inside Canter's.That said, the sandwiches here are big (and on the expensive side). The menu might say "hot" corned beef or pastrami, but the meat comes sandwiched to you sort of warmish. It might bother you, if you're that type but there's enough for two or three normal sandwichs in one Canter's Brooklyn Avenue. Also, at times, the crust on the rye can be a little unforgiving to tender mouths, so take some care.The chicken broth is pretty good, I guess. It's better than Campbell's and tastes like the perfect remedy for a cold. I also like the heartier soups, particularly the barley bean soup, and the split pea (if I'm ever there on a Wednesday). The huge bowls come with some bagel chips, some of them sturdy enough to break a crown, but not totally impervious to soup. There are also half sandwich/soup cup combos that are very nice and won't put you under a food coma.There are entrees on the back of the menu that come either ala carte, or as a full meal with bread and butter, a starter like their big bowls of soup, and a simple dessert. I've only had their brisket, but that's because of my weakness for potato pancakes. I've had the corned beef and cabbage. Not bad, but don't be surprised if there's half a head of boiled cabbage underneath that seemingly huge pile of deli sliced corned beef. I've also had their big serving of short ribs, suitable for sharing, which are on the bland side, but tender as ever.Once, a tablemate ordered a salad that looked like it was supposed to feed a family.There's a huge deli case in front and also a bakery section, of which I've never been a huge fan.Toilets for the main dining room are upstairs, making it sort of a trek after a big meal, but it's almost the same effort to walk to the back dining room, adjacent to the noisy lounge area, for the first floor restroom.Their parking lot is nearby, at the Fairfax/Oakwood intersection, and it validates. There's also another smaller lot across that can handle a bit of overflow, but with both lots full, you might have a better chance winning the lottery that finding street parking. FYI, more often than not, a homeless person stationed between the bright restaurant entrance and your parked ride gets you coming and going.The service can be salty, depending on who's assigned to your section, but I wouldn't say it's intolerable; this place, transplanted from Boyle Heights a faint lifetime ago, is an L.A. landmark. It's nice to go just to say you've been there.

Reviews.Author: Jenn L.
Reviews.Content: Finally, finally made my way over to this place.  Have been wanting to try it for ages and it came to mind when my friend and I where thinking of a place to go after hitting up Melrose.  I was overwhelmed by the menu and definitely want to go back soon!  As for what I got - decided on the roast tongue with a bowl of matzo ball soup added on.  The matzo ball soup was lovely!  Nice fluffy matzo ball and a very clear simple soup.  The roast tongue was so tender - it's a wonder this meat isn't more popular among mainstream eaters.  I'm a foodie through and through so can appreciate it!  I chose the mashed potatoes and potato pancakes to accompany my entree - neither was anything to write home about.  I expected my potato pancakes to be a bit lighter with more crisp to them - they had more filler taste than potato taste.  But.... I'm a Chinese girl - what do I know about latkes, right?  Maybe it was an off day for the potato pancake maker?  I departed with a dollop of chopped liver from the deli and a slice of their creamy cheesecake.  The cheesecake survived no more than a few hours after coming home - it was rich and creamy and not too sweet.  Perfect.  Can't wait to come back and continue to explore their menu!

Reviews.Author: Shane H.
Reviews.Content: Their pastrami sandwiches are fantastic.If you could name the best deli you've had,"Canter's" should be somewhere in that sentence.I believe they're open 24 hours?We had great service even at 1-2am on a weekend.You won't leave hungry, but stuffed! Portions are epic.When you are about to leave,pick up a few items from their legendary bakery near the entrance.The baker I've seen there a couple times is always very friendly and helpful for first time customers.Believe the hype.

Reviews.Author: Thomas G.
Reviews.Content: Everything I expected from this place and more.  Perfect pickles.  Amazing meats.  Fast service.  Generous portions.  Huge take-out and bakery to tempt you.Definitely check out the potato knish with gravy.

Reviews.Author: Michael Q.
Reviews.Content: When you visit an icon like Canter's, your mind plays alot of tricks. You hear about it as one of the longest standing delis in Los Angeles,  You know that legends like Guns 'n Roses and Jim Morrison hung out here in the wee hours back in the day.  But what you really want to know is.  HOW'S THE PASTRAMI SANDWICH?We went here on a Saturday, for an early Mother's Day treat.  Our waitress, Linda, was awesome. Friendly, funny, with a lot of conversation and relation.  We ordered:  2 pastrami sandwiches,  a pastrami/corned beef combo and a roast beef sandwich.  Our expectations...were high.On first bite, the pastrami was nice. Spiced enough, thin sliced, etc.  But after that, the experience became more and more disappointing.  The bread for us all was dry and crumbly. My wife's sandwich was small and had only the pastrami on bread. Linda brought 5 kinds of mustard to our table, but it still wasn't the amazing eating we thought it would be. The meat was also a bit on the dry side.On the other hand, the vegetable beef soup was the best ever.  Chunks of tender roast beef, with carrots, potato, green pepper, onions, white beans.  Awesome flavor without being too salty.  Lots of fresh veggies.So bottom line:  Not what we expected, which was pretty much perfection. Parking's not easy, and we had a 20 minute wait to be served in the deli (with one person ahead of us).Suggestion:  Try Langers.  We wanted to love Canters (because it took almost an hour to get there), but Langers is the supreme end-all-be-all for pastrami.  This experience did not even compare.  Sorry, Canters. We appreciate the history, but the #19 (though more pricey) has so much on you.

Reviews.Author: Michael K.
Reviews.Content: With so many reviews, mine won't even make a dent.Nevertheless,  I HAVE FOUND THE ULTIMATE LATE NIGHT SPOT IN LA, EVER!!!!!!!  Thank Jesus!    Yeah that's right, this is a Jewish deli and Jesus was a Jew, so thank Jesus!I LOL'd when I tried to order buttermilk.  It's a weird thing to order, but they had it on the menu and I love it.  So the waiter gave me this kind of look    O_o       because clearly, he had never even heard of the stuff.    After he consulted with various other staff, he produced an ice cold glass of buttermilk, yum.  Anyway, Canter's has everything you'd expect, and my reuben sandwich was the fuken bomb!  Also..... Buttermilk FTW!(SHUT UP you jerks, and you know who you are, thinking buttermilk is gross, and therefore I am gross for liking it.   Well, it's NOT GROSS, it is delicious.   I assume you already know it's not really butter in the milk, it's more like yogurt... and if you don't like it it's probably because your palatte needs another 100 years of training before it can compare with mine, muhahaha)    ;)

Reviews.Author: Greg B.
Reviews.Content: Do I like Canter's?  Not really.  But do I still go there from time to time?  Yes.  Why?  I dunno.  Please stop asking me stupid questions.I have a question for you:  What kind of a place serves a turkey & stuffing plate and then puts SLICED ALMONDS in the stuffing?  That's just f**ked up, Canter's!  The food isn't great here, but if you stick with a simple deli sandwich it's not terrible.  But it's been there forever and it's open late so it's not a bad hangout if you're in the area with a group of friends who feel like just hanging out.  Don't take a date here.  There's nothing impressive about this joint.  If you want great deli food, visit Nate & Al's in Beverly Hills -- the ONLY deli in town that gets everything right!!

Reviews.Author: Sunny D.
Reviews.Content: The reason Canter's gets two stars instead of one is twofold: When I was in college (and my taste buds were clearly less refined), Canters did provide those late-night snacks when no one else would. Secondly, it is an historical relic. Props for that. I would not eat here even if I had crawled in from the desert, starving and dehydrated, and landed at Canter's door. I would find a tree outside Canter's and eat the leaves. You would think that my sentiment has something to do with a terrible, horrible, no good, very bad experience here. It does not. The lighting is awful. The waitstaff is indifferent. Even if those two things were not true, I still wouldn't come here because the food is just that gross.

Reviews.Author: Jake L.
Reviews.Content: Canters.... heartbreaking.this place has a reputation, we're talking some real street cred; and i expected it to live up to the hype. even at 2am.  Kenny says "what do you feel like jake?" "i could really go for some fucking thanksgiving!" i replied.   little did i know, i would soon get my wish.we arrive at canters.  i take a look around, it seems legit.  the deli is stocked with all the stuff that it should be.  the waitresses are haggard and run down.   I'm in the right place.i open a menu, and to my delight i see it:  THANKSGIVING SERVED EVERYDAY!  my prayers are answered, i couldn't be happier.  It wasn't that great, but it would suffice.  the matzo ball soup, which i see as the Flagship dish of this place, was shitty.  I'm not Jewish, but i know a crappy matzo ball when i eat one. Celina's club was ok.THE SERVICE SUCKED!  we constantly had empty drinks, and the waitress pretty much forgot about us a couple of times. i had to break a $100 and that was a pain in the ass.  i went to the bar to get it broken, and the bartender thought it was a counterfeit bill.  and refused to break it.  [thanks]

Reviews.Author: Eric T.
Reviews.Content: There's better pastrami and corned beef in town, but you aren't getting it at 3AM and that is precisely why Canter's exists and has been holding it down for so long.They have a complete deli menu and bakery that they offer 24/7. It is a beautiful thing. My two favorite items on the menu are the potato knish, which I have yet to find a better one in Los Angeles, and the potato salad, if you like it sweet, it rivals only Philippe's in my book.The pastrami reuben is fantastic, but I think Langer's has the better pastrami. People rave about the monte cristo, but you really have to be hungry and little nuts to order and conquer that thing. However, the turkey pastrami is possibly their best meat.The pancakes and french toast are both great, and make sure you get some pickles regardless of the time of day.   You pay for everything at the front. Splitting the bill and paying with a credit card and some cash is always difficult so try and figure all that out in advance. The waiting staff and cashiers here don't have any patience, as with any good deli.The bakery has a enormous selection too. I always snag a few things on the way out, but I'm slowly coming to realize that there are far better bakeries and places to get my sweet fix, although options are limited late night.

Reviews.Author: Scott S.
Reviews.Content: Since I didn't grow up on the east coast I knew deli through the Canter family's eyes.  Yeah...  Every family occasion wouldn't be complete without a Canters deli or fish platter.  The Bagels, pastries and deli counter is superb and I usually will take food back up to SF with me when I visit the folks.  I've had almost everything on the menu...The best:  Corned beef...  Slaw... Russian Dressing on what else.... Fresh Canters Rye bread!The potato salad takes me in a way back machine.  If chopped liver is your thing it's fantastic as well.A trip to LA isn't complete with a visit to the institution on Jewish fine dining.

Reviews.Author: Denise Michelle S.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is an LA staple and being a Angelino it's almost sacrilege to give it a bad review.  However, the truth is I have had better.  Though it's been a while since I have consumed any type of meat product, I frequented Canter's when I was a carnivore and have since accompanied many friends who are carnivores. My 13-year old daughter LOVES the matzo ball soup.  The pastrami use to be my favorite, until I tried Carnegie's deli in NYC (circa 2001).  I do indulge in Canter's pickles whenever I visit the restaurant. I still cannot get use to the funky, musty smell in the restaurant.  It's a food establishment people!

Reviews.Author: M. Apple T.
Reviews.Content: Something tells me that this place isn't 'what it used to be'  like in the olden days.  No doubt there's a lot of history there, but the food is not so awesome.  The potato knish is bland, the meat knish tastes like plastic.  Plus everything is a bit overpriced.  I come from the east coast, and I know my Jewish-style delis.  I have tried this place over and over again, wishing for it to be good.  I have not lived in Los Angeles long.  So despite everyone's "I've been here since I was a kid" thing, I have no fond memories as a teen going here.  Just as an adult that knows the difference between a good and a bad  deli.This is not a good deli.   I prefer going to Greenblatt's on Sunset.  They have parking, too.

Reviews.Author: Allie S.
Reviews.Content: All in all, it was a pretty good place. I had the Pastrami and the Corned Beef as well as the apple pie a la mode.  The sweets seemed very interesting, I found myself not wanting to enter the actual restaurant because of the display cases out front.  My favorite part of this restaurant is the staff.  The usual wait staff you see in this area are all 20-something actors who think they're too cool to be serving you, yet expect $100 tips.  This was not the case at Canter's.  The staff is older and actually know what they are doing. No hubub, no apathetic hosts, just your good ol' waiters and waitresses and good food.Like.

Reviews.Author: Renita K.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is good because it's Canter's, but I felt like it wasn't as good as the last time I came.Matzo ball soup was delicious.The potato pancakes were OK.Brisket sandwich on rye - SO dry I could cry.Our server was great. Super friendly and attentive and funny, too.

Reviews.Author: Ranch S.
Reviews.Content: As I sit here, back home in San Francisco nibbling on the best chocolate chip rugula I have ever had, my judgment is skewed and my taste buds are happy.  This place is simply amazing.  Among the best Jewish delis I've ever had the pleasure to feast at.  A place I look forward to visiting anytime I'm in L.A..

Reviews.Author: N S.
Reviews.Content: After a 5 year absence from the States, I scurried back to LA with Canter's on my list of "to eat" whilst I'm visiting.  After an early breakfast of fibre cereal at home, a summer job interview, a bit of wandering LACMA, by 11:30a I was well and truly hungry.  Mum and I both ordered the Reuben.  She ordered hers with pastrami and I with corned beef.  I can never eat it all and engoy a couple rugala on the way out....and this time was no different.  I packed up the other half and then after arriving home, I went to swim class and left hungry again....I quickly unwrapped our reuben halves, and heated them thru on a skillet.  Yum. Yum. Yum.  This world would be a better place if everyone got a Canter's Deli Reuben.

Reviews.Author: David B.
Reviews.Content: One of the things that makes people fiercely loyal to a restaurant is history. If the place grows along with the people, it can start to take on a life of its own. But this is only one half of the equation- to have real staying power, an eating establishment needs to serve food that people are compelled to eat- food that stands the test of time.                       Enter Canters Jewish Delicatessen, a genuine LA landmark that is as famous for its celebrity clientele as it is for its Reubens and house-made pickles. It started in Jersey City in 1924 and then came west.         Canters proceeded to grow with LA, and establish itself as an institution.                     We wet our whistles with a couple of cream sodas to start, and quickly dug in to our fat sandwiches. The Canters Special was corned beef with saurkraut, and it lived up to its name, and then some. We also enjoyed pastrami that was hot and savory, and about five different varieties of mustard that really made each bite unique. Matza ball soup is a must, and the crispy bagel chips accompanying it gave a nice crunchy contrast. The menu is huge here, and with so much to try, youll be coming back again and again. The world famous pickles were crisp and tangy, with just the right balance of salt and spice.                The huge selection of pastries and sweets in the bakery seems to go on and on. Cupcakes, scones, bagels, loaves of bread, pies, muffins, rolls, tarts...it really is endless.

Reviews.Author: Jess P.
Reviews.Content: Ok Canter's, I did you love your not-too-fatty pastrami on caraway dotted rye....However, it is to my detriment that i didnt ask to see a menu again and check prices before ordering the cheese blintzes. Because when the bill arrived and they were over $10 for two, I nearly threw them back up.

Reviews.Author: Morgan P.
Reviews.Content: This is a fairly standard Jewish deli. Slightly above average compared to the many delis I've been to in Chicago, Philadelphia, and NYC. Highlights:Pastrami sandwich (4/5)Beef brisket (4/5)Potato pancake (4/5)Lowlights:The vegetable (peas) that came with the brisket (1/5)My mom's bland salad (2/5)The overly-dense matzo ball (2/5)The decor, neighborhood (traffic is heinous), and prices ($85 for lunch for 4)Certainly wouldn't return on my own dime.

Reviews.Author: Tanya S.
Reviews.Content: It was PACKED when I got there on New Years day, but we were immediately seated. I ordered a matzo ball soup and bloody mary and there were both deeeelicious! I asked for noodles and chicken and the waiter looked at me like I was cuckoo. I thought that was common?! Ha! The broth was perfect along with one HUGE matzo ball. Yumz.Anyhow, food and service was fantastic. My only complaint is the prices and that I don't like closer.

Reviews.Author: Brandy B.
Reviews.Content: I like to go here because I feel like I am timequaking to the 1970's mixed with some 60's flair... I always get the turkey melt. It's good. The other item I get is Matzo Ball Soup. Also, good. The servers are all very interesting and talking to them is fun. The people watching is interesting.

Reviews.Author: Aldo V.
Reviews.Content: To know the phrase "Jewish Guilt" is to have a meal at Fairfax's Canters - not only do they offer up some of the best selections of Jewish Comfort food - but staff will make you wish you were never born. Rude, Rude, Rude!  But I wouldn't have it any other way!!!!

Reviews.Author: Wes B.
Reviews.Content: My favourite place of all places for Kosher. I remember in 1978 coming here with my Dad and we would wait for the Corn-beef Sandwich and Matzo couldn't be better anywhere else unless you at Katz in NY but for West Hollywood it's the best.

Reviews.Author: Joe P.
Reviews.Content: It's Canter's, everyone has been here. Look at the place objectively though... $10 for a pastrami sandwich with no sides in a Dennys-like environment. Sorry but that's overpriced. The food is okay but you're not getting your moneys worth.This place compares unfavorably to Norms where you can get food that's almost as good for a lot cheaper. Oh and you don't have to wait ten years up front to pay the check at Norms and the stupid cashier loser won't scoff at you because you "only" tipped 13% or whatever. Next time you do that one Canter's cashier guy you're getting 0%.

Reviews.Author: Raul T.
Reviews.Content: One of my dreams would be to get in my delorian, set the date for 1931,location: Fairfax in los angeles, load the flux capacitor with plutonium for the needed 1.21 gigawatts and press the gas to 88mph.. go back in time, get out of my car and order me an original canters deli pastrami sandwich at .75 cents on opening day, then maybe hit upa strip club or something ..yeah..the 30's...wait what was I talkingabout again?This place is insanely awesome for various reasons. Its  been there since 1931, meaning they are definetly doing something right,its open 24hrs ,It is family owned, and most important  the food portions are huge and packed with so much taste you may drop a tear or too while reaching your foodgasm.The menu can be a little confusing because there is SO much stuff on itI by the amount of options you got your brain hasn't explode yet..take a pick..Burgers? got it, wanna keep the party going with some alcohol? You can get it here!,desert? Got it.Fish? yep that too,breakfast? Of course my horse!, I mean..you can live inside this place and not repeat a meal for a long time.It ll take you a couple of months to try every single thing on it..but trust me, if its your first time, do it right, get your noob hat on and ..aim for the "canter's Fairfax" ..where you most likely will dislocate your jawtrying to fit the insane amounts of meat  in your mouth.If for some odd and almost humanly impossible reason you have room for a desert , by all means order the homemade stuff..dont forget to wear your "I am an insatiable creature" tshirt if you achieve this; otherwise  if you are  human like me you will be rolling out of the door after the sandwich alone

Reviews.Author: dimitri s.
Reviews.Content: Loved it. This is definitely not Es Ef, no sir. Kicking dust up and down Fairfax ave, searching for a  retail spot has never been so much fun though,  all thanks to Canters' . Several Bloody Mary's, a couple of poppy seed cakes and some guidance from Her Majesty Stella Artois... and we are ready to bend over backwards to open  a shop on the next block.

Reviews.Author: Dana T.
Reviews.Content: I went back and forth for a while whether or not I would recount the following experience, but I now realize that despite having free parking, amazing bagels, and a great location- I can never go back the Canters.This could be a long drawn out dramatic story but I'll cut to the chase-While my friend and I were eating, a cockroach crawled across our table- Not across the floor, or ceiling, or by the front door-across the table we were eating on! YEESH! We jumped up, and the waiter suggested we moved tables. We tried to finish our food, but our appetites were gone. The Manager was really sweet and brought over a plate of yummies, they didn't charge us for the meal, and she explained that they had just sprayed the night before, forcing the critters flee the scene.Even though they were great about it, the whole thing just gives me the wiggins.

Reviews.Author: J C.
Reviews.Content: Good 24hr joint in LA.  I can't remember what I had, but it was good. Better than Denny's or Norms any day...I remember having a long wait to pay the bill.. and I had to walk to the other side of the restaurant. Parking is a MAJOR bitch!!!  Their private lot was full, and it's pretty small! We ended up parking illegally and praying not to get busted.. we got lucky!

Reviews.Author: Dessert D.
Reviews.Content: CARROT CAKE:Carrot Cake... right?! How do you go wrong with Carrot Cake?!  My dear friend and actress, Autumn Reeser, and I set out to find a a slice of heaven as we both love carrot cake. However, we could not have gone more wrong than we did with Canter's.  "Repulsive" was all Autumn could mutter as she grimaced, gingerly trying small bites.Autumn thought that the carrot cake resembled a large honkin' protein bar with waxy glaze and all.  Her sentiments were not far off.  The "icing" left a terrible taste in our mouths as it was the worst combination of chalky and waxy, and the dried out bread.. oops, I mean "cake," had barely any seasoning or flavor. Is this place for real!?  Canter's looked gross from the outside, continue to look gross from the inside, and ended up just tasting gross all around.  Repulsive, Gross.. what have you.. this cake? Definitely not worth the weight!To see my other dessert reviews, check out my site, Dessert Darling dot com! :)

Reviews.Author: Rogerio G.
Reviews.Content: It is a must in LA.  I just love the Pastrami melt!  This is good stuff!

Reviews.Author: Aerin J.
Reviews.Content: Nummy and always open. And close to home. I love this place and all it's Jewish goods.

Reviews.Author: Bonnie L.
Reviews.Content: I asked for nova on a bagel. This is something i eat regularly when I'm on the east coast in Philly. The waitress had to ask the cook if they had nova - he said he didn't have nova, only lox. Really?? How many transplants come here and ask for the same thing??

Reviews.Author: Jeranel J.
Reviews.Content: Canters is a pretty decent place. It isn't mind blowing but it is fun and loud and an all around good time. Great place for a crowd. Solid food. Huge menu. You never know who you are going to run into. The menu items are hit or miss. Great salads, sandwiches and soups, you can't ever go wrong with one of their sandwiches or salads, they are always great. The dinner plates are average. My favorite thing about Canters is the old school LA vibe that comes with it. It is one of the only places left in LA where freaks, hipsters, the elderly, families, students, whoever...converge. I highly suggest the hungarian cheesecake. OH MAN! Back when I was broke and couldn't afford air, I would go to Canters and buy a piece of that cake and eat a few bites a day to make the awesomeness of it stretch through the week. That cake is so nostalgic for me now. Great bakery! Fun atmosphere.

Reviews.Author: John M.
Reviews.Content: Godawful, unless you're one of those who will suffer dreadful food for the privilege of being surrounded by Guns N' Roses memoribilia. I ordered the pita appetizer. The hummus was watery and flavorless, the accompanying eggplant salad greasy and, well, greasy. My pal ordered a baked potato. I have literally never seen anything less appetizing-looking served in a restaurant. But then I got a load of the pile of bean sprouts that accompanied his (gulp!) veggieburger. They appeared to be just slightly younger than our waitress, and to have recently been stepped on. Avoid, sweet child o' mine.

Reviews.Author: Bert K.
Reviews.Content: Try the Corned beef on rye it's very very good. They usually will bring you a plate of briny pickles.Pastrami/Corned beef on rye is as good too. Try the Danny Thomas sando. Maybe get a side of home made french fries.  The coffee: its so bad, its good! black and smells like burn motor oil!I like the desserts here: black n' whites, hamantash, Horse shoe cookies, plenty of strussels to satisfy.It would be wise to spend 5 minutes and check out all of their baked goodies.  Decor: straight outta the 50's and 60's , kitchy and great fun.During my college days,  I used to love coming here after perusing the various Art Openings in West LA. Our west coast version of Carnegies in New York. Not the same but it works.

Reviews.Author: Mea H.
Reviews.Content: How does Canter's not have 5 stars, or at the very meager least, 4.5? This is the best deli I have ever been to. Granted, I did not grow up in New York, so perhaps this isn't the best deli in the world, but I will make the bold statement that this is the best deli west of the Mississippi. What is there to say about this place? They have fantastic food. Matzoh balls the size of softballs, the best Reuben I've ever had, great latkes and blintzes and even their sandwiches are great. Their deli meat is beautiful, and you can get them lean if you like. (Though why would you??) Excellent pastrami, corned beef, you name it.They have added more items to their menu which has bumped it from being kosher to being all-inclusive, and I pity the fool that goes here for a salad or a burger. They're fine, don't get me wrong, but would why would you go to a deli for something you can get anywhere? Delis are for deli food, and Canter's does that best. The waitstaff is adorable. I love Douglas and his giant hair, and the little man who is always there late, late at night who is always so gracious and fills your water glass every 5 minutes, and the gruff Jewish waitresses that don't smile but actually love you. It can get crazy there around dinner and 2 am, when the clubs get out, but I've never waited for a table in the 24 years that I've gone there.Also one of the few places where you can find Dr. Brown's soda. What a treat, truly. And for the people who want to get their Jewish comfort food fix, they have pickled herring in sour cream, cabbage borscht, kreplach, kishka, and all the goods. And it is damn good. But if you're not in the mood for anything weird, the more recognizable dishes are fantastic.And the baked goods. Who could forget? This review is so scattered because thinking of Canter's makes me pine for the food and the hamentaschen and the cookies and the cakes and the marzipan and the bread and everything is good! Nothing comes close to the splendor of Canter's in the Bay Area, and it's always the one place I'm guaranteed to go to when I come down to LA to visit.

Reviews.Author: Craig W.
Reviews.Content: Another classic deli which I hope is never scrubbed down.  The waitresses are surly in a good way and the food is reliable and good.  It's good breakfasts when no one cares if you roll in in your sweatpants, and it's good for deli sandwiches at lunch and it's a great late night stop, too.What's not to like?

Reviews.Author: Siao J.
Reviews.Content: Summary:Deli's don't get more classic than this. Once you walk in, you smell that warm corned beef and pastrami scent on one side, and on the other side, the sweets of the bakery. This is a classic place on the north side of Fairfax with a complete deli menu. It is a lot like Jerry's Famous Deli, but better. The place has a very homey but historical environment loaded with pictures famous celebrities and athletes who've dined here before. While I was way to full from my huge sandwich to try their bakery selection, the local patrons said its fabulous, especially their tarts.This is the kind of place you want to keep in the back of your mind because there is so much there that makes you say, "Okay, i gotta come back next time to try this, and this, and that." Recommendations:While their menu is vast and has everything from pancakes to burgers and everything in between, if it's your first time there, you HAVE to try their deli sandwiches-- whether its a pastrami, or rueben, or turkey sandwich that tickles you.  There is a whole set of special sandwiches on the top and bottom of their menu in boxes.  Their potato salads are also superb. Minor Complaint:The parking lot is a bit small for a restaurant that's so big.

Reviews.Author: Misha T.
Reviews.Content: The reuben sandwich here is definitely legendary for a reason. It's Amazing. Absolutely succulent  and hearty. Add that with 24 hour convenience and you'd think you'd have a winning combination. but alas it costs 13 dollars. which is kind of alot for a sandwich that comes with crappy potato chips instead of fries. honestly it's good food at bad prices, if stuff there was in the 7-8 dollar range i would be there at least every week.
