But at 12-20 dollars you could do better.If you like canter's, teddy's cafe on pico and bundy makes a pretty good reuben, not as good but it's only 6 bucks and for being less than half the price it's way worth it

Reviews.Author: Jan D.
Reviews.Content: I can tell you that when i first walked in there, the place just hit me like it is a very old place.  But the variety of food there and deserts are fantastic. Unfortunately i only go there just for is their pastrami.  Their pastramis are delicious!!  I can't tell you what else is good but most of their sandwiches are great.  So if you have the time just to sit back and enjoy a cup of coffee or something and act like you are on the set of Seinfield, then this is the place to go.

Reviews.Author: Kate W.
Reviews.Content: Feeling like death warmed over and with questions of swine flu floating in the back of my mind, I decided to treat myself to some chicken soup.  Move over, Campbell's, I wanted something that actually tasted good, with real chicken and maybe a giant matzo ball or some homemade noodles.I'm new in town, but I've already heard the name Canter's mentioned enough that it was the first place I thought of.  I didn't expect it to be cheap, but these prices were a little outrageous - and chicken in the soup is extra!!  Okay fine, I think, I guess they've been around long enough and have such a great reputation that they can justify these prices.  So I fork over my money, drive home, get under the covers with my box of Kleenex, and shove the first warm spoonful of glorious soup into my mouth.  Blech!  Never in my life have I ever been so disappointed in chicken soup.  Salty, oily, and totally tasteless.  The crappy old can of Campbell's hidden in the back of my pantry could kick this soup's butt.  In conclusion, don't go here for the soup.

Reviews.Author: Orsolya D.
Reviews.Content: Dear Canter's Gods,Thanks so much for filling my Hungarian mouth with your tasty Hungarian Cheesecake which was true to form with what I grew up with in the old country. Ricottta cheese, cream chesse, YELLOW raisins, sugary crust... Finally. In this melting pot of Los Angeles cultures, I finally get to fill my mouth with the food of MY people.Thank you. Regards,One satisfied stomach

Reviews.Author: Alexander M.
Reviews.Content: I'm no deli afficionado but from what I hear from my Jew-ish friends, Canter's is more history than substance. But it is a fun place to go in a group to eat and hang out, especially late at night (I don't think they ever close...) The sandwiches are served in hefty portions with tons of meat. The pastrami on rye is great, as are the soups. The menu is very thorough and diverse and there are tons of sides if you're still hungry after your towering sandwich. The dining area is huge and always bustling with activity. The walls are steeped in history  and so are some of the waiters. First stop on the LA deli circuit.

Reviews.Author: Corey Tess T.
Reviews.Content: OY VEY! Matzo Ball Soup & Corned Beef on Rye.. ain't nothing wrong with that!..  The atmosphere is pretty diverse, cafeteria like..  sort of like Phillipe's - very old school...  the wait was a bit long, but you know I was in the mood to be around lots of people, so that was okay with me..It is one of those places that you expect to see a Tarantino scene taking place in...

Reviews.Author: stephen p.
Reviews.Content: I don't think Canter's needs another review, but I wanted to have it on record for my own sake since I have a love/hate relationship with Canter's since moving nearby years ago. That means this is the first time I've uttered Canter's name on Yelp. After coming here after a screening at Silent Movie Theatre Sam and I came here since it was walkable and open late. Being seated in the booth area near the bar was a great start considering we were only a party of two. And being served by Charmaine was a treat. She's pleasant and efficient and made sure we ordered the good stuff.I can't remember exactly what we ordered, but I think it involved a turkey dip sandwich with fries and chicken noodle soup.You may go for the history, the kitsch, the bar scene or the late-night diner convenience. Do go, but may be not too often. ;)

Reviews.Author: Jay B.
Reviews.Content: This place was featured in Swingers, how could you NOT come here?!?  ha ha ha  I would give it 3.5 stars because of the service, but I don't want to mistakenly lead anyone into thinking this is a very tasty restaurant when there is no alcohol in your blood stream.I used to come here pretty often after partying up in LA back in the day.  Now, it's just one of those places I like to revisit and remember the good old days, he he he.  And that's more or less it.I would see it as an upscale Denny's; with far more variety.  You pay more than you would here than @ aforementioned, but Denny's and Ihop just don't cut it ALL the TIME.  Plus this place is open 24-7, and a lot more spacious, so there's room for you and all of your inebriated friends!   Although the food isn't the greatest(well I guess you can say it's the greatest late-night post-party food, but then again, all food is great post-party....) the service has always been awesome here, which again is why they get an extra half star from me.  I seriously wish they would let us start doing 1/2 stars....Anyway, come late, and come happy :)

Reviews.Author: Rachel G.
Reviews.Content: I feel especially entitled to write this review, because I was born and raised on corned beef and pastrami from New York City.  Canter's isn't the real kosher deli deal, though they come close at times.  I have had better (and don't even ask my parents because they were really down on Canter's, and they've had more kosher deli than me simply due to age, so I'm giving them 2 stars).I was there for a private party.  We were seated in the back room.  The first thing I noticed was the old-school '60s-style ambiance.  Loved it.  The light fixtures, the refrigerated cases, the bakery counter, the pink banquettes - it was all so retro.  Very cool.  We had a spread of deli sandwiches along with the classics - pickles (salty as ever), cole slaw and potato salad.  There was a greek salad in the mix, too.  Weirdly enough, we also had a fish/dairy plate for those who wanted a bagel with cream cheese and lox.  Now, I have no issue with these two being served, but together on the same table seemed weird to this Long Island girl.  A real kosher deli would have no cheese or dariy whatsoever.  I know I know, this isn't a big deal to most, but it just seemed weird (no I'm not kosher).  I had corned beef (with russian of course) and enjoyed it (though what gives - why would it be on white bread - ew - removed that and just ate the meat).  Potato salad was great.  Cole slaw needed a little bit more mayo.  Pickles were delish.  Service was mediocre.  I can't judge a normal table's service, since I was at a party, but you'd think that we would've gotten more attention than we did for drink service.  Two thumbs up for having Dr. Brown's Black Cherry and Cel-Ray available.I'd definitely go back just to chill out in a pink banquette and look at the pretty pastries (good or not, I didn't try them)...rugalach, humantaschen, etc.  Canter's is a classic, that's for sure.  Also - open 24 hours - how's that for late-night munchies!  Sure beats pizza.

Reviews.Author: Ronny D.
Reviews.Content: I can't really talk about the history of this place because I am not a local. I also can't talk about the environment or the table service since I got my food to-go.But I will say that I ate one hell of a corn beef pastrami sandwich on rye.It seriously is something I crave for now, every time I go back to LA, I will need to get back there and get me one of the sandwiches. One star down because it was a little bit on the expensive side.

Reviews.Author: Heather G.
Reviews.Content: The best thing about the pastries here is the tasty pecan beehive, which we sampled from a sample tray at the register.  Easily the best of the 5-6 things I tasted at Canters, including rugelach (coconut and raspberry varieties), bowties, and black and whites.Upon entering, I inquired abut the rugelah and some other items, and the man behind the counter allowed me to taste-test a bunch, while telling me which his "favorites" were.  I found all the rugelah to be very underwhelming and dry, so I passed on those.We had originally come in for Black and Whites for the bf's parents, and ordered a half dozen boxed up, and one for us to share.  We were instructed to pay at the counter on the other side of the foyer, so we ventured through the crowd to do that.  Coming back to the bakery area, we saw a big cluster of patrons looking confused, as there is NO NATURAL FLOW to the  purchase of pastries here.  That was very frustrating.  Finally, we started waving our paid receipt and ringing the little bell on the counter in order to be handed our black and whites.Overall, the setup for the pastry counter (and payment method) could be improved vastly.  Also, because it was also a restaurant, the bakery counter wouldn't sell us a black-and-white cookie to share (un-boxed) to eat on-site, because apparently to do that, we'd have to wait for a table in the restaurant, be seated, and then order one from a waitress.  No thank you, we'll share our cookie outside.Not very customer-service friendly in the way of logistical execution, but the staff was friendly.  However, I must note that I personally disagred with every recommendation the bakery staff gave me, but perhaps you will have more aligned tastes...just be sure to trust, yet verify (request sample before purchase).And the Black and White we ate in the car?  The "white" was runny and soft, and the cake was dry dry dry.  I've had much better.

Reviews.Author: Jess R.
Reviews.Content: I think growing up on the east coast has sort of ruined me for any sort of Jewish Delicatessen here on the west coast.  Usually they just don't match up.Canter's was ok.  It wasn't terrible, it wasn't mind blowing.  The tuna was ok, the pastrami was pretty good, the rye bread and pickles were GREAT.  The crust on the rye bread is very special.My vegetarian friend was made a cheese sandwich - I'd hate to say it, but I was sad for him as I saw him chowing down on it.  It just didn't look happy, nor did he.The fact that it IS a landmark is what made us come in.  We were driving w/ a director from out of the country, and he is the one who exclaimed from the back seat, "Canter's!  They're famous, lets get lunch here!"  None of us LA residents ever even heard of it...  :XIt was good - it filled us up, and gave us the fuel to finish shooting for the day.  It's an experience worth having I suppose.  I'll probably give it another change down the road.

Reviews.Author: Carlos C.
Reviews.Content: Still one of the staples of LA's delis.Possibly the some of the best Matza Ball soups, Corned Beef Sandwiches, Grilled Cheese on Rye, and Pickles I've had. The Reuben is superior, and so are their SWEETS. Those were always the death of me.Love our trusty ol' Canters.

Reviews.Author: Kat T.
Reviews.Content: No wait. Friendly host. It looks crowded outside but just a bunch of kids hanging out. We came here for our 4 yrs anniversary. I know weird but we are pretty much simple like that. I'd be excited if we went out to eat at Mikey D's. Just the going out is fine with me and that I don't have to cook. Now about the food!! Menu is so huge you can't decide what you want. But I had to get my usual when if it is on the menu. Monte Cristo. I thought I liked it the last time we came but I guess it was no Bennigan's. To me the turkey was dry and it was not a monte cristo. The sandwich was not dripping with oil. BOOO.. it was tastey but I won't get it again. The hubby got roast beef dip. He said it was OK but not the best beef dip. The meat looked dry, which it was. That's the reason why he got the dip so he can dip it into something. The service was a little s.l.o.w. waiting a while for them to refill our water. It's great eats if you like dry stuff, like to look for parking if parking is packed, and yes it's a lil pricey.. There is a full bar next door and a bakery in front.

Reviews.Author: Lisa C.
Reviews.Content: Everyone in LA knows that most restaurant kitchens close at 10PM. This is a bummer for unsuspecting out-of-towners and hungry local people seeking a late-night meal (McDonalds and Denny's aside).Canter's is a great place to grab a hot meal, at any time of the day or night. It is practically an LA landmark. The matzo ball soup and pastrami sandwich have saved me so many times. :-)

Reviews.Author: Liz T.
Reviews.Content: Finally a place that has black and white cookies!!  They have a bakery section with so many goodies.  I tried the black and white cookie, lace w/ chocolate cookie, apple turnovers, crossiants, cheesecake and had to control myself from buying all the breads too.Good and fresh.

Reviews.Author: Daniel H.
Reviews.Content: I'm Jewish.  I like good Jew food.  Canter's fits the bill quite well.Came here while I was on a business trip down to LA and got a reuben and matzo ball soup.  On the menu I thought the reuben was spendy, but when I got it I realized why.  It was gigantic.  And delicious...perfectly prepared.  And the matzo ball soup, as mentioned in other reviews, has one of the biggest matzo balls you'll ever see.  It's quite a tasty achievement.I can't wait to go back.  This place just makes me smile.

Reviews.Author: Sara P.
Reviews.Content: I've only been to Canter's for breakfast. Not sure if the rest of the options stack up. Visit #1 - I had an all egg white omelete with mushrooms, avocado and spinach. They were very generous with all the items!! YUMMMMY Seriously one of the best omelete's I have ever eaten! My mouth is watering right now thinking about it. Visit #2 - I was convinced to change it up and ordered the French Toast combo. Eh to the French Toast. I'm not sure I like the bread they made it with. I ended up not eating the HUGE peice of ham that came with it. I'm not really a ham/pork fan, and though I thought I might eat a few bites it just looked oily and pretty much gross. I ate up my eggs and sausage like they were going out of style though. ;) The service is good. We try and sit in a certain area when we know our favorite waitress is working, so that we get her. The bathroom is upstairs and was well kept when I went up there. I think next time I'm in the area I will try to go for lunch or dinner.

Reviews.Author: Win K.
Reviews.Content: This place is particularly good if you are going for something a bit old school.  For the type of restaurant that this is, a 24 hour restaurant that actually has pretty good food, this one is up there.   I mean, how many 24 hour restaurants do I know?  Well, at the top of my head, I would say Denny's..but it's not particularly great--they do okay breakfast, I admit.  Norms is a little better with their cheap steak and eggs.  Canters, however, has a wide menu--even literally, as the menu can cover half of a table.  The food is pricier compared to Denny's (like $11 or higher), but the quality is noticeably better.So my buddy and I came here after a press screening.  I ordered the Canter's half pastrami and half roast beef sandwich.  Quite tasty, not too salty, and the pastrami had a nice fluffy texture (not too greasy).  As pastrami sandwiches go, it was very tasty.  I wouldn't gotten a beer too (which would've been perfect), if I didn't have to take off soon after.The interior is pretty large, so a group of 6 or 7 would be fine, unless it happens to be crowded. This deli has a certain 70's feel with the colors.  It reminded me of some of those old restaurants in Vegas.  This deli is also part bakery, so when you enter, you can smell the sweet pastry. The service was quick, at least when we were there--about 10 minutes--and the lady was very friendly too.  We gulped down our dinner and headed out as we had a call from a buddy who was stuck in LA because his job interview went too long and his car was stuck in a garage.  We found him eating at Subway.  Poor guy.

Reviews.Author: Vicky C.
Reviews.Content: I went to high school right down the street from this place, and during high school, I'd go to Canter's to grab a sandwich and soup and a quiet booth to study.What I loved about it was that everything I tried on the menu was good, and the service was so comfy, homey and sweet.  I've been done with high school a while ago, but I still like going back from time to time - even if it's just to hear the ladies call me "honey" again...

Reviews.Author: Rajiv S.
Reviews.Content: Oh give me the Brooklyn sandwich loaded with piping hot pastrami and coleslaw! A side of their slightly sweet potato salad rounds out my whole night. For a 24 hour place,  Canter's can't be beat!

Reviews.Author: Svetlana S.
Reviews.Content: Apparently it was my second time in the restaurant, it's just the first time I didn't know what it was : ) Even with the awareness of this place being legendary, I wasn't too impressed. The menu was big, but none of the 5 of us was super thrilled with their food. The service was rushed (of course they needed tables), and then the guy at the check-out was just plain rude to us. So for the next time, I pass.

Reviews.Author: Nicole Q.
Reviews.Content: If you want a late night meal that is not Denny's and has a bit of ethnic flare, this is where you go. Old School LA diner, Jewish Style!My ex LOVED the blintzes, but I preferred the potato pancakes. Often I would just fill up on pickles: BEST PART OF CANTERS! You HAVE to get the pickles! It is compulsory to bring them out, I believe. Oh, and with the pancakes, ask for the applesauce and the sour cream, then mix. YUM!It can be a bit dingy, with a feeling of an 80's diner, but that is part of its charm. The back room is my least favorite place to sit, I much prefer to be in the main dining room, at a booth, watching the interesting people who come in after clubbing all night. Great people watching!In all, this is the quintessential historical L.A. diner. If you live in L.A. and haven't been, you should really make a point to go. Not because the food is "off the charts" good, but because it is an experience every Angelino should have!

Reviews.Author: Jeff B.
Reviews.Content: (Dined 6/12/11 SU) Again, it's been years since I've eaten at this place, but thanks to a Groupon offer, I was happy to return...and this time with my wife, who has never been. You still get the complimentary all-you-can-eat pickles! The old-skool decor is still as I remember it with some minor updates.We ordered onion rings, the Eddie Canter's Delight, and the Fairfax Canter's. Wherever we go, I must always try the onion rings. They were good with a nice crunch to them, and when you bite into each one, the onion doesn't slide out of the fried batter. Both sandwiches were excellent (I had to box up a portion of the Eddie Canter's which I ended-up giving to a homeless man as we were leaving).The service was also excellent, as we were seated immediately, were given our silverware and pickles at the same time, and our drink order soon after that. Our waitress was amazing! I'm a stickler about getting my drink glass refilled constantly, and she was on it!Needless to say, we didn't have any room for dessert or even any take home pastries.Value-wise, the prices are a bit high but felt they could be a couple dollars less comparable to similar eateries. Nonetheless, the food was all very tasty.I do have to give a BIG THANK YOU to the cashier. Somehow, my $20 Groupon was coming up "used" which I hadn't used yet. After several attempts, they manually adjusted the file check to accommodate this error. This alone will make me want to return.If anyone from Groupon is reading this, please create a way for us patrons to check the balance or validity of our Groupons (like many companies do with their gift cards), so this doesn't happen again. I can't imagine this is the only instance of this happening. I've used several Groupons without incident, but I felt this needed to be brought up.

Reviews.Author: Pete C.
Reviews.Content: This place has an old school feel.  The service is friendly.Came here to try the pastrami.  The pastrami was good.

Reviews.Author: Tanya K.
Reviews.Content: I want to give Canter's five stars but the place is just too expensive. The food is delicious but every sandwich is priced about $3 too high. The matzo ball soup is phenomenal but still priced about $2 too much. Ask for mayo, dressing, whatever when you order a turkey sandwich as, for some reason, the turkey is always dry. You will end up spending around $20 plus per person.The real standout is the bakery... To die for. The best cheesecake I have ever had in Los Angeles. I'm now pregnant and literally crave it.

Reviews.Author: James B.
Reviews.Content: Canter's has been on my bookmark list forever and I was finally able to check it out! Pastrami:  Some of the best pastrami I've had in LA. Langers got nothing on Canters' pastrami! Perfectly seasoned and cooked. The pastrami was so soft that it broke apart so easily after biting into it... *droool*yelp.com/biz_photos/cfwI…Fries: Large portion standard unsalted steak fries, so it's recommended to share.Parking:Make sure you validate!

Reviews.Author: Sam C.
Reviews.Content: It's difficult to find aged diners in LA, but in the heart of WeHo, we have Canter's!  Of course the facade isn't the best, but given the 70s vibe, it makes you enjoy your hearty breakfast so much more.  The staff is friendly, the menu has tons of food, and that pastry/pie counter looks amazing.Only been here once, but it's not such a bad experience... probably because I love breakfast food too much.  I've also heard great things about the Thanksgiving dinner.. which is served all-year-round!  The plate of food doesn't look too intimidating, but when you start digging into it, it's overwhelming.  I'm sure to try that next time!Breakfast foods good, deli sandwiches good, and Thanksgiving dinner anytime you want.. what more could you ask for =)

Reviews.Author: Robin W.
Reviews.Content: Conflicted here by delicious, authentic, properly- leaden matzoh balls but are they worth $7 a piece? Yes, a quart of matzoh ball soup which comes wit exactly two balls, broth and nothing else- no noodles, carrots, chicken (those are $$). So, $7 a ball it is. $6 for a pound of their delicious, garlicky pickles is fine in my book. $12.50 for 6 of their perfect hamentashen and black and whites was also worth it.Did I mention the matzoh ball soup comes with bagel chips, not even rye bread.So, kudos for the baked goods and pickles. But be prepared to pay.

Reviews.Author: Jim A.
Reviews.Content: Open 24 hours!!   This place is great because of that. Get your fix around the clock!

Reviews.Author: Ryan S.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is really a staple in the Los Angeles community.  If you've got a hankering for tender pastrami or corned beef piled high on your choice of bread...well...then you've probably already been here...or at least heard about it...or had a neighbor who has gone...or your best friend's cousin's hair dresser's uncle's nephew's dog groomer.You get the point.  It's consistent, it's been around for roughly 384 years, and it's going to keep on keepin' on.Yum!

Reviews.Author: Karen T.
Reviews.Content: We tried the mishmosh soup with chicken (mazo ball soup with rice and noodles) and the fairfax special (pastrami and beef on rye). Portions are hearty and they start you off with a big plate of pickles. This was  my first time trying mazo ball soup. I liked the broth - flavorful but not too salty. I actually liked everything about the soup except the mazo ball itself. It also came with bagel chips that was really good by itself as well as in the soup. The sandwich was good with the deli horseradish mustard. The interior is really dated but I think there is a lot of history behind it. The service was mediocre. Our server looked like she wanted to smack us when we asked for an extra bowl.

Reviews.Author: Kelly M.
Reviews.Content: I went here on New Years Eve and was impressed with the huge selection of food and desserts.The restaurant is able to accommodate large parties (there were 8 in the group).  I ordered the eggplant parmesan and friends ordered brisket.  The brisket was a little greasy, but looked delicious.  The knish was to-die-for. I definitely recommend ordering it when you go. The knish is mouth watering mashed potato ball wrapped up in a pastry ... need I say more?Another friend order a green chile omelet as big as his plate, the fried chicken looked delicious and even the salad was made in such a way, that there was a face made out of vegetables.To top it off... we stopped by the bakery on the way out and got some mouth watering carrot cake to take home!

Reviews.Author: AJ R.
Reviews.Content: I have been here a few times now for late night food runs and I have never been blown away by anything that they have.        The food was ok, the service was good.  This place seems to be more of a staple of LA than anything.  It was just ok.  Not great, not bad.       The bakery is awesome - love it.  My wife went crazy over there.... you definitely need to check this place out if you have never been.

Reviews.Author: Alex K.
Reviews.Content: I haven't been to Canter's since my college days, but I happened upon this establishment recently, and it's timeless and a throwback to the Golden Age of Hollywood.  The food does not change either.  I ordered a corned beef sandwich.  The meat was flavorful and brought back memories of late night runs for munchies.  There's nothing complicated or fancy about this place.  But it doesn't really matter because it's delicious.

Reviews.Author: ryan c.
Reviews.Content: Quality of meat - good.Portions - huge, you'll probably be fullService - greatBest in LA - probably until I try other placesBest I've ever had - nope! Eat here again? Most likely since I'm writing this review after the 2nd time I've been here.

Reviews.Author: Rachel S.
Reviews.Content: I am from New York and so a great Deli is a restaurant after my own heart. Canter's is seriously old school, with a cavernous dining room that looks straight out of my childhood and food that will make you misty-eyed. If you have a love of pickles (as I do), try the ones they bring to the table - amazing. Canter's in known for having the best reuben in town, but I'm also a big fan of the simple stuff, like the scrumptious tuna sandwich. The steak fries are also perfectly cooked and make me wish for a world without calories, as that's the only acceptable reason for eating the plate-sized portion they bring you as a "side."Also a note about the service. The people who work here genuinely seem to enjoy their jobs and interacting with the customers, which is something you don't see every day. I'm happy to over-tip every time.

Reviews.Author: Myke F.
Reviews.Content: New York style, but far from the actual thing.  This isn't Katz's Delicatessen, the Stage Deli, or the Carnegie Deli, and don't let any Angelino try to tell you otherwise.  Sure, it's as close as you'll get in LA aside from Langers, but still a far cry from the top deli's of New York.First thing you'll notice is that it's way overpriced.  Sure, the sandwiches are a good size, but it's no Carnegie Deli sandwich!Splitting the bill and paying with credit cards is also quite difficult... the cashier will throw a fit if you take more than a second to instruct her on who ordered what.  You'd think the waiter would be able to bypass this headache by making separate bills, but of course, that's too much to ask.All that negative stuff aside, the Matzo Ball soup is damn good.  The food is very fresh, and the portions are generous.  If you want a NY Deli in LA, there aren't too many options, so if that's what you crave then give Canter's a go!  If you've got some time, I'd recommend heading down to Langers downtown or Art's Delicatessen in Studio City.

Reviews.Author: Willy W.
Reviews.Content: We came to visit Canter's armed with a Groupon!I was excited to try their pastrami sandwich, but was happy to find the combo:Pastrami and corned beef!The sandwich was very tasty and because the meat was very good. But it wasn't the best, but I won't knock it it too much just for that.The gf ordered a chicken liver plate with a matzo ball soup.The soup was great, but her plate itself was just alright she said.Service was pretty bad honestly. But I guess that's what happens at Jewish delis.They do have their own parking lot which is free for 90 mins with validation.All in all, it's a good 24 hour deli with a pretty expansive diner/deli menu.

Reviews.Author: Sarah J.
Reviews.Content: I love Canters!My boyfriend and I go here all the time when we are staying in LA.They have an awesome bakery and deli in front. Canters is open 24/7 and the food is delish! They give you complimentary pickles while you wait for your meal. My boyfriend always gets a roast beef sandwich which is PILED high with meat. I highly recommend the open face turkey sandwich (it's like thanksgiving on a plate)! Some of the staff isn't the friendliest.. But whatever the food is so good!

Reviews.Author: Nyron V.
Reviews.Content: I went here with my friend Cleon, two of his baby mamas, Clarice and Trisby, and his five sons and five daughters: Kiambu, Paris, Demetrius, Khalid DeMarquis,Dimona, Regla, Shasta, L'Onique, Persia, and man did they cook up some good stuff! We all had the masta ball soup and then we all had sandwiches. I had a Reuben, and wow was it off the chain. Canter's has the best quality meat of any deli I ever been to, as good as New York, Toronto and Montreal. Hava Nagila baby!

Reviews.Author: Erin M.
Reviews.Content: I love Canter's! I didn't discover it until 2003 or something, but I know I should have been here much earlier in my life. Upon initial viewing of the menu, items may seem a little expensive, but the portions match. I rarely leave the place without leftovers. The menu can be a little overwhelming too; there are a lot of items on it. But I think this is good, because everyone can find something they want to eat!One of the best things there, in my opinion, is the Matzo Ball Soup. The Matzo ball is huge and filling and delicious. It's so big, this soup does not come in a cup. Everything on the menu is very fresh. The Potato Pancakes come with sour cream and apple sauce (just the way good latkes are served!) and the half order is three of them, I think. If you have had a latke before, you know they are pretty filling. Quite honestly, I can't cover everything on the menu. It's just too much!More often than not, when I go, the servers have been older ladies. Whether they are Jewish or not, they seem like Jewish mothers: concerned that you are not eating enough or (maybe "and") somewhat surly. But I personally think that adds to the charm and authenticity of the place.The place is huge too. There are a lot of tables so I have rarely had to wait long to be seated. And it's open 24 hours! In LA that is a definite bonus. You can go to a concert or a club or what have you, and you will always have a great place to come eat after that isn't Denny's (because let's face it, Denny's isn't a place you go, it's a place you end up). Sometimes you'll even see celebrities there. Some are better sightings than others... I saw Andy Dick once; he walked out right behind us. We didn't say hi. :P

Reviews.Author: Mahogany C.
Reviews.Content: get the meatloaf!

Reviews.Author: Ana C.
Reviews.Content: I've had: (1) Corned Beef sandwich, (2) Pastrami, (3) Reuben Pastrami, (4) Blintzes, (5) Knish, (6) Coffee, and (7) Fries.The best is their fries: thick, big, crispy on the outside, and soft in the inside.  Everything else, go to Langer's.  Langer's has the best Pastrami sandwich or meat sandwich that I've ever had in my life.  Even better than the Prime Rib at Tam O'Shanter.

Reviews.Author: Andrea M.
Reviews.Content: You just can't compare to Langer's #19 sorry. The bakery items were delicious but they all seem to have had the same base cookie recipe... I would return for baked goods!

Reviews.Author: Harsh K.
Reviews.Content: Soooooo many late nights spent here, especially when I was in highschool.  Certain restaurants in LA tend to be hangouts for people I don't dislike, but don't necessarily want to hang out with. like the last time I went out and had the following conversation 3 timesFriend1: Hey harsh, isn't that  Zme: hmm, yeah that's ZF1:  Isn't Z still really good friends with {insert ex's name here}me: yes, yes s/he is, and Z still (hates me, wants to hook up with you, has that annoying rat-dog she keeps in her purse)F2: ohhh Z  is friends with {relevant ex}! Well looks like s/he is coming by. Wow, s/he's really hawtme: Hey Z! how's it goingZ: {random anecdote about another mutual friend}, careful avoidance of topic of {relevant ex}me: Well I don't want to keep you Z:  don't be silly I'll join you guys for a minute...and repeat 2 more times.  There's something about this restaurant that draws all the friends of people I used to date especially around the holidays.  So you may ask "Harsh, if you're gonna meet all these people you don't want to talk to why do you keep going?  Isn't that like hitting yourself with a hammer repeatedly?"Well gentle reader, sometimes it's 3 in the morning, you're a little drunk and all you want is: some blintzes, a ruben and fries, all followed by a black and white( king of the  deli cookies).  When that's the case, hitting yourself with a social hammer is a small price to pay to bask in the culinary glory that is canters

Reviews.Author: Abdul Hasib S.
Reviews.Content: Ive tried the Reuben multiple times after a long night of deep Fried Poetry at the Poets slam. Nothing says yumm other than sourkraut.....! Their open face Philly cheese steak sandwhich with potato pancakes and a pickle isnt half bad after a long nights drink fest less the sidewalk yackathon. Its a good refill i guess. i love this place, i mean come on, its Jewish deliciousness....!!!!!!

Reviews.Author: Sabrina B.
Reviews.Content: When I entered I was starving.When I left I was stuffed - and smiling - AND had a bag of sweets to go in my hand.I had stopped in here a few years back when I wanted a quick sweet treat and was shopping in the area.I remembered the sweets being good and wanted to stop in for a meal this visit. Convenient to where I was shopping - The Hundreds, Hall of Fame, Diamond, etc. it was a perfect place to grab a bite.We ducked in, were seated immediately (no time to gaze at the wall of delicious desserts and treats), and had drinks as soon as we named our beverage of choice.Our waitress was old, hilarious and sweet - just what I expect at a diner! LOL. The pickles were not my preference, but a nice little treat. I ordered the beef dip sandwich with cheddar cheese and my fiance had the spaghetti with meat sauce. Both were amazing. They were straight from the kitchen and steaming hot when they arrived. So hot in fact I had to disassemble my sandwich and allow it to cool or risk severe injury to my tongue. Portions were huge and impossible to finish, but major bang for the buck.Also, make sure you stop at the dessert counter on the way out and get a sweet treat to go. We got an eclair and sugar cookies. Delicious!!

Reviews.Author: Ken L.
Reviews.Content: If you like observing people from all walks of life and can enjoy a well built pastrami sandwich, Canter's is calling your name.Walk into this place and you'll be sent back into time just like Marty McFly; the place seems ancient; including their waitresses, but hey they're nice!  I came here to soak in the old aura and to try out their food, particularly the pastrami sandwich, but we'll get to that in a second.  I tried their matzo ball soup first and I must say, I was pretty impressed.  Dense in appearance, the matzo ball was flavorful and complimented the soup very well.  Up next was the meatloaf and mashed potatoes.  TV dinner status so I'll move on.  Corned beef and hash with a side of carrots and corn.  1989 Cafeteria status--if that sounds like good food somethingwrongwitchu.  Washed that all down with Mr. Brown's Cel-Ray soda (an acquired taste for some people). Yada yada yada ok ok the pastrami dut dut duuuuuut.Pastrami and corned beef on rye: GREAT SANDWICH.  I'm not a fan of rye bread usually, but Canter's rye is soft and the flavor is subtle, so it doesn't overpower the taste of what's important: THE MEAT.  The pastrami and corned beef was tender yet wasn't dripping with juices and still had a bite to it; not to mention it was pretty damn flavorful.I'll try their baked goods next time.

Reviews.Author: Gregory W.
Reviews.Content: I've been going to Canter's for over 20 years now.  I don't think I have ever had a bad experience or a bad meal.  You don't go for the scintilating personality of the waitress or the contemporary decor.  You go for traditional Jewish deli food.  Great corned beef.  Great pastrami.  Great rye bread.  Chopped liver almost as good as my mother made.  If you order quesadillas then you get what you deserve.

Reviews.Author: Scott M.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is great. We used to go there late night after partying many years ago when I lived in Hollywood. I went back recently and had a Pastrami on Rye...you can't get that kind in very many places. No where in Sf or the greater Bay area and only a handful of place in SoCal...maybe Jerry's and a few places in NYC and South Florida. Five stars for the memories.BTW - There's a Carl's Jr. Pastrami Burger commercial running right now that's shot inside of Canter's...AND THERE IS NO WAY THAT BURGER COULD EVEN COME CLOSE TO COMPETING... Sorry Carl's' Jr.

Reviews.Author: Julie E.
Reviews.Content: Big deli with a big menu. All the standards. Can't really go wrong, though it's not the BEST deli I've ever been to (try Nate 'n Al's for serious quality). Open 24 hours. Hooray for that!Very, very good matzo ball soup.They have DELICIOUS french fries, especially when asked to be cooked well done. Sometimes they skimp on them though. Ask them to be generous. I have eaten here when I was not drunk. I strongly suggest at least a small buzz to heighten the quality of your meal. I've run into lots of other drunk friends here on several occasions. It makes it fun!You sit in booths that have this truly unappealing tan color, and it makes you think, with all the colors of the rainbow, this is what someone chose? I wonder...Always crowded, but I've never waited for a table.The Kibitz Room, which is connected to Canter's, is my new favorite dive bar. Great local bands and cheap beer. Very nice.

Reviews.Author: Carlos R.
Reviews.Content: yay! Canters  review number 279!!!!1!!I just got back from Canters and the Kibitz Room.  I haven't been for a while so it was nice to go back. After I park I make sure to jump up and give Sandy some skin and walk to the door. There's  Rodney Bingenheimer sitting in the corner. He looks the same...after all these years.Anywho, I Had the usual Brooklyn Ave (corned beef topped with slaw on rye bread), Douglas the waiter and his impeccable hair did a fine job on my cherry phosphate. The wait staff is about 30 years younger than they used to be. Which is a shame and a plus all in one. Shame because those gals were fun to talk with. A plus because it no longer takes 24 minutes for my meal to walk from the deli counter to my table in the back. The old days of writing on the bathrooms upstairs are gone too it seems.There was someone jamming at the Kibitz room so I stopped by for a beer. Still dark and dank as ever. Bonus! And thankfully it was kinda dead.Still one of my favorite places to have a meal a beer and people watch.Great for a date, a gathering of like minded friends and even meeting new ones.I think I need to head back on Sunday. I need me some of that Hollandaise they do so well and a blintz.

Reviews.Author: Davey G.
Reviews.Content: OK. Well, holy cow... there's already 280+ reviews for Canter's on here.It was my first time ever. I ordered the mishmosh and it was brought to the table by a waiter with the awesomest beehive I've ever seen. He kept my friends well-hydrated with several rounds of Diet Cokes.So yeah, the mishmosh. I've never had a matzo or a matzo ball soup or schmaltz. Who knew it wasn't a gigantic cracker swimming in soup?! The ball--about the size of a baby's head--was more satisfying that a regular meat ball. The fattiness of the chicken essence with the matzo was magical. Magical! I could have fallen asleep right in the booth after finishing off my soup.Other things at the table I wish I could have tried (but couldn't because it was a Friday during Lent), were the thick ass sandwiches, knackwurst, and over sized salads. Considering how they never close and maintain a pretty friendly staff, the prices were right in line with what I imagined. It's a pretty good value, if you ask me. Next time I come around (which will probably be soon because the Regency Fairfax around the corner has a great Midnight Movie schedule), I'm planning to plant myself in front of the bakery section and try every single cookie and danish in stock! Fat-tastic!

Reviews.Author: Jenny D.
Reviews.Content: I've been going Canter's since 1989 and nothing has changed.  I love Canter's only for two things that are near and dear to me on this earth: THE best Matzo Ball soup and their Rainbow bar cookies.  Everything else... is OK.  The deli sandwiches are hearty, the servers nice and friendly and there's always something on the menu I haven't tried.  I brought a friend for the first time and he liked everything he had for breakfast except the hash browns.  He immediately spit out his only bite proclaiming that it tasted like "soggy cardboard."  (I have to take away one star for that.)

Reviews.Author: Heidi M.
Reviews.Content: This is the second best Corned Beef in the country - second only to Katz' Deli in New York.  The bread is delicious, the corned beef (and pastrami) lean and tasty.  The bakery is GREAT!  The plain cheesecake is as cheesecake should be!  The 24 hour schedule is a plus.  Our favorite waitress is Fran - She's a classic.  Her recommendations are right on and her level of service is top notch. The pickles are divine - garlicky goodness!Make sure you ask for the full mustard selection - my favorite is the sweet hot.

Reviews.Author: Dennis I.
Reviews.Content: Every time my father-in-law was in the area he would bring back Canter's corned beef and pastrami sandwiches.  This went on for years and was a nice perk in the beginning, but I have to say I grew tired of their sandwiches.  You can tell the quality is very high, nice rye bread, lots of lean meat, and I had to think about why it just wasn't doing it for me.  After all, I do love pastrami with corned beef being a close second.  Plus I was getting these great sandwiches from the famous Canter's for free!  So, I came to the conclusion that there are so many choices for restaurants that serve pastrami and corned beef that I became more spoiled and picky over time.  Canter's probably has a better sandwich when eaten at the restaurant (based on ther reviews).   Maybe it's the overall experience thing I'm missing out on.  However, from a pure sandwich viewpoint, I prefer the stronger pickling spice flavors of Johnnies or the Hat.  So, I would have to say the pastrami lacked the gusto of flavor, had a tendency to be a little dry (remember it's really lean), and didn't quite satisfy my craving for a high caloric meaty pastrami sandwich.

Reviews.Author: Johnson N.
Reviews.Content: Canter's Deli is a very good late night spot (they don't close!), so if you're jones'in for some food at night, you can definitely try them out.  The Good:  Pastrami / Corned Beef Sandwich, Matzo Ball Soup, and Napoleon.The Bad:  Spaghetti w/ Marinara, Pesto sauce of any kind, anything other than their sandwiches.The Ugly:  The majority of their pastries that LOOK amazing, but are dryer than chewing sand.  Add milk to make it feel like WET sand.Don't expect to go to Canter's for a quiet night.  On most nights, it's a bit rowdy... especially on weekends when the drunks arrive post-bar-hopping lookin' to score them some Matzo!

Reviews.Author: Kari O.
Reviews.Content: I hate to say it, but I've had better dining experiences at Panera. Sure, Canter's is famous, but I'm thinking their name is the only thing to get excited about.I came out here with friends back in June after a double feature at The Silent Movie Theatre just down the street. We were starved, it was open, and we figured we couldn't go wrong if they were still in business after all of these years.Boy were we wrong.Most people can find something they like at a deli, and our little group of four had a pretty diverse order. Sadly, it seems Canter's missed big time with two of the group, and of the other two (one of whom was me), the food was just so-so. One friend's whitefish was so bad he had to send it back and order a bagel with lox instead. At least his replacement order was acceptable. Another friend was less than impressed with her eggplant dish. I ordered a grilled cheese (a safe bet) with some sauerkraut on the side. While the grilled cheese was decent (albeit a little cold), the kraut tasted like it was never cooked. I know not all kraut is cooked, but the hot kraut was my aim that evening. Disappointing to say the least. The last order, a simple bagel and schmear, went without complaints, but it's hard to mess that up anywhere.I would have liked to say the pickle spears served to us when we sat down were a high point, but they were luke-warm and floppy (not crisp by any means). It's hard for me to be disappointed by pickle spears, so this was a first.If you're in the area, it's late at night, and you are craving a bagel with cream cheese, Canter's may just be your place. You can even have a beer with it should you desire. If you're looking for something of decent quality and flavor, keep walking.

Reviews.Author: Jodie M.
Reviews.Content: Of course this place is good. Anything you order is deli delicious.  But to be honest, I've never gotten past the Reuben sandwich - corned beef of course.  They'll give you a plate of pickles while you're waiting and the cocktails are very good.

Reviews.Author: Aaron R.
Reviews.Content: I've only been to Canter's to get Bagels and Schmeer. The Schmeer is not overwhelming, and the bagels are not great. The ordering is a little annoying having to go to different counters to get what you need.But when it comes down to it, where else in LA is there a Jewish Appetizing store? Nowhere that I know of.P.S. the bar side is interesting scene. I got my ears blasted off by some rockish type band one night, not bad, pretty amusing all in all. But again anywhere that serves Matzo ball soup is okay by me.UPDATE: Walked in to get my friend a Rugelach. She ordered one. The guy just gave it to her, no charge. Very nice of him. I like it when places do that.

Reviews.Author: Patrick C.
Reviews.Content: Canters:  Nice historical old-fashion diner-style eatery.  The experience was a little more worthwhile than the food.  Couple things that stood out to me... 1.)  We ask for a table for 5 and noted that our group had not completely arrived.  The host looks around at all the half empty tables and tells 'em.  "Take 'em to the upstairs."  We then proceed to walk up 4 steps to the "UPSTAIRS" where there was a gang-load of unused tables.  Weirdness.  I didn't know whether to feel special or offended.  2.)  Historically, this place use to be the hangout for rock stars and celebrities.  Now I dunno. 3.)  The service was pleasant.  We got served by a lady who looked exactly like Angela Kinsey from The Office... the scary cat-lady hahaha.  4.)  I had the pastrami and corned beef sandwich on Rye.  The meat was decent, but the rye bread tasted too spongy for my taste.       5.)  Specialty is a fruit bowl, which had a whole article written about it and how it was cut fresh everyday by the old owner.  It was meh.

Reviews.Author: Takechiyo L.
Reviews.Content: This place has got history (pics and art), on the wall, in the air (smell of its traditional food), and in the bathroom too!  I used to come here frequently after a weekend night out to the west side.  Still do, but a lot less since I now live in OC.  Man, I miss coming here for the deli style late night snacks, and the authentic Jewish desserts and bakery stuff.  I once came here @ 4 in the morning and was amazed by the number of people still hanging out here.  It's like an upscale Norms =).It's a great place to complete the night, especially if you've just finished your dinner @ nearby restaurants (there are a bunch of them on La Cienega).Those who plan to come here for the first time, watch out for their entrance door(s) and don't get confused. =D

Reviews.Author: M B.
Reviews.Content: Okay, REALLY?! How does Canter's NOT have 5 stars?! I have no idea what you people are on, but this place is the freakin' bees knees. Do you really think a true 3 star place would be around for 78 years? Probably not.I come to Canter's every time I am in LA. You walk in, and your eyes are instantly drawn to the bakery case on the left. Seriously, every single type of pastry you can imagine. My personal favorite are the cupcakes.The menu itself is massive...there is a huge selection, and no one will walk out of there hungry. You are served bagel chips and pickles as an appetizer, which is always nice. The matzo ball soup is delicious. They have all kinds of sandwiches and traditional meals you'll find at a diner. They're open 24/7 as well which is nice too for late night bites while having drinks at their bar. Looooove this place, it's a must-try if you're in LA.

Reviews.Author: Margaret T.
Reviews.Content: Kinda cool that after I came to Canter's, I saw them on an episode of Carson Daly's show.  I know, who watches that show?  In my defense, it was late and there was nothing else to watch.Okay, focus.  The food was just like typical diner food.  I got the sausage and eggs which also came with hash browns and I would have to say it was below average.  Our server was nice and the food came out in decent time but I have to give it 2 stars for the quality of the food.

Reviews.Author: David B.
Reviews.Content: Great food, prices and always a good time.

Reviews.Author: David P.
Reviews.Content: Do you wish it could be Thanksgiving everyday?  For $12.95 at Canter's, it can.We went 8 people strong.  We were picky, hungry, and not easily satiated.  Canter's hit the spot for every one of us.   We walked right in at 8:00 pm on a Friday eve, with a group of our size.  No problem whatsoever.If you are into deli's - Junior's is the poor man's Canter's.  As alluded to earlier, I had the thanksgiving dinner and it was so delicious.  I just needed some football, pumpkin pie, and my aunt Pauline making quasi-racist statments for me to feel like I was at home.Oh, and help yourself to a plate of cheese-fries.  Those things were nasty-good.

Reviews.Author: Harrison G.
Reviews.Content: Pretty standard deli/diner food.  I like this place because it's 24 hours and it has history.  Since I don't live in the area, I wouldn't suggest it as a place to go unless we happened to be nearby.  The food isn't outstanding that I need my fix all the time.  There are plenty of 24 hour diners around town that offer similar quality.The food here is good.  The service is decent.  The atmosphere is really the reason to come, I think.  All sorts of strange people coming and going throughout the day and night.I do want to mention that they have great, filling breakfast specials that are only available in the morning (I think from 7-11am).

Reviews.Author: Rosemary M.
Reviews.Content: I would like to stop exercising and healthful living/eating and try to shack up in Canter's for a month. The results may not be pretty but I am ready. The place is a time warp with deep Jewish history that fascinates me. The place is a 24 hr diner but I really am only able to comment on the fabulous chocolate ruggalah and sweet orange/cinnamon/raisin bread we got. Both were fabulous but I want to try it again. I will force my LA friends to take me there in a few months when I am back down. Fortunately they have parking next door with the friendliest attendant ever and he made up for the straight faced teen working the pastry counter.

Reviews.Author: Richard M.
Reviews.Content: The deli sandwiches are FANTASTIC and the bakery has so many options that are all delicious!  Since I grew up in that area, I've been eating there for years.  The quality of the food stays consistent, but the service varies from time to time, depending on how busy it is.I've been to delis in New York, LA, and pretty much everywhere else, and the prices at Canter's for the amount and quality of the food cannot be beat!  The same sandwich that sells for like $12 is almost double that at Carnegie's in New York.  I've ordered just about everything on the menu, but my favorites are the corn beef and pastrami double decker sandwich, and the chicken and matza ball soup.  The reuben is another good one, and the mushroom and barley soup is spectacular.  And the pickles are delicious, too!And it's funny that the bakery is conveniently located right at the front of restaurant so you have to pass it on the way out.  All the baked goods are delicious, including the cheesecake, rugala, macaroon, pumperknickle raisin bread, etc etc etc etc...  But literally, you can't get a bad baked good.

Reviews.Author: J W.
Reviews.Content: Late last night, we tried Canter's Fairfax and the Pastrami sandwich with Swiss cheese + sauerkraut. I liked the latter more... only wished it was less oily........our waitress was really sweet, she definitely made contribution to the 3 stars!!!at first we were seated in the dinning area up the stairs, but because the music was getting too loud, couldn't have a normal conversation, we asked to be seated elsewhere. After one waitress seated us down in the outer room, an elderly looking waitress walked over and told us we have to sit by the counter because the booth we were sitting at does not belong to our waitress o__O, so apparently each waiter/waitress gets an area of seats?!?? WTH? food was not spectacular, but beause of Canter's history, I think it's worth trying out at least once...

Reviews.Author: Katie M.
Reviews.Content: I can't go to California without a visit to Canter's. EVER.It actually has to be on the agenda to start with so everyone knows that I will spend an entire afternoon eating: a plate of pickles a cup of chicken broth noodle soup with bagel chips, a hot pastrami on rye with mustard and a big box of black and white cookies.This is then followed up with a 3 hour nap of course.The food is to die for, the service is witty, quick and to the point and the prices aren't too outrageous for what you receive.Did I mention I can't NOT stop at this place?!Make it a journey and eat to your hearts delight.I'm going down in October and I'm already salivating at thought of a luscious meal there!!

Reviews.Author: Karla U.
Reviews.Content: This place, oh this place...I came here with my friends last night after a Steel Panther show...It was fun times. :D They have this chocolate frothy soda drink there, I don't remember what it's called, when I find out I will update this. I had to Avacado,Swiss and Mushroom omelette, omg. It was soft, fluffy, the cheese was melted great, so much cheese, and it did the pizza stretch thing....omg heaven! And the potatoes, to die for! Soft and delicious and not mushy. My friend had the Marilyn sandwhich, she said it was great, the cheese melted just right and not burned up bread. :) This place is cool for the late night crowd, it's pretty dead on Mondays, but the staff is very friendly and nice, and service was awesome.  Lots of interesting people there. Canter's is an experiance, the layout is very classic, and the ceiling has tree tops on it as if you are looking up. THE BAKERY LOOKS DELICIOUS! OMG! My friend had a red velvet and it was pretty good. :D This place is great, check it out atleast once. you will love it. TAKE TOURISTS THERE!  TAKE VISITORS! :D FUN TIMES! The ambiance makes you feel like you're just in a classic place filled with fun memories and talking about your night with others.

Reviews.Author: Renee B.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is the best deli in LA. I've been going here for years- and I'm usually a late night patron, well past midnight and the place is always filled with at least 10 or more tables that time too. I love going to Canter's and don't be surprised if you run into someone famous sometimes...I always see Rodney from KROQ here :)I'm always torn between ordering breakfast or a deli sandwich. If I'm starving, I go for the sandwich because sandwiches are HUGE. They're kinda pricey, usually more than $12 each, but I always save the other half for lunch the next day. You can never go wrong with the Canter's Fairfax that's a pastrami sandwich, or my favorite the For Dedicated Fressers Only that has corned beef and pastrami and you get both potato salad and cole slaw. I like that their potato salad is sweeter than most potato salads I've had. For breakfast I LOVE their corned beef and hash with scrambled eggs. There's only one other place I've had it better and that was in Portland- so for Los Angeles- this is the best, hands down. The service is usually good here. If they're ever slow, it has to be because it's too busy, but otherwise, they're always asking if everything's ok.

Reviews.Author: Kathleen D.
Reviews.Content: This is a hard one to review because I would eat here again just to people-watch, but the food (especially for me, as I'm a vegetarian) is certainly not the draw.So, the ambiance that won me over: step into the restaurant, and you are immediately in the '70s. The dark wood, the gold, textured glass, even the lighting indicates this place hasn't changed. And, the crowd is terrific! There were a couple of old men at the table behind us, with thick, New York accents. There was a guy wearing a nylon jumpsuit with gelled hair - if he had a gold chain around his neck, I would have sworn he was in the mafia. As I said, the setting alone is worth it.But, the food: not bad, but not worth driving for. It's a deli, so vegetarian options are not as prevalent as other places in L.A. (My friend picked the place, if you're wondering why I ate there to begin with.) Again, it was fine, and the prices are fairly reasonable, but I'd rather eat somewhere I actively enjoy my food, rather than putting up with it.

Reviews.Author: Justin B.
Reviews.Content: A friend and I came here for a late night dinner the other night and I must say I was pretty pleased with the way the night turned out.We came in around 1:30am and were seated right away back in the open room beside the bar area. There was a band playing so it was pretty loud, but the bar closed shortly after and we could finally hear each other talking.Our waitress was very friendly and came over right away to take our drink orders. They have pretty much any drink you want, including a full bar until 2am, but i decided to settle with a simple coke. Never being here I had a very hard time deciding what to get off of their humongous menu, until I got a recommendation from our waitress to try the Monte Cristo, which I took her up on. My friend got a Reuben as thats what she was craving and what lead us to Canters in the first place.We decided to do a little splitsies and trade half our sandwiches, and I have to say I'm very glad I did. The Monte Cristo was awesome and I think I'll need to start getting it more often at other places. The Reuben was very good as well and the sauerkraut was prefect. The Reuben came with steak fries and we got a side of ranch for it on the side by request. Now I wouldnt come here if your looking for one of those tasty and cheap diners as both our meals were upwards of $14, but they do give you a pretty hearty portion of meat, and the food was pretty delicious. I would definitely recommend it to try as your next late night diner experience if you have yet to go, and I myself will definitely be going back for more once my pockets are deep enough!

Reviews.Author: C P.
Reviews.Content: I went to Canter's for the first time about 4 years ago, initially I wasn't crazy impressed other than the cool ass decor and vibe but over those 4 years my love has grown : )Pastrami on Rye, YUM...French Fries...MY NEW FAV...French toast...OMG....sometimes their bread isn't the freshest but I still take a chance.  Oh....and their coffee is great!  Uh, and I haven't even gotten to the bakery...it's all good there.  I like the fact that nothing is over the top sweet.  It's super tasty!  And they are open 24 hours!  What more could I ask for??The parking attendent is now my buddy and always has a secret parking space which he lets me have when the lot is full.

Reviews.Author: Timothy W.
Reviews.Content: Canter's delicatessen, first deli that I beenI like they open late, for when my hunger gratesOn my mind like coal on ice, my brain is melting feeling niceDope pastrami, and (of course), no salamiThe matza ball soup, had me in an ordering loopAnd the pickles on my plates, I never would berateFor some reason I recall, one drunken night in fallI think there is a bar, right attached and not too farI could though have been drunk, I'm not sure so I'll just dunkAnd go out on a limb, say there's a bar withinRight attached to the restaurant, with a stage, the jazz was onCool little environment, made my mind calm retirementThere was a guy in what appears, I'm not sure but I am clearA sailor uniform he wore, I swear, I said I'd never lie no moreAnyways back at hand, the food is topic, not jazz bandI've had the dip roast beef, big, and lots of meatThe signature pastrami though, I eat up in all wholeBut overall, I don't give love, I might be cheap, but just becauseI always end up paying more (than), just bout fifteen dollars or moreFor a sandwich and a little side, so need to return, meh, let it slide**Sandwiches are good, but crap dude, almost $20 everytime, no thx

Reviews.Author: Heather T.
Reviews.Content: I'm starting to feel a little self-conscious about all the five stars I've been handing out lately. Maybe I'm in a really good mood, or I'm just having lots of awesome experiences lately. Nearly four years after moving to LA, my boyfriend and I finally made it here and it lived up to the hype. My pastrami reuben was heaven on bread, the matzo ball soup is perfect on a rainy day and the pickles are pure heaven. The decor is tacky, the people are frumpy and the food is great. I can't wait to go back.

Reviews.Author: Chris C.
Reviews.Content: I hope this place never changes, because when you walk in here you almost feel like you've gone back in time to a day when Jewish delis dotted the landscape and going to a restaurant like this was just an everyday thing. These days, it's almost impossible to find a place like this, even in a city of 8 million people and a large Jewish population. The inside of this place looks like it hasn't changed since the 1970s, particularly with the orange and brown color scheme. Many of the servers here also look like they've probably been working here since then, too. I tried the Brooklyn Ave. (hot corned beef) with swiss cheese. It's a pretty big sandwich, more than enough to take home for lunch the next day. Definitely one of the better corned beef sandwiches I've ever eaten, rivaled only by Wolfie's Rascal House in Florida (now closed) and D.Z. Akins in San Diego. I'm usually not a huge fan of rye bread, but the bread here was particularly fresh with a nice crunchy crust. The french fries were excellent too, nice and crispy but not overcooked. Service is not overly friendly but was extremely fast...we came at around 6pm on a Sunday and were in and out of here in less than 45 minutes. Can't wait to make it back here again sometime soon.

Reviews.Author: Jennifer L.
Reviews.Content: It's an iconic and fun place to visit. The food is just fine. Nothing special that I can't find within 5 minutes of my home...but if you're in town and are hungry I would say this should be one of your scheduled stops....and yes the homeless are relentless outside...but...they still have it worse than you so bring them out some leftovers you weren't ever planning on really eating anyway.The dessert shop is the #1 reason I would return. I think we spent $30 on our way OUT! Selection is great.

Reviews.Author: Albert K.
Reviews.Content: Decent matzo ball soup and sandwiches.  Love the pickles.  Friendly and attentive service.  But overall overpriced.  Not a bad option if you're hungry in the wee hours of the night, but it's just a typical diner.Free parking helps, but the lot is always jam packed and you gotta wait 15-30 minutes for a spot.

Reviews.Author: Leslie D.
Reviews.Content: Best favorite love everything.  When I was in college at USC, we used to go there all the time after performing.  Then I moved to the neighborhood.  It is the best deli I have been to ever including NYC!

Reviews.Author: Allison S.
Reviews.Content: what can I say, it's canters! We drive 2+ hours to enjoy some of our favorite food! BEST bakery EVER!!!!

Reviews.Author: Lindsay C.
Reviews.Content: I like Canter's Deli! The bakery gets me every time; lots of yummy things! It's a quality Jewish deli, with tons of selection. Sometimes I come here for breakfast, but typically their pastrami sandwich for lunch & their garlic pickles are the reason I make the trip. Not too far from the LACMA or the Grove if you're sightseeing!The interior of the building is very old. I often find myself staring up at the ceiling - fall foliage with the sunlight coming through... The demeanor of the employees is often grumpy, but I like it, for some reason it to fits the place. Parking is in a lot right next to the place, which with validation is free!

Reviews.Author: Danny N.
Reviews.Content: 2 dollar beers at the bar during happy hour!

Reviews.Author: Tony F.
Reviews.Content: So I have been here a few times but its been years. Brought my wife and son for a late lunch, early dinner. Waitress was very nice. My sons bacon burger with a fried egg on top was pretty good. Fries were crispy. Wife got a Denver omelette with hash brownsit was ok. Not memorable. I started us off with potato pancakes, no flavor. Next I got a bowl of matzo ball soup with some noodles in it. I just tried this for the first time at another deli, Brents in West Lake village. Theirs was incredible. Piping hot loaded with chicken, carrots and a huge Matzo ball. Canters was luke warm broth with some noodles and and Matzo ball.... NO CHICKEN OR VEGETABLES. What a joke. My turkey on rye with russian dressing was like eating saw dust. The bread was at its past due date and the turkey was so freaking dry. The food I mentioned with a few sodas a coffee, a tea and a rootbeer float = $70.00 plus tip. We got a loaf of bread and 2 black and white cookies bringing the grand total to... $90.00I always expect to pay more when your in the city but usually the food is worth it. Gave our waitress a nice tip because other than her it was a major let down. Save your money and go to Brents in Northridge or Westlake or find another jewish deli in LA, anywhere is better that Canters.

Reviews.Author: Singha F.
Reviews.Content: The sandwiches are too expensive here.  Most of them don't even come with fries or anything for that matter.  I've been here twice, and both times I felt my eyes pop out of my head when I got the bill.  The first time, I got the pastrami reuben, which was pretty tasty.  This second time I got the turkey melt, which was dry, dry, dry.  I overheard someone order chicken soup, and they charge you extra if you want rice or noodles in your soup!!  Are you kidding me?  Like previous yelpers, I think I need to be drunk in order to enjoy this establishment more.I'll probably eat here at least one more time to break the tie because I enjoyed my sandwich the first time, not so much this second time.  For now two stars because I really feel like you don't get what you pay for.

Reviews.Author: Leah D.
Reviews.Content: I love the retro atmosphere with the cushion-y booths! I feel like a character on Seinfeld just sitting in the booth eating my pastrami sandwich. Chocolate Phosphate beverage? Nice! Do you know any other place still serving that? Seriously. Best rye bread I've ever had! I'm officially a rye bread convert. I was on a date and so what kind of a Jewish girl orders a traditional pastrami sandwich without rye bread? I usually opt for different bread with my pastrami sandwich... because I don't like dried-out rye bread with too many grains. But their rye bread tastes very fresh and soft and has just the right amount of rye grain..____Now onto the bad: Terrible matzo ball soup... the balls were pretty good, but how can you call it soup if it has no carrots, celery, chicken pieces, noodles, and some seasoned flavor? Just the matzo balls and broth? C'mon!Service was slow and inattentive... We got our soup before the drinks. Ok, that one didn't make sense. And oh. We never got our pickles until we were midway finished eating.  We had to wait in line for 10 minutes for a table. My stomach was getting mad at me. Granted, it was 7:30pm on New Year's Day. All in all though... I had a pleasant experience because I had a cool date and I love their rye bread and retro atmosphere.I'll be back... especially since it's open 24 hours. 2am meal. Awesome!

Reviews.Author: Steve J.
Reviews.Content: This place isn't getting four stars because of its food. Canter's merit comes from the following (in no particular order):1. cool, spunky servers - it sounds overrated, but when it's late at night, you'll appreciate it2. big piles of dill pickles3. the biggest menu I've ever seen - if it's past midnight and you have no dining options, just come here; they'll make you practically anything you want4. open 24 hours in a non-seedy part of town; plus for a place that never closes, the food beats out the PantryThe food ranges from mediocre to solid. I usually get the pastrami reuben. It hits the spot late at night, that spot being abdominal adipose tissue. Langer's definitely has better pastrami, but if it's after 4pm, you don't have any other choice. Canter's is always there for you.

Reviews.Author: Denise S.
Reviews.Content: My fiance and I love to come here after a fun night at The Grove.  To die for corn beef sandwiches...and true down home jewish style food!  mmmm....thank goodness they're open 24 hours because I have the feeling that one day I'll crave this when I'm preggers...lol.  Little on the pricey side, but worth it!  Try to cornbeef/pastrami combo and fries.  yummers!  Top off your night with a drink at the kibitz room bar next door.  Definitely a hipster hangout, not as rough around the edges as the pantry.

Reviews.Author: barry m.
Reviews.Content: Preface: I love(d) Canter's and ate there at the drop of a hat. Recommended to my all friends.Tale of woe:Oh Canter's, why did you go and do me like that?I suggested Cater's for the LA Metafilter meetup, and everyone agreed. I showed up, hung out, ate a reuben sandwich and had a beer.I had been extremely busy (getting ready for vacation) so the reuben at Canter's was the first and only thing I had to eat that day. The next morning I felt...not good. It started out feeling like really bad heartburn. Next thing I knew I was throwing up in the toilet. I felt better after doing this. Temporarily. I headed out on my road trip (Mammoth Mountain! Woohoo! Three days of snowboarding!). I got really worried after the second time I had to pull over and throw up on the road trip. By the time I got to Mammoth I had a full-blown fever and diarrhea, stomach cramps, and a bonus splitting headache. I was too sick to snowboard the next day, so I spent new year's day throwing up and convalescing on the couch. All the research I've done on this indicates that it's a textbook case of salmonella poisoning. This is definitely the sickest I've been in at least a decade, and I wish I could die. Given that Canter's has an A health department rating, my confidence in the health department is now in the toilet next to my trust in Canter's =[

Reviews.Author: Trung N.
Reviews.Content: There's a reason why this famous landmark has been here since the 1930s. You can't go wrong coming to this diner/deli/bakery; they have a huge menu to satisfy all kinds of appetite. Food ranges from Kosher-friendly matzo balls to heart-attack inducing Monte cristos. The restaurant has a lively atmosphere and is known to attract celebrities, politicians and the likes. It still retains much of the 1930s decor, as it appears. Even the waitresses appear to have been the original staff of that time. This 24 hour joint a great choice for hungry late-nighters in Hollywood, although I wouldn't take a date to this place if I wanted to win her heart. Keep in mind parking can be an annoying issue during dinner time.

Reviews.Author: Robert S.
Reviews.Content: Pastry Review:Their horseshoe shaped chocolate rolled pastry is possibly the best pastry I have ever tasted, flaky, crispy and filled with melted sugar/chocolate chips.  I have been enjoying this pastry for more than 25 years now and still my all time favorite.Many of the other baked goods are only fair in quality.French Fries:The fries have consistently been bland and mushy here, avoid these fries, nothing special.

Reviews.Author: Matt H.
Reviews.Content: Pastrami sandwich: piled high with lean, tasty, pastrami on very good rye bread. Good selection of spicy mustardsStuffed cabbage entree: sweet and sour. enormous portion. Hot and juicy. Potato knish: not quite like I used to get in Coney Island but awfully close and just excellent.Potato pancakes: spiced just right and fried to a crisp.Corn rye bread from the bakery: the best I've eaten in years.Cherry phosphate for me: I'm 14 again. Guiness for my wife: there are Jews in Ireland, you know. And there are Irish Americans eating pastrami sandwiches in Canter's who like Guiness with their meal.I don't think I've enjoyed a meal this much in a long time. 75% good comfort food, 25% nostalgia for my teen years.

Reviews.Author: C H.
Reviews.Content: The best pastrami, the worst ambience, the most remnant of the 60's.Really, old hollywood? They don't have to change.  I'll stay here for a slice of american pie and my favorite loveable Jew watching spot.  I love america.  Writers, producers, actors, talking and talking and talking... anoying and interesting..where else can you hear shit like this?Love you Canters.

Reviews.Author: Shonda M.
Reviews.Content: Open 24 hours.  The corned beef here  will knock you out and the homemade pickles are soooo good!Gotta warn you not to get the turkey with dressing and mashed potatoes.  Wasn't good -stick with the obvious typical deli sammys and you won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Author: Lyndsay S.
Reviews.Content: Being a jew and from New York, I'm always excited to try a new Jewish deli. I was a bit skeptical in the beginning since it's hard to beat the NY delis, and it turns out my skepticism was not unwarranted. I did not like Canter's. The pickles were so bitter I could hardly eat it, and my sandwich had so much cream cheese on it, I could not even taste the smoked salmon. To top it off, just these two things cost me over $20!Also, what kind of Jewish deli serves Penne pasta?Update: according to my friend Josh, Canter's "deserves another star because of the stained glass ceiling and it's history." There you go.

Reviews.Author: Enrique B.
Reviews.Content: Just went to Canter's this morning at about 2am, and dayumm....How is it that I have spent so much time in LA, practically my second home, and never enjoyed the late-night experience that is Canter's? I walked in with my buddy and immediately felt like I had entered a 1950s Jewish deli. The lighting over the dining area is so funky. I don't think I've ever seen such lighting before. Yes, i know, they are just colored pieces of plastic, but I was impressed.The service was spot-on, and the menu has everything I would want EXCEPT smoked sable. The prices are pretty standard for a Jewish eatery ($14/person) but it is well worth the price when you need 24/7 comfort food. I will surely be visiting Canter's again soon.

Reviews.Author: Lisa T.
Reviews.Content: I was really hungry after all the New Years Eve hoopla but was scared off by the crazy wait for a table in Ktown at BCD.  As I drove towards the Westside, I was really excited to pass by Canters and was reminded of how much I've always wanted to eat there.  Last night was my night!I ordered the brisket french dip and some cheese fries.  It was perfect!  The au jus was the best part and I made good use of it by also dipping in my cheese fries.  Yum!Can't wait to go back to try their famous Fairfax and knishes.

Reviews.Author: Bree C.
Reviews.Content: Sooo. Where to begin...after heading over to Langers and finding it was already closed (BUMMER) we went here. One of my great grandmothers old haunts. What a trip going with her and seeing it through her eyes. That being said...take a moment and look around. Go upstairs, look at the stories on the wall, appreciate the history. And appreciate it for what it simple is. A Jewish Deli. Three sandwiches ordered: Regular Pastrami, Corned Beef Pastrami and the Monte Cristo. Their deliciousness? Exactly in that order. (don't even bother with the Monte Cristo) I am now a firm believer in sauerkraut .Service was so so. When we asked a guy (not sure what he was doing besides holding the wall up) for something he informed us he didn't know, couldn't help us and we'd have to ask our server...um..ok.DON'T skip out on getting something from the bakery. DO have them warm it up. Ok. Now all THAT being said. We'll def being trying Langers the next time we're in LA.

Reviews.Author: Talley H.
Reviews.Content: Had a Pastrami Sandwich on Rye with a pickle.  Canters gets 3 stars until I return... stopped over here with 2 friends after attending a party in Hollywood, where I had a couple/many drinks.  Can't say my taste buds and judgement were at their peak.  But I promise, I will return and update this post, sober.  :)

Reviews.Author: Christine H.
Reviews.Content: Canters has a solid rueben that even come with ruffles :] When I'm feeling a little more on the "healthier" side, I'll order the pastrami with sauerkraut and I must say I LOVE the sauerkraut here because its got that real kick and its crispy.  Oh and the pickles you get to munch on while you wait, absolutely amazing. The matzo ball soup is really good and the matzo ball is basically the size of a fist and super dense... and the bagel chips make the soup all the better.For those that say this place isn't that great, I agree that it isn't better than places like Katz in NY but its pretty good for LA.

Reviews.Author: Lindsay A.
Reviews.Content: I visited Canter's about a week ago, and had the French Dip Sandwich. My friend had the Monte Cristo, and we shared a side of pickles. I had half of his sandwich, he had half of mine, and we couldn't have been happier... or more full! We tried to get past the deli and bakery, but there was no success. We both got dessert, but the story still ended happily ever after. LOL

Reviews.Author: ruby w.
