Reviews.Content: Not impressed with their bakery items although they look very promising and reminds me of NY.The black and white cookies were on the dry side and the rughlahs were not flaky.

Reviews.Author: Tania S.
Reviews.Content: I've always wanted to come to Canter's, there are always actors there and heard the pastrami was to die for.I did see an actor, and the pastrami was good.But it's a bit over priced if you ask me. I did dig the free pickles, even though I don't like pickles, I thought it was a nice touch.As for the food, well...the Matzo Ball soup was mediocre to say the least, but the pancakes were to die for. Fluffy and delicious. I really don't see myself returning to Canter's, but at least I can say I've been there.Next time I'll save on gas and money and head to Togo's for my Pastrami.

Reviews.Author: jasmine a.
Reviews.Content: First things first. Ever since my trip to the East Coast, I have become a "self-proclaimed" connoisseur of Jew food. In fact, I have considered converting just for the kosherness and the power to scream "MAZELTOV" at any given moment's notice. But I can live with screaming it silently in my head for now.Anyways. Every trip we make to LA (which has been quite often lately) we make it a point to stop at one of LA's fine Jew establishments. Today was Canter's. This was my second time here, and although its not my fav in the land of angels, it is the most convenient to where we visit. And it is also very reasonable so we don't mind coming back. Canter's is definitely an establishment. The workers are as old as the building and that's cool. Especially when they can't hear you and you enter a screaming battle just to get your order right. The thing I like best about this place are the pickles. And no I am not some attention-seeking Smurf like Snookie. They just have a damn good Kosher pickle. Not too briny. Not too salty. But there is a bit of spice and a bit of spice is always nice. The corned beef I had on this day was OK. I've had better (cough Langer's cough.) Coleslaw was more like cabbage mayo soup but whatevs. Matzo ball soup was of course a winner. This is what they're known for. Picture a huge mound of doughy goodness plopped right down in a puddle of the most perfect chicken secretions...I mean broth. Of course I ate this first and of course it filled my belly and of course I did not stop there. I mean, corned beef was staring at me in the face, taunting me, telling me to rapture is pink juicy flesh so I divulged. And I'm not sure where this is going...But they did have something on the menu that was UH MAZE ING!! Sweet potato fries. Hella (yes I'm from northern CA) non-Jew-all-the- way-but-any-attempt-to-draw-in-the-trendy-health-­freaks is sure to be a crowd pleaser. Perfectly crisp on the outside. Ooey gooey on the inside. And not salty at all. And the best part. After our gluttonous smorgasbord of all things Kosher, there were two fries still on the plate. Did I hesitate? Of course not. We don't have a spec of Jew food in my village. So I ate it. And yep. Still crispy and ooey gooey. My only qualm with Canter's is that the sandwiches are dry. The meat is good. But unless you specify or order the extras, all you get is meat and bread. It'd be nice if the thousand island and coleslaw and swiss weren't the cost equivalent of a Nike sweat-shop worker in the end. I mean, if I wanted to pay $12 for meat and bread I would have gotten a freakin' steak and loaf of bread at the grocery store and called it a day. Just sayin'. But commendable effort every time nonetheless.

Reviews.Author: Laura S.
Reviews.Content: I had a wonderful experience eating here.First of all, we had a magnificent waitress. I can tell she's been working there long since she knew exactly what to recommend. I had some of their meat sandwiches and I loved it. Unfortunately I can't eat pickles, but I know they are well known and seeing my friends loved it I must say they must be pretty good. I just wish I had a bigger stomach, or that their menu isn't a maze. So many items that I just don't understand what they are.The 2nd visit was less stellar, but wonderful regardless.The waiter spent less time with us but he didn't neglect us with our food or drinks. I noticed the bar with live music which I can't see how I missed before, definitely will be checking that out next time.I'm not too familiar with Delicatessens, so I can't really comment on the price or the taste by comparison to other Deli's. But I really did enjoy my time here and I will return here when I am in the area.

Reviews.Author: Chris M.
Reviews.Content: Pretty boring food.I got the reuben, had their pickles. The reuben was below average quality, and they didn't even cook the dressing into the sauerkraut - critical part of making a reuben. The corned beef in it was pretty flavorless. Their pickles tasted kind of off. Their fries were steak fries at least - probably the best part of the meal.It's cool they're famous and all, but for $14 for a reuben you better blow me away. Not even close.

Reviews.Author: tina t.
Reviews.Content: Love this place because it's 24 hours and definitely always an interesting place to people watch. I've seen a few celebrities here of the sports and music variety over the years. The only reason I knew about the sports celebrities is because of the people gawking and size of these guys. It's an ecletic mix of people and I like it like that.  I usually go late at night and automatically order their fruit cup which is AMAZING! It's pretty good quality of fruit and fresh. I love white peaches and when they are in season it is in the Canter's fruit cup. I also like their dinner with the cabbage rolls. Hold on, I'm hungry now......Ok, I'm back. Anyways, oh yeah, their sandwiches are great as well. The meat is piled way high and you almost get lock jaw from trying to fit it into your mouth for a bite. I act like a real lady and remove some of the meat so it's doesn't look vulgar when I eat. Matzo ball soup? Loves it, especially since they give you the bagel crisps to dip it in the soup. If I have people visiting LA, I take them here for great food and experience. It never disappoints.

Reviews.Author: Carissa E.
Reviews.Content: This place is iconic and every time I go here it just brings an "old school" type of feeling that I really do enjoy. Food is a classic jewish deli and diner food that you can't really find anywhere else. It's delicious, good, not quite good for those who are trying to be on a diet. I haven't tried the Matzo ball soup yet-----but I will next time!

Reviews.Author: Gene K.
Reviews.Content: Another LA staple! To make it even better they also have the Canter Truck. and it's open 24 hours This is another classic Jewish deli but not as good as Langer's though.The pastrami and the matzo ball is pretty good. It's priced more moderately but you are definitely getting your money's worth on the portion while enjoying every bite of it. Expect to pay around $15-$20 person with a drink which is not bad.If your feeling hungry this is another 24 hour spot you can also depend on.

Reviews.Author: Anny Y.
Reviews.Content: Man, the menu is so extensive! I had trouble choosing, so my friends and I decided to get one of each and try them all.Matzo ball soup was yummy, the onions/friends were yummy. And the service was great =)

Reviews.Author: Joyce W.
Reviews.Content: Ordered the pastrami after my friends who are LA locals recommended that for my first time at Canter's.Meat was pretty good but the bread was slightly dry. Nice variety of mustards on the table. Also had the potato pancakes which had a great taste dipped into the sour cream and apple sauce.Coleslaw was a little watery but tasted fresh.Sweet potato fries were delicious, not too greasy and went well with the ranch dressing.

Reviews.Author: Rae W.
Reviews.Content: I went here with my mom a few weeks ago, and it was delicious! Huge portions, and everything was good.We split a large order of potato pancakes (with sour cream AND applesauce) and a bagel with lox and couldn't finish it all.The front deli and bakery counters are awesome as well, where my mom got enough pastrami to feed an army and an entire cheesecake just for my fiancee. I'd love to come back and try the blintzes and matzo ball soup too!

Reviews.Author: Tony S.
Reviews.Content: NOTE:  I've visited Jewish delis my whole life (LA - where I grew up, NY - where I lived for a while, and just about everywhere I've ever traveled.)  IMHO - Katz's in New York might be one of the best, especially because they ship.  But, Canter's has always been very good and very consistent.  Heck, I've been coming here for over 40 years... for real, no exaggeration.  And, today was one of THE best visits ever!The waitress was able to order me a LEAN pastrami sandwich!  Normally, when I make this request, they roll their eyes and tell me it's too fatty a cut and the deli guys can't/won't do it and blah, blah, blah.  Well, this waitress today must have been in a good mood, or didn't know the script, or something.  Anyway, it was TOTALLY AWESOME!  A real treat.  Paper thin slices with all that great spice, but without the chunks of fat.  The best of all worlds!My Mom had the corned beef (which is usually what I order when I regularly get turned down on the lean pastrami request.)  The corned beer today was also thin sliced and terrific... juicy & flavorful but not fatty.  Other comments:- The rye bread was super fresh & tasty.- Matzo ball soup was very good and the matzo ball light & fluffy (yes, it is too much food, but you can take it home)- Pickles were done just right (not to underdone, which has happened in the past)- Seltzer was plentiful (they've sometimes been stingy and/or too busy in the past because they have to go all the way to the back to get it.)- Fruit salad was surprisingly good too.Those of you who didn't like Canter's, try ordering something else.  My recommendation:  a 1/2 sandwich of a lean corned beef & bowl of matzo ball soup.  You can't go wrong... and it's way closer than New York... and they have FREE parking!

Reviews.Author: Kat V.
Reviews.Content: Came here to pick up some late night food for me and the bf.  I'd never been here before but he has and he likes it.  I ordered him his usual Fairfax sandwich and chicken broth noodle soup.  For myself, I got the Las Vegas sandwich that comes with a side of potato salad.  2 sandwiches and a chicken noodle soup = $36... expensive as hell for a couple sandwiches! I had a taste of the chicken broth noodle soup and that was good.  But as I bit into my Las Vegas sandwich, I just got mad as hell cause I couldn't believe I had just paid $15 for this crap!  First of all, I love sandwiches and to eat a bad sandwich makes me really disappointed.  My sandwich had turkey, ham, swiss, and their  thousand island dressing.  Why do they not believe in veggies in sandwiches??  The sandwich was so incredibly bland and dry.  The turkey itself was sooooooooo dry.  I tried the potato salad and it was way too sweet for me to eat.

Reviews.Author: A.J. P.
Reviews.Content: Even at 7 am on a Sunday, Canter's delivers all the nostalgia of visiting my extended (Jewish) family in the Fairfax from a decade ago.I'll always write home about how good the pastrami and bakery are and always worth going out of your way if in the area to visit.

Reviews.Author: Eleana C.
Reviews.Content: Boyfriend loves this place because he had his old USC Tuesday night glory days here at the Kibitz Room. Apparently it used to be totally happening every night of the week, but now I sadly think that it is a think of the past.The food is decent and reminescent of Katz's Deli in NY but the service is totally not as efficient. The items are a bit overpriced for what they are (a pastrami sandwich!) but if the quality is good, I'm not going to complain. It is a bit hard to cough up $10+ for a sandwich and not have it come with any fies or other accompaniments, though. Try it if you're in the area, or if Animal next door won't take you as a walk-in!

Reviews.Author: Bob G.
Reviews.Content: Best Jewish delicatessen in Los Angeles, by far. Great ambiance, great if you are in groups. Good service. 1930/70 decor. Two eating areas: Left, small groups, right, large parties.Food: Hot corned beef with cabbage and potato, hmmm =). Cream cheese and lox, pricey but excellent. Great late entrees, pass on the all day breakfast. Egg sandwich, all sandwiches are served with whole pickle. In sum, great food, no misses so far.Drinks (non-alcoholic): Cherry phosphate, Egg cream, New York cherry soda, Hot cocoa =DDesert: Anything.Misc: pastries on any kind at entrance left, take out or make your own meal to go, right. Great for late/very late dinning. Caveat!: The large section dining area is glued to a bar not part of Canter's. Music band nights some days, so forget your hearing and conversation =( Some items (Bagel and Lox) pricey (loots of Lox and condiments on it, but still pricey).

Reviews.Author: Jessie F.
Reviews.Content: I've been coming to Cantor's for many years. The sandwiches here are awesome! I've tried many dishes here: the turkey ruben, the Cantor's pastrami on rye, the triple deli meats (roast beef, pastrami & tongue), and so on. All are delicious. This is not a place to be health conscious, this is a place to indulge yourself with all kinds of wonderful deli meats, lox, and desserts. The thanksgiving plate is also very nice. I always bring home some hamantash after eating there. All the desserts are nice.  However, it's cheaper to buy the desserts at the bakery separately than order them after dinner.The restaurant has been around since 1931. It's retained it's old world charm. The parking can be a little tough on weekends. But if you go on off peak hours, there is no problem finding parking. They open 24/7.

Reviews.Author: Rachel W.
Reviews.Content: Typical Jewish deli/diner, a little pricey for a diner but good.  Good place for breakfast or lunch or late night snack.  The Monte Cristo sandwich is amazing!!Service is decent but slow.This is an old LA restaurant with a lot of history.  Anthony Kiedis used to go here a lot when he went to fairfax high and in his younger days.

Reviews.Author: Eileen K.
Reviews.Content: Free parking for 1.5 hours in a lot around the corner. Great service by our waiter, Salvador!Loved:matzo ball souplatkes (potato pancakes served with sour cream and applesauce)the brooklyn sandwich (w/pastrami)i also ordered a few items from the bakery. sadly, neither the rugelachs nor the black & white cookie blew me away. on top of all this, the restaurant is definitely overpriced for what it is. i will come back for the other items on the regular menu that i mentioned above.

Reviews.Author: Suzanna L.
Reviews.Content: Second to Langer's, but first to everything else. If I was blind to Langer's, I would say that this is the best pastrami around. It's moist and somewhat thickly cut. And it does beat Langer's in regards to hours: it's open 24 hours. There's also some great people watching to be had... we saw a pseudo Martin Short wannabe, which was neat.

Reviews.Author: Robert R.
Reviews.Content: Feels like home. The cold beet borscht with sour cream is fabulous. All the soups are great.  Don't eat the Eggs Benedict. Seriously flawed. The half sandwich with soup is plenty to eat.

Reviews.Author: Alan G.
Reviews.Content: If you love pastrami this is a must!!!! Absolutely amazing. It's ugly and old and the menu is huge but the food is really special. Unlike anything I've tasted anywhere and pastrami has been one of my all time favorite food. The fries are Del Taco style but the meat in that pastrami is heavenly. Melts in your mouth and honestly a huge sandwich.Do yourself a favor and go check it out...It's worth every penny and all the hype!

Reviews.Author: Taylor G.
Reviews.Content: This is a try staple in Los Angeles history. The architecture an layout is classic and the staff is very welcoming. I always get the corned beef hash and eggs. A true delicatessen and bakery, they have a big spread of all things breakfast related.

Reviews.Author: Ginger T.
Reviews.Content: I like Canter's for breakfast only.  I don't consider Canter's the best deli in town.  It's just  a landmark eatery that's been around for over 50 years.  I think their prices are too high and the lunch and dinner is just okay, and nothing to write home about.  A coffee shop can compete with Canter's just fine.  On a positive note, the eatery has an ample amount of seating, and parking is validated.  If you visit Canter's on the weekend, get there before noon or you'll be waiting in a very long line.

Reviews.Author: Eric N.
Reviews.Content: I think this deli is overrated, don't get me wrong, the food is pretty damn good, service is normal. Very Hollywood... Open late, I feel it's a bit over priced

Reviews.Author: Craig R.
Reviews.Content: Canter's never fails after having a bunch of cocktails and you're now in hungry mode and crave a decent meal at 3am then this is the place to be. Been here three times and all 3 were definitely memorable.  Easy available parking for customers. Once inside of the Deli always quick seating. Servers are always on the beat ready to take your orders. This time around I decided to give their burgers a try. I had a pastrami burger with a side of fries and a cheese cake. The burger was a decent sized burger, flavorful and packed with meat. The French fries were golden and lightly salted to perfection (don't expect a mountain of fries on your plate though); I've had better french fries but it's okay for what it is.The cheese cake is also a hit with me. One thing about Canter's they got allot of pastry goodies and baked goodies that you can have for desert!!I'll definitely be returning anytime I'm out for drinks in the area and need a late night hunger quick fix.

Reviews.Author: Janey S.
Reviews.Content: Ok, loved it , first time there and now we are fans ! I ordered the reuben, he ordered the Eddie special or something like that.We even had leftovers for the next day.We spent about $35 for two, and i beleive that was including tip. Kind of out of the way but worth making a trek back. May i add, do not sit near the Kibbitz room if you don't like loud crazy music.Ask to sit in the dining area, nice and quiet.oh and don't forget, they have a counter with sweet and pastries and all kinds of sweetness.  yumz !

Reviews.Author: Ann Marie M.
Reviews.Content: There are two kinds of people in Los Angeles:  People who love Canter's and everyone else, who in my book, don't count.Canter's is one of the best Jewish delis in LA, located in the heart of the Fairfax, one of LA's oldest and famous Jewish neighborhoods.My standing order:Before 5, I get the salami and eggs with a side of cheese blintzes, a side of potato pancakes, a bagel, and plenty of coffee. After 5, a martini and a reuben.

Reviews.Author: JoAnne M.
Reviews.Content: We were lucky enough to not have one of those "New York attitude" waitresses I have heard about that are short and rude with their service.I had a pastrami sandwich... HUGE portion of meat and tasty too, probably one of the best I have had, outside of Carnigie deli in NYC.The potato latkes were very tasty and nice size portion also.We sat in the huge side dining room and were not rushed at all thru our lunch.My friend had the Matzo ball soup, the ball was huge, I am not a fan of this soup, but he said it was very good.This place is just fun to go to because it is a landmark and legend in LA.The bakery was hard to pass on the way out without getting some of their yummy looking cookies on the way out.

Reviews.Author: Kimberly K.
Reviews.Content: This place makes my whole digestive system happy.  I think the last 2 times I walked in, I felt my mouth start watering for pickeled herring.Yup, just writing it now (pickeled herring) is making my mouth water. Man, when you walk into this down home place you are hit by 2 beautiful sights: on the left - pastries and carbohydrates galore!!! and to the right - freshly made pickeled herring, stuffed cabbage YUMness.Whew. moment of silence.YEAH!!  My boyfriend Art & I attempted to make some hardcore sauerkraut at home for the first time. He searched Los Angeles far and wide for KRAUT from the BARREL. This was very important to him. No jarred stuff will do for a really tasty, good quality home batch of KRAUT.  Canter's delivered! (Not literally, we went to pick it up :)The big guy behind the counter tested Art out with some Polish, Rozumiesz? AWESOME! He probably wondered, "Who is this kid who is demanding KRAUT from the barrel??" We went for dinner once and HOLY FOOD!  We both got a combo meal that includes appetizer and dessert. WE COULD'VE FED A SMALL COUNTRY!  Thank God for American sized portions. Pierogis, stuffed cabbage, pickeled herring, cabbage soup, mashed potatoes, potato pancakes, and stuffed kishka. They even put our ice cream in a doggie bag!Good plentiful times.Golobkis as big as your head.What more can be said.

Reviews.Author: R J.
Reviews.Content: Hi, Canter's! You're not very good, are you?The most this place has going for itself is that it's open 24 hours. Apparently that means that they never have off hours to clean up the place or cook good food. Maybe close the place for an hour or two, Canter's?Yes, in some ways, it is an LA institution. You can read all sorts of accounts of famous musicians running over here after a gig during the 60's folk rock or the 80's hair metal days. Kudos to them for not going out of business. And yes, they have cantankerous old women slinging coffee who have been there for 30 years. But guess what? That's not an oddity in most parts of the country. If you want crabby waitresses who have hated their lives to serve you bland bagels and pickles on greasy plates, I can take you to any truck stop town in the midwest. But why come here and fork over a boatload of money for it? So you can feel as if you're a part of history? At 3 am, I'd rather deal with the hipsters at Fred 93.46 or Swingers to get some good food.

Reviews.Author: Sarah F.
Reviews.Content: To those who gave fewer than five stars...you clearly have never had a black and white malt at this place.  That being said, I also love this place for being one of the few that will make me a rare burger, and you can't beat a rare burger and a delicious, godly shake at 4 in the morning when you're drunk.  Also, some other highlights:-middle-aged rockers with grey ponytails in the kibbitz room-getting invited to parties by sketchy people-getting to see my future husband (that waiter with the elvis hair)-everything

Reviews.Author: Brian S.
Reviews.Content: No amount of complaining is going to have any effect on Canter's, especially when this is the 414th review.But still, I had to warn people -- do not get the eggs benedict.  The hollandaise has a very thick, sort of gravy-like consistency and is weridly bland.  Very unappetising.Canter's is good for sitting around for long periods of time, but next time I'm going to try the pastrami/egg scramble that my breakfast-mate got.

Reviews.Author: Larry M.
Reviews.Content: We've eaten here probably a dozen times now, and while this place is an LA icon, it's just ok food.  The Matzo soup is about the best I've had in a restaurant, but everything else we've tried, while not bad, was also not spectacular.  The knishes were meh...  For good knishes try Izzy's, or just go to New York.As others have said, this is a great place to hang out for a long time.  Coffee is typical american coffee house stuff.The bakery up front is really good.We'll probably be back, if it's 3am and we're hungry... :)

Reviews.Author: Kevin W.
Reviews.Content: Every time I come home late at night, my grumpy-ass dog looks up at me with his smushed face as if to say, do you mind?  Sleeping furball over here.  It's clearly a huge burden on him, and I feel bad about it, but it's not going to stop me from making a late night a bit later with a trip to Canter's.  Sorry, furball.I love Canter's.  It's old school, serves up huge portions of good food.  My standby is a roast turkey with cole slaw and russian dressing on rye, a black and white milkshake, and enough pickles to choke a goat.  Also lovely are the pastrami and corned beef offerings, and the Thanksgiving dinner.  Matzo ball soup is nice, but I need that with noodles and chicken.  I'm a big boy.  Give me some meat.Only thing to skip would be the pasta.  Not their strength.  On my way out I load up on cookies: the rainbow and chocolate fudge cookies are especially good.

Reviews.Author: Jon R.
Reviews.Content: There aren't a ton of authentic Delis in Southern California and Canter's is up there with the best. Open 24 hours, and open every day. Amazing history, great food. I end up here every Christmas. Good pastrami, good Matzah ball soup.

Reviews.Author: Kenny P.
Reviews.Content: Best hand sliced smoked salmon in the west. Great pickles too. Love the bakery items, especially the chocolate race track cake. When eating in, their lunch and dinner specials are worth the money. Usually for around $15-20, you get an entree plus app (soup, salad, etc), beverage, and dessert (jello, pudding, ice cream).Open 24/7, the people watching is best after midnight.

Reviews.Author: Makoto N.
Reviews.Content: This place is as good as it gets when it comes to a Jewish Deli.  The food is the best!  I just got the Fresser's sandwich (Corned Beef and Pastrami) on Rye with Potato salad and Coleslaw.  It was heaven on a bun.  The meats are juicy and the rye is firm so it doesn't get mushy when you pick it up for  your first bite all the way to your last one!  The potato salad was a bit too sweet for me but had a really creamy taste to it.  The garlic pickles are firm and garlic-y.  Also had the Matzoball soup with noodles.  The matzoballs are the size of softballs and the soup was very tasty without being too salty.  Came with a few bagel chips that great with the soup.The place is open all night and has the best bakery too.  I got a few butter cookies with sprinkles and some small apricot pastries that were to die for.  I live in Yorba Linda and I drive to Canter's regularly to get the baked goods!

Reviews.Author: Tory A.
Reviews.Content: So much to say about this place. Having been open for a long time, Canter's has a very quirky atmosphere, from the servers (some of whom are sweet Jewish mothers, others are young wannabe actors who are not bad to look at) to the autumnal paneled ceilings which apparently used to attract acid-dropping rock stars in the 60's. This is a great place to get your Ashkenazi grubbing on, with excellent sandwiches (the pastrami is supposedly the best in LA according to a variety of sources) and signatures Jewish staples like latkes and gefilte fish. The potato salad is one of my favorite things to have here too, alongside the tuna salad sandwich or some kishkes. Canter's is a good place to get real Jewish food and do some people watching. I highly recommend.

Reviews.Author: Jim Y.
Reviews.Content: I don't suppose that I can write anything new about Canter's that hasn't already been written, but I'm going to give it a shot.In my humble opinion the very best time to go to Canter's is between 9 p.m. and 2 a.m. mostly on any Thursday through the weekend.  That is when I go and while I go for many reasons the very best is people watching and to listen to the very worst bands in Los Angeles at the Kibitz Room.  Now most people may not find this near as fasinating as I do but people watching is great at this location for sure.The other thing that I like about Canter's is the wait staff.  Now I don't see them as much these days, but the older ladies that were the wait staff there are great.  There is something about the "rude" and loud way that they operate.  It is refreshing to me.Now for the food and prices...out of the thousands of things on the menu to choose from, all that I have tried are great and the prices are very reasonable.  Do yourself a favor and go there often as you can; it is a great experience.

Reviews.Author: Melinda L.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is a vintage delicatessen in the heart of Los Angeles. A friendly serving staff with a classic sandwich/diner menu that will almost overwhelm you once it is opened. The good thing is that everything on the menu will bring your tummy to full hunger, even if you had eaten a big meal not too long before settling at Canter's. Glancing the menu from left to right, you'll see dishes such as Corned Beef and Cabbage, Monte Cristo, a variety of sandwiches, meatloaf, soups, etc. The never ending menu makes you go, "Whoa, is there any other menu I've seen that's this insane (in a good way, of course)!?" I decided to try their pastrami/corned beef sandwich on rye bread and coleslaw. Delicious! I also got to try their meatloaf with mashed potatoes and boiled string beans. Very rich and creamy. It almost tasted like the food was carefully cooked in their kitchen with extra love and care; very yummy in the tummy! I give Canter's 5 stars for tastiness and 5 stars for good service. I would definitely visit again!

Reviews.Author: Michael N.
Reviews.Content: Canters Deli is a place like so many in L.A, you can't really complain as it is what it is, but for what you pay you'd expect more. I lived in Florida for 11 years, and spent a great deal of time in Jewish enclaves on the east and west coast. I've dated Jewish girls, heck I even took a Jewish girl to prom. :)I feel like certain places think because they heap mounds of meat on a sandwich, that makes it a sandwich. What came to my table wasn't bad, it just wasn't worth 12 dollars. I would have loved to order some potato pancakes, but not for 9.95. I would of loved my matzo ball soup (5.50 for a cup?) if it it wasn't a gigantic matzo ball sitting in a bland broth devoid of any herbs, with a good deal of broth under the bowl on the plate. Considering how many times I pray to the garlic god, I was amazed that I felt the pickles where over garlicky and under par.  What's with the cash register and the "credit card line?" They ask you what you would like to tip at the register, it felt very unprofessional. Very poor direction and lack of signs. The service staff was mildly attentive but seemed to be much more focused on when they were leaving which they loudly announced. The menu looks like it hasn't been redesigned since 1950, so many items with lack of adequate description. They are 24 hours in an area where nothing is, but if I paid 1/2 of what I did this would be a 4 star rating and I would be a repeat customer.

Reviews.Author: Jennifer H.
Reviews.Content: Great place to go after a night out in Hollywood.  Usually friendly staff and good food.  A tad overpriced, but it's Canters!  It's a landmark... well if not, it should be!  Love the veggie sandwich and the Eggs Florentine.  Oh and must order pickles before hand if you like pickles.  With one of the biggest menus I have ever seen (except maybe Barneys Beanery) there has got to be something you will like.Afterwards head over to the backery and grab some cookies to go.  They are insane and cheap.  Just pissed off I left them at someones house last time!

Reviews.Author: Joey L.
Reviews.Content: How can you go wrong. They stay open all night. Their menu is like reading a novel on deli food. The prices are easy on your wallet too (in case you just broke the bank out drinking). Had a patty melt and was very pleased. For some reason I love patty melts at delis.Staff is kind and fast and it's been there forever (you can sort of tell) but worth it!

Reviews.Author: Unknown
Reviews.Content: Canter's Deli is so much a part of Los Angeles, it puts Pink's Hot Dogs and Rodeo Drive to shame. Canters is to L.A. restaurants what Magnolia and Collateral are to L.A. films. It is the ultimate old-style Jewish deli, with absolutely perfect cuts of kosher meat, and all the mediterranean trimmings one could want. They've been owned and operated by the Canters family for nearly 80 years. Their baked goods are divine, with eggy bread that makes the heart melt and feel as one with humanity. Their soft rolls and perfect baked-then-boiled bagels will increase your joie de vivre and make you want to do a good deed for the day. As an L.A. resident for the better part of my 28 years, I "get" Canters, having grown up with Jewish delis such as Katz's Deli in Manhattan, and I absolutely love my 100% beef hot dogs and knishes. I think people outside of L.A., particularly non-Americans, are always a bit baffled by Canters. When customers first walk in, they are greeted with the gorgeous view of old-fashioned deli and bakery counters filled with beautiful plump meats and baked treats -- Canters displays put The Nutcracker sets to shame. But after that, you enter the restaurant, and this is where it gets sort of strange. The decor is...weird. Imagine an old, beat up coffee shop in NY in the 70s -- think yellowing lino floors, dark pressed wood benches with vinyl tables, and wood paneled walls, and you've got a vision of Canters. The weirdest feature is the ceiling, which is composed of a panorama picture of a blue sky dappled with autumn leaves, through which the lights shine. It's not pretty. It's gaudy. But that's Canters. The food is on the expensive end, with Lox and Bagels starting at $7.50, and full entrees heading up to $12.50. But as the place that Sly Stallone heads after a heavy night out, it's ok for Canters to up the ante on prices. The best thing you could have at Canters is the Matzo Ball Soup, which is a nice combo of unleavened Matzo (cracker) all rolled into gorgeous balls that are slow-cooked in chicken broth. Lovely drunk food, and perfect for if you're under the weather. And they're open all night, so you can enjoy the treats at 4am, post Sunset-strip. The biggest debate in L.A. is not whether Arnie is doing a good job, but whether Canters or Jerry's Deli are the best. For anyone wondering -- it's Canters.

Reviews.Author: Jonathan C.
Reviews.Content: Good: Good food. What can I say? All around hours. Even better!Bad: Parking is usually an issue here, especially during peak meal hours. Final: This place definitely gets four stars for being open 24/7.

Reviews.Author: Mimi T.
Reviews.Content: It was close to 10PM and my friends and I were driving around for a place to eat. We were approaching Canter's and decided to come in because it was open 24hrs and it has been on my list of places to eat for awhile. It was my first time here and the menu was a bit overwhelming. so much to choose from!! The waiter had to keep coming back because we couldn't decide what to order, but he was pretty cool about it. We got a plate of free pickles and they were pretty yummy! I ordered the egg scramble with pastrami, sour dough toast, and hashbrowns. The eggs tasted very fresh. I love potatoes, but the hashbrowns just weren't my style of liking.Overall, the food was alright. Not sure if I would come back again. Some things on the menu seemed a bit pricey for me.

Reviews.Author: smriti k.
Reviews.Content: What happens when you watch a movie like Iron man?Simple! you would want to junk it up and try becoming one,and so did we! We came here after a late night show.   This place is pretty spacious and is a perfect diner,with caramel color booth seating and it was pretty crowded.We all sat in a huge semi circle,and got some coffee and 2 mini cupcakes ;which was extremely dry and not very smooth. This place is known for it's pastrami and so we got one order of that,and a cheese omelet and some fries. I took the safe side and just had the coffee.   My friends were pretty much satisfied with their food,and we had an amazingly funny+sweet old lady serving us,who i bet is a silent gangsta *winks*    We had a good time talking,and just chilling out and like my friend said "With a menu like an Encyclopedia,how do you expect the food to be good? " And yes, it wasn't amazing i guess,but if you want to eat a meal by 3am,then i guess this isn't that bad?   This could be the secret eat out place for Iron man!!*Drools*-Smriti

Reviews.Author: Joy B.
Reviews.Content: Meh on food quality & not good vegetarian options, but this is a classic kosher deli, what did you expect?BUT this is rock history, baby. You kinda gotta hit up these institutions. You can feel the power! RAYMOND PETTIBON was walking out when I walked in! NO LIE! I've also heard a million other stories about rock god sightings here.Great for late night!

Reviews.Author: Rodene R.
Reviews.Content: If you miss NY, then order a black n' white cookie and a slice of their strawberry cheesecake, sooo good. They usually have a plate of samples, don't pass it up.As for dining food, order the following:Matzo Ball SoupPlate of Picklesand the Monte CristoThe Matzo Ball soup isn't too flavorful, but its so classic, you can't not order it there. Plate of pickles aren't crispy, but again, classic. And when I used to eat meat, I remember the Monte Cristo being a mouthful of flavors. Crispy deep fried bread with layers of deli meat! You'll have some to either share or to take home.

Reviews.Author: Penny O.
Reviews.Content: Food here is bad and priceyIts a deli? The sanwiches i ate here were dry, tasteless and bad, i can prepare myself the same sandwich 10 times better for half the price! Their menu is huge, some italian and mexican dishes, soups, etc. Service is ok, restaurant is most of the times crowded and noisy.You can see all pastries when you walk by, but dont be fool... that they look good doesnt mean they taste good!, i have tried their chessecake and chocolate cake, both were a disappointment.I would never pick this place to eat.

Reviews.Author: H O.
Reviews.Content: +:  Pastrami, drooooooooool!-:  Cole slaw wasn't so hot.!:  Popped my matzo ball soup cherry and I'm in love!?:  Open 24 hours since 1931? Nothing but respect.

Reviews.Author: Adam F.
Reviews.Content: Here's the deal: Regretably, the only times I've actually been to Canters was between the hours of 1 and 4 in the morning after a night of fun.  Therefore, I'm here to mention one thing in particular.In LA, if your looking for something to munch between the hours of 1 and 4 in the morning after a night of fun, Canters on Fairfax is your place.Breakfast food, burgers, soup, whatever strange cravings a possibly stranger nights calls for, it's there and it's good.  It's not all that cheap, but in the type of mindset you're problably in that time a night, you won't care.

Reviews.Author: Kate R.
Reviews.Content: I like Canter's - my favorite thing to eat there is the matzo ball soup - one would think, though, that a Jewish diner as old as this would have their own special recipe for MBsoup by now... not so. It comes straight out of the Manischewitz mix. Tastes EXACTLY as it does when I make it at home. Now, it's always delicious, but srsly c'mon it's about time they added their own spin on it.Or maybe not...

Reviews.Author: Meg S.
Reviews.Content: The sandwiches are the size of my head.  The egg creams are perfect.  What more could a girl ask for? Parking can be tricky, but I've always managed to park within a few minutes.  Canter's is an experience.  It's totally old school and fantastical.  I've managed to turn many of my friends into converts.  Super delicious, but be sure you're prepared to take home leftovers - or bring friends to share.  The portions are ginormous!

Reviews.Author: Jamie Q.
Reviews.Content: I've wanted to go to Canter's for a while now. Not for the food per se but more because it is an LA institution. Sort of the same feeling I had about going to Pink's Hot Dogs.It took me 3 years to finally get here and what did I think? Meh.I got the Canter's Fairfax which is corned beef and pastrami on rye. I love both meats so I was glad there was a sandwich that had both. The bread was soft and the meat tender but overall I would still go with the same thing at either Langer's or Brent's. It came with a side of coleslaw which was surprisingly quite good. The cabbage was crisp and the dressing not too heavy. And how can you possibly complain about a side of pickles?The service was great though. I was greeted and seated immediately and my server checked on me at several points of my meal to make sure everything was going OK.Overall, in a city with a dearth of late night establishments, I would go to Canter's again if need be. I just wouldn't go out of my way.

Reviews.Author: Chandler M.
Reviews.Content: I came here for a basic Pastrami on Rye, and ended up getting the Brooklyn special (Pastrami and swiss on rye). Parking was easy enough, and I was welcomed and seated withing 20 seconds. The servers are amazingly fast at what they do, and When my seat with a view of the carving table was opened, I saw that the sandwich people were old hat at this as well. All I saw were sandwiched being served up lightning fast. The bread of my sandwich was very flavorful rye, at some points overwhelming the meat. the crust was crunchy and very tasty. The Pastrami meat itself I could tell would have been very good if it were warmer. Unlike Langer's, this pastrami is true New York deli style, served piled high up with tiny slices of meat. It makes me long for a trip to Junior's in Brooklyn. I was overall impressed with the whole resturant and the food, but the only ding was that my sandwich felt not as warm and juicy as I think it was capable of. I'll definitely be returning though!

Reviews.Author: Molly R.
Reviews.Content: More like a 2.5 than a 3.  The food is only so-so and waaayy over-priced for what it is.  Our bill was $33 for two sodas, a (flavorless) avocado melt, scrambled eggs w/ lox, and some French fries.  The most noticeable flavor in my avocado melt was the taste of alfalfa sprouts, and the bottom bread slice was completely soggy.  If only they had bothered to use a flavorful sauce and/or some high quality cheese, the sandwich probably could have been saved.  At least the fries were tasty.2 stars for food quality1 additional star for old-school diner charm and ambiance

Reviews.Author: Bryan T.
Reviews.Content: I coordinated a small group event last week.  Although Canters has been around for 1,000 years, none of us have been there before.Parking was easy as there is a lot just south of them that validates.  Our server was extremely knowledgeable, friendly and helpful.We enjoyed a plethora of great tasty items.  Corned beef and pastrami sandwiches.  Their meat is so lean and flavorful.Chopped liver was plentiful and very goodlGefiltefish  was a good appetizer for us.  The carrots had nice color.We left with quite a few desserts.  We must say that we really enjoyed their rye bread and we purchased two loaves to go.  A wonderful experience for us!

Reviews.Author: Wes P.
Reviews.Content: First time I came here I was pretty sloshed and we ended up playing flip cup with the little coffee creamer cups. Obnoxious yes, thank you canters for putting up with us. The food was okay-good, nothing to complain about or rave about, but for those prices I almost rather go eat at Denny's. Their flagship hot corned beef has a really nice texture. Holds together but is tender and flakes apart when you bite into it. However, it's lacking in flavor. Not salty enough, no other notes. The rye bread is good, it's dense but spongy & doughy. Not to die for. And for some reason the hot corned beef and rye bread didn't go together harmoniously for me.But this past week they gave 80cent hot corned beef sandwiches, can't complain about that!

Reviews.Author: Steve P.
Reviews.Content: In the world of LA Deli's Canter's is King. From the infamous Yenta's masquerading as waitresses to the iconic Matzo Ball Soup and Bakery counter, Canter's is a must for locals and visitors alike. Eating at Canter's is a rite of passage. My parents took me for the first time circa 1964, and I was hooked! Canters is not my absolute favorite Deli in the LA basin, but that doesn't mean it is not a "10," or at least an 8.5. This place is historic, as is most of the Fairfax district. The people watching here, especially late in the evening, is off the charts. And yes, if you think you see Slash or any of the Chili Peppers there, it's most likely them, in the flesh! And for you Vegas-ites, good news! Canter's is in the TI, right in front of the Sports Book and Keno Room.

Reviews.Author: Alexander Aaron P.
Reviews.Content: I went in one morning to apply for a job and grab a quick bite to eat. (This review is based on my savory and sweet breakfast.)Walk in and on the left, there is a huge case of pastries, assorted cookies, and amazingly delicious sweets. Behind that, you have a wall of what seems like hundreds of fresh baked bread. Turn to your right, and they have an equally huge case of deli meats and cheeses. Didn't venture that way, but walked by.I sat down and saw they had a lot of options with lox. I'm not one for lox with my eggs, so I ordered my usual: Two over-easy eggs, side of sourdough toast, bacon, and potatoes. (Basic breakfast but I will venture out next time I'm here.)This place is NOTHING like the chain breakfasts you'll eat. The eggs had that almost crispy oily texture around the whites but had a perfectly cooked yolk. The bacon! OMG THE BACON! Thick, delicious! I would have ordered a whole plate of that shit. I've never had bacon this thick other than at home and on a gourmet burger. The potatoes were scalloped and were crispy like hash browns. Everything here was so delicious, I left craving more and excited to go back.I paid, exited, and proceeded turned around. With my breakfast still making me a little wet down there, I wasn't going to leave without trying their baked goods. I walk back in, order a loaf of sourdough, a bearclaw the size of my face, and a slice of what was identical to a rich, creamy, chocolate/chocolate chip, melt in your mouth dense chocolate cheese cake with cake swirled throughout. SIMPLY DECADENT.The sourdough was amazing when I finally got home. And the bear claw had my tongue doing flips all morning. I had no idea this place was 24 hrs AND they have validated parking lot right next door. So there's no reason to park on the street.You only know I'll be back to Canters... as soon as I find that job I was looking for.

Reviews.Author: Steve C.
Reviews.Content: I judge any deli, much less an outwardly Jewish one, by their Reuben sandwich. Canter's was very disappointing. The bread tasted and felt like it had been recycled from another sandwich, overly buttered and better used with jam. After that, it really didn't matter what the rest of it tasted like. And when you charge $12 for it, it better be right every time. I've been coming in since arriving in LA and used to grab a late night bite after bartending, so I loved the waitresses and the vibe. Plus you would always spot a celebrity or two (Harry Dean Stanton was at the counter getting a take-out order my very first visit). But I think it's yet another place that nostalgia drives many a good review. I'll probably get a bite there again some day, but as a aficionado of the greatest sandwich every invented, I can tell other Reuben fans seek elsewhere, like on PIco. Or Jerry's, which might be a chain but knows their Reubens.

Reviews.Author: shaya m.
Reviews.Content: I won't eat pastrami anywhere else. Pastrami is the only thing I'll eat at Canter's.  The best, hands down!

Reviews.Author: Erika G.
Reviews.Content: Full bar! Everything's better with a little jack in ya.. ;)We sat down to lunch and were greeted promptly. He ordered the roast beef and it didn't come with anything BUT the sandwich which was pretty disappointing. He ordered the slaw for a dollar and he was happy. I got the hot sandwich, I think it was the roast beef dip, and it was huge. Came with fries. Delicious. I also got wine (tiniest glass ever, save your money) and he got a coors light. And we paid TEN BUCKS for those two drinks. Ridiculous! Food - 4 starsService - 3 starsPrice - 1 starMight be back, but only for the bakery.

Reviews.Author: Brian B.
Reviews.Content: Great. Old school. Jewish Deli. I came here for lunch and got a Pastrami sandwich to go, so I can't attest to the sit-down experience. Up front they have a deli counter and pastry counter for people getting food to go. Then in the back they have a big dining room with an old school counter. The Pastrami sandwich was very good. Soft, flavorful rye bread and thinly sliced meat (much thinner than Langer's). The mustard was good and the sandwich was pretty stacked. This sandwich is a little bit small overall (diameter-wise) compared to some others. This isn't my favorite in town, but I'd take it as a solid lunch option.When I was waiting for my sandwich, I was captivated by the pastry counter. In a moment of incredible sugar-induced weakness, I ended up buying an enormous apple turnover and a Black and White cookie.The turnover was ABSOLUTELY incredible. Possibly the best turnover I've ever had. Apples were tender, crust was flaky. Sweet but not too sweet. And there was possibly an entire pound of butter in my turnover alone. Thumbs way up. However, as a connoisseur of fine NY-style Black and White cookies, I can tell you: this one sucked, haha. It was really dry on the inside. Hardly the scrumptious yellow cake cookie that you expect. The frosting was okay, but without a solid cookie base, what do you have?

Reviews.Author: sara a.
Reviews.Content: Classic!I loved Canters. So yummy!!!Fast service, awesome employees.Matzo Ball SoupSandwichesMacaroonsWish I lived closer!

Reviews.Author: Kristin S.
Reviews.Content: Went to canter's because hubby said he'd loved it last time he was in L.A. & I had to experience it. We went on a Wednesday night, I think, earlyish. Maybe 6 pm? Parking in the lot was no problem.As some people have said, the decor's a bit...outdated. That said, I didn't exactly expect a Jewish deli to be on-trend. I expected it to be tasty, & it pretty much delivered.I started with a bowl of matzoh ball soup - they don't do cups because the matzoh balls are the size of baseballs. Huge matzoh ball, average flavor. Nothing special about the soup.Next came the main course - hubby had a burger/fries while I had a French dip/fries. Hub's a burger expert - he's eaten many burgers at many places. This one was excellent, in his measured opinion. And the fries! I can comment on those - my comment is "Awesome!". Steak fries, the perfect meshing of crispy/creamy. Delicious. The French dip was high quality, freshly sliced roast beef - no thinly-sliced cold cuts. Maybe a smidge dry, but the au jus took care of that with gusto. Heated up well the next day.At the bakery, we snagged a black & white as well as a chocolate chip cookie. The black & white had a great flavor, with a bit of citrus to bring out the icing. The chocolate chip cookie had something like nuttiness on the back end, which was interesting as well as delicious.I'd go back to try more items, for sure.

Reviews.Author: Doron L.
Reviews.Content: I am a fan of Canters and have been coming here ever since I was a kid.  There is a lot of variety of food here.  Everything from corned beef  to pancakes.  I usually order a corned beef sandwich with cole slaw on the side.  You Can choose  the type of bread for your sandwich so if you are bored with rye try it on an onion roll.  The service here is fine with a friendly fast efficient staff who will put a smile on your face.There is also a deli counter here where  you can take home some really delicious desserts.  My favorite is the chocolate race track cake that is gooey with melted chocolate. Parking here is also easy, there is a lot next door that requires validation.Canters is open 24 hours non-stop!

Reviews.Author: Josephine C.
Reviews.Content: I am so glad we still have this nice cultural icon.  I enjoyed their tasty roast beef sandwich.  The bread is very soft and the beef was juicy.  Also their potato salad is very tasty. The waitress is very attentive in refills.   It wasn't busy before 12noon so I was able to sit anywhere.

Reviews.Author: Katie G.
Reviews.Content: This is one of my favorite brunch spots in Los Angeles. I love the pickles, and I have never had anything that I did not enjoy here. I usually stick to the breakfast dishes. They have great bagels, and I always stop at the bakery on my way out to get a few treats for the week. Great place to come if you have family visiting. Rarely a wait, and plenty of booths!

Reviews.Author: Gretchen N.
Reviews.Content: Great place for deli food that is authentic. Great hot pastrami sandwich, good matzo ball soup.  The bakery is GREAT!  Only reason it's not a 5 star review is the pricing. Wish it were a little more reasonable.

Reviews.Author: Gary H.
Reviews.Content: The absolute best Pastrami Rueben I have ever eaten!!! Can't wait for my next trip back to have another! I also had the matzo ball soup which was also delicious! Kuddos Canter's!

Reviews.Author: Arman A.
Reviews.Content: I went in here on a Saturday night for some coffee and dessert, well I first bought over $30 dollars...then I went to the host to get seated she told me I can't take the pastry in because I have to order it from the waiter...I told her that I just purchased it from the bakery, why can't I just get seated and have the dessert with my coffee and she said sorry you have to order it from the table instead of the bakery there. That doesn't make sense at all, I can't believe a place like this so famous can have such rules...that's some bull.

Reviews.Author: Ken M.
Reviews.Content: Pastrami Ruben is great. I used my groupon then got a slice of Peacan coffee bread awesome!

Reviews.Author: Rachel R.
Reviews.Content: Service is always excellent! Pastrami is tasty beyond words, and I have never had better pickles. This past visit, we picked up a loaf of eye and a Danish on our way out. I can't wait to enjoy a piece of Canters at home!

Reviews.Author: Enrique S.
Reviews.Content: Food was good. But a little too pricy.

Reviews.Author: JL S.
Reviews.Content: Could you just die? I love this place. PIckles on the table. Great waiters. Great huge kosher and deli menu. I always eat eggs here. Eggs and Lox. Oh and Chicken Soup of course. Have great bagels for LA too. When you eat a NYC bagel, its hard to go elsewhere, but..I do love Canters.See you soon zhagazint

Reviews.Author: Bob F.
Reviews.Content: They know what kasha is. They know what kasha varniske's are. They know what lean pastrami looks like. They know how to make a matzoh ball. Which reminds me of a story about Marilyn Monroe. Marilyn was briefly married to Arthur Miller, the famous playwright (Death of a Salesman), who happened to be Jewish. Marilyn was the ultimate schiksa. One day, Miller took Marilyn to his mother's house, and she served matzoh ball soup.Marilyn said, "This matzoh ball soup is delicious, Mrs. Miller. Tell me, do they use any other parts of the matzoh?"bah dum bump

Reviews.Author: Laurel V.
Reviews.Content: There are many better diners.  I've never found the food to be that good so paying extra for it doesn't make any sense.  the only thing i can think of that I would get again was the egg salad sadwich.  that was good and I don't think overpriced either.  Also i recall the Mac&cheese being good, but it's been a while.  that's it though.Pretty good pastries.  I'm more about the food than the atmosphere when it comes down to it since I'm a picky eater.  So it's a good place for the atmosphere and ok food if you don't mind paying too much for it, but thee are better diners for food 24 hours a day.  (Cafe 101, Fred 62's, Swingers is open most of the day, etc.)

Reviews.Author: Raph J.
Reviews.Content: Although the menu is massive, there are only two things that actually matter to me...A pastrami reuben, and more recently, the monte cristo.Get either with a side of fries and pickles and you will surely be satisfied. Unless of course you were born without taste buds or are on a diet.

Reviews.Author: Kipp P.
Reviews.Content: This place is a total treat for me because I usually shun away from all things carbs!  Well let's just say that Canter's is all about carbs!  I absolutely adore their turkey pita!  It's loaded with tons of goodies that keep your mouth awake throughout the entire experience.  I won't bore you with the pickles...they're good.  That's it.  But truth be told I am an eclair-a-holic.  They have one of the greatest eclairs that I've had to date.  2 "YUMS" up!

Reviews.Author: Michelle C.
Reviews.Content: Canter's has the BEST potato salad I've EVER had in my life!!! No joke....get some...you'll thank me!!oh..and the rest of the food was actually great too...but man, that potato salad!

Reviews.Author: John M.
Reviews.Content: I love pickles.Therefore, Canters would already get 5 stars, BUT, they also have an incredible selection of food, drinks and hot waitresses.   Okay, the waitresses were hot in 1955, but everything else about this place is authentic and good.  Not even that pricey for LA.  Probably more traditional than Jerrys, and just as unhealthy.  The kind of place you can just hang out for a few hours.Parking is a problem but... it's LA.  Just find a small spot on the street and use the 'bump & feel' technique.

Reviews.Author: Kyle M.
Reviews.Content: Definitely the best jewish deli in Los Angeles by far...try the Mishmosh soup...it's a HUGE bowl of soup with..MATZO BALLCHICKENRICECARROTSSOME OTHER SHITit's so good...check it out.

Reviews.Author: DUTCHIE L.
Reviews.Content: I think Canter's was my first deli I visited in LA. And I instantly fell in love with the place, looking at the old Jewish couples on a Sunday morning was like watching a Woody Allan movie... love it. I do not go to Canter's because they serve great quality food; because it's average. but, I love the atmosphere and their matzeball soup is not bad at all, to say the least. Canter's is an experience as simple as that. And that's good enough for me  to keep coming back.

Reviews.Author: Nicole P.
Reviews.Content: Let's be honest.  The service here sucks, and there's just no way around it.   Wait staff were openly/verbally complaining and arguing with the hostess.  Don't they know you do that in private?  Sure, they keep it real, but it was just slow and bad. The reuben and the matzo ball soup on the other hand, THOSE were IN-SANE and delicious, and I would go back and bear with their shitty-ass service a million more times just to get me a taste of some more.  I honestly did not know that a sandwich could be that good.  I want another one now.

Reviews.Author: Abbe A.
Reviews.Content: My husband has raved about Canter's so we stopped for take out yesterday. I preface this by saying I grew up in NY/NJ so I am a deli snob. I ordered 2 corned beef sandwiches and 2 knishes. $40? The knishes were not good. I prefer a different outside dough. The pickles were interesting, one was really garlicy and awesome, but the other tasted icky.I also got rugalach and other cookies. They were enjoyable, but again...$40?$80 spent, got to hear some of the waitresses bitching about the dining room customers, and ate some average deli. I'll be in NY next month...YUMMMM!

Reviews.Author: DJHighYello W.
Reviews.Content: Oh my, did you see the size of that matzo ball?This place was technically the first place we ate in Hollywood after a night out with my boys from up north.  The soup was tasty, the sandwich was enormous  and I was buzzed enough to order the noodle kugel, which I ended up liking.  We had to go back the next day just to double check the goodness of this Kosher eatery.  The lunch portions are so big you could get too meals out of it.This is going to be a stop we make every time we visit LA.

Reviews.Author: p f.
Reviews.Content: TOTALLY AWFUL AND TOTALLY OVERPRICED!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!this place is a complete ripoff!!  selling bland, dull food at exorbitant prices.  i mean, $20 some bucks for a plain corned beef sandwich with some bland cabbage and bland pickles and cold bread served with cold hard butter???  my friend had some bland casserole with hard dry noodles which was worse than my bland sandwich.  save your money and go to a tasty chinese restaurant.  you know how they say jews love chinese food?  one trip to canter's and you'll see why.  or better yet - if you want a sandwich that's tastier and fairly worth its value = GO TO DENNYS!!!

Reviews.Author: Neon W.
Reviews.Content: Matzoball soup, bagel chips, pickles. Perfect.The lil ol' ladies that waitress in the wee hours are incredible, they've seen it, heard it, smelt it, touched it. I like it.The deli, rugala, rye bread, perfect midnight snack always...As an LA native, this place never gets old.

Reviews.Author: Jo N.
Reviews.Content: Their homemade matzo ball soup is so yummy and comforting. Ordered their turkey with all the fixings plate and it was more than enough to share with my kid. Our server was a no-nonsene, serious looking woman who could definitely stand her own ground. She served us right up and was very courteous and always came around to check on us. Had to give Canter's 4 stars because they're open around the clock and when I"m in town, I can indulge anytime of the day! The food is so good it has soul to it!

Reviews.Author: David E.
Reviews.Content: I need to go here more often.Desserts are classic and yummy.

Reviews.Author: Michael L.
Reviews.Content: I lived in LA for 7 years. Never been to Canters. This past weekend i was down in LA for a wedding and someone mentioned late night eats and someone else suggested Canters. I was skeptical but my friends were local jewish brothers so i figure if they're talking Canters as if it were the deli of all deli's in LA that i'd have to give it the benefit of the doubt and try it. Prior to arrival they said that the Reuben with Pastrami is the deal so i sat down without even looking at the menu and that's what it was. I have to say, the Pastrami Reuben with Sourkraut, Toasted (which is the key i think) is the real deal there at Canters. Highly recommended. I have a craving even now thinking about it. Dayam living 400 miles away from LA and all it's good food accessible at all hours of the day and night... The fries were also good. Steak fries cooked the the perfect crispy texture was a good way to top it all off. So next time you're in LA. Canters for the TOASTED Pastrami Reuben with Sourkraut. DO IT!

Reviews.Author: Ev T.
Reviews.Content: Classic place, with a mixture of  being great and absolute mediocre at the same time. The menu is gigantic, and Canter's is pricey, so if you slip up and order the wrong thing, it's a huge blunder. The bakery is where you can put your trust.Get a Pastrami Reuben and call it a day.

Reviews.Author: Jessica S.
Reviews.Content: I have lived about 5 minutes away from Canters nearly my entire life, yet the first time I stepped foot inside this iconic establishment was last year, a few days before my 21st birthday (this seems to happens a lot, since I don't have a life and all. I've never even been to Sprinkes!)The menu is indeed massive, as is the restaurant itself (sort of). The first time I went here, I was seated right behind a woman yelling at her someone (partner? sister? mother?) while everyone stared and went right back to not caring. I had some soup. While taking a look the amazing-looking pastries afterward (cupcakes!), I randomly saw Rodney Bingenheimer walk ever so slowly out of the restaurant with a much younger lady-friend, looking and acting exactly as you think he would if you've heard his voice. The second time I went here was right after I went to a concert (a small show really, at a random art space in Echo Park) on Halloween. I immediately eyed a Ronald McDonald (sans the makeup) with a glum look on his face talking with 3 of his buddies who were not dressed up at all. Seated next to us a bit later was a woman dressed up as a peanut butter jar, and later on some fabulous and flamboyant gays came in wearing silver sequined hot pants, makeup, and platform shoes a la KISS. Some girls took pictures with them. Hot! I ate a very large potato with french fries. Bad combination! Why do I pick the most random and awful things to eat? Potato + potato is never a good idea, kind of like denim on denim (I'm looking at you, Jay Leno!).I am sure anything I would have ordered would have been good anyway. I vaguely recall ordering dessert and the waiter coming back to let me know they ran out of fudge. So that blew, but maybe that's also a sign?The cashier, dressed as some kind of gothic shaman, got mad at us and complained about counting and using her calculator because we didn't order separate checks or something like that (the ONE time I don't attempt to order separate checks!). IDK.Someday I shall come here again and finally try their pastries!

Reviews.Author: Fred R.
Reviews.Content: Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner or Bakery...It's ALL Good!Want a throwback to NY delis? Make your way to Canter's! The surly vintage waitresses will make you feel like you are in the 5 boroughs. The pastrami, corned beef and reubens melt in your mouth and the traditional deli fare will make you wish you could visit this place more often (it's an hour drive for me).Nosh on lox and bagels. Try the pancakes or eggs. Heck I love all of the breakfast options. Don't be afraid to explore. Go with a group and order many different items so that you can share and sample.Stop by the bakery on the way out and take some Canters baked love home with you to enjoy for a day or two.

Reviews.Author: Akiko Y.
Reviews.Content: 2nd time around wasn't so bad... I remember going there a long time ago with high expectations for the matzo ball soup and being disappointed. The broth was flavorless and so was the matzo ball. Maybe that's how its made traditionally but I've had way tastier ones around town. This time I split a hot corned beef sandwich and a pastrami sandwich. Corned beef was on the dry side but the pastrami was super yummy and moist. What was great was that they gave us about 5 different kinds of mustard for our corned beef sandwich! Their claimed world famous pickles were something I couldn't put my finger on. They had a funny aftertaste and I thought I didn't like them but ended up eating like 4 or 5 of them. The french fries were really good, crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. They have a parking lot outside but we parked at one of the meters. I'll be back for sure, maybe try the matzo ball soup again and ofcourse to pick up that Guns n Roses book!!

Reviews.Author: Stephen H.
Reviews.Content: I see a range of reviews on Canter's.  I can only base my review on my own experiences.  I've really never had a bad one.  I've eaten here countless times and loved most everything.  I primarily go to get my fill of Jewish food.  Be sure to ask for some of the free pickles when you're seated.  They're a little spicy.  Love 'em.   I'm a vegetarian so I get the blintzes and latkes.  I think my favorite is the noodle kugel (better than my mom's I have to admit).  The French Toast is fluffy and flavorful and I get it often.  I've also heard complaints about the atmosphere.  I like the old cheesy vibe in this place.  I feel like I'm stepping back in time about 25 years.  The wait staff is usually very friendly and a few are characters who are fun to talk to at 3 a.m.  BTW, there's a bar and lounge here too.The thing with a deli like this is that they probably have 100 or more items on their menu.  Obviously ordering spaghetti at a deli might not yield the best results.  Stick with the lox and bagels and blintzes and sandwiches and you'll be fine.Also, I should mention the bakery.  The rugalach are buttery and rich - like I like them.  In fact everything in the bakery is pretty buttery - and I say that as a good thing.  My favorite is the chocolate racetrack.  It's hard to describe.  Layers of chocolate and pastry.Canter's is an original and perhaps the best deli in LA.  Reminds me of when I was a kid and visiting the grandparents in Miami and going to the famous (and now closed) Rascal House.

Reviews.Author: Man E.
Reviews.Content: When I think deli, I think Canters.  The down side? Canters has spoiled me. It has become the standard by which I compare all other deli's.  Yes it's a time machine set to the early 60s but if it ain't broke why fix it?Generous portions never fail to delight.  Matzo Ball soup is tasty soothing and the matzo ball is the size of a grapefruit.  The corned beef and pastrami are both lean and flavorful.  Their pickles are crisp and tangy. Try a cherry or chocolate phosphate and where else can you still order a phosphate?The wait staff have seen it all and while they may not be all bubbly and smile a lot they do a great job.Open 24hrs the food it great anytime of day.  At night there is live music.  Stop by some late night after last call and see who drops by.If you go, have deli food.  Why else would eat at a deli?

Reviews.Author: Bill S.
Reviews.Content: First of all, what's with the cracks about the waitresses? While they will not tollerate foolishness, they are friendly and go out of their way to make you happy. While the the deli seating area is ok, my choice is to dine in the adjoinning diningroom. I am built for comfort and the somewhat "cozy" booths in the deli-bakery are not for me.  Nosh on the pickles until your order comes. Then sit back and enjoy a little bit of heaven. If I'm within an hour of Canter's, I've got to stop by for my Reuben fix. Best sandwiches in town.And don't forget;Tell 'em Bill sent you...

Reviews.Author: Grape D.
Reviews.Content: I hadn't been in Canter's for a few years so my wife and I stopped by recently for a snack.It still has all the same old plusses and minuses. Canter's is a 24 hour deli insane asylum housed in a kitschy-creepy lox-infused netherworld of naugahide, and populated with cartoon-character waitresses. We had a couple of really nice big salads. Everyone else's food looked really good, and we had very good service.Hint: Don't look up at the ceiling. If you ever wondered what a 90 year old linoleum salesman's interpretation of a backlit jungle-scape would be, it is here. You will be blinded and have LSD flashbacks.Dropped by Canter's Kibitz room on the way out and a 75 year old Jewish rapper woman asked me if I knew how to "beat box" LOL.  A few minutes later she was performing her song and she was rapping a very loud "OYYYYYYYYY" and the audience was responding "VEYYYYYY!" which was really funny and amusing for the first 47 times. And there was the usual assortment of VERY quirky characters hanging around, but we didn't stay for more music that night. The verdict: Canter's is still a fly place for a late-night drop-in.

Reviews.Author: Rox P.
Reviews.Content: Fantastic food - Great service and laid back atmosphere.In my opinion the best deli outside of New York.  I first heard about this place from my brother and from Zagat.  I've been back twice and the service and food has been consistent - Fantastic.  The menu is a little overwhelming at first glance but stick to the meat sandwiches and you can't go wrong.  I came here with a group last night and everyone loved their entrees.  I had the french dip sandwich - the bread had a crunch,  meat cut thick and cooked right the au jus was good enough to drink - according to the bf.  The other people in the group had the Reuben sandwiches - one with pastrami and the other with corned beef.  The sauerkraut in the sandwich had the right acidity and consistency.  The bf had the hot brisket of beef open sandwich with mash potatoes and gravy.  The brisket was cut thick and large portion over white bread with brown gravy - the bf says "I liked it a lot but it got cold too quick."The consensus from the group - the BEST deli in the west.  Don't forget to check the bakery as well.

Reviews.Author: Justin S.
Reviews.Content: Simply put, there is no better deli east of New York than Canters. The food is the best. I honestly do not remember the last time I had a better turkey reuben, or any reuben for that matter. The place also has amazing matzo ball soup, salads, dessert, breakfast and  everything else. The great thing about Canters is the experience you also receive. Yes the service is not the best in terms of speed, but you usually get a server who will make you laugh. I once had a server basically yell at one of my friends saying the place does not offer a half sandwich in the funnest way possible. While that may sound unforgivable, when you see the woman who did it, you cannot help but laugh. The place is also an experience because it is how an old deli in a classic area of Los Angeles should be. The light is dark, it offers a bakery, deli and dessert, it is open 24 hours a day and if you go after a concert is let out, you may see some of the most interesting people in the world. The portions are huge, so you can easily take at least half of your meal home for later. Having said that, it is overpriced. A reuben will run your $14, but it is basically two sandwiches. The menu is extensive, you can order world class sandwiches, soup, salad, breakfast, potato pancakes and even Thanksgiving any day of the year. Canters is a place that you should have to go, there is just no other way to put it. The food is amazing, the atmosphere is unforgettable and you will just look back with positive memories.

Reviews.Author: Ryan S.
Reviews.Content: My buddies dragged me here at 3am and other than the fact that I lost credit card roulette and had to pick up the bill it was great.We wanted to try a few things so my buddy got the rueben and I got a beef dip and we split the two. The beef dip was better than average but nothing great. The horseradish they had there was unbelievably good though.The reuben was by far the best one I have ever had and I don't think it was just because it was 3am. The slaw was nice and crunchy and the pastrami was really juicy and flavorful.I have heard that Langers is better but until I try it thin is the best pastrami on my list.

Reviews.Author: Brian W.
Reviews.Content: Great deli: You rarely find these west of the Mississippi. Canters offers good food, good service and good hours.Very solid Corned Beef sandwich, with side of coleslaw and fries. $13 ishDrawback is that if you're looking for French Dip you should really go to "the Original French Dip place by Union Station"...but hey it was pretty good here too. Our server gave us a hefty amount of pickles and was very attentive to us, despite it being 11 pm.When it gets to the wee hours of the evening and morning, you'll be very hard pressed to find such good food without having something being fried. Canter's delivers-"substance"!(Small private lot that requires dine in validation)

Reviews.Author: Jordan L.
Reviews.Content: This place is a classic NYC deli. Just ate there this weekend.The reuben was above average. As were the pickles. But all in all, the price was just too much. $15 for a reuben? Yeah right! I know we are in Hollywood but come on....

Reviews.Author: Amy A.
Reviews.Content: Was in the mood for some deli treats...Ordered the pastrami on rye and matzo ball soup. Cheers to tradition, culture and history but just wasn't my cup-a tea. Had better of both dishes...I will say that I can easily get obsessed with their pickles... hell of a good pickle! =) and I'd like to go back and try the freshly made cookies and pastries...

Reviews.Author: Pouya B.
Reviews.Content: I love me ethnic food. So the thought of eating at a Jewish deli made me excited. Though the sandwiches are good just nothing overly special about them that I want to overpay. The rest is so bland and tasteless. Like American food but worse. I am not going to experiment with the foods here because doesn't appeal to me. I had the gefilte fish which in hebrew has some meaning about fish combo and matsa ball soup.

Reviews.Author: Shay A.
Reviews.Content: Based on the two times that I've been here, I'm stuck between a three and a four. So I decided to just smack it with a four and call it a day. Here is why:Walking in, its your typical Jewish Deli. Glass cases are on either side of you, one for your deli needs and the other for your breads and sweets. Each time we were seated promptly and greeted by our server.The ambiance of the place is very casual, borderline campy. I say this because this venue is old and boy does it look it. In an effort to keep its original 'flare' it has lost the meaning of 'upkeep'. Not that the place is dirty or anything, it just needs a little love. Some of the servers rush around with this frazzled look upon their faces as if they had just gotten the scare of their life. But for the most part, they are friendly.The menu is massive! If you have problems deciding on what you want to eat (like myself), I suggest looking at the menu before you arrive. After you place your order, the servers come back with your drinks and a little plate of pickles. Yay pickles! Careful though, they are kinda strong, so I wouldn't suggest eating them if you plan to have a make out session later.On to the food!Matzo Ball Soup - I could eat a bucket of this soup. Its very simple and straight forward but it is done very well. The best part are the bagel chips that they give you on the side. Perfect for dipping in the broth. I've been to several of my friend's passover/Hanukkah dinners and I will say that I prefer their Matzo Ball Soup over Canter's but it does come a very close second.Smoked Turkey Sandwich - Turkey was damn tasty, though it comes without any sauce on it. However, Canter's provides you with four kinds of mustard: Yellow, Dijon, Sweet hot, and Hot Russian. Holy crap... that last one will burn your nostrils, be warned!Monte Cristo - First off... this is NOT a monte cristo. Not by a long shot. I would label this as a french toast bread with grease sandwich. The two things that made this a mockery of the beloved artery enemy was the fact that there wasn't a single piece of bacon on this sandwich and it wasn't even battered or fried. They slap a stack of dry meats, turkey and ham (I think), onto two pieces of french toast and serve it with strawberry jam. A sad, sad imitation.Meatloaf with Mashed potatoes - I am not usually a fan of gravy, but when my boyfriend got this dish, I of course tried it. I'm glad I did. It was deeeeeeeelicious. Nice rich gravy on top of some pretty flavorful meatloaf. The mashed potatoes were quite good as well. The plate did come with a side of green beans, but they weren't seasoned... at all. So I would avoid their veggies.Breaded Chicken... thing - Yeah... I don't even remember what it was called. That is how unimpressive this particular dish was. It comes with fries and some sort of green salad (no dressing). Just avoid anything that says 'breaded chicken'.Overall I would say I will visit just for their Matzo Ball soup. Everything else is hit and miss.

Reviews.Author: Sean R.
Reviews.Content: Got myself some an awesome Pastrami sandwich, not just awesome but one of the best I've eaten, they have a giant section for baked goods, and all the other standard items you'd expect from a deli like this.
