You will also likely taste Javex if you order hot tea. Relax, it's always been this way. If you don't like drinking Javex, don't order tea. You can't taste it in the coffee. I wonder why?Second is the canterankerous (my word Canters + cantankerous)  waiting staff. Some of them have served Janis Joplin. One second they are endearingly calling you honey and the next they are being sarcastic with you bordering on rude. If you're lucky you'll get a grizzled really old waitress who might have served Janis and who knows exactly how to give you the business. This is part of the signature charm that goes with the signature odor of the establishment. For more fun try asking your waiter or waitress to take back the tea and bring you some without the Javex taste. Third is the psychotic florescent back-lit ceiling shining above your head in the main dining area. I can't explain it, you would have to see it but it is somehow nauseating. Just don't stare at it. Of course if you are an abuser of certain illegal substances, this can be difficult. Since it was installed about twenty years ago, stoned-out clubbers have preferred to sit in the adjoining dining room. Fourth is related to third since Canters is one of this cities few twenty-four / seven restaurants. For the juice of the juice go there on a Friday at two in the morning. Fifth is their bar, The Kibitz Room.  You can see really bad bands, and occasionally really good ones. You can also hear jazz for the price of a drink and that is becoming rare in this city. Sixth is the take-out bakery. Depends what you are talking about. Compared to a supermarket bakery it shines. Compared to a specialty bakeries where trained chefs 'create'  from the best ingredients, butter for example as opposed to shortening or margarine, fresh apples as opposed to the canned kind, then the fare at Canters suffers. Yes, I know that the cakes and cookies are dense as lead because it is once-removed from the pastry Jewish babas baked half a century ago. Even if the person who throws the slab of shortening into the stainless steel industrial mixing-bowl has Spanish as his first language, I'd give Canters a pass on density and weight for that reason. But a real apple strudel is labor intensive and built from layers upon layers of paper-thin filo-dough between which are fresh apples, nuts, and raisins. The more flaky layers, the more status for the baba. This is the desert Baba would given you as a prize for eating all the over-cooked mushy vegetables on your plate. Still if you need your strudle at four in he morning where else is there? Now about the sit-down food: Always a bride's maid never a bride. Canters is not La's best once-Kosher deli in any category but often they rate in the top two or three. (Well maybe the best baked apple in town can be had at Canters but there is not a whole lot of competition.) What deli people care about they do well at on average at Canters. The corn beef or pastrami on rye is quite good. The Matza ball soup is above average but, again, only a contender when compared to a few other similar joints. The soups generally are better at Juniors in the West End, which is in an entirely different world. The crusty rye bread at Langers, however, beats them all out by a huge margin and the pastrami and corn beef between those magnificent slices of the rye bread edges them all out as well. The problem is, if you want to eat a sandwich after 4:00 PM you can strike Langers off your list. Langers has truncated business hours due to the fact that the Pico-Union location where they've been serving those sandwiches since the age of the dinosaurs is now perceived to be dicy going after the sun sets. Canters, however, with its well lit free parking is situated in the more up-scale but still not sterile Fairfax district.  This location, just a little off the beaten tracks of The Strip or downtown Hollywood, contributes to the fact that Canters remains one of LA's venerable late-night institutions. Those semi-naked pierced tattooed cuties are no where near as tough as their boyfriends look.What I'm saying is, although other delis compete on food, as far as the LA zeisgeit goes, Canters stands alone. Langers, for example, is more a museum of delis as they once were and worth the visit for the food alone, whilst Canters remains a scenester hot spot with the quite unusual distinction that, unlike say Denny's,  the food is actually reasonably good.  The price is, of course, reasonably high but that is to be expected, no?

Reviews.Author: Skydog C.
Reviews.Content: I love this place ..its historic, seems like 1950's. Whats great is the huge menu, and its open way late. Can't go wrong with the corn beef and cabbage, and I often get the turkey dinner, which they call Thanksgiving Dinner. Quite good.

Reviews.Author: jalisa s.
Reviews.Content: Holy Tuna Melt! It's been a while since I've had such a good one. And rugala and hamantashen?! Maybe L.A. isn't so bad after all.

Reviews.Author: kathryn s.
Reviews.Content: mmmmm! the pickles are so good. no wonder they are world famous. i stared at the expansive menu for at least 15 minutes and still probably didn't notice everything. i have to say, it being my first time, it was a smidgen intimidating.  i chickened out when ordering and asked for the BLT instead of the monte cristo. the BLT was good, but regret not being more adventurous this morning. the food came out ridiculously quickly. good, old fashioned service was nice to experience. would totally go back to try the reuben or monte cristo sandwich. totally.

Reviews.Author: Taylor D.
Reviews.Content: I've been hearing alot of hype about Canter's for years but I never ate there till today. I rarely go to L.A. but today was one of those rare days. I wanted to try a Tongue Sandwich because it's a bit out of the ordinary and I'm all about Lengua tacos so it seemed like a grand idea. Here's the thing, The tongue sandwich I ordered was fucking delicious (as were my french fries) BUT when the waitress (Who was a complete flatliner and borderline dickish) brought me my sandwich it was this sad little thing that looked like it belonged in a McDonalds value meal rather than a NY style Deli. I thought to myself maybe I just assumed they served giant sammiches like the ones you see on TV and I should really be more realistic.....well I thought that until the dude next to me ordered the exact same thing as me and received a giant, amazing looking tongue sandwich stacked at least 3 or 4 inches tall and a good 5 inches across. Why did I get the tiny sammich? Was it circumstance?....or something more sinister? I did see some nazi regalia hanging in the kitchen when a busboy left the door open for a little too long. They must hate me because I have some polish jew in my ancestry. I guess it's a mystery for the ages, why did I get the scrawny sammich? WHYYYYY?

Reviews.Author: Matt P.
Reviews.Content: Huge selection.  Love the pastrami,  This is the place where I learned how good cornbeef and cabbage can be.

Reviews.Author: Brian B.
Reviews.Content: Yes it is an old establishment (since 1953); and yes it is famous due to the advertisement efforts and moneys spent on it. However, i would wish that they would put more effort into making their food as well as giving better service. I would rate the food as 2 1/2 stars, and the service as 1 star. Waiters (depending who you get) are basically rude. The food is not a find either--I would expect a Jewish Deli to have a good matzo ball soup--but instead we tasted something that must have come from a can or a premix container. I have visited this establishment for years now; and regretfully, it is not the same! Once there existed attention to service by the waitresses with the uniforms you may find in older photos--but now it is non existent. Lastly, it is way overpriced, perhaps double of what it should be. The bakery is not so special either. I guess, the only plus is the fact the it is opened all night; and only if you come already tipsy in the middle of the night to fill your stomach (in that case you don't really care much with what you fill your stomach and how much it will cost you).

Reviews.Author: Rob B.
Reviews.Content: Good soups and corned beef and Pastrami. Their bakery is the best. My only complaint is the place is dirtier than I like. The service is OK.

Reviews.Author: Emily L.
Reviews.Content: Good jewish style deli food and fairly large portions.  The menu is HUGE. \

Reviews.Author: Jessica C.
Reviews.Content: Nicest Jewish ladies ever. And you're bound to see someone famous. Also, free pickles.

Reviews.Author: J M.
Reviews.Content: Canters is an LA institution. You don't go for the food; you go for the atmosphere, the bakery and the fact that it's open all night. Love this place.

Reviews.Author: george l.
Reviews.Content: Ugh - pastrami had absolutely no taste and extremely fatty. Rye bread hard as a rock! Try Billy's in Glendale for a real pastrami sandwich. Of course, this is very subjective but once you try them, you will avoid Cantors! Trust me!

Reviews.Author: Harry G.
Reviews.Content: My favorite Jewish Deli..period.  Old school staff, some have been there for decades...matzo ball soup, sandwiches on rye piled high with hot corn beef or pastrami, add some regular or spicy mustard...fresh pickles,, and a chocolate egg cream. Boom!  Delicious.  After the bars close in Hollywood at night see the all the hipsters, actors, and late folks.  FRESH bakery...baked goods, strawberry cheesecake.

Reviews.Author: sasha s.
Reviews.Content: i grew up going to this restaurant with my parents all through the 80's and i keep comin back.  the romaine hearts salad is the best anything ive ever had.  i mean man, this salad is so good and i feel healthy after i enhale it.  i do mean enhale.

Reviews.Author: Richard K.
Reviews.Content: Good deli. A little tired but good.

Reviews.Author: Louis T.
Reviews.Content: we sat down and wanted to order a dessert and a drink real quick.  Oh and we wanted hot water to try to warm our baby's food.  we waited and waited and nobody really wanted to serve us.  The old grouchy white hostess was not happy/friendly n mumbled smth like she's not the server.  The server at one point gave us some sort of signal like he'll be there (when he wants to).. but of course, he doesn't want to, so he just did not come.  The nicest person there was the Mexican man who was the bus boy.  He asked if we wanted a drink so he got us the coke and hot water and he wasn't able to take our order so the only thing was to wait for the server.  During the whole time, the bus boy came over quite a few times to check on us to see if we're ok.  After about 20 mins, our baby was done eating, and 2 glasses of coke has been finished - still no server.  He finally passes by our table (passes by, NOT stopping by) and tells us hot water has a 50 cents charge.  We had to basically scream for a slice of cheesecake that he didn't seem to intend to place the order for us til maybe way later or never.  At that point, I went from irritated to KILL mode in that split of a second.  Although I'm not about to start anything verbally, so I stood up while he was being super friendly w/the table next to us.  We signaled to have order cancelled (not like it was a problem since it's not even placed) and HE had the nerve to say, FORGET it w/the hot water... it felt like he was taking pity on us 2 who don't seem to want to gush out 50 cents!!!  He had so little interaction w/us that he most likely didn't realize we ordered a coke.  So we throw $ down the table n we just left.  So angry.

Reviews.Author: Judy J.
Reviews.Content: Quite honestly, this is a tourist only place.  Once upon a time it held sway on the Jewish style deli list, but now it's merely a relic.  Turkey is dry, pastrami under-flavored, and prices are through the roof.  It's location will always ensure a crowd, but really below par food.  In addition, the folks working the deli counter invariably get the orders wrong and they take an ridiculously long time doing it. It's more of a sentimental journey for folks visiting the old neighborhood or late nighters who enjoy a 24-hour mix of cranky old waitstaff and hipsterish newcomers.  If you want the experience of being in a old landmark, try something from the bakery section, which is still pretty good, but skip the lousy deli counter.  Don't even think of ordering any non-deli food, such as spaghetti or a hamburger...you will be punished, if not immediately, soon enough.  A much better choice is Nat n Al's in Beverly Hills.  Granted, it's not the same ironically aware atmosphere, but the food is better.  And if you are a tourist, why not?  Even better, just a few blocks north, there's Greenblatt's.  It does not have the same old deli feel, but the food is wonderful, with an expert counter staff.

Reviews.Author: Elizabeth L.
Reviews.Content: I used to love Canter's. I live in San Diego and it is kind of a long drive to get there. Took my nephews out to eat and had the worst service EVER! I tried to call Lynn this morning and was told "she comes in later" and the guy that answered the phone just hung up! Huh? Our waitress was rude, slow and was saying snarky remarks when we were leaving. Seems like the service is definitely something they need to work with. Never saw a manager so no on really helped us when we waited 30 minutes for refills. When we wanted her to put our order in for a sandwich she told us we had to order that upfront. So, I am going to eat my meal and then wait upfront for 15 minutes for a sanddwich. I paid $40 ffor two meals and drinks. If I am going to pay that much I sure as heck don't expect to deal with a waitress that is miserable and rude. It was obvious.My sister wanted to go to another deli but it was closed. Don't know if I would be back. It's sad because some of the servers are really nice. There should be someone walking around to make sure tables are taken care of....

Reviews.Author: Seth J.
Reviews.Content: great food, great staff, always open... perfect

Reviews.Author: Food C.
Reviews.Content: this place is digusting. i'm not sure what the rave is over it. even the fries were bad. never a good sign if you can't do fries right. i'll never be back.

Reviews.Author: Rabbit B.
Reviews.Content: Canter's is a trip.  Not many of these type of restaurants are left, unfortunately, so it's nice to know you can still find an old school restaurant like Canter's these days.  I've never had anything other than breakfast there, though, so I can't comment on anything but breakfast.  Sure it isn't the most fabulous breakfast I've ever had--though it is always good--but that's not why I go to Canter's. I go there for the blast-from-the- past atmosphere including wait staff like Fran who have worked at Canter's for years.  She brings your food out on a rolling cart.  Priceless.  As for the bakery, I defy you to get out the front door without buying something delicious to take home.  Everybody needs to go to Canter's at least once in their life so they can see what I'm talking about.  So do yourselves a favor and check it out and I promise to stop in after a night at the club.  I guess that's where to go to people watch and scarf down some grub after a night of drinking and let's face it...what tastes better than greasy food at 2am??

Reviews.Author: marc w.
Reviews.Content: canters is awsome all the things people say they hate about it are whats charming about it- the old decor and the old wait staff- its open 24 hours for great hot corn beef sandwiches and chicken soup. i been going here for 33 years since i was a little kid...canters is an institution. every major star in hollywood has been here.
